HEADLINE: U.S. Still Pays Contractor Bills For Whistle-Blower Lawsuits

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 23

 BODY:
Five years ago, the Energy Department, trying to protect workers who raised safety concerns at its nuclear weapons plants, said it would stop covering the legal bills of its contractors when they were caught retaliating against such whistle-blowers.
But witnesses and lawmakers said at a Congressional hearing today that the department was still paying those bills, sometimes without knowing it. 
 Even though the department announced a policy of "zero tolerance for reprisals" against whistle-blowing employees years ago, department officials acknowledged today that they had not written a final rule on when to withhold taxpayer dollars from financing contractors' legal defenses against such claims.
Employees of contractors, from pipefitters to senior engineers, who have called attention to on-site safety concerns, have spent tens of thousands of dollars in legal fees over the years, often while enduring hostile conditions at work, or unemployment, their advocates say.
In a hearing by the House Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations, Representative Diana DeGette, a Colorado Democrat and a former labor lawyer, said the agency should praise "the enormous courage and unmeasurable contributions of whistle-blowers." Instead, Ms. DeGette said, "They can just bleed these poor individuals dry."
The subcommittee chairman, Representative Richard M. Burr, Republican of North Carolina, said the department appeared to be "providing virtually no support for the whistle-blowers, while providing generous taxpayer support to the contractors fighting these meritorious claims."
The Commerce Committee chairman, Representative Thomas J. Bliley Jr., Republican of Virginia, released two agency documents on legal costs incurred by Kaiser-Hill, a contractor at Rocky Flats, a defunct plutonium plant near Denver.
The contractor was defending itself against accusations that it retaliated against a security supervisor who complained about the safety of bomb fuel stored there. The employee brought his case before the Labor Department, which ruled in his favor, and Kaiser-Hill did not appeal.
Among Energy Department repayments to Kaiser-Hill was $220,000 in legal fees incurred fighting the whistle-blower, Mr. Bliley said.
The agency said last week it had not approved any expenses and was still reviewing them. But today it said Kaiser-Hill included the costs "in general subcontractor billings that were not conspicuous to D.O.E."
The company has returned the money but is still seeking reimbursement, the department said.
The department does nearly all of its work through contractors, many on a "cost-plus" basis, in which it reimburses all costs and then adds a profit. It includes legal defense costs and, usually, the cost of any settlements imposed on the contractors.
Department officials said today that they could decline to make such reimbursements, but they could not cite a case where they had done so. Mary Anne Sullivan, the department's general counsel, said the agency had proposed to do so in some pending cases.
One witness, Tom Carpenter, of the Government Accountability Project, which brings cases on behalf of whistle-blowers, said the system encouraged contractors to drag out cases and then settle on the eve of trial. A policy of full reimbursement was "an incentive for the contractors to litigate the case," Mr. Carpenter said. "If they had to pay, they'd have a much more realistic view" of the cases against them.
Whistle-blowers complaining of retaliation take their cases to the Labor Department, Mr. Carpenter said, because its procedures allow for discovery, access to documents and company officials, whereas Energy Department procedures do not.

HEADLINE: THE CHINA TRADE WRANGLE: THE OVERVIEW;
THE HOUSE OPENS A SPIRITED DEBATE OVER CHINA TRADE

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT and JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 23

 BODY:
The House opened a spirited debate today on the China trade bill, as a furious final round of horse-trading with undecided members demanding everything from gas pipelines to a weather station left supporters confident that they would eke out a victory on Wednesday.
Republican and Democratic vote counters in favor of the bill said they were within a vote or two of their targets needed to grant Beijing permanent normal trading relations and give President Clinton a crowning foreign policy triumph. About a dozen Democrats, including six Texans, announced their support. 
 But opponents insisted that the margin was still too close to call, and that the spotlight had swung from undeclared Democrats to about 10 undeclared Republicans, who were receiving a wave of phone calls from veterans groups and human rights advocates. Many in both camps predicted that the vote could go down to the wire.
"I expect the bill to pass, but it's going to be one of the most exciting 15 to 20 minutes on the floor," said Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the majority leader, who is a supporter of the measure.
In the debate that opened this afternoon and will resume on Wednesday, supporters like Representative Bill Archer, Republican of Texas, urged passage for economic and foreign policy reasons: "This will create hundreds of thousands of new jobs and enhance our national security." Excerpts from the debate, Page A14.
Representative Sander Levin, a Michigan Democrat who brokered an amendment to the trade measure that creates a human rights monitoring commission in China, said: "China's integration into the world trading system inevitably presents opportunies and challenges. We have to take advantage of benefits we negotiated with China and actively address our problems."
But foes, including Representative George Miller, Democrat of California, argued that passage would lead to multinational corporations "setting up low-wage sweatshops and dumping their pollution" in China.
Representative Dan Burton, Republican of Indiana, said replacing Congress's annual renewal of China's trade status with permanently lower tariffs would strip lawmakers of their leverage to curb China's repression of its own people. "There are 10 million people in slave-labor camps who have nothing more than a bowl of gruel a day," he said.
From the White House to Capitol Hill, both sides fanned out to intensify their lobbying. Mr. Clinton met with several wavering Democrats, and he and his cabinet members telephoned several more uncommitted lawmakers.
"We can try to move China in the right direction, and gain the benefits, or we can push China in the wrong direction and pay the price," Mr. Clinton said today in a letter to House Speaker J. Dennis Hastert.
Scores of union workers, environmental activists and human rights advocates, who attacked China as a Communist regime that flouts Western labor and environmental standards, rallied on the steps of the Capitol to oppose rewarding Beijing with a trade plum.
Many held placards reading, "No Blank Check for China," and "880,000 Jobs to China -- Could Yours be Next?" Harry Wu, a prominent human rights advocate and opponent of the measure, drew huge cheers when he declared to the crowd, "Vote your conscience, not just for profit."
But the White House and its backers were pulling out all the stops. In a move timed in part to sway a handful of Hispanic and black lawmakers, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Hastert announced a set of tax breaks and public investments aimed at helping distressed rural and urban areas.
At least three previously uncommitted Democrats, Ruben Hinojosa of Texas, Sheila Jackson-Lee of Texas and Gregory W. Meeks of New York, said the tax breaks made it easier for them to announce their support today.
White House officials were locked in discussion with a number of Democrats over deals that have little to do with the vote on China trade.
Though administration officials insist the pork-barrel politics are far less intense than during a close vote on the North American Free Trade Agreement six years ago, the vote has prompted perhaps a dozen members to take up unrelated matters with the president and the House leadership, although most insisted that the requests were not quid pro quos.
The Texas delegation has been especially active. One big victor appears to be Representative Martin Frost. Mr. Frost, the third-ranking Democrat in the House, had been pressing the administration for help in avoiding the closure of a Northrop Grumman Corp. defense plant in Grand Prairie, Tex. The plant is the single largest employer in Mr. Frost's district.
Mr. Frost declared that he would vote yes today after Northrop Grumman indicated to its own employees that it would remain in Grand Prairie. The company said it had received assurances from the Navy that it would receive sufficient business to justify keeping the plant open, an aide to Mr. Frost said.
Two other members of the Texas delegation also tipped their hands after negotiating unrelated local-district matters with the White House. Representatives Silvestre Reyes and Solomon P. Ortiz had been pressing the administration to help arrange a waiver from Environmental Protection Agency regulations to allow the construction of a gas pipeline in western Texas.
Congressional aides said both members declared that they would vote yes after receiving signals from the administration that the matter would be dealt with shortly. The aides said the White House did not make a firm commitment that the waiver would be granted, however.
Representative Robert E. Cramer of Alabama, another Democrat, said he would favor the bill after he held discussions with Commerce Secretary William M. Daley over the fate of a National Weather Service monitoring station in Huntsville. The weather service, which is part of the Commerce Department, had indicated that it planned to close the weather tower. Mr. Cramer had been protesting the planned closure because his district often has tornadoes and relies on the weather stations for early warnings.
An aide to Mr. Cramer said today that Mr. Daley had promised to decide the fate of the weather tower shortly and that Mr. Cramer was satisfied it would be dealt with properly. But the aide said Mr. Cramer had not received a firm commitment to keep the tower operational.
Administration officials said that as the vote approached, they had the support of 68 Democrats in the House, just shy of the baseline goal of 70 they had targeted months ago. Republican vote counters said tonight that they had 148 firm yes votes, two short of their target, and were still hoping to recruit as many as eight more Republicans still undecided.
"One fear I have is that people will say, 'They have all the votes they need,' and could cause it to go down," said Representative David Dreier of California, a Republican vote counter who favors the measure.
But opponents claimed that the race was effectively even. One opposition vote counter said that the administration and the opposition could each count on 210 votes. That meant that the White House needed at least eight more supporters to assure passage.
The Democrats who declared that they would vote yes included six from the Texas delegation: Representatives Reyes, Ortiz, Frost, Jackson-Lee, Hinojosa and Jim Turner.
Others who said today they would vote yes were Allen Boyd of Florida and Mike Thompson of California.
White House officials said that they might pick up several more votes, but that pressure was now on the Republican caucus to achieve at least 148 supporters.
A surprisingly large number of Republicans remained officially undecided, and opponents claimed five successes in recruiting no votes in the caucus: J. D. Hayworth of Arizona, Howard Coble of North Carolina, Lamar Smith of Texas, Michael A. Collins of Georgia and Curt Weldon of Pennsylvania.
Many of the Republicans who said they would vote no said they would do so because they felt that it was not in the national security interest of the United States to grant China higher trade status. Mr. Smith and Mr. Collins had been expected by many vote counters to vote in favor.
John J. Sweeney, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said today that he was focusing much of his lobbying effort in the final hours on the undecided Republicans.
"I am meeting with a number of conservative Republicans that we haven't worked together with on many issues in the past," Mr. Sweeney said. "We hope to convince them to vote the right way."

INTERNATIONAL A3-13
 
Israel Quits Lebanon; Guerrillas Pour Into Zone
Shiite Muslim guerrillas reclaimed the Israeli-occupied zone in southern Lebanon and rode abandoned Israeli tanks through village after village, six weeks before the Israelis planned to shut down the military buffer zone they controlled along the border. A1 

Prime Minister Ehud Barak declared an end to Israel's two-decade occupation of southern Lebanon, as the last Israeli troops and pro-Israeli militias pulled out of what was once known as Israel's security zone. A13
 
Debate on China Trade Bill
The House opened debate on legislation to grant Beijing permanent normal trading relations, as a final round of horse-trading with undecided members reached furious intensity. A vote is set for today. A1
 
Push to Ease Cuba Embargo
Powerful American farm groups, sensing a shift in sentiment on Capitol Hill, are pushing Congress to soften the 38-year-old trade embargo and to permit the export of food, medicine and medical products. A10
 
U.S. to Revise Arms Controls
The Clinton administration will overhaul controls on arms exports to friendly nations for the first time since the cold war, officials said. The changes are intended to reduce the red tape involved in the licensing of technology sales, information sharing and joint ventures between governments and contractors. A10
 
U.S.-Indonesia Military Ties
Senior defense officials said the administration had quietly resumed military cooperation with Indonesia, eight months after cutting ties following massacres in East Timor. A10
 
Visit to Russian Germ Lab
The State Research Center for Applied Microbiology invited 200 scientists from 10 countries, Western officials and an American reporter into what was once a crown jewel of the Soviet germ warfare empire. The center says it is determined to conduct only peaceful work. A10
 
Germany to Reduce Its Army
The defense minister accepted a recommendation to overhaul and shrink the draft-based army, which is still set up to fight the cold war. A5

NATIONAL A16-23
 
Bush Backs Arms Cuts And Antimissile System
Gov. George W. Bush, flanked by prominent figures from four Republican administrations, called for a "new approach to nuclear security," one that includes possible unilateral reductions in American nuclear weapons combined with a robust antimissile defense system. Mr. Bush said he wanted to reduce the size of America's nuclear arsenal to the "lowest possible number consistent with our national security" and below the levels called for under the START II treaty with Russia. A1
 
Mr. Bush discussed his broad agenda with House Republicans. A20
 
Assessing Ruling on Cable TV
Analysts said they did not expect sexually explicit cable offerings to increase significantly in the wake of a Supreme Court decision striking down a law that required many cable systems to limit sexually explicit channels to late-night hours. A16
 
Best Water in Rural America
Water from a 5,000-year-old source beneath Independence Village, a 40-unit housing development for the elderly in Montville, Conn., was judged the best tasting in a competition sponsored by the National Rural Drinking Water Association. A16
 
SCIENCE/HEALTH
 
Insulin and Breast Cancer
High levels of insulin in the blood augur badly for women with breast cancer, a Canadian study found. Women with the disease and high levels of insulin who received standard therapy were about eight times more likely to develop a recurrence and die of the disease than women who had normal insulin levels. A22
 
Penalizing Medical Lapses
The Clinton administration said it would seek authority from Congress to levy fines of up to $250,000 on scientists who violate federal human research rules, and $1 million on the universities that employ them. A23
 
A Benefit From Caffeine
A study of 8,004 Japanese-American men in Hawaii suggests that coffee may prevent Parkinson's disease, with caffeine the main factor -- the more the better. But the researchers said it was uncertain whether their results would hold true with other ethnic groups and with women. A17

HEADLINE: United Plans to Buy US Airways, Creating Giant in the Northeast

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN and DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
The world's largest airline, United, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the biggest carrier in the Northeast, US Airways, for $4.3 billion in cash, which would create a carrier with by far the largest share of passengers from Boston to New York to Washington.
If the acquisition is approved by shareholders and government regulators, United will carry almost 500,000 passengers a day, have hubs in nine American cities from Philadelphia to San Francisco and employ 145,000 people. The acquisition represents the first merger of two large American airlines since a wave of consolidation in the 1980's, and analysts said United's new strength would force other airlines to consider deals as well. 
 The UAL Corporation, the parent of United, said the combination would allow millions of travelers in the Northeast -- long the company's weak spot in the United States -- to tap into its vast network of flights to the Midwest and West Coast and, on partner airlines, to Europe and Asia. The company also pledged not to raise fares on some domestic routes for at least two years except for price increases needed to cover inflation and higher fuel costs.
In addition, UAL said it intended to shed many of US Airways' routes at Ronald Reagan National Airport near Washington and sell them to Robert L. Johnson, a member of the US Airways board and the founder of Black Entertainment Television. Mr. Johnson plans to operate a new airline with those planes, employees and routes. But it will not include US Airways' lucrative shuttle service between Washington, New York and Boston, which United would continue to operate.
The step is intended to satisfy regulators who might become concerned about market concentration in the Washington area, where United is the largest carrier at Washington Dulles International Airport and US Airways is in a similar position at Reagan Airport.
Even after selling some routes to Mr. Johnson, United would dominate many markets in the East, from Charlotte, N.C. -- where US Airways has a hub -- to Boston. At Dulles, one of the nation's fastest-growing airports, United would fly about 62 percent of all passengers, according to 1999 airline traffic data published by Aviation Daily, an industry newsletter. At La Guardia Airport, United would jump over Delta to become the largest carrier with a 32 percent market share. In Baltimore, it would surpass Southwest and fly more than a third of travelers.
United agreed to pay $60 a share for US Airways, a rich premium over the $25.9375 that the stock closed at yesterday. United is also taking on $7.3 billion in US Airways debt. United will not lay off any of its new employees, the company said, and will instead profit from the deal by winning more of the coast-to-coast and overseas business of the passengers who now fly US Airways. United has long hoped to gain a better foothold in the East, the busiest region in the United States.
The combined company will be run by UAL's chief executive, James E. Goodwin, a career United employee who unexpectedly won the top job last year in large part because of the unions' support for him. Mr. Goodwin, 55, joined United as an accountant in 1967 and has since overseen many of its divisions.
The merger would complete a flirtation that continued on and off in the mid-1990's. The chairman of US Airways, Stephen M. Wolf, and its chief executive, Rakesh Gangwal, are both former United executives.
United backed away from a deal in 1995 after its powerful pilots' union expressed concerns about combining seniority lists.
Executives involved in the negotiations said objections from UAL's pilots might prove difficult again.
The pilots' union, which is represented on UAL's board, is likely to announce today that it opposes the transaction.
"The pilots will not be fully on board," one executive said. "Integration of seniority lists is a particularly difficult issue for the unions, and the issue exists now, as it did in 1995."
UAL employees, which own 55 percent of the company, have three representatives on its board, two of whom are representatives from the pilots' and machinists' unions. According to the corporate bylaws, approval of this sort of transaction is required from at least one of the two union representatives.
US Airways, the sixth-largest airline in the United States, has struggled in recent years even as the industry has enjoyed its most profitable years ever. With maintenance, labor and computer-related difficulties, the carrier has reported three consecutive quarterly losses. Airline analysts expect it to return to profitability this year.
Since January 1999, its stock has fallen to its current level from $62.25, leaving the company vulnerable to a takeover.
As a hodgepodge of the original airline and a group of companies it acquired in the 1980's, including Allegheny Airlines and Piedmont Airlines, US Airways suffers from high costs that come with different fleets and complicated work rules, said Glenn D. Engel, an airline analyst at Goldman, Sachs.
US Airways also flies relatively short routes in the crowded Eastern corridor, where flights are often late and planes spend more time waiting on runways than they do elsewhere in the country. And in recent years it began to face more competition from Southwest Airlines, the profitable low-cost carrier that has started flying out of Baltimore, Providence, R.I., and other Northeast cities, driving down many fares.
United now faces the difficult task of merging US Airways' fleet and its 45,000-person work force with its own while it is in the midst of increasingly contentious labor talks with its pilots' and machinists' unions. In 1995, United became the nation's largest company in which the employees owned a majority stake after the pilots and machinists agreed to concessions in exchange for stock. That agreement expires this year, and US Airways employees are not expected to receive shares as part of the merger
Wall Street analysts said they expected both investors and regulators to approve it. Other deals could then follow, the analysts said.
"The moral to the story is that the dance commences," said Kevin Murphy, an analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "This is the beginning of consolidation in the United States and around the world. It won't stop here."
The airline industry has enjoyed some of its healthiest profits the last three years after executives, smarting from a glut of capacity that helped cause billions of dollars worth of losses in the last recession, cut back on their purchase of new planes. Over the last year, however, capacity growth has increased again, and many unions have negotiated raises for the first time since the industry's troubles in the mid-1990's. Profits and stock prices have declined as a result.
The biggest American airlines have already paired up in alliances over the last three years, agreeing to combine their frequent-flier programs and, in the case of Continental and Northwest, sell seats on each others' flights. Northwest owns a stake in Continental.
The rationale behind the agreements is similar to United's interest in US Airways: the carriers want to be able to feed passengers from anywhere on to their more lucrative, long-haul flights.
The merger would effectively end the frequent-flier partnership between US Airways and American Airlines. It also calls into question United's and Delta's frequent-flier alliance, which United signed largely to gain access to Delta's many passengers on the East Coast. If the US Airways acquisition becomes final, United and Delta will become much more direct rivals.
A representative of the merging companies offered news of the merger yesterday to The New York Times, The Washington Post and The Wall Street Journal, on the condition that reporters not post it on the Internet until after midnight or speak to outsiders about the pending deal.
Early yesterday evening, The Financial Times of London reported the merger on its Web site, citing people in Chicago, where United is based. That story quickly led to television and news service reports.

HEADLINE: Moment of Decision: The Vote on China Trade

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"Labor and the China Vote" (editorial, May 21) concedes that "some American workers will doubtless be hurt by foreign competition." You argue that American labor should make this sacrifice to help unleash the "forces of economic globalization" that supposedly offer great benefits to workers in China. 
 How would you explain these benefits to workers in Guangdong Province, who make handbags for Wal-Mart 12 to 14 hours a day, seven days a week? According to a recent study by the National Labor Committee, a human rights group, nearly half of these workers actually owed their employer money after several months of labor, because of deductions for food, housing, work permits and other items.
Linking China's trade status to the annual review of its human rights performance remains the best tool available for creating positive change in China.
 
STEPHEN P. YOKICH
Detroit, May 22, 2000
 
The writer is president of the United Automobile Workers of America.

HEADLINE: Moment of Decision: The Vote on China Trade

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Alan Tonelson ("China's Mythic Market," Op-Ed, May 18) is right to decry the portrayals of trade partners and business objectives in the Chinese trade debate as inaccurate. But it doesn't necessarily follow that "trade agreements cannot bring widespread benefits to the United States." Framing the debate too narrowly around Chinese consumers obscures the real sources of value creation in today's economy. 
 Most of the future global opportunity is in e-business, and business-to-business transactions are assumed to account for 95 percent of that revenue, estimated at nearly $7 trillion annually by 2004. Competitive companies create this value by uniting customers and suppliers with their brand. Countries like China can help supply these companies with manufacturing, freeing the brand owner to focus capital on invention, innovation and customer satisfaction. The consumer element is but a small fraction of the whole.
 
MICHAEL N. BAZIGOS
New York, May 19, 2000
 
The writer is worldwide director of globalization strategic consulting at PricewaterhouseCoopers.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 2037 words

HEADLINE: Florio's Style, Like Tax Rise, Remains Issue in Senate Race

BYLINE: By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

DATELINE: TRENTON, May 23

 BODY:
For all the countless, impassioned speeches Jim Florio has delivered in his quest for the Democratic nomination for New Jersey's United States Senate seat, the most telling two words in his campaign are the ones Mr. Florio has refused to utter: "I'm sorry."
Both admirers and critics say it is hardly surprising that Mr. Florio is standing by the single act that has most defined his political career: the $2.8 billion tax increase he pushed through the State Legislature two months after becoming governor. 
 The tax rise, enacted in 1990, set off a tirade by angry voters.
Democrats were swept from offices across the state and lost control of both houses of the Legislature. United States Senator Bill Bradley, who had nothing to do with the plan, was nearly toppled simply because he hesitated for months before disavowing Mr. Florio's tax package. In 1993, Mr. Florio was cast into exile by a thin margin, becoming the only governor in New Jersey's modern history to be denied a second term.
The tax increase also defines the crucial question about Mr. Florio's record as governor. Was he a principled leader willing to take unpopular stands for worthy causes or an arrogant blunderer whose tin ear left him out of touch with the state he now wants to represent in the Senate?
In his campaign against Jon S. Corzine, the former chairman of Goldman, Sachs, leading up to the June 6 Democratic primary, Mr. Florio has gone beyond merely defending his decision to raise taxes.
Conceding only that he should have better explained to voters that a court-ordered increase in school financing made the tax increase necessary, Mr. Florio defiantly describes it as a courageous action to protect the core values of the Democratic Party.
"It's fine for Republicans to walk away from a commitment to finance education for all of our children, to comply with a court order that said there's something wrong with a child getting the quality of education that depends upon the accident of what town they live in," Mr. Florio said. "Those kind of know-nothing views about not standing up for our children don't belong in our party. They belong in the other party."
A former Navy boxer from Camden County who has spent almost all his working life in politics and has practiced law since leaving office, Mr. Florio, 62, has been emphasizing health care, Social Security and education in his campaign, while dismissing Mr. Corzine as a rich neophyte trying to buy his way into the Senate.
Mr. Florio was leading in the polls earlier this year, but that lead has shifted in the last month, as the better-financed Mr. Corzine has begun running television ads reminding voters of Mr. Florio's tax increase.
Beyond its disastrous political fallout, the tax increase raises two critical questions about Mr. Florio: Was it smart policy and what kind of governor was he anyway?
By casting the tax increase as a matter of principle, Mr. Florio hopes to remind voters of his record of activism as governor and congressman.
Those same principles, Mr. Florio says, spurred him to take on the National Rifle Association by passing the nation's first, and strongest, assault weapons ban. Mr. Florio also defeated an attempt by Republican legislators to overturn the ban, and was later granted the John F. Kennedy Profiles in Courage Award for his efforts.
As governor, Mr. Florio tightened New Jersey's environmental laws, curbing the ocean dumping that had dirtied the state's beaches and created an office of environmental prosecutor to go after polluters.
Before suburban sprawl became a major statewide issue, Mr. Florio used the governor's office to restrict development, by signing an executive order requiring that all new construction had to conform with the state development plan.
Mr. Florio also riled the auto insurance companies by eliminating the $220 surcharge state drivers paid for the risk pool to cover bad drivers, and forcing the companies to assume more of that cost.
Executives at Allstate Insurance were so upset by that move, and at Mr. Florio's other policies, that the company threatened to pull out of the New Jersey market. Mr. Florio responded by saying that Allstate was trying to frighten the state into granting the company a huge rate increase, and insisted that if it wanted to pull out of auto insurance in New Jersey, it would be required to pull out of all insurance in New Jersey. Allstate backed down.
"Jim Florio wasn't always effective at communicating with the public," said Carl Van Horn, who was Mr. Florio's chief public policy adviser. "But he was a problem solver, someone who wasn't afraid to tackle big issues, even if that meant making powerful enemies."
But the paradox of Jim Florio is that his style of leadership has often angered the very people he proposed to help. Even supporters say his single-mindedness and self-assurance can make him seem like the political world's version of castor oil -- his policies may be good for you, but they sure leave a bitter taste.
Members of the state's powerful teachers' union, who should have been pleased by Governor Florio's increase in school financing, accused him of weakening their pension system by shifting the obligation for employer contributions from the state to the local districts. His overhaul of the state's welfare system helped shrink the size of the state's dole, but also angered many Democrats because it froze benefits for recipients who became pregnant while on public assistance.
Other state employees also have disturbing memories of Mr. Florio's term as governor. At a recent A.F.L.-C.I.O. convention in Atlantic City, Mr. Florio reminded labor leaders of his efforts in Congress to promote workers' rights and the many picket lines he had walked with them. He singled out more than a dozen union officials in the room by name. But members of the Communications Workers of America, which represents state employees, still remember Mr. Florio's trying to back out of a contract they had agreed to in 1991.
To make matters worse, when Mr. Florio met with the union's political action committee this year, seeking an endorsement for his Senate run, Mr. Florio was anything but contrite, labor leaders say.
"He should have just come to us and said, 'Look, I know we've had our problems, but I'm a good labor guy, so let's get on with the future,' " said Jim Marketti, president of C.W.A. Local 1032. "But instead, he was all defensive, and trying to rewrite history. So a lot of what he said just seemed to ring hollow to our members."
The union did not endorse either candidate in the primary.
Even before the fallout from the tax increase, some of Mr. Florio's harshest critics were other New Jersey Democrats.
When Mr. Florio took office as governor, his advisers persuaded him to push for the tax increase early, so voters would have time to forget before re-election time rolled around. Some Democrats, both in New Jersey and outside the state, agreed with the wisdom of his move. The Star-Ledger compared the ambitious agenda of Mr. Florio's first 100 days in office to Franklin D. Roosevelt's. Mario M. Cuomo, who was then governor of New York, praised Mr. Florio's courage and said in June 1990 that he should be considered presidential material.
But all around New Jersey, Democratic legislators, county freeholders and city council members began hearing complaints that Mr. Florio's actions were arrogant, that he broke a pledge not to raise taxes and that he was pushing ahead without convincing the public that a tax increase was unavoidable.
In the end, voter anger, fueled by talk radio and hostile groups like the N.R.A., were too much. In 1993, he lost to Christine Todd Whitman by 26,000 votes, one of the slimmest margins in state history. Republicans in the Legislature declined a challenge to simply repeal the Florio taxes, but Mrs. Whitman later made good on her pledge to cut income-tax rates by 30 percent.
Despite the loss, some political analysts say his record as governor was commendable.
"There's only one worst recession since the Great Depression and he had the bad fortune to assume office just when its effects were being felt," said James Hughes, a professor of political science at Rutgers University. "He didn't have much choice but to increase taxes, and once he did, he lost the Legislature and had to be creative in order to carry out any agenda."
Others, including Mr. Corzine, assert that Mr. Florio worsened the state's economic pain by raising too many taxes too high too fast.
Many economists agree that Mr. Florio's policies made New Jersey a difficult and expensive place to conduct business. Irwin Kellner, an economist for Chase Manhattan and Manufacturer's Hanover Banks during Mr. Florio's term, said he recalled New Jersey business owners' complaining that they were overtaxed and overburdened by environmental and labor regulations.
"Even during a recession, communities compete against each other," said Mr. Kellner, now a professor of economics at Hofstra University. "The tax increases made things in New Jersey worse than neighboring states, and businesses stayed away."
Larry Sabato, a professor of political science at the University of Virginia, whose 1980 book, "Goodbye to Good-Time Charlie," was a study of governors who lost re-election bids, said Mr. Florio was largely a product of his times. The two New Jersey governors who preceded Mr. Florio also broke their campaign promises not to raise taxes, but still won re-election. By 1993 however, the recession and the political partisanship of Washington left voters in a far less forgiving mood, Mr. Sabato said.
"He was actually quite successful with the Legislature and he achieved a great deal as governor on the environment and gun control and education," Mr. Sabato said. "But in a sense, he achieved too much. You can't achieve more than the public wants and expect to be re-elected. He tried to do so much, and it cost so much, that taxpayers said, 'Bye-bye, Jim.' "
Given the lingering resentment over the tax increase, many Democrats say that Mr. Florio's attempt to win political redemption without ever repenting shows that what was wrong with Mr. Florio as governor is what is wrong with Mr. Florio as Senate candidate.
"He's a good person, but he's so intense," said Anthony Impreveduto, a Democratic legislator who voted for Mr. Florio's tax increase in 1990 and now supports Mr. Corzine. "He's the kind of person who, if you see him at a dinner party and make small talk about your summer vacation, he wants to talk about ocean dumping."
To some, Mr. Florio's career is a lesson in how smart politics and smart policy are inseparable -- to the point that it is impossible to credit him for one without the other.
Thomas H. Kean, the governor who preceded Mr. Florio, said he, too, was forced to raise taxes when he assumed office and found an unexpected budget deficit.
But Mr. Kean said he held extensive public hearings to prepare voters for the unpleasant news, and when the bill passed, with bipartisan support, he signed it while literally holding his nose.
"I didn't smile and hold up the bill when I signed it, and I didn't push it through the Legislature without bipartisan support," said Mr. Kean, a Republican. "Jim Florio should be proud of the assault weapons ban. But his inexperience in his first year in office, and the failures it caused, made it a pretty difficult term the rest of the way."
So, given the lingering bitterness, why not apologize now?
Mr. Sabato suspects that the tax increase is such an integral part of Mr. Florio's legacy that he is wary of distancing himself from the issue.
"He can live with the political failure of losing re-election," Mr. Sabato said. "A lot of people have been crucified for doing what they think was the right thing. But if he backs away from the tax increase in any way, then history might view him as a policy failure as well, and that would take away from his reason for political being."
Mr. Florio is not nearly as philosophical in describing his motives.
"The idea of, sort of, apologizing for funding kids' education is something I'm not comfortable with," Mr. Florio said.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 27, 2000, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article on Wednesday about Jim Florio's record as governor of New Jersey referred incorrectly to the rarity of a defeat like the one he suffered in 1993. Mr. Florio was the second governor in the state's modern history, not the first, to lose a bid for a second term. Gov. William T. Cahill lost the 1973 Republican primary to Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr.

HEADLINE: ONLINE SHOPPER;
Finding Out How Much Free Shipping Is Worth

BYLINE: By Michelle Slatalla; E-mail address: Slatalla@nytimes.com

 BODY:
I HAVE been told that in some families a hammock can last for years. I am more familiar with the sort of situation in which eight small and medium-size children who are pretending to be pirates routinely pile onto a hammock, rock it vigorously to simulate high seas and dangle 16 legs through the mesh to taunt imaginary sharks.
One cannot really expect miracles from a natural cotton rope structure supported by two spreader bars and zinc-plated hanging hardware. Even the sturdy old oaks that suspend the "ship" are in peril. 
 So almost every year, I buy a new hammock, and it's always the same model (since there's nothing wrong with the product that pirate-proofing wouldn't fix): the "original Pawleys Island rope hammock," made in North Carolina and distributed nationwide. According to the manufacturer's Web site, Pawleys.com, it comes in three sizes. I buy the middle size, which can hold two adults or 450 pounds or as many as eight bloodthirsty buccaneers.
The last hammock, if I recall correctly, came from a mail-order catalog. I paid about $100 for it, plus shipping, which set me back an additional $10 or so.
"Plus shipping." In the months since buying the hammock, I have come to realize that "plus shipping" is one of the ugliest phrases in the English language. Thanks to the multitude of online retailers who offered free shipping during last winter's holiday shopping season, I have been conditioned to believe that I am entitled to this perk forever.
A lot of online shoppers share my expectations, it turns out. Last week, Forrester Research reported that 94 percent of online shoppers were concerned about shipping costs and that 44 percent had abandoned an online shopping cart after they found out how much the shipping costs would add to the total. These are, mind you, the same shoppers who for years accepted mail-order catalogs' shipping charges, which often add up to 15 percent to the cost of a purchase.
"Consumers have different expectations when they shop online, not only because the retail sites raised their expectations during the Christmas season, but also because shoppers see that they are giving the sites something in return, information about themselves," said Susy Chan, director of the e-commerce technology program at DePaul University in Chicago.
Now that she mentioned it, I did resent typing in all kinds of valuable personal information -- name, address, phone number, name of street where I grew up in case I forgot my password and needed a prompt every time I bought something online. Beyond the privacy concerns, these questions are annoyingly time-consuming. I should be compensated.
So last week, I started my search for a hammock at a site called freeshipping.com (www.freeshipping
.com), which has a search engine to point shoppers toward about a million products that the site's 125 retail partners are willing to sell without charging shipping and handling fees. Freeshipping.com's partners -- who include both well-known retailers like Cooking.com and smaller specialty retailers like Kideo.com, which sells personalized children's videos -- pay freeshipping.com a commission for sales referrals.
Freeshipping.com's founder, D. J. Vallauri, got the idea for creating the site after starting another Web site called Mustardstore.com (which he eventually sold). "I kept getting feedback from people who wanted to order a bottle of mustard that cost a few dollars and were complaining that the shipping cost a fortune," Mr. Vallauri said. "They were right."
The selection at freeshipping.com -- 10 categories, including apparel and office supplies -- is more quirky than comprehensive. "I just want people to think of this site as a first stop when they shop to see if someone is willing to sell whatever you want to buy without charging you for shipping," Mr. Vallauri said.
After I did a search for "hammock" on the home page, the site returned matches in three product categories. Although the search results were displayed in a confusing way -- many matches, were redundant, for instance -- I quickly found the model I wanted, at Ezshop.com for $95.70.
When I clicked on Buy Now, freeshipping.com sent me directly to Ezshop.com's Web site. But after I arrived, I hesitated because Ezshop.com said the item "usually ships within 14 business days." That seemed like a long time. More important, I was shopping in an unfamiliar store. The home page said Ezshop.com was located in Dallas, and it listed a phone number -- unfortunately not toll-free -- that I could call for customer service. When I phoned anyway, no one answered.
That made me uneasy. So I did some quick comparison shopping. Using search engines, I found the same model at higher prices and with shipping costs that ranged from $8.95 to $14.95 at several other online shops. One, Smith & Hawken (www.smithandhawken.com), was a store I know well. But there I would have to pay nearly 40 percent more; even on sale, the hammock would cost $133.95, including shipping and handling. On the other hand, the Smith & Hawken hammock would arrive much sooner: in 7 to 10 business days.
Was it worth it to pay extra for security? In this sort of situation, many experienced online shoppers will choose the brand name they trust, said Ms. Chan, of DePaul University. "Convenience, the time spent and knowing that the item will arrive when it is expected are more important than just getting a short-term benefit like free shipping," she said.
But brand names do not mean that much to me, not when the items offered by two retailers are identical. The only perk that I can think of that is more valuable than saving money would be something along the lines of guaranteed baby-sitting on a Saturday night. Any online retailer who offered that would earn my loyalty. Friday night would be good, too.
In the absence of such luxuries, I sent e-mail to ask Ezshop why shipping took so long and why the phone wasn't answered. Within two hours, Ezshop responded: "We seem to have had some trouble with our phones earlier today. They are now working and we would be happy to help you via phone. In regards to shipping, all items ship directly from the manufacturer, and this particular manufacturer needs this long to ship orders. Although they tend to ship much faster, normally in five business days."
I ordered the hammock from Ezshop. I hope it arrives when it's supposed to. Or else, I have been told, I may walk the plank.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Europe Refuses to Drop Ban on Hormone-Fed U.S. Beef

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, May 24

 BODY:
The European Union decided today to extend its ban on beef produced with growth hormones, rejecting demands by the United States and the World Trade Organization to drop the prohibition.
The decision reignites an ideologically charged battle between American cattle ranchers, most of whom use hormones to accelerate beef production, and European consumers, who generally distrust food additives. 
 Nearly three years ago, the World Trade Organization ruled that that European prohibition was illegal because it was not based on scientific evidence that hormones endanger human health.
Today, European officials in Brussels released what they described as a new review of scientific studies that concluded that one popular hormone causes cancer and that others are "likely" to pose increased health risks.
Armed with the new opinion, European trade and health officials said they would extend the ban on hormone-treated beef.
"We believe this proposal will bring us into line with the W.T.O.'s findings, and definitively resolve this dispute," said Anthony Gooch, a spokesman for the European Commission's trade ministry.
American officials, who were still scrutinizing the new pronouncements today, said they were not impressed.
"We were of the view from the beginning that they didn't have the science to back them up, and we don't see any new science now," one official in Brussels said today.
The United States is currently imposing punitive tariffs of $117 million a year, an amount that the World Trade Organization says is equal to the lost American beef exports, on European products ranging from Danish ham to Italian tomatoes.
In an effort to intensify the pressure, President Clinton recently signed legislation that requires American trade officials to rotate the penalties to different industries every six months.
But there is little likelihood that the two sides will reach an accord anytime soon, in part because many Europeans have a deep mistrust of anything that smacks of genetically modified food.
Just last week, farmers from Scandinavia to Britain and Italy found themselves in the middle of a political uproar after a company admitted that it had accidentally mixed a small percentage of genetically modified rapeseed from Canada into seed shipments sold across Europe.
Genetically modified crops are common in the United States and Canada and only about 0.4 percent of the seeds mixed into the shipments that arrived in Europe appeared to have been genetically modified. Nevertheless, the slip infuriated officials in several countries and Swedish farm regulators went so far as to order farmers to destroy the questionable seeds.
The battle over beef hormones could easily become an important test case in future trade disputes based on real or perceived health risks.
Under international trade agreements, countries are only allowed to impose trade restrictions based on health concerns if those concerns are backed by scientific evidence.
American trade officials, echoing the views of American cattle farmers, have argued that there is no evidence that beef produced with hormones poses special health problems.
Among other things, they argue that growth hormones are naturally present in beef and other foods and that two pounds of hormone-treated beef have about the same amount of growth hormone as that in an ordinary egg.
European officials, prodded by persistent anxiety among consumers, have argued that there are many reasons to be worried. After protracted hearings at the World Trade Organization, the organization ruled that European officials had not made their case and deemed the ban illegal in 1997.
Today's report, from a scientific committee organized by the European Union, said there was evidence that high doses of the hormone 17 beta oestriadol had carcinogenic effects and that five other hormones might affect the development of sexual organs.
Under the legislation proposed today, the European Union would impose a permanent ban on beta oestriadol and "provisional" bans on the other five, pending the outcome of future studies.
The scientific committee acknowledged that the evidence of health risks was based on exposure to very high doses of hormones. But in a tortuous use of double negatives, it warned that there was "no compelling evidence suggesting that these effects do not also occur at low doses."
It said that continuous exposure to low doses of hormones was likely to add to long-term health risks, but said this risk "as yet, cannot be quantified."
Unlike many other trade disputes, the battle over beef hormones has little or nothing to do with protecting local producers. A recent poll, commissioned by the European Commission, found that two-thirds of 16,000 people queried said they preferred hormone-free food.
"These cases have a lot to do with ideology," said Stefan Tangermann, a professor of agricultural economics at the University of Gottingen in Germany. "The real problem is that European consumers are deeply concerned about these issues, and the public expects politicians to protect their interests."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Big Japan Contractor Asks Banks to Forgive Billions in Debts

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 24

 BODY:
For the second time in just a few weeks, a large Japanese company appealed to its banks today to forgive billions of dollars in debts, intensifying pressure on Japan's stressed financial system.
The decision by the Hazama Corporation, a general contractor, to request 400 billion yen, or $3.7 billion at current exchange rates, worth of debt forgiveness is yet another sign that the bad-loan problems of Japanese banks are far from over. 
 On April 26, Sogo, a faltering Japanese retail company, astonished its bankers by asking them to write off 639 billion yen, or roughly $6 billion, in debts. That was the largest amount of debt forgiveness ever sought in Japan, where the practice is far from standard.
The shock of Sogo's request was magnified a few days later when the senior executive in charge of the retailer's restructuring plans was found dead in his home, apparently having committed suicide.
On Tuesday, the company's lenders postponed a decision on the request for debt forgiveness, although its largest lender, the Industrial Bank of Japan, has said it is willing to do so.
Sogo's outstanding debts to the Industrial Bank -- 180 billion yen, or $1.7 billion -- are roughly equivalent to a year's worth of operating profit, according to James P. Fiorillo, senior banking analyst at ING Barings here. Nor does the bank have sizable unrealized gains on its securities portfolio to offset such a write-off.
"The question of whether to forgive these debts or not is a big one," Mr. Fiorillo said.
Hazama's largest lender, Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank, is apparently willing to waive 90 billion yen of the construction company's loans, according to Nihon Keizai Shimbun, Japan's leading business daily.
Changes in accounting standards are intensifying the pressure on troubled companies. In the fiscal year that began on April 1, they must value their real estate and securities holdings at market levels. The new rules also strictly limit their ability to hide their debts in the accounts of affiliates, requiring that they report their financial results on a consolidated basis.
Including Hazawa and Sogo, more than 10 large companies have asked for debt relief this year. The greatest number seeking such forgiveness have come from the construction industry, and analysts warn that many more contractors are in similarly weak shape.
Like Hazama, they took on loads of debt to finance real estate purchases in the 1980's, only to watch the value of that real estate plummet when Japan's economic bubble burst.
But whether debt forgiveness will in fact help such ailing companies regain their footing is a matter of much debate here. Unlike in the United States, where creditors of distressed companies can force radical changes on businesses in exchange for debt relief, Japanese creditors have very little power to do that.
"It would be much better if these companies went bankrupt," said Tadashi Nakamae, a prominent economist here. "Debt forgiveness is only going to prolong their problems."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Work visas are allowing Washington to sidestep immigration reform.

BYLINE: By Alan B. Krueger; This column appears here every Thursday. Alan B. Krueger is the Bendheim Professor of Economics and Public Affairs at Princeton University and editor of The Journal of Economic Perspectives. Four economic analysts -- Professor Krueger, J. Bradford DeLong, Jeff Madrick and Virginia Postrel -- rotate as contributors.

 BODY:
THE inscription on the Statue of Liberty is quietly being rewritten: "Give me your tired, your poor, your huddled masses yearning to breathe free; I'll also take your skilled employees under the temporary visa program, H-1B."
The H-1B visa was established in 1990 to permit foreigners with a college degree or higher to work in the United States for a renewable three-year term for employers who petition on their behalf. In 1998, the program was expanded to allow 115,000 workers, up from 65,000, to enter the United States in fiscal years 1999 and 2000. Demand for H-1B visas by employers is high, particularly among high-technology companies. This year the limit was reached just six months into the year. President Clinton and many members of Congress would like to increase the limit to 200,000 a year the next three years. 
 The expansion of temporary work visas should be evaluated in the context of overall immigration policy. But immigration reform, replacing Social Security, has become the new third rail of American politics. So instead of tackling the issue head on, Washington has come to rely on temporary work visas as a substitute for addressing the economic and social shortcomings of current policy.
The United States is in the midst of the "Second Great Migration." The first occurred between 1880 and 1924, when 26 million immigrants arrived on our shores. The second began in the late 1970's: more immigrants have come to the United States since 1980 than in the previous 60 years.
Workers admitted under the H-1B program are not immigrants, but experts in the field expect that most of them will end up staying permanently in the United States.
In addition to workers with H-1B visas, hundreds of thousands of other foreigners are admitted to work temporarily in the United States under visa categories covering intracompany transfers, individuals with extraordinary ability, registered nurses and nonprofit religious organizations. A fast-growing category is the Nafta TN visa, which offers an unlimited number of temporary visas for professional workers from Canada and soon Mexico.
In a new book, "Heaven's Door," George Borjas, a Harvard economist, proposes that the United States adopt a Canadian-style point system, in which applicants for visas are assigned points on the basis of characteristics like their ability to speak English, work-force skills, family ties, refugee status and ethnic diversity. Those whose total points exceed a certain threshold would be admitted. Going even further, Professor Borjas favors setting the threshold so that the number of immigrants entering the United States falls from about 900,000 to about 500,000 a year. The total number can be debated. If nothing else, this policy would be transparent.
Who should become an American? The question is profound, involving more than economics alone. But economic considerations obviously play a role.
Theoretically, the economics of immigration is straightforward. If more workers are admitted to the country -- as permanent immigrants or temporary workers -- the earnings of native American workers competing with them for jobs should fall. At the same time, the price of goods and services they produce should decline, and the profits of businesses should rise.
The winners are employers, consumers and the immigrants themselves. The losers are workers in the same job market as immigrants.
Economic research has not been able to estimate with any confidence the wage decline for native workers that results from immigration. Much solid research finds no effect. This suggests to me that any effect is likely to be small.
Professor Borjas's evidence indicates that the skills of legal and illegal immigrants have slipped relative to those of natives since the 1970's. A third of employed male immigrants are high school dropouts. At the same time, the labor market increasingly demands more high-skilled workers, as suggested by the long-term rise in the number of workers with college degrees and their sharply increased pay compared with that of those with high school degrees. Therefore, it would be economically beneficial to admit relatively more highly skilled permanent immigrants -- not to mention that skilled immigrants are less likely to take advantage of the safety net.
If immigration reform is off the table, it makes economic sense to increase the number of skilled immigrants by issuing H-1B visas -- through what might be called heaven's backdoor. Yet economic principles also suggest that the playing field between H-1B workers and the rest of the work force should be leveled.
American workers are protected from exploitation on the job by three defenses: exit, voice and regulation. Exit entails the ability to move to a better job if one is available; voice results from representation by labor unions and other organizations; and regulation is a labyrinth of standards enforced by government agencies.
These protections are deficient for H-1B workers.
They cannot easily switch jobs because they must find another employer willing to petition the Immigration and Naturalization Service on their behalf. Even if they manage to do that, they must wait months for a reply. H-1B workers are also unusually beholden to their employers, the ones who can sponsor them for permanent immigrant status.
They lack voice because no organization effectively represents them.
And they have less regulatory protection than other workers because the Labor Department is precluded from investigating their conditions of employment unless a complaint is filed.
Evidence suggests H-1B visa holders suffer as a consequence. Even though 70 percent of them are in well-paid computer-related and engineering fields, a 1996 report by the Labor Department's inspector general found that 19 percent of H-1B workers are paid less than the salary they were promised.
Legislation to increase the number of H-1B visas should provide protection from exploitation. This also would help native workers and improve economic efficiency.
What could be done? Permit H-1B workers to change jobs freely after they are admitted to the country. Authorize the Labor Department to conduct random investigations of their employment conditions. Finally, require the immigration service to process applications for permanent, employment-based immigration more quickly, which would reduce the need for H-1B visas in the first place.

HEADLINE: THE CHINA TRADE VOTE: THE LOBBYISTS;
With Smiles and Cell Phones, a Last-Minute Assault on the Undecided

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 24

 BODY:
By this morning it was quite clear that the China trade bill would pass, but no one on either side was taking chances.
From a stuffy conference room in the basement of the Capitol, about 50 business lobbyists were dispatched, cell phones in hand, in a final effort to nail down the votes of the dozen or so lawmakers who were still thought to be undecided. 
 A lobbyist for Procter & Gamble, for instance, was sent to see Representative Ernie Fletcher, a Republican from Kentucky. The company makes Jif peanut butter in Mr. Fletcher's district and employs 239 workers.
An official from United Parcel Service went to see Representative Robert C. Scott, Democrat of Virginia. U.P.S. has a hub in Newport News in Mr. Scott's district.
Representative Van Hilleary, Republican of Tennessee, had his arm twisted by a lobbyist from TRW, which has about 500 workers at an automotive plant in Morristown in Mr. Hilleary's district.
"We can't afford to get overconfident," said Johanna Schneider of the Business Roundtable, an organization of giant corporations, who was working from the room in the basement, Room HC-8.
And despite vote counts that showed them losing, the opponents of the measure were also out in force today. Scores of union members from back home were on the phone, and at least a dozen labor officials from across the country were on Capitol Hill.
Art Pulaski, president of the California A.F.L.-C.I.O., paid a final call on Representative Henry A. Waxman, a Democrat from Los Angeles, who had not tipped his hand on how he would vote.
In the end, Mr. Fletcher, Mr. Hilleary and Mr. Waxman voted for the bill. Mr. Scott voted against it.
They, and the handful of other lawmakers who were truly undecided as the vote approached, were besieged in the last few days, and the pressure peaked this morning.
"It's like a big wave hitting the shore," said Representative Vito J. Fossella, a Republican from Staten Island, who did not let on until just before the vote that he planned to support the legislation.
He said he took a call this morning from a driver for U.P.S. whom he had met at a Boy Scout function on Staten Island last weekend. He was also called by members of the food workers union. The driver favored the trade bill; the food workers were against it.
For the first time since he entered Congress three years ago, he said, he was lobbied by rank-and-file workers in financial services companies -- at the banks and brokerage houses and insurance companies -- who live on Staten Island, or in the slice of his district that is in southwestern Brooklyn, and work in Manhattan.
"I finally decided, I don't see how voting no is in America's interest," Mr. Fossella said.
For him and the others who were undecided -- most genuinely trying to weigh the national security and economic implications of the legislation as well as the direct interests of their constituents -- all the attention was exhausting.
"I finally let people know today I needed some space to breathe," said Representative John E. Sweeney, a freshman Republican from upstate New York.
He more or less decided overnight to vote for the measure, Mr. Sweeney said, but at 3 this afternoon he still had qualms and was following the debate on television in his office, "just to make absolutely sure I'm making the right decision."
As a matter of policy, Mr. Sweeney said, he concluded that "we lose a little more than we gain if the status quo remains."
"But in the end," he said, "you always vote your district."
And his district, which includes Saratoga Springs and Glens Falls along the upper Hudson River, was divided.
He heard, he said, from the dairy farmers and the apple and pear growers and small-business owners who favored the concept of expanded trade with China. And he heard from the paper workers and other union members who feared losing their jobs.
Former President George Bush called recently. So did Defense Secretary William S. Cohen. The congressman was given a special briefing by the Central Intelligence Agency. Dennis Hughes, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. in New York, visited him on Tuesday.
"I've talked to absolutely everybody," Mr. Sweeney said. "It was a very hard call." He finally voted yes.
Representative Peter Deutsch, a Democrat from southern Florida, dropped out of sight today while he pondered his decision. He took no calls and held no meetings.
"I've made myself available to everybody for weeks," Mr. Deutsch said. "Today I needed to think on my own."
He especially thought, he said, about the huge Motorola plant in his district with its 2,000 workers and its hopes of selling two-way radios in China.
"There are very few values I would put above them," he said. "But national security is one of them."
Just after lunch, about three hours before the vote, Mr. Deutsch decided to vote against the bill.

HEADLINE: AIRLINE DEAL: THE PASSENGERS;
Gains Predicted for Frequent Fliers

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
If the proposal by the UAL Corporation to buy US Airways clears government and shareholder hurdles, members of the US Airways frequent-flier program could find themselves in the unaccustomed position of winners.
Even though much of the fine print has not been made public, Kurt Ebenhoch, a spokesman for United Airlines, which is owned by UAL, said yesterday, "By the time this deal is consummated next year, our two airlines will be one and US Airways frequent-flier members will become United Mileage Plus members." 
 "The difference," he said, "is that US Airways members will then have the opportunity to accrue miles faster, to redeem them for more places and to earn flights with our 22 airline partners."
Among those partners are the 11 members of the Star Alliance, comprising United as well as airlines from Austria, Australia, Brazil, Canada, Germany, Japan, New Zealand, Scandinavia, Singapore and Thailand -- in short, much of the world.
The US Airways alliance with American Airlines, which includes honoring each other's frequent-flier programs, remains in force. "Until the acquisition takes place," said David Castelveter, a spokesman for US Airways, "it's business as usual."
Although United promises to freeze some domestic fares for two years after the acquisition, except for increases to pay for fuel costs and inflation, some industry experts think the deal will ultimately lead to higher prices for passengers, especially in the Northeast.
"I think the merger will be a good one," said Terry Trippler, the airline writer for 1Travel.com. "But if a lessening of competition does not result in higher prices, it will be the first time in history."
Still, even outsiders agree that US Airways' frequent-flier passengers stand to benefit by gaining access to more flights and more destinations. "Except for Southwest, US Airways is the only one of the major airlines without flights to Hawaii, which is by far the preferred destination of most frequent fliers," said Randy Peterson, the editor and publisher of Inside Flier magazine. United has daily flights to Hawaii from Chicago, San Francisco and Los Angeles.
"While US Airways' frequent-flier program has always been a competent follower," Mr. Peterson said, "it has never been a leader. Now it will be aligned with a leader."
Mr. Trippler added that United's extensive routes to Asia and the Pacific and South America will also be a big plus for US Airways frequent-flier members, as will United's many more flights to cities in Europe.
Moreover, United has far fewer flights to Florida than does US Airways, so the acquisition is likely to give passengers who participate in United's Mileage Plus program a wider choice of flights and destinations to that state.
Mr. Peterson and Mr. Trippler both pointed out, however, that frequent-flier "reward" flights to Hawaii are often very difficult to get and Florida destinations are scarce much of the year.
US Airways has hubs in Philadelphia, Pittsburgh, Baltimore and Charlotte, N.C., while United hubs are in Chicago, Denver, Los Angeles and San Francisco and at Dulles International Airport in Washington. United has already said that it will increase flights from Pittsburgh and possibly Philadelphia and Charlotte.
Furthermore, passengers to and from Washington are likely to benefit if DC Air -- the airline start-up that is expected to be owned by BET Holdings II, the parent company of the Black Entertainment Television -- becomes a low-fare carrier. BET's owner, Robert L. Jackson, has been a member of the US Airways board since 1998. The airline, which will operate from Ronald Reagan National Airport in Washington, will fill the void created by United's plan to sell its slots and other operations there to satisfy regulators.

HEADLINE: An Ambitious Airline Merger

 BODY:
There is a morbid expression that no one ever got rich hauling passengers. Not the railroads. Not the buses. Not the airlines.
That is the backdrop for the proposed takeover of US Airways, the sixth-largest domestic carrier, by United Airlines, the world's largest carrier. Ordinarily, a merger that decreased competition would be worrisome. But airlines are not ordinary. Though profitable over the past couple of years during ebullient economic times, they struggle year in and year out to make a decent profit. They are plagued by chronic excess capacity and gigantic losses when the economy slips. By wringing out excess costs and creating large networks that provide lots of travel options and convenient schedules, mergers can do consumers more good than harm. Whether that is true in this case will not be known until the Justice Department completes an exhaustive review. 
 United, whose employees own a majority of the company, has many international partners and domestic routes that spread out from centrally located "hub" airports. The merger gives it more routes in lucrative eastern markets and a prized asset, the shuttle route from Boston to New York to Washington. US Airways, by contrast, lacks international heft and even full national reach. Its labor costs are high and its labor relations sour. It is racking up losses even as the rest of the industry makes record profits. For this struggling carrier, United offers a lifeline. If Justice decides that US Airways cannot survive on its own and that the merged airline will offer travelers better schedules, one-stop ticketing and more attractive frequent-flier programs, then approval will follow.
But Justice has taken an aggressive stance against airline mergers, for good reason. There are often specific airports -- in this case, in Washington, Baltimore, New York and Boston -- where mergers threaten to strip travelers of competition. To solve this problem at Reagan National Airport in Washington, US Airways has announced it would turn over many of its routes to a new airline, DC Air. Justice, however, may find other pockets of diminished competition and demand further divestiture.
Travelers often blame the airline deregulation of the late 1970's, and the merger wave it spawned, for flight delays, baggage mix-ups, cramped leg room and other woes. But most of this criticism is misplaced, according to a recent study by Clifford Winston of the Brookings Institution and Steven Morrison of Northeastern University. Mergers, they say, have not raised fares and have been pursued to cut costs. Indeed, average prices have fallen by more than 25 percent under deregulation.
True, travelers flying to locations served by only one airline may find themselves paying prices they consider exorbitant. There are also some troubling allegations of anticompetitive behavior, such as attempts by large carriers at their hub airports to drive smaller rivals out of business by cutting prices temporarily to punishingly low levels and then raising them when the competition is driven away. It will be Justice's task to determine whether this proposed merger is benign or threatens to jack up prices and diminish service.
Labor opposition could still derail the merger. The pilots' union at United scuttled an earlier effort to merge the two carriers out of fear that many of its members would lose seniority. Meshing the employee-owners of United with the often disgruntled, costly employees of US Airways may prove a graver threat to completing the merger than anything thrown in the way by antitrust authorities.

HEADLINE: Charitable Giving Surged Again in '99, by an Estimated 9%

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
Charitable giving grew faster than the economy last year, although it did not quite keep pace with the tremendous accumulation in wealth, according to figures released yesterday.
The ebullient stock market and the prosperous economy helped drive donations to charity up nearly $16 billion, to $190.2 billion, 9.1 percent higher than in 1998 and well ahead of the 5.7 percent growth in gross domestic product, according to the figures, estimates presented by the A.A.F.R.C. Trust for Philanthropy, the nonprofit arm of the American Association of Fund-Raising Counsel. 
 After inflation, donations increased 6.7 percent, making 1999 the fifth year in a row that they rose in "real" dollars.
And, said the philanthropy trust, which uses an economic model to estimate annual charitable contributions, donations equaled 2.1 percent of gross domestic product, the highest level by that barometer in 28years.
Fund-raising executives and others called the growth substantial. President Clinton's domestic policy adviser, Bruce Reed, who spoke at a Manhattan news conference where the trust issued its figures, referred to "a new golden age of philanthropy in America."
"The new figures are remarkable," Mr. Reed said, adding that giving in the last seven years now totaled $1 trillion.
Since 1995, charitable giving has risen 53 percent, or 40 percent after inflation. The fund-raising association's chairman, George C. Ruotolo Jr., called the rise "meteoric."
Despite last year's gains -- and huge contributions from some Internet billionaires like William H. Gates of Microsoft -- the growth in giving appears not to have kept up with the growth in wealth. Using the figures released yesterday, Edward N. Wolff, an economics professor at New York University, calculated that giving amounted to 0.69 percent of the nation's wealth last year -- down from 0.71 percent in 1998, although slightly ahead of the 0.68 percent of 1997.
Daniel Feenberg, a research associate at the National Bureau of Economic Research and member of the fund-raising association's advisory council on methodology, suggests that another yardstick to measure charitable giving is its relation to personal consumption. He too used the figures released yesterday, and calculated that donations last year equaled 3 percent of personal consumption expenditures, up slightly from 1998 and a significant jump from the 2.5 percent in 1995 but still below the 3.3 percent of the late 1960's.
"There has been steady growth over the past five years, but we are still not back to the historic peak," Mr. Feenberg said, although he cautioned that the association figures on which he was basing his calculations were only estimates.
Giving by foundations last year rose at more than twice the rate of individual giving, spurred by a law that requires them to give away at least 5 percent of their assets each year. (They are allowed to average their assets over several years to even out their spending.)
The bullish equity markets, which provided most foundations large gains in their endowments, forced them to increase their giving sharply. Grants by noncorporate foundations jumped 16.5 percent, to $19.8 billion from $17 billion.
The Foundation Center, a New York-based group that gathers data on foundations, reported that the number of them had also been surging in recent years. By the end of 1998, there were 46,832 foundations, up from 23,770 in 1982. (The center does not yet have figures for 1999.)
In contrast with the extraordinarily robust growth of foundation giving, personal giving -- which accounts for about three-quarters of all donations -- was up 7 percent last year, to $143.7 billion from $134.1 billion.
The A.A.F.R.C. Trust said philanthropic giving by individuals amounted to 1.8 percent of personal income last year, the same as in 1998 but up from 1.5 percent in 1995. The last time personal giving was above the 1.8 percent level was 1973, when it reached 1.9 percent.
After personal giving and donations by noncorporate foundations, the two remaining categories of charitable contributions are bequests and corporate giving, both of which had a good year. Bequests rose $2.8 billion, to $15.6 billion, while corporate giving climbed $1.4 billion, to $11 billion.
Religious charities remained by far the largest recipients of charitable giving by Americans, receiving nearly $82 billion, a rise of 5.5 percent from 1998.
Education organizations, including universities, were the second-largest recipient, with $27.5 billion, an 8.5 percent increase.
The sharpest gain in percentage terms was to organizations focused on international affairs, like Doctors Without Borders and the United Nations Foundation, although the total still remained relatively small. Donations to these groups rose 24 percent, to $2.7 billion.
Environment and wildlife organizations also enjoyed a strong increase, 11 percent, to $5.8 billion.
The charitable giving data released yesterday is available on the fund-raising association's Web site (www.aafrc.org). A more detailed picture of charitable giving in 1999 will be contained in the association's book "Giving U.S.A. 2000," which will be available on disk in June and in book form in September.
