HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
From Ur, the First and Most Famous

BYLINE: By ROBERTA SMITH 

 BODY:
Mesopotamia, whose name comes from the Greek for "between the rivers," is one of the places where it all began, a cradle of Western civilization, like ancient Egypt. The rivers are the Tigris and the Euphrates, and the land between is a flood plain that today is in Iraq. It was inhospitable terrain: flat, arid and lacking in indigenous plant life or useful materials like stone, metals and wood.
But in the seventh millennium B.C. it was settled by people whom historians call Sumerians. And by the late fourth millennium, the Sumerians began to meet the requirements for ranking as a cradle of civilization. They probably invented the wheel; they established one of the world's first irrigation systems, essential to both agriculture and flood control; and they created one of the first written languages. The keeping of written records made large urban centers possible -- most notably the city-states of Uruk and Ur -- as well as an elaborate economy that included trade with places as far away as Afghanistan (from which the Sumerians imported various kinds of stone). 
 Beginning about 3500 B.C., the Sumerians also produced artworks of lasting beauty. Some of these, belonging to the University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology, form the core of "Treasures From the Royal Tombs of Ur," a sumptuous exhibition at the Pierpont Morgan Library. They were allowed to travel for the first time while the museum in Philadelphia is being renovated.
Everything in this show came to light between 1922 and 1934, when archaeologists sponsored by the university and the British Museum discovered and excavated a vast cemetery full of hundreds of intact, often lavishly equipped tombs at Ur, the southernmost of the ancient Sumerian city-states. Leading the team was C. Leonard Woolley (1880-1960), an English archaeologist known for his energy and meticulousness.
Gertrude Bell, another archaeologist of the time, described Woolley as "a tiresome little man but a first class digger." At the Morgan, photographs blown up to sepia-toned wall murals indicate the substantial size of one of the main pits at Ur and also the work force. But once the heavy work was done, Woolley usually sent everyone away and did the most delicate, time-consuming excavating himself, working face down in the dirt with a knife and a little brush beside his wife, Catherine, who was also an archaeologist, and one trusted assistant.
In a letter quoted in the catalog, he describes the tedium of stringing beads from this vantage point, the better to preserve the order in which they were found.
Anyone who has taken an introductory survey of Western art has seen images of the exhibition's stars. There is the Ram Caught inthe Thicket, a small sculpture of an avid ram made of gold, lapis lazuli and silver, whose wool is ingeniously depicted as rows of spearheadlike pieces of shell. He stands on his hind feet, as if to graze on a gold tree. There is also the Great Lyre, with its big prow-like bull's head bearded in lapis. Just below is the lyre's four-tiered inlaid front panel, rich in intimations of gods and myths to come.
The panel's four scenes include one of the first appearances of what art historians call the nude bearded hero as well as figures and creatures that presage the Holy Trinity, the minotaur, and the clever beasts of Aesop. Also present is a scorpion-tailed man resembling a devil. All the standard textbooks of Western art reproduce two of these three items.
It is, however, something else to see the real thing, and in the company of nearly 200 other objects from the tombs, sensitively lighted and displayed in nearly invisible vitrines. There have been significant reconservations: the ram's feet, for example. After an earlier conservation, they had hung oddly in the air in photographs published as recently as 1993; now they rest on the tree's gold boughs, as if on the handlebars of a bicycle.
The show also has vessels of gold, silver and calcite, a pale translucent stone; tools and weapons; and, perhaps most interesting, the small stone cylinder seals that served important people as amulets and early identification cards. (These are supplemented by a selection of Middle Eastern cylinder seals from the library's own holdings, displayed in the East Room.) Most prevalent is all manner of jewelry: headdresses, rings, earrings, cloak pins, beaded necklaces and chokers, belts and even a beaded cape belonging to a queen or aristocrat named Puabi, whose grave accounts for more than half the exhibition.
The assembled objects suggest that the Sumerian elite lived well and died even better. Not only were their bodies lavishly adorned and surrounded by objects both useful and entertaining (lyres, for example, and little lapis tablets that may be the first dominoes), but they were also accompanied by attendants, themselves richly adorned, along with oxen and carts. The burial was the culmination of a feast and processional march into the tomb, where the animals were slaughtered and the attendants either committed suicide or were ritually killed.
The objects in this exhibition suggest their own purely visual criteria for qualifying as a cradle of civilization. While neither as unbending nor as pure as the Egyptians, the Sumerians achieved a consistency of style that operated over a range of media: sculpture, incised relief, inlay and the incised cylinder seals, whose cartoonlike narratives are made visible here with enlarged photographs and modern clay impressions.
Given the barbarism of human sacrifice, the style is surprisingly buoyant, characterized by a wide-eyed innocence and alertness that are also visible in Minoan and Etruscan figures. (The Sumerian animals are also depicted with wide round eyes: those of the bull on the Great Lyre, emphasized by repeating creases, make clear why targets are known as bull's-eyes.)
The recurrence of certain motifs from one medium to another is a further consistency, one that indicates art's increasingly complex mirroring of life. The sketchy lines visible around the heads of the tiny figures on the cylinder seals are drinking tubes, like a long gold one, resembling a bit of miniaturized plumbing pipe, in one of the vitrines. The fringed garments worn by the figures are sheepskin, as verified by a front panel for a lyre where a figure wears a garment incised with the same spear shapes that appear in three-dimensions on the back of the ram.
An oddly shaped pouring vessel appears in the hand of an upright lion in the front panel of the Great Lyre, and others like it are in a vitrine. These vessels seem to have developed from the bisected conch shells used for the same purpose, which are also in the show.
Lions are a frequent subject, especially impressive in a simple cast silver lion's head with staring eyes of lapis and shell. Also intriguing is a small, bedraggled copper relief that shows two striding beasts facing in opposite directions, as they would nearly 2,000 years later in the stone reliefs of Assyrian art. That lions were both a symbol of power and a real threat is apparent again in the cylinder seals, where they are repeatedly shown attacking domestic animals.
One of the less expected pleasures here is the plentiful jewelry. In addition to suggesting that beautification of the human form is among the most ancient impulses, it also reflects a continually evolving ingenuity and technology. In jewelry the Sumerians made extensive use of three materials, all imported: red carnelian, blue lapis lazuli and gold.
This triumvirate -- a mineral version of the primary colors -- recurs in different ratios, combinations and motifs and in beads and other elements of varying shape and size. It is a leitmotif that grows surely and irresistibly into a major theme of the exhibition.
"Treasures From the Royal Tombs of Ur" remains at the Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street, Manhattan, (212) 685-0008, through Sept. 10. It will travel to the Oriental Institute Museum in Chicago in October and to the Detroit Institute of Arts in February.

HEADLINE: Economy Continues Hot Growth, at 5.4% Rate in First Quarter

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 25

 BODY:
The nation's economy grew at a 5.4 percent annual rate in the first quarter of this year, led by rising exports and business investment along with the fastest consumer spending pace in 15 years, the government reported today.
Gross domestic product expanded in the first quarter at the same rate that the Commerce Department first estimated a month ago, making it the third consecutive quarter in which growth was faster than 5 percent. In the fourth quarter of 1999, G.D.P. rose at a 7.3 percent annual pace. 
 In a separate report today, figures from the National Association of Realtors showed that home resales decreased in April after rising a month earlier to the highest level in seven months, offering little evidence that higher borrowing costs are cooling the economy. Though resales fell 6.2 percent last month, to an annual rate of 4.88 million, that followed a 9.2 percent gain in March that had been reported a month earlier as a 1.5 percent increase.
"It looks like there is a lot of momentum," said Carl Tannenbaum, chief United States economist for ABN Amro North America in Chicago. The strength in house sales means "solid spending for the next few months as people furnish their homes," he said.
The level of home sales in March was the highest since the 5.3 million annual rate in August, and sales for the first four months of 2000 averaged 4.8 million houses -- just below the record of 5.2 million set last year. That is likely to bolster purchases of furniture, appliances and other household goods.
All this momentum could prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates again. The Fed officials have raised the overnight bank lending rate six times since last June in an attempt to slow the economy and keep inflation from accelerating. Last week, the Fed's policy-setting committee raised the overnight bank rate half a percentage point, to 6.5 percent -- the highest in nine years -- and signaled that further increases were possible.
Job growth shows little sign of cooling, with unemployment at a 30-year low of 3.9 percent. First-time claims for state unemployment benefits rose 6,000, to 284,000, last week, the Labor Department said today. That followed a drop of 20,000 the week earlier and left the average for claims this year at 278,000, down from an average of 298,000 last year.
The G.D.P. report showed that consumer spending rose at a 7.5 percent annual rate. Though that is slower than the 8.3 percent gain that was first estimated, it is still the fastest since the third quarter of 1985, when spending also rose at a 7.5 percent rate.
Exports rose at a 5.5 percent rate in the first quarter after the previous estimate showed a drop of 0.2 percent. Net exports, which include the effect of imports, subtracted 1.1 percent from G.D.P. compared with a 1.3 percent reduction in the first estimate.
The government releases three estimates of each quarter's gross domestic product as more information becomes available to its analysts. The final estimate will be released June 29.
The G.D.P. deflator, a broad measure of inflation tied to the report, rose at a 2.7 percent annual rate in the first quarter, the same as previously estimated and faster than the 1.9 percent rate of the fourth quarter.

HEADLINE: Applying RICO To Civil Cases

 BODY:
The lawsuit filed by the California Medical Association is an effort to apply the civil provisions of the federal Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, or RICO. The statute is best known for its use in criminal cases in which the government charges that groups like organized crime or gangs have engaged in a pattern of conspiratorial activity to further their crimes. 
 In civil lawsuits, plaintiffs like the doctors' group use the civil provisions of the RICO statute to contend that they have been economically harmed through a pattern of misconduct. If successful under a RICO claim, they can win up to three times the amount of damages that they would in a traditional lawsuit.

HEADLINE: Mrs. Clinton, in Rochester, Takes On Queries on Motive

BYLINE: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD 

 BODY:
Hillary Rodham Clinton used a town hall forum in Rochester yesterday in part to answer what she acknowledged were continuing concerns about her ambitions and motives in running for a Senate seat representing a state where she had never lived until five months ago.
Would she serve a full six-year term? 
 "I am committed," Mrs. Clinton said, "because I think it would take a good six years to be able to accomplish issues that I care about. Doing what I would like to see us do to get the pieces in place for a good economic strategy, you can't do that in a year or two or three."
Will she live in New York even if she loses?
"Absolutely."
When told by a participant that "many of your potential colleagues in the U.S. Senate knew you as a polarizing personality; that scares me," Mrs. Clinton rattled off a list of issues on which she has worked with the Republican leadership. And she drew titters with an end point, "After what I've been through for the last seven years nothing they can say can possibly hurt my feelings."
Mrs. Clinton has addressed some of those concerns before, particularly on her residency and ambitions, but they have been freshly raised by her new opponent, Representative Rick A. Lazio, a Long Island Republican who announced his candidacy on Saturday after Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani dropped out.
Mrs. Clinton took questions for about an hour and a half from 85 people participating by e-mail, by fax and in a studio for a "Voice of the Voter" program sponsored by WXXI Public Broadcasting, WOKR-TV and the Rochester Democrat & Chronicle. The program was broadcast live on radio and the Internet and was to be shown last night on television in an upstate region where the two candidates are vying for critical votes.
Mrs. Clinton appeared on the program after a Manhattan news conference to accept the endorsement of the National Abortion and Reproductive Rights Action League. Mr. Lazio scoffed at the endorsement, saying he too is "pro-choice." But he has drawn criticism from abortion rights advocates for opposing public financing for abortions and a late-term procedure critics call "partial birth abortion," a stance he says is more in line with "mainstream New Yorkers."
Many questions, however, focused as much on style as on substance. Mrs. Clinton appeared poised in response to questions about her personality and ambitions, issues Republicans cite as faults. She sounded surprised only when she was asked "if you were to die tonight do you know if you would spend eternity in heaven or hell, and if you don't know would you allow me to tell you how you could know?"
Mrs. Clinton seemed to wrestle with a response. She started by saying "I greatly respect the question" and ended with "I also do not believe that we should be, in public, putting people in a position of responding to questions that are really focused on ones of personal faith."
In between she said, "I hope that I will be someone who will live a life that is worthy of my strong Methodism and my Christian faith and my commitment to doing the very best I can to keep the example of our Lord and savior. But I cannot tell you where I will be. I can only hope and pray that I will find favor in God's eyes."
Mr. Lazio only came up once directly, when a questioner inquired about the linking by her supporters of Mr. Lazio to former House Speaker Newt Gingrich. Mr. Lazio supported much of Mr. Gingrich's so-called Contract With America, the 1994 agenda of conservative policies that Republicans used to regain control of the House.
"I cannot speak for all my supporters because certainly the facts are that he was closely allied" with Mr. Gingrich during those years, she said. "I think New Yorkers need to know that."
And, responding to a question on whether she would favor local issues as Alfonse D'Amato initially did or national ones, like Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Mrs. Clinton stayed in the middle. "I would hope to do both," she said.

HEADLINE: Bush Unties the Social Compact

BYLINE: By Alan S. Blinder; Alan S. Blinder, a professor of economics at Princeton and visiting fellow at the Brookings Institution, is an adviser to the Gore campaign.

 BODY:
George W. Bush is advocating radical change in Social Security, which he himself calls "the single most successful government program in American history." He would take a part of the payroll tax that now flows to the Social Security trust fund and divert it to personal savings accounts.
But doing so would seriously undermine the finances of the present Social Security system. It would subject Americans, especially financially unsophisticated ones, to large additional risks. And it would abandon the noble commitment to social insurance that this country made in 1935. 
 While Social Security is a great success, its current large surplus masks a serious long-term financing problem. Simply put, we have promised far more in future benefits than future payroll tax receipts are likely to finance -- about 14 percent more on average over the next 75 years, according to the Social Security trustees' estimates. This is a huge hole that must be filled by some combination of raising payroll taxes, cutting benefits and infusing general revenue into the trust fund.
With the system in need of more revenue, not less, diverting part of the payroll tax into private accounts, as Mr. Bush proposes, appears irresponsible, unless, of course, you make up the difference by cutting benefits. Without such cuts, privatization would dig the financing hole even deeper, which is why thoughtful privatization proposals generally include significant tax increases to make good on promises that have already been made. But Mr. Bush has not proposed any. This is no minor omission. Diverting 2 percentage points of the payroll tax into individual accounts would drain trillions of dollars from Social Security over the next quarter-century.
And that's just the beginning.
The Bush plan not only would imperil Social Security's finances, but would add new elements of cost and risk to the retirement security of millions of Americans. Privatization is superficially attractive for two main reasons: the higher returns that can presumably be earned, say, in the stock market, and the virtues of individual choice. That's all well and good for financially sophisticated Americans, who happen (by no coincidence) also to enjoy every other advantage in our society, and who, by the way, do not rely heavily on Social Security for their retirement income. But what about the less fortunate citizens, the ones who will need to live on their Social Security checks but who may not know the difference between a stock and a bond?
Is freedom of choice such a blessing for them? Will they understand the risks to which they may be exposed? When funds are invested in stocks and held to retirement, the accumulated balance at retirement is as volatile as the stock market, which not so infrequently moves up or down by 50 percent or more within a few years.
It is a cruel illusion to pretend that small individual accounts will enjoy the full returns that people see in the stock market. There are commissions and, even more important, management fees that can easily exceed 1 percent of assets per year. Then, when they retire, people will discover that buying an individual (as opposed to a group) annuity eats up another chunk of the money, whereas Social Security offers annuities automatically and at zero cost. Furthermore, Social Security's annuities are protected from inflation, whereas private ones are not.
Finally, let's remember the central idea behind the Social Security system: to provide social insurance. Both words matter. High-wage earners like me would undoubtedly be better off under the Bush proposal, and even better off under full privatization. After all, universal social insurance forces us to remain in the same pool with, and partially subsidize, those who are less fortunate. Social Security's benefit formula offers a better rate of return to lower-wage individuals.
From a self-interested point of view, that's a bad deal for us high-income people. Were Vanguard or Fidelity to offer me a mutual fund like that, I wouldn't buy any. But people like me cannot opt out of Social Security, and frankly, I don't want to. Universal social insurance is one of those precious ties that bind our society together. Privatization, whether partial or total, would weaken that tie. 
http://www.nytimes.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: As Protests Grow Violent, Peru Says Runoff Will Go On

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, May 25

 BODY:
The government of President Alberto K. Fujimori said today that a runoff presidential election would be held on Sunday as scheduled despite nationwide protests and calls from Washington and other allies that it be postponed to ensure a clean ballot count.
The decision appeared to increase the possibility of economic sanctions against Peru after it ignored the recommendations of the Clinton administration, the Organization of American States and several European and Latin American governments. 
 Within minutes of the announcement, violent clashes that had left several people injured earlier in the day resumed, with protesters setting fire to a balcony of the presidential palace and hurling stones at the building and at the police, who responded with tear gas.
The electoral crisis had been gathering momentum since Alejandro Toledo, the opposition candidate, dropped out of the race last Thursday, saying he would not compete in a fraudulent election. He had said he would rejoin the contest only if it were postponed by several weeks, with guarantees for a free vote.
Upon hearing today's decision, Mr. Toledo said, "This will bring Peru enormous instability, with totally unpredictable political and economic consequences."
During intense negotiations all week, United States and Latin American diplomats had urged Peruvian officials to delay the election so a computer system used to count votes could be overhauled and rechecked by independent auditors.
A brief announcement that the National Elections Commission had voted, 3 to 2, to go forward with the runoff was met with shock by international observers who had become increasingly hopeful that President Fujimori had decided to give in to international pressure.
"We are quite disappointed," said Eduardo Stein, head of an election observer team for the Organization of American States, "because other options were being intensively considered." He added, "It's been a terrible week."
A senior United States Embassy official said: "The U.S. government deeply regrets this outcome. Even a relatively brief delay would have put the Organization of American States in a position to speak to the integrity of the election results."
President Fujimori had appeared to be going back and forth on the election scheduling during the past three days, but Western diplomats said that mounting protests had perhaps strengthened the hand of hard-liners in the government.
Just Wednesday night, Mr. Fujimori had said in an interview in the government palace: "The possibility for an adjustment of the election date exists. We are in a fluctuating situation." It was one of several signs that Mr. Fujimori and his aides were satisfied that they could win the election at a later date and avert a crisis in its foreign relations.
"It was a close call," Francisco Tudela, Mr. Fujimori's vice presidential running mate, said of the decision in an interview tonight. The electoral commission "could not escape the Constitution and the elections law." Under the law, he said, the election could not be held more than 30 days after results of the first-round presidential vote were announced.
A wave of strikes and street demonstrations that followed Mr. Toledo's withdrawal from the race last week grew increasingly violent today.
A small group of protesters attacked the offices of the National Elections Commission, the highest government body that supervises the elections, and broke windows and damaged a door with rocks, pipes and at least one gasoline bomb. Scores of people were arrested in the northern jungle city of Iquitos for blocking roads, and the police used tear gas to clear protesters gathering in front of the government palace here in the capital.
Truck drivers and teachers staged a strike in the Andean city of Cuzco, a Toledo stronghold. Bands of university students in Lima and Arequipa repeatedly attacked riot police officers with stones, and the police counterattacked with tear gas through much of the day.
A growing number of influential businessmen had warned that holding the uncontested election on Sunday could mean years of economic sanctions and tensions with Washington that could impede investment and growth. Their arguments were strengthened through the week as Peruvian bond and stock prices dropped sharply and foreign financial institutions issued risk warnings that threatened to increase interest rates.
In recent days, the government's policies on the campaign and political process have been inconsistent. Several television stations allied with the government had begun showing Toledo commercials and coverage of his rallies, while tabloid newspapers thought to be directed by Mr. Fujimori's intelligence service had softened their negative coverage of Mr. Toledo's personal life.
Nevertheless, on Wednesday night, three unidentified men broke into the offices of an opposition journalist who was said to hold incriminating videotapes of Vladimiro Montesinos, Mr. Fujimori's intelligence chief, meeting with election officials. The journalist, Fabian Salazar, said the burglars tied him up and tortured him as they demanded that he reveal the sources within the intelligence service who gave him copies of the tapes, which apparently were made by Mr. Montesinos himself.
Mr. Salazar said the intruders cut his left wrist to the bone with a saw during their questioning. He was hospitalized, and his videotapes, archives and computer disks were stolen. Human rights activists said Mr. Salazar's descriptions of his ordeal, which were verified by doctors, may represent the worst example of torture in Peru in at least two years.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
In Far West 50's, Project Will Bring New Rentals

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
A pair of mixed-income rental buildings that will offer a total of 222 apartments will soon rise on 10th Avenue between 54th and 55th Streets in the Clinton section of Manhattan, bringing new housing to the far West 50's for the first time in a decade.
The $60 million development, called the Foundry, will have studio, one- and two-bedroom units, with 460 to 1,183 square feet, spread between the two buildings. A 12-story structure with 164 units and 13,500 square feet of ground-floor commercial space will rise at 505 West 54th Street at 10th Avenue, and a six-story building with 58 units will go up at 510 West 55th Street. 
 They replace a parking lot and a taxi garage respectively that once stood on the sites, which are in the Clinton urban renewal area, extending from West 50th to 54th Street and from 10th to 11th Avenue.
Each of the Foundry buildings, which are separated by a five-story co-op at the southwest corner of West 55th Street, will have its own lobby and entrance. Eighty percent of the units will be leased at market rents. The remaining 20 percent will be rented to people with annual incomes of $19,650 to $37,100, depending on family size. The project is being developed by the Gotham Organization of Manhattan, which bought the sites in December from New York City's Department of Housing Preservation and Development for $8 million.
"The neighborhood has the potential to be the next TriBeCa," said David L. Picket, Gotham's president.
In exchange for setting aside the units for lower-income residents, the city provided tax-exempt bond financing to the developer, which is also eligible for a 20-year tax abatement from the city. Gotham also secured a letter of credit from Key Bank and is investing some equity into the project, which is to be completed in the summer of 2001.
The Foundry underscores renewed developer interest in the neighborhood, where the gentrification of the mid-1980's was cut short when that building boom deflated and the economy faltered. There were also concerns from community groups over displacement of residential and commercial tenants in the urban renewal area. Five of the original 12 parcels were developed from 1969 through 1981 into 1,396 mostly low-income housing units, plus Park West High School, according to the city's housing agency.
But now, with the economy strong, the 42nd Street redevelopment drawing attention to the whole West Side, and commercial tenants venturing into former industrial areas on 10th and 11th Avenues, "the flow of housing can expand farther west," said Brian Edwards, leasing director at the Halstead Property Company, a residential brokerage in Manhattan.
"Offices were the wild card," added Nancy Packes, president of Feathered Nest, a Manhattan rental brokerage and the leasing agent for the Foundry. Younger people who work in the dot-com and Internet businesses moving into the area "also like the older Midtown neighborhoods," she said.
There is a spate of residential projects planned in the West 50's, mainly on or off Eighth and Ninth Avenues, industry professionals said. "And we expect more pressure to rezone along 10th Avenue," said Katherine Gray, chairwoman of Community Board 4, which guides growth in the neighborhood.
In the Clinton urban renewal area, up to 700 new and renovated mixed-income residences could be developed on the five remaining city-owned sites. The understanding is, Ms. Gray said, that those sites will be developed with a larger percentage of apartments subject to income limits than is the case with the Foundry.
But the Foundry is the first project to go into construction west of Ninth Avenue in the West 50's. The Gotham Organization, however, built the New Gotham, a 375-unit mixed-income rental building at 520 West 43rd Street between Ninth and Tenth Avenues -- relatively untested terrain when the project was completed three years ago. Now there are other residential buildings under way or planned in the far West 40's.
The Gotham Organization was selected to develop the two Clinton urban renewal sites because of its work at the New Gotham and "its responsiveness to community concerns over the impact on the existing corner structure and the design of the new buildings," said Christopher J. Cirillo, director of large-scale development for the housing agency.
The scale as well as the exteriors of the Foundry buildings, which will be clad in red brick and feature oversized windows, will blend with their low-rise neighbors. Most of the apartments at the Foundry will be one-bedrooms and be marketed to the young professionals who work in the area, Mr. Picket, Gotham's president, said. To appeal to those tenants and distinguish the Foundry from its competition, he said, he would do there what worked at the New Gotham -- offer lobbies and common areas with innovative designs.
Joel Sanders, a Manhattan architect who is also the director of the Parsons School of Design Graduate Program, has given the lobbies an urban pastoral design. The lobby of the taller building, for example, will feature a suspended concrete floor with openings to view a rock garden below as well as concrete furniture that seems to grow from the floor.
Amenities planned for the buildings include a landscaped terrace and laundry room. The taller building will also house an exercise room and parking for up to 60 cars.
Mr. Edwards, the Halstead leasing director, said rents in the area averaged $41 to $43 a square foot a year, or $2,000 to $2,150 a month for a 600-square-foot one-bedroom apartment.
Rents at the Foundry, where leasing will begin in March, have not been set. But Mr. Picket said that if rented today, they would lease at $45 to $47 a square foot a year, roughly $2,500 to $2,900 a month, comparable to the rents at the New Gotham.

LENGTH: 1055 words

HEADLINE: Hong Kong Faces Loss Of Luster to Mainland

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, May 25

 BODY:
For a city that has prospered as an intermediary between the Chinese economy and the outside world, Hong Kong has lobbied hard to help China win full membership in the world's club of trading nations.
Now that the United States House of Representatives has voted to give China permanent normal trade status -- bringing normalized trade relations closer and easing China's accession to the World Trade Organization -- Hong Kong has to begin facing the consequences of its successful campaign. 
 A China more open to commerce with the outside world, many experts say, will jeopardize Hong Kong's historic role as a trading post.
"There's no question that companies are going to do business directly with China," said Robert C. Broadfoot, the managing director of the Political and Economic Risk Consultancy here. "It's not a question of if, but when, you're going to have shocks to Hong Kong's role."
Mr. Broadfoot contends that in the long run Hong Kong will benefit from China's integration into the global economy as the overall volume of China-related trade grows.
But in the short term, China's march into the World Trade Organization will pose a thorny challenge. As a former British colony and now a semiautonomous region of China, Hong Kong is a separate trading entity that already has its own membership in the W.T.O.
Hong Kong's stock market reflected this ambivalence, falling slightly today while shares in the mainland Chinese cities of Shanghai and Shenzhen roared ahead.
In 1998, more than $52 billion worth of goods passed through Hong Kong's port bound for mainland destinations. Mr. Broadfoot estimates that a third of that traffic will disappear after the United States and other countries start shipping directly to mainland ports.
Likewise in air travel, Hong Kong could lose its role as a gateway to China. As part of the W.T.O. negotiations last year between the United States and China, Beijing agreed to increase the frequency of commercial flights, which would enable more American cities to have more direct flights to mainland Chinese cities.
That could hurt Dragonair, a Hong Kong carrier that serves many mainland cities. It stands to lose Western passengers who fly to Hong Kong and transfer to planes to popular Chinese destinations like Xian or Guilin.
Hong Kong's position is further threatened by Taiwan, whose new President, Chen Shui-bian, has signaled that he is open to negotiating direct trade links with China. In 1998, Hong Kong's container port handled nearly $10 billion worth of Taiwanese exports bound for China. If Taiwan and China were to break down these barriers, some of that trade would also bypass Hong Kong.
"Once China gets into the W.T.O., Taiwan would presumably get into the W.T.O. soon as well," said Eden Woon, director of the Hong Kong General Chamber of Commerce. "That means that Taiwan would have to deal more directly with China."
With all the troubling implications, why did Mr. Woon and other Hong Kong officials push so energetically for the House to pass the bill?
Part of the reason is political. Beijing has made entry into the trade organization the centerpiece of its economic agenda. In Hong Kong, where politicians and business leaders try to outdo each other to be seen as loyal to the motherland, supporting the trade campaign was a natural.
Even Martin Lee, Hong Kong's most prominent pro-democracy leader, traveled to Washington to lobby for the bill. Mr. Lee, a longtime critic of Beijing, said his motives were political rather than economic.
"I went to support the 1.2 billion people of China, not the Chinese government," Mr. Lee said. "I see in this bill a reasonable possibility that China will change its culture toward observing the rule of law."
Other supporters argue that Hong Kong can retain its middleman role -- with a few tweaks -- as a provider of services to the next generation of foreign companies that try to get into China. Hong Kong, with its legions of lawyers, accountants and consultants, is quite likely to remain a valuable guide for those companies.
"In order to handle all this trade, China will have to have a very well-developed service sector," said Victor K. Fung, the chairman of the Hong Kong Trade Development Council and the owner of a trading firm. "In the short run, it will be very difficult for China to ramp up those services."
But some more old-line Hong Kong industries will have to redefine themselves. With the United States set to lift import quotas on Chinese textiles and textile products by 2005, Mr. Woon predicted that many Hong Kong clothing makers would move their factories to the mainland to take advantage of lower production costs. Hong Kong, he suggested, could recast itself as a center for Asian fashion design, rather than a manufacturing center.
China's entry into the trade organization is also quite likely to deprive Hong Kong of its thriving gray market in goods like oil, cigarettes and agricultural products. Those are smuggled from mainland China by the truckload and exported from Hong Kong so that they will be subject to lower tariffs.
Despite its expected negative effects on some Hong Kong industries, China's trade campaign has made people here recognize that their economic fortunes are inextricably tied to the mainland. It seemed no coincidence that last week Hong Kong announced a $12 billion expansion of its rail system, including a direct link between central Hong Kong and Shenzhen.
Hong Kong's government estimates that China's joining the W.T.O. would add more than 5 percent to the territory's gross domestic product over the next decade. It also predicts that investment by Hong Kong companies in China will explode. Local companies have already poured in a cumulative $156 billion.
Because Hong Kong and China would retain separate memberships in the World Trade Organization, officials said Hong Kong would not necessarily gain access to Chinese markets earlier than other countries. But business people here are lobbying for special treatment. Even without it, officials say, Hong Kong will flourish.
"We do not mind if multinational companies go directly to China," the government's chief spokesman, Stephen Lam, said. "As long as the pie gets bigger, even if we get a smaller piece, it will still be more than enough for us."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Justice Department Clears AT&T Deal for MediaOne
The Justice Department approved AT&T's proposed $58 billion acquisition of the MediaOne Group, giving the telephone giant control over more than a third of the nation's cable network for television, high-speed Internet access and online telephone service.
The decision requires the companies to sell their interest in Road Runner, the nation's second-largest cable Internet service. The companies now await a decision by the Federal Communications Commission, which is considering requests by competitors and consumer groups to force the sale of more assets. Page A1. 

Shares of UAL and US Airways Fall
The European Commission said that it would probably have to take a close look at the competitive aspects of United Airlines' proposed $4.3 billion takeover of US Airways. And investors focused on the challenges facing the deal, sending shares of both companies lower. US Airways slumped $4, to $45, while UAL, United's parent, fell 37.5 cents, to $52.50. C2.
 
Floor Plans With Internet Access
For a growing number of home buyers, high-speed Internet connections are becoming as important as a two-car garage or fireplace, prompting some developers to jump into the telecommunications business. A1.
 
Shares in African Diamond Company
An African diamond company plans to sell shares on the London Stock Exchange, offering investors a stake in a venture that includes as partners the embattled governments of Congo and Zimbabwe. C2.
 
Stocks Fall, Led Lower by Goldman
Stocks slumped, led lower by financial shares after Goldman Sachs told analysts that its second-quarter profit would fall short of expectations. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 211.43 points, or 2 percent, to 10,323.92. The Nasdaq composite index fell 65.26 points, or 2 percent, to 3,205.35, erasing an earlier gain of 2.9 percent. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 17.53 points, or 1.3 percent, to 1,381.52. C7.
 
Japan to Correct Economic Data
The Japanese government said it would correct its deliberate omission of data made in a report on economic growth. The new figures will show a 1.6 percent decline in gross domestic product for the October-to-December period, rather than 1.43 percent. C4.
 
Credit Card Duel at Senate Hearing
Credit card company executives clashed at a Senate hearing over an antitrust lawsuit accusing Visa and MasterCard of restricting competition by barring member banks from also issuing American Express or Discover cards. Visa and MasterCard "operate a closed, self-serving, self-perpetuating system," said Harvey Golub, the chairman of American Express. MasterCard's chief counsel fired back: "If American Express gets its way, neither competition nor the consumer wins." C2.
 
$8 Billion Sold in TV Advertising
Even after a season that saw ratings declines for most programs, executives from the six broadcast networks said they pulled in record amounts of money from advertisers in the upfront sales market, racking up a total advertising take of $8 billion. Advertising. C6.
 
Time Warner and Disney Finish Deal
Time Warner and Walt Disney completed a deal that allows the cable company to continue carrying ABC stations for six years. C6.

HEADLINE: How the Hard-Driving G.O.P. Gave Clinton a Trade Victory

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 25

 BODY:
When Representative Tom DeLay came to work on Wednesday, he was still a vote or two shy of the bare-minimum 150 Republicans he needed to help push the China trade bill over the top.
Mr. DeLay, the Republican whip, had lined up lots of help. Gov. George W. Bush of Texas was recruited to cajole several wavering Republicans. So was Gen. Colin L. Powell. Dozens of pro-trade lobbyists and corporate chieftains fanned out on Capitol Hill to buttonhole the last dozen or so undeclared members for what both camps predicted would be a nail-biter. 
 Over the next crucial hours, those calls and an array of other influences paid off, as virtually every undeclared Republican, and even a few others who had been written off, broke Mr. DeLay's way. In all, 164 Republicans joined 73 Democrats voted to grant China permanent normal trading status, wiping out economic restrictions rooted in cold-war policy for a quarter century.
"Frankly, they surprised me a little bit," said Mr. DeLay, whose bare-knuckle approach to head-counting has earned him the nickname the Hammer. "Members in the last few hours really turned around and understood how important this was," he added.
The bill now goes to the Senate, where critics are already preparing amendments that could upset the delicately crafted measure.
Normalizing trade with China was a victory for the Clinton administration, but House Republicans had their own reasons for voting three-to-one in favor of the bill. Passage insured that Republicans' corporate benefactors would fully benefit from a market-opening accord Washington and Beijing negotiated that slashes Chinese tariffs on a wide range of farm and industrial products and removes some barriers to American service providers, like banks and telecommunications companies.
The House Republican leadership closed ranks behind the bill, arguing passionately that economic engagement would foster political change. But they needed to produce two-thirds of the yes votes, and had a tough sell with many Republicans who balked at rewarding a trade plum to a Communist government with a record of religious persecution and political repression.
"There was nothing simple about this," said Bob Schaffer of Colorado, one of the last conservative House Republicans to climb down off the fence in favor. "The 51 percent of this bill that's good only barely outweighs the 49 percent that is truly deplorable."
Republican leaders said a number of factors helped sway undeclared members in the final days and hours to provide the unexpectedly large margin of victory. An amendment creating a commission to monitor human rights in China won half a dozen Republicans and many more Democrats.
Republicans lined up Chinese dissidents who said that the bill would improve the rights of religious minorities, arguing that persecution cannot survive the advent of the Internet. Representative David Dreier of California, a chief Republican supporter, enlisted the evangelist Billy Graham to endorse the measure.
Two dozen Republicans with national security concerns were steered to General Powell or Representative Porter Goss, a Florida Republican who heads the House Intelligence Committee. "I told them, the more open a society the better opportunity we have of getting results," said Mr. Goss.
Many members cited increased trade and national security benefits as reasons to vote yes. These broader merits, combined with the home-district considerations, collectively sealed the decisions of many borderline supporters.
"The key factor for me was that this was the last best hope to save family farms in middle and eastern Tennessee," said Representative Van Hilleary of Tennessee, who said Europe's agreement with China last week on Beijing's entry into the World Trade Organization also convinced him that American jobs were at stake.
Finally, a few members who were leaning toward voting yes needed a touch of outside help to reach their decision. Governor Bush, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, spoke to a handful of Republicans, including Ernie Fletcher of Kentucky, who was impressed by Mr. Bush's commitment to improving human rights in China.
Christopher Cox, a California Republican and outspoken critic of China, endorsed the measure after provisions in the human rights commission were strengthened. Elton Gallegly, a California Republican, said backing the bill was easier after he spoke to Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman about keeping a ban an Argentine oranges, which could introduce a citrus-killing insect into southern California orchards.
Representative Spencer Bachus, an Alabama Republican with steel mills in his district, voted in favor after Republican leaders agreed to amend a spending bill to address his concerns about imported coke, which is used in steel-processing. "We're always sensitive to our members needs," said Susan B. Hirschmann, Mr. DeLay's chief of staff.
By the roll call, all but a handful of the 15 or so Republicans who started the day on the leaders' lists as undecided voted yes.
"I've been counting votes for a long, long time and never in my life have I seen that many undecideds break in favor of a position," said Nick Calio, a bill supporter who was President Bush's top lobbyist on Capitol Hill.
Labor leaders said they had been outgunned. "The business community unleashed an unprecedented campaign that was hard for anyone to match," said George Becker, president of the United Steel Workers of America.
The China bill's 40-vote margin of victory in the House, 237 to 197, would seem to give it unstoppable momentum as the legislation now moves to the Senate for consideration, probably next month. Passage in the Senate, which is usually considered more pro-trade and internationalist, had appeared more certain.
But lurking in the Senate are critics like Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican who heads the Foreign Relations Committee. Mr. Helms, a fierce foe of the Beijing government, said after the House vote that he would not allow the Senate "to simply rubber-stamp the President's plan to reward the Chinese Communists."
Opponents do not have the votes in the Senate to kill the House bill, but amending it -- open to any Senator -- would force House and Senate negotiators to hammer out a compromise of the competing chambers' bills. The House would then have to cast a second vote on the revised bill.
Supporters vowed today to push for speedy Senate passage of a clean House bill.
"There will be efforts to derail this by using amendments and other parliamentary means," said Senator Chuck Hagel, a Nebraska Republican who supports the measure. "But we have to keep this moving."
Rushing to the next legislative battleground, Commerce Secretary William Daley, Mr. Clinton's point man on the China bill, marched to the Capitol today to meet with the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, and senior members of the Finance Committee, which has jurisdiction over the bill.
Mr. Lott gave no hint of when the Senate will take up the measure, Mr. Daley said in an interview, and when asked how serious Mr. Helms's veiled threats were, the secretary said, "It's hard to judge how serious anything Chairman Helms does."
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, the senior Democrat on the Finance Committee, said he and panel's chairman, William V. Roth Jr., Republican of Delaware, had no problems with the House bill. "Our job now is to see that the bill stays right on the floor and is passed as it was sent to us," said Mr. Moynihan.

HEADLINE: Are We Happy? Let Us Count the Ways

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"A Happiness Index With a Long Reach" (Arts & Ideas pages, May 20) has a profound implication for the Consumer Price Index. If the C.P.I. is to measure changes in the cost of living, as most analysts think it should, it should incorporate some kind of quality-of-life index. Including an index like Marc Miringoff's social health index or William J. Bennett's cultural index, both of which have shown declines in the last quarter century, would make the cost of living go up faster than the C.P.I. alone. 
 If the C.P.I. is to be an unbiased measure of the cost of living, it must also reflect those aspects of the quality of life that affect consumers.
 
JOEL POPKIN
Washington, May 22, 2000
 
The writer was in charge of the Consumer Price Index at the Bureau of Labor Statistics from 1969 to 1973.

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE REVIEW;
When Ideas Took Shape And Soared

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
SPEAKING at a symposium held at U.C.L.A. in January, the historian Anthony Vidler announced, "All architecture is the result of panic." Panic has broken out with particularly vivid style in "The Triumph of the Baroque," now on view at the National Gallery of Art. A survey of European architecture from 1600 to 1750, the show reveals that buildings, like people, can be overtaken by mass hysteria. For a century and a half, European walls, doors, roofs, windows and entire cities were contorted into quivering, writhing shapes.
Organized by Henry A. Millon of the National Gallery along with Guy Cogeval, Paolo Viti and Marie-Paule Vial, the show documents the histrionics of Baroque architecture with about 100 artifacts, including antique wooden models and period paintings of buildings, gardens and urban vistas. Besides representing a style, the show explores a state of mind. Simultaneously embodying fight and flight, Baroque buildings look eager to escape the very reality they wish to dominate. 
 "The Triumph of the Baroque" can be seen as a sequel to the National Gallery's 1994 exhibition on Renaissance architecture, which also featured large wooden models as its star attractions. In Chapter 1 the models resembled Trojan horses: as expressions of humanism, Renaissance churches and palaces subverted the authority of the feudal institutions they were commissioned to glorify. In Chapter 2 the subversion grows more complex.
Baroque architecture was a theatrical art. Here's how history set the stage: by 1600 all the instruments that would eventually topple absolute authority came into play, but absolutism concentrated ever greater power unto itself. Martin Luther's tracts against the church, published in 1520, were best sellers. They were significant not only because of their content, but because they demonstrated the power of the press as well. Ideas could now be easily circulated. In 1600 Descartes proposed his solution to existence, a philosophical formula that predicated reality on the capacity to doubt. Oh, and by the way, the Earth was no longer the center of the universe.
The word baroque, originally applied to architecture in a pejorative sense, means irregular or misshapen. The show invites us to watch absolutism become literally bent out of shape. The Counter-Reformation granted people the right to question dogma, provided they ultimately submitted to the church. The Baroque style gave architects liberty to pursue infinite formal variations, provided that they ultimately submitted to Classicism. "The Triumph of the Baroque" offers a broad sampling of the results.
The show is organized thematically. Designs from Italy, Germany, France, Britain, Russia and the Netherlands are grouped into sections on ecclesiastical, royal, military and commercial buildings. Besides emphasizing the international reach of the Baroque, this arrangement conveys the extent to which feudal institutions had evolved toward the modern corporate culture. Call it Baroque Inc.: travel specialists for the rich and holy, with an array of services provided by church and state.
The show starts (like Anita Ekberg) with a plunge into the Trevi Fountain in Rome, a stellar tourist attraction that introduces two themes coursing throughout the show: theatricality and psychology. A precisely detailed wood-and-plaster model highlights the fountain's theatrical dimension, for it depicts the palace facade, sans palace, designed by Nicola Salvi for the Trevi's magnificent sculptural tableau.
Since the model does not include water, visitors will have to imagine the Trevi's psychological dimension, or read Eleanor Clark's 1950 book "Rome and a Villa." Clark's chapter on Rome's fountains may well be the finest depiction of the Baroque's emotional atmosphere ever written. "You walk close to your dreams," she begins. "In another minute, people in the crowd will all be naked, or will have fish tails or horses' behinds, like the characters in the fountains. . . . This is the vocabulary of our sleep, and the key image is always water."
The fountains are pieces of urban infrastructure as well as incentives to free association. Fusions of art and technology, they bring the rational and the irrational together at the center of public space. Bernini's Four Rivers fountain in the Piazza Navona, also represented by models and paintings, shows that these waterworks were political emanations as well. The fountain advertised the relocation of the local water supply to the pope's family palace.
It is bizarre to move from this Mediterranean atmosphere toward the gilded dome resembling Chinese bells that crowns St. Isaac's Cathedral in St. Petersburg, but models of Russian Baroque buildings are a highlight of this show. This is one of the first occasions in which the Russian Baroque has been presented in a European context. Mr. Millon says that Russian curators have been besieged in the last decade with requests for material on Constructivist design while models of Baroque buildings have gathered dust.
A model of Smolny Convent in St. Petersburg is the most extraordinary of the Russian treasures. Designed from 1750 to 1756 by Francesco Bartolomeo Rastrelli, architect of the Winter Palace and other St. Petersburg landmarks, the complex is a cross-axial composition with a cathedral at the center, flanked by four smaller chapels. Rastrelli's palette of gold, celestial blue and white, and the repeating bays of his facades will put some viewers in mind of Balanchine's "Ballet Imperial," with its star ballerina, soloists and precisely drilled corps.
An enfilade of royal residences dominates the Baroque show's second-floor galleries. The great palace of Caserta, court of the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies, is the finest example of these.
Designed by Luigi Vantivelli from 1756 to 1769, the project induces a dreamlike state without recourse to water. The gentle incline of Caserta's grand staircase, the use of indirect lighting, the twisted pattern of the coffering within the building's domes induce the sensation of suspended gravity. This is Piranesian space, awesome and relentless. In comparison Versailles resembles a poorly planned suburban mall.
Gothic spires are for the soul, Renaissance domes for the mind, Baroque facades for the senses. But there is no telling where emotion, once aroused, will be directed. The most horrifying object in the show is a model of the Great Kremlin Palace. Designed for Catherine the Great by Vasily Ivanovich Bazhenov in 1769-70, this is a vast dominatrix of a building, encircled by stones that resemble the studs on a sadist's belt.
Psychological manipulation has a tendency to backfire. How long would it take before people began to wonder what kind of sovereign would want to appear in public dressed like a Mistress of Pain? Or what kind of saint would want to recline in ecstasy on an altar, like Bernini's sculpture of St. Teresa? In time the Baroque emphasis on psychology would invite the public to question external authority in all its forms. It would accelerate the modernity it sought to retard.
As Christian Norberg-Schulz remarks in the show's excellent catalog, the Baroque era was a time of choices. People could choose a different faith, a different occupation, or they could quit Europe altogether. It was, that is to say, a time of competition, an era that heralded the rise of the consumer and of the arts dedicated to persuading consumers to make a particular choice.
With Baroque architecture, space itself becomes a consumer product. In a recent conversation Mr. Vidler observed that the distorted forms and urban scale of the Baroque register the anxiety that came with the collapse of the distinct boundaries that once surrounded cities. The erosion of medieval fortifications and the rise of new modes of transportation went far toward undermining the traditional sense of place. Baroque spectacle helped to compensate for the loss.
Mr. Millon is correct to suggest that this show will hold special appeal for a generation now preoccupied with computer morphing. Scrolls; spiral columns; trompe l'oeil ceilings that extend physical architecture into the firmament of heavenly illusion; gilded wave crests; cornices folded and refolded to distraction; facades drawn out horizontally to the vanishing point; arches, saints and topiary endlessly repeated as if produced by a malfunctioning keyboard: such devices easily outstrip most of what I have seen on the monitor screens of today's design studios. And they should give pause to those who think that computer-generated, so-called blob architecture has no place in the old bricks-and-mortar world.
The affinity between the Baroque age and our own, however, goes deeper than the formal complexity common to both. We, too, have a complicated relationship to power. In a sense it is the reverse of the predicament in which church and state found themselves in the 17th century. Modern consumer society is committed to a way of life that is constantly corroding authority and its traditional institutions.
Nowhere is this more evident than in our museums, and in the increasing difficulty with which they seek to maintain a balance between scholarship and entertainment, connoisseurship and popularity. The Bilbao branch of the Guggenheim is merely the most prominent in a vast proliferation of museum buildings designed in part as pilgrimage destinations to lure tourist dollars. As such, they are part of the corporate monoculture that many artists want to resist.
The Guggenheim's serpentine steel skin and the Piranesian Turbine Hall of the new Tate Modern in London are formally quite different, but both are innately Baroque in their appeal to the emotions and in their ambition to set culture apart from commerce. Yet they also stand for the increasing importance of culture in the emerging global economy.
Still, I came away from this show convinced that we need more museums, larger museums, better-financed museums, particularly in the United States. The National Gallery show, sponsored by EduCap Inc., presents only one-fourth of an exhibition originally presented in Turin, Italy. I'm glad I didn't catch it there. The National Gallery's 1994 Renaissance show was truncated, too, and after seeing the complete edition at the Palazzo Grassi in Venice, I found the abbreviated version a thorough letdown.
A Baroque show four times the size might prove daunting for many visitors. But then the point of this style was to overwhelm the viewer. How amazing it would be to feel overwhelmed by it in the nation's capital. The Baroque is everything Americans came here to escape. And where can we go to flee the Baroque contortions of our day?
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: When Bubbles Are Corporate Ferment;
House of Taittinger, A French Demi-Icon, Is Raider's Quarry

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: PARIS, May 25

 BODY:
As Europe's economies and bloated companies streamline, the Continent has become the latest playground for American leveraged-buyout specialists.
The cutthroat tactics of the 1980's, with vulture investors searching the landscape for takeover prey, have fallen somewhat out of fashion in the United States. This phenomenon, it turns out, did not die, but migrated across the Atlantic. 
 In the thick of this trend is one of the brashest and most feared of the old-style raiders, Asher B. Edelman, who is trying to outwit a venerable French family institution, Taittinger, the Champagne maker, luxury-goods producer and top-of-the-line hotel company.
But while corporate raiders used to slash and burn in relatively brief battles, Mr. Edelman is conducting a prolonged siege, having stalked the Taittinger family since 1996.
At one level, the battle has evolved into a clash of personal and corporate styles. Taittinger is represented by its chairman, Claude Taittinger, 72, and his niece Anne-Claire Taittinger, chief executive of the Societe du Louvre, the company that is the main Taittinger asset. They have been scrambling to transform Louvre from a French heirloom into a leaner American-style corporation, and they refuse to deal with Mr. Edelman.
But they face a formidable foe with potent allies, including the New York investor Guy Wyser-Pratte. Through a combination of legal expertise and sharp financial elbows, Mr. Edelman has been transferring the skills he honed in the United States to pursue Louvre. And Mr. Wyser-Pratte has successfully laid siege to another French institution, Groupe Andre, which owns a Champs-Elysees shoe shop, Chaussures Andre, and the Kookai fashion chain.
For Mr. Edelman, giving up seems the furthest thing from his mind. "There's every reason to stay in, and to continue to push for change," he said by phone from New York.
Beyond the clash of French provincial style and American bluntness, larger stakes are in play. As the Andre case showed, old French family companies are under pressure to perform or be taken over. Moreover, the way companies protect themselves is a hot topic of corporate and political debate. Several French companies, like the conglomerate Vivendi and the bank Societe Generale, have recently limited stockholder voting rights, sending minority shareholder groups to the barricades.
Luxury products are hot now, and the Taittinger properties of Societe du Louvre, like the Hotel de Crillon in Paris and the Baccarat crystal works, are thriving. Mr. Edelman thinks that breaking Louvre into separate companies could vastly enhance its value. But the Taittingers say that a loss of family control would weaken the company's image.
Early this month, in a Paris court, Mr. Edelman contested the Taittinger family voting rights in Societe du Louvre. A decision is expected early in June. But even if the court rules against him, Mr. Edelman says he will not give up.
The struggle can be wearing, as each side tries to push on as though the other does not matter. The history of the battle goes like this:
In 1996, Mr. Edelman began buying shares in Taittinger S.A., the holding company that owns the Champagne maker and more than half the voting rights in Societe du Louvre. He also went after Louvre itself, bringing his holdings and those of his allies to about 25 percent. At a stockholders meeting in 1998, Mr. Edelman's group presented a list of 52 questions about the company's inner workings, including delicate matters like whether family members used company apartments rent-free or held fictitious jobs.
Such methods, tastelessly aggressive by Taittinger standards, are part of Mr. Edelman's corporate arsenal. In the 80's, he was feared for his assault on companies like Datapoint, a computer concern he took over after a long and bitter battle. By the early 90's, Mr. Edelman, an avid art collector, retired to Switzerland and opened a gallery. His reputation had become one of lavish living more than of financial acumen. In 1996, his sale of a Jasper Johns painting for $3 million drew attention, as had his sale two years earlier, for $5.8 million, of a 23-room Manhattan apartment overlooking the East River.
But by the mid-90's, he was back at work, running Edelman Value Partners from New York, investing mainly in undervalued French and Swiss stocks.
Despite the sniping, his continuing struggle has had its playful moments. When Claude Taittinger said in an interview that if the Taittingers wanted to paint the Crillon pink, "we can, and Mr. Edelman can't," Mr. Edelman responded by having a can of pink paint delivered to Mr. Taittinger's home.
In this spirited give-and-take, Mr. Edelman has been clear about his motives. He says there is great value to be unlocked in Louvre. He wants to shed nonluxury businesses and focus on the Concorde hotel chain and its flagship, the Crillon, where stars and statesmen congregate; the midprice Envergure hotel chain, and a luxury-goods division centered on a revived Baccarat.
Mr. Edelman makes no secret of wanting to ride the wave of demand for luxury. France remains Europe's, and the world's No. 1 tourist destination, and Societe du Louvre's chief luxury hotels, which also include the Hotel de Louvre in Paris and the Martinez in Cannes, are hot properties. Baccarat he sees as a glass company around which to build a luxury-goods group in the style of Louis Vuitton or Gucci.
"When we first bought in, we thought we would enter into a basic cooperation agreement," he said. "We now see it differently. Whether through a takeover or a proxy fight, in either event we have a plan for three different public companies."
Mr. Wyser-Pratte agrees. Societe du Louvre, he said in a telephone interview, is "highly, highly undervalued," adding, "The value of the assets is two, two and a half times the value of the shares."
But Ms. Taittinger wants no part of a breakup. "We have a very great sense of security," she said in her office paneled in black wood on the edge of Paris. As for Mr. Edelman's continued pressure, she remarked: "It's nothing new. There's no rational explanation for it."
What she wants is to keep Louvre together, to keep focusing on its main businesses. Over the next five years, she wants to double the number of rooms in the Envergure hotels and to spread into markets like Spain, Italy and Eastern Europe.
Ms. Taittinger, a slight, engaging woman of 50, was educated in sociology and urban studies, and says her passion is urban planning. Asked why she joined Louvre in 1979, she hesitated, but an associate who knows her well said, "Duty." In 1997, after running several divisions, including a line of perfumes and Baccarat, she succeeded her father, Jean, then 70, as chief executive.
"A family company must be run like a company," she said, adding that family-owned companies have it harder in France, where envy of wealth is a national sport, than in Germany or Italy.
But the Taittingers are not just any family. Nine Taittingers are listed in "Who's Who in France." Ms. Taittinger's father was mayor of Reims and French minister of justice in the 1970's. Her uncle, Pierre-Christian, was a senator; her brother, Jean-Frantz, is a member of Parliament. Yet business has always been the family's inclination. Ms. Taittinger's son recently dropped out of college to join a dot-com company.
By shedding nonessential businesses like ELM Leblanc, a heating concern, and a controlling share in the private Banque du Louvre, and then sprucing up the perfume and glassware businesses through increased marketing and more closely controlled distribution, Ms. Taittinger raised revenue 10 percent a year, to 677 million euros in 1999, now $617 million. Net profit has risen 52 percent since she took over. Now, Baccarat plans four new stores in the United States, including locations in Los Angeles and Las Vegas.
Some of the changes, she acknowledges, came partly in response to Mr. Edelman's pressure. "I have to thank him for the opportunity," she said.
Mr. Wyser-Pratte accuses her of arrogance. "It's the Marie Antoinette story," he said. "Let them eat cake."
Mr. Edelman, for his part, says the improvements are not enough. Claude Taittinger, he said, now brags that Louvre is "run in the Anglo-Saxon fashion." But he added, "They've been put in a position where they have to run it that way." Even with the changes, he said, the hotel chains and luxury-goods businesses have yet to fully exploit the Internet. The company should sell costly hotel buildings, like the Crillon, he says, and concentrate on hotel management. To bolster his arguments, he commissioned a study by Jones Lang LaSalle, the real estate firm.
"The company is basically un-run," he concluded.
Ms. Taittinger says she does not need the advice. What separates the family from Mr. Edelman, she says, is a question of credibility. "And then," she adds, "there is Datapoint."
Indeed, Datapoint stands out as perhaps the muddiest chapter in Mr. Edelman's career as a turnaround artist. Under Mr. Edelman, Datapoint, once a leading-edge producer of computer networking equipment, collapsed, crushed by losses and a series of irregularities. In 1996, when Mr. Edelman was still registered as holding 20 percent of its voting shares, Datapoint settled a lawsuit over a fraudulent Texas land sale after a jury had ordered Datapoint to pay $63 million in penalties.
Five years earlier, Mr. Edelman agreed to pay almost $437,000 in a settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission, which had accused him of delaying the disclosure of Datapoint stock purchases.
But the past does not interest Mr. Edelman. "If I were to go away," he said of Societe du Louvre, "they would go back to the way they used to run it."
