SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 31; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 3561 words

HEADLINE: ON THE ROAD;
Renaissance on the Schuylkill

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
This is a city on second base, wondering if it can make it all the way home.
The old Philadelphia, which lived on manufacturing and banking and lawyering, ran out of steam a half-century ago. Now the city is betting a billion dollars and more that a new Philadelphia can prosper on history and culture and tourism -- that people will come here not merely for the obligatory visit to the Liberty Bell with the kids but for several days of meetings, music, art, shopping and good food as well. 
 An unmistakable new energy has taken hold in Center City, as the locals call downtown Philadelphia. Without losing its civilized manners, the city has begun to bounce after dark; Walnut Street's sidewalks are still crowded at 10 p.m. A Democrat, Ed Rendell, a husky, dynamic former mayor, gets much of the credit for setting the transformation in motion, but the first big payoff is this year's Republican National Convention, opening here on July 31.
"People at the convention will see signs of a real renaissance in key parts of the city," said Senator Arlen Specter, who served as Philadelphia's district attorney before heading to Washington. "But don't delude yourself: 15 blocks from the center, enormous problems remain."
Philadelphia was, of course, America's original convention city, beginning in 1774 with the Continental Congress, which two years later produced the Declaration of Independence. But no major political party has held its quadrennial powwow in the city since 1948, when no fewer than three of them did so (the Democrats, to choose Harry S. Truman; the Republicans, to nominate Thomas E. Dewey, and the Progressives, to name Henry A. Wallace).
A lot has happened since then, too much of it bad. Philadelphia lost many of its defining institutions, including The Saturday Evening Post, once the nation's leading magazine; The Bulletin, a powerful and venerable evening newspaper; the Pennsylvania Railroad, one of the first great routes to the West; John Wanamaker's department store, a pioneer of mass merchandising; and the Philadelphia Athletics, who made baseball history under Connie Mack. It had a surly white mayor, Frank Rizzo, whose confrontational approach to blacks was typified by the nightstick he once famously tucked into his cummerbund, and a star-crossed black mayor, W. Wilson Goode, who in 1985 dropped a firebomb on the headquarters of a radical group in his own city.
In 1976 an outbreak of a mysterious respiratory disease killed 34 members of the American Legion attending a convention here.
David L. Cohen, a co-chairman of the host committee for the Republican gathering, defined the status quo ante in these words: "People didn't have low expectations of Philadelphia; they had no expectations of Philadelphia." They saw it, he said, as "an old city, falling apart, dirty and unsafe."
A first important step toward recovery was a new convention center, which opened in 1993. Then, in 1996, 548,000 people came to see a Cezanne exhibition at the Museum of Art -- many of them suburbanites who hadn't been downtown in years, many others from New York, Washington and elsewhere.
Local leaders realized that there was big money in culture. Broad Street got a face-lift and a new name, the Avenue of the Arts, and this year steelwork for a new, $245 million Regional Performing Arts Center began rising there. Designed by Rafael Vinoly of New York in emulation of London's 19th-century Crystal Palace, it is scheduled to open in the fall of 2001.
To house the hoped-for throngs of visitors, 5,000 new hotel rooms have been added in the metropolitan area in four years. Two of the splashiest new hotels and several restaurants have taken over old banks; the metaphor is almost too apt.
The much-admired PSFS building (the letters stand for Philadelphia Savings Fund Society, though few remember that) is now a Loews hotel, with all its architectural glories, including a polished black granite base that bends around a corner, miraculously intact. Designed by William Lescaze and George Howe in 1932, it was the first International Style skyscraper built in this country, just at the end of the Art Deco era. Soon the old Girard Trust Company, a little Ionic temple with a perfect dome, designed in dazzlingly white Georgia marble by Stanford White, will be a Ritz-Carlton.
Philadelphia used to concentrate on food that filled big men up fast: cheese steaks, hoagies, soft pretzels, L. D. Bassett's world-class ice cream, scrapple (a Pennsylvania Dutch blend of cornmeal and unmentionable pig parts), sticky buns and pepper pot soup (a potent brew of honeycomb tripe and hot chilies). Most of the traditional fare can still be found at the Reading Terminal Market (often sold there by Amish or Mennonite women in white gauze caps) or at Bookbinders Seafood House on 15th Street or both.
 
Booming (and Shrinking)
But now the city is a playground for foodies, with heroically hip restaurants opening every month. These are no storefront improvisations; by the end of the year, Neil Stein, who started it all with a place called Striped Bass, will have opened five sophisticated spots at a cost of $10 million. "I think it will work," he told me, "if the economy holds up."
Rick Nichols, who has watched the city's travails for years from various posts at The Philadelphia Inquirer, sounded similarly cautious.
"The fate of Philadelphia really hangs in the balance," he said. "Can we live off this culture-dining-service boom, or do we need more lunch-bucket jobs to keep the thing going?"
Look carefully on the side streets downtown, and you will see vacant shops and even a few vacant buildings. The region's retail nexus is not there but out in the suburbs, at King of Prussia, in a megamall where Hermes and Neiman Marcus and other chic merchants court the carriage trade. Jobs have fled the city, too, as companies like CoreStates Financial and Bell Atlantic have closed or shrunk their Philadelphia offices because of mergers.
New stadiums for the Phillies and Eagles are all talk and no action, and the ballyhooed DisneyQuest mall is just another hole in the ground, its financing having collapsed. Mr. Rendell, now the Democratic national chairman, must be devastated; the project had so excited him that he told an English visitor, "To call it virtual reality is to call Michelangelo a house painter." The city will now have to make do with a $300 million Family Entertainment Center at Penn's Landing on the Delaware River, featuring a children's museum, an 18-screen multiplex cinema, restaurants and a wide range of shops. Not exactly the sort of thing that brings the Renaissance to mind.
William P. Hankowsky, Philadelphia's industrial development czar, acknowledged frankly that "you have two contradictory phenomena here at the same time: Center City is booming, with people moving back downtown, while the population as a whole is still in decline." With some exceptions, like Chestnut Hill, the northern, western and southern parts of Philadelphia are worn and worried. Between 1990 and 1998, the city lost 9.4 percent of its population; of the 10 largest cities in the United States, only Detroit and Philadelphia shrank, and Philadelphia shrank more.
Philadelphians tend to undersell Philadelphia. Is it the Quaker heritage of dour understatement? Or the city's position halfway between the nation's political capital, to the south, and its economic and cultural capital, to the north? Could it possibly be an inferiority complex?
"Cheering against the home team is a time-honored tradition in Philadelphia," wrote the social historian E. Digby Baltzell.
Whatever the reason, locals have allowed a Philadelphia-born comedian of minimal talent, W. C. Fields, to fasten a joke to their city like a barnacle. Asked what he wanted on his gravestone, the great man is said to have replied, "On the whole, I'd rather be in Philadelphia." That one-liner has been repeated ad nauseam.
Yet this has always been a richly endowed city, full of distinctive neighborhoods, a center of artistic and intellectual life since the days of Benjamin Franklin and the Peales, much loved by those who live here. The population is less transient than in most large American cities; Philadelphians may flee to the suburbs, but most of them go no farther.
Whether they call it Philadelphia or Philly, a nickname loved by some and loathed by others, whether they are Rocky Balboas (or Frankie Avalons or Vic Damones) from gritty, Italian-American South Philadelphia or Tracy Lords from the wealthy, pastoral Main Line, they are staunch loyalists.
The Philadelphia story started with that redoubtable Quaker, William Penn, who laid out the city's grid in 1682. It was he, not some latter-day adman, who named it the City of Brotherly Love, and he who gave it many of its characteristics: its respect for education (Temple, Villanova, Haverford, Swarthmore, Bryn Mawr and Drexel, as well as the University of Pennsylvania, with its celebrated Wharton School of Business, carry that tradition forward today); its wide streets and its extensive parks, religious tolerance and closely knit families.
As usual, Mark Twain got the picture. In Boston, he said, people ask, "What does he know?" In New York they ask, "How much does he make?" In Philadelphia, the crucial question is, "Who were his parents?"
Some of those families can be frosty, snobby and self-satisfied, their lives consecrated to the First Troop of the Philadelphia City Cavalry, the Merion Cricket Club and the Union League Club (whose brownstone clubhouse bears a plaque celebrating its loyalty to the North in the Civil War). Many live in the western suburbs known as the Main Line because the Pennsylvania railroad connected them on a route running from Philadelphia to Paoli.
Generations of young college students learned a mnemonic aid to help them find their way home: "Old maids never wed and have babies," for Overbrook, Merion, Narberth, Wynnewood, Ardmore, Haverford, Bryn Mawr.
But of course Philadelphia is not all socialites or Quakers or Italian-Americans, and even if the current gamble succeeds, it will not become a tourist target and little else, like Las Vegas or Orlando. Anne d'Harnoncourt, the director of the Museum of Art, New York-bred but devotedly Philadelphian by adoption, calls this "a city full of nooks and niches."
It is not just Rittenhouse Square, the traditional center of patrician Philadelphia, bounded by mismatched buildings that give it visual vigor, used every day by dogs and bums and Frisbee-tossing adolescents and pram-pushing nannies and students from the nearby Curtis Institute of Music, and celebrated for its vitality by no less than Jane Jacobs.
Philadelphia is also the home of an old and eminent black community, which has produced national leaders like A. Leon Higginbotham Jr., who was a towering presence on the Federal appeals bench; former Congressman William Gray, who now heads the United Negro College Fund; and William Coleman, a former transportation secretary. And it is a river town; the Schuylkill (pronounced SKOO-kul) ) is one of the city's delights, especially on days when it is filled with sculls and eight-oared shells from clubs along its bank. Grace Kelly's father and brother, both named Jack, rowed there and won national titles.
 
From Greek Revival to Pop
The tide of the Revolution flowed through and around Philadelphia. Washington crossed the Delaware just north of town, lost to the redcoats at Germantown and spent the severe winter of 1777-78 at Valley Forge. But it is in the Old City, in the blocks south of Walnut Street between Second and Sixth Streets, that the drama of those astounding years comes to life.
Perhaps it is, as its promoters say, "The Most Historic Square Mile in America." Few visitors miss the Liberty Bell or Independence Hall, where both the Declaration and the Constitution, those two extraordinary products of Enlightenment genius, were debated and finally approved. Even the history-averse are stirred, though the fabric of the buildings has been mended as often as an old sock.
Benjamin Franklin was a dominant figure in the life of the city and the young nation, so it seems fitting that he is buried nearby, across the street from the Free Quaker Meeting House. His grave is strewn with coins tossed by tourists mindful of his maxim "A penny saved is a penny earned"; the site of his house is marked by a steel frame devised by Robert Venturi, a "skeleton" of the original, much more evocative than a mere reconstruction.
But many of the red-brick houses where Washington and Madison and the others lived during the decade from 1790 to 1800, when Philadelphia was the nation's capital, still stand on the cobbled streets, shaded by plane trees, south of the Independence National Historic Park. You can sit in the pews where the Founding Fathers sat (Washington used Pew 58) at Christ Church, whose six-sided, 209-foot steeple, built in 1753 and 1754, was the tallest structure in America for more than a century. Influenced by the work of Gibbs and Wren in London, the church is remarkable for its broad expanses of clear glass.
Some idea of the wealth of Philadelphia may be gained from late Georgian mansions like Cliveden (1767), in Germantown, and Mount Pleasant (1762), in Fairmount Park, the nation's largest urban park. Cliveden, seat of the Chew family, still contains chairs and a sofa by Thomas Affleck, one of the greatest Colonial furniture makers. At the end of the 18th century, Philadelphia was the leading American city. Once the government left, it never again enjoyed that eminence.
But it built as if it did. That was the doing mainly of Nicholas Biddle, the city's social, cultural and financial star (and the founder of its most notable dynasty of civic leaders). He returned from a trip to Athens in 1806 with this in his diary: "The two great truths in the world are the Bible and Grecian architecture."
Soon the city was awash in Greek Revival temples, from the Philadelphia Water Works (1819) along the Schuylkill River to Biddle's own magnificent house, Andalusia (1836), high above the east bank of the Delaware, with a grand, six-column-wide portico designed by Thomas U. Walter. The Second Bank of the United States (1819-1824), designed by William Strickland, parts of which literally copied the Parthenon, is the masterpiece of the genre. In this white marble temple, Biddle, the bank's president, fought with Henry Clay against Andrew Jackson for control of the nation's monetary supply, and lost.
 
Monuments and Culture
Ever since Biddle's day, Philadelphia has had a taste for the monumental. A climax of sorts was reached in the exuberant Second Empire City Hall (1872-1901), a hulking, multi-pavilioned mountain of a building topped by a statue of the city's founder, William Penn. The creation of Alexander Milne Calder, Penn stands up there in a broad-brimmed hat, all of 37 feet tall.
Benjamin Franklin Parkway, the city's ceremonial boulevard, is a Calder-to-Calder-to-Calder triple play. Halfway along its length, one comes to Logan Circle, which was modeled after the Place de la Concorde in Paris; the fountain in the center is by A. M.'s son, Alexander Stirling Calder. At the far end of the parkway, at the top of the steps leading up to the Greek Revival facade of the Museum of Art (remember them from "Rocky"?), stands a bold red stabile called "The Eagle," by A. S.'s son, Alexander Calder.
The transitional figure in Philadelphia architecture was Frank Furness, whose taste for the exotic and the eclectic is evident in the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts. His enthusiasm for certain kinds of foliate decoration communicated itself to a young draftsman in his office named Louis Sullivan, who returned to Chicago and became a pioneer modernist.
Philadelphia has had two great latter-day modernists: Louis I. Kahn, whose Richards laboratories at Penn (1960-64) turn the unavoidable technological folderol into crisp design elements, prefiguring the Pompidou Center in Paris, and Mr. Venturi, the father of Pop architecture. For me at least, local buildings by Frank Lloyd Wright (a synagogue in Elkins Park) and Helmut Jahn (the Liberty Place skyscrapers) are less successful.
The Museum of Art and the Philadelphia Orchestra are both ranked among the top five or six institutions of their kind in the nation.
Founded exactly 100 years ago, the orchestra is older. Wolfgang Sawallisch, its current music director, surprised many here by presenting its subscribers with a centennial program composed entirely of 20th-century music, from Scriabin and Poulenc to Lutoslawski and Takemitsu. Many of the pieces had been given their American premieres by the orchestra under Eugene Ormandy and Leopold Stokowski, who introduced Stravinsky's "Rite of Spring" here in 1922. Joseph H. Kluger, the orchestra's president, said that the programs of more-or-less modern music had given a boost to single-ticket sales, brought the average age of audiences down and provided "an idea we plan to build on."
The orchestra has been housed for years in the Academy of Music, a charming, 143-year-old opera house whose acoustics are poor for symphonic music. Soon the orchestra will be the main tenant in the new arts center, and a new conductor is expected to replace Mr. Sawallisch, who is 76, once the move is made. The move is not without controversy; the old academy may be the city's most beloved building, and neither the Pew nor the Annenberg foundations, two of the city's cultural mainstays, contributed to the new center's cost.
Nonetheless, it will confer at least one indisputable benefit on the city by opening more room at the academy for the Philadelphia Opera, which has made considerable progress under Robert B. Driver, and the Pennsylvania Ballet. Their growth has been stunted by a dearth of free dates there.
Across from the academy is the Wilma Theater, designed by Hugh Hardy. Two Czech-born directors, Blanka and Jiri Zizka, present works there by David Gow, Tom Stoppard and many others, in productions that are often controversial but very seldom dull.
 
A Vast Bastion of Art
The vast, honey-colored Museum of Art looks as if it had been there for 700 years, not 70. It will soon get an annex -- an Art Deco building across the street, which will provide 100,000 square feet of additional space. Its holdings are enormous, ranging from period rooms (including one by the great Scottish designer Robert Adam) to impressive arrays of armor and Oriental art. It also continues, in the tradition of the Cezanne show, to mount and aggressively promote special shows, though I must confess that I found the current exhibition of 18th-century Roman art a letdown; for me, it's a struggle to accept Pompeo Batoni as a seminal figure among European painters.
But the museum's permanent painting collections more than make up for that. Its old masters are dominated by the pictures accumulated by John G. Johnson, the prototypical Philadelphia lawyer, who appeared a record 168 times before the Supreme Court. And his pictures (among them arresting works by van Eyck and Giovanni di Paolo) are dominated by the majestic Rogier van der Weyden portrayal of the Crucifixion with the Virgin and St. John the Evangelist.
The austere figures are shown against brilliant red hangings, the Virgin crumpling in grief, Christ's loincloth lifted by some mysterious force. It is the saddest, greatest painting in the museum and one of the greatest in the United States. I have sat before it a dozen times, always mesmerized.
In another part of the building are assembled the brilliant, before-their-time collections of Walter and Louise Arensberg and A. E. Gallatin, notably Miros, Brancusis and Duchamps, including the once-scandalous "Nude Descending a Staircase." At the moment, the modern galleries are being renovated, but that gives visitors a chance to see (and compare) three large-scale masterpieces in one small room: Leger's colorful, mechanistic "City"; Picasso's "Three Musicians," a pivotal example of Synthetic Cubism; and Cezanne's architectonic yet lyrical "Large Bathers."
Of course, the museum also prides itself on its paintings by local artists, and it would be a mistake to miss Thomas Eakins's "Concert Singer." But a greater Eakins painting, "The Gross Clinic," hangs at Thomas Jefferson University, and others are at St. Charles Borromeo Seminary in Overbrook, where the painter sought solace on Sunday afternoons.
Art is, in fact, almost omnipresent in and around Philadelphia. In Merion, the truly fabulous Barnes collection (reserve in advance) mixes rustic ironwork with paintings that people travel thousands of miles to see. The Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts boasts a brilliant American collection, including superb works by Gilbert Stuart, Winslow Homer and all the Peales. The museum at the University of Pennsylvania houses the golden treasures from the ancient Sumerian city of Ur, amid much else. And the Rosenbach Museum and Library contains not only the rare books and manuscripts accumulated by A. S. W. Rosenbach, a scholarly, piratical dealer who helped to build the Folger Library in Washington and the Huntington Library near Los Angeles, but also important antique furniture.

SECTION: Section A; Page 5; Column 1; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 576 words

HEADLINE: Angry Election Monitor Leaves Peru 2 Days Before Runoff Vote

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, May 26

 BODY:
The head of the Organization of American States observation team, saying he had been deceived by Peruvian officials, angrily left Peru today, two days before the presidential runoff election that he was supposed to monitor to guarantee against vote fraud.
"The conditions of the election do not provide a strong basis of legitimacy," said the organization's chief, Eduardo Stein, who has been the senior foreign observer of a process that has been tainted with allegations of dirty tricks and fraud. "I feel deceived and disappointment." 
 Mr. Stein's views will be crucial as his organization and the Clinton administration and the United States Congress consider applying economic sanctions on the government of President Alberto K. Fujimori. In a report released late Thursday, after the government's announcement that it would not postpone the runoff on Sunday, Mr. Stein's team offered a stinging rebuke.
"The Peruvian electoral process is far from one that could be considered free and fair," the observation team said.
The team then ordered its election observers to leave Peru.
Mr. Fujimori's election to a third five-year term was effectively assured when his opponent, Alejandro Toledo, dropped out of the race last week, saying that he was not ready to enter "a butcher shop" of fraud in a fixed election.
But Mr. Stein, with Washington's full backing, tried to mediate a solution between Mr. Toledo and the government in which the election could be postponed to give foreign observers ample time to test computer programs to make sure that the count would be transparent and clean.
Mr. Stein, a former foreign minister of Guatemala, led the international criticism of the first-round balloting, on April 9, saying, "Something sinister is happening here," as ballots and tally sheets disappeared for hours without explanation and votes were counted in undisclosed locations. Mr. Fujimori fell just short of winning an outright majority victory in that round, according to an official tabulation made over three days as the United States and other countries pressed for a runoff.
Since that round, Mr. Stein has been cajoling the government to stop spending public money in the Fujimori campaign and open television networks to covering the opposition. He has had limited success.
In the last few days, Mr. Stein had expressed renewed optimism that an agreement could be worked out, with a new date to be set on June 4 or some weeks later. Negotiations had reached the level where Mr. Fujimori was talking directly by telephone with Cesar Gaviria, head of the Organization of American States and a former president of Colombia, Peruvian officials said.
Mr. Stein said he saw strong indications that the government would postpone the election as late as midday Thursday, before he was shocked by the news in the afternoon that the National Elections Commission voted, 3 to 2, against a postponement. "We were led to believe that there was going to be a favorable outcome," he said.
The decision was met with an increase in violent demonstrations across Peru, including a rock and gasoline bomb attack on the presidential palace by protesters late Thursday.
In a television interview today, Mr. Fujimori brushed aside Mr. Stein's complaints. "Globalization does not mean there can be unlimited intervention in a country's internal affairs," he said. "The software problems have been resolved. There will be no fraud."

HEADLINE: Demand for Big-Ticket Goods Logged Steep Decline in April

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 26

 BODY:
Demand for big-ticket goods in April registered its steepest decline since late 1991, and consumer spending rose at its slowest pace in nine months, the government said today, indicating that the economy may be slowing.
Orders to factories for costly manufactured goods fell an unexpected 6.4 percent last month, to a seasonally adjusted $205.6 billion, pulled down by a record drop in demand for electronics, the Commerce Department said in one of two economic reports it released today. Economists had been expecting a decline of only 0.5 percent. 
 Americans also pulled back slightly in April from their generally free-spending ways, the second report showed.
Consumer spending, which accounts for two-thirds of economic activity and is the engine of the supercharged economy, rose 0.4 percent last month. That was the smallest increase since July.
At the same time, American incomes, a category that includes wages, interest and government benefits, grew by a brisk 0.7 percent, the second month in a row in which income went up faster than spending. The figures on consumer spending and income were in line with forecasts.
Looking at both reports, "we might conclude there is some fraying around the edges of the booming economy -- that the economy is going from white-hot to perhaps simply red-hot," said Mark Zandi, an economist with RFA Dismal Sciences. "We might be seeing the first signs that the broader economy is throttling back a notch."
The Federal Reserve has raised interest rates six times since last June, including an aggressive half-point increase last week, trying to slow the economy and keep inflation from becoming a problem.
The increases are intended to raise borrowing costs and cool demand for big-ticket items like cars and homes.
"Together, the reports provide unambiguous evidence of a slowdown emerging," said Gordon Richards, economist for the National Association of Manufacturers.
The reports, economists said, suggested that the Fed's interest rate increases were beginning to bite. But analysts offered conflicting views as to whether the reports would discourage the Fed from raising rates again in June.
The 6.4 percent decline in orders for durable goods -- items expected to last at least three years -- was the steepest since December 1991 and followed the first increase this year, a 4.5 percent rise in March.
A record 20.1 percent plunge in orders for electronics and electrical equipment, including semiconductors, circuit boards and home appliances, led the April decline.
Even with the big drop in April, total durable-goods orders in the first four months of the year are running 7.6 percent higher than the same period a year earlier, evidence of the economy's strength.
In the other report, the government said the slower growth in spending helped lift the personal savings rate, or savings as a percentage of after-tax income, to 0.7 percent in April, the best showing since January.

HEADLINE: House Vote on China Trade: The Politics Was Local

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 26

 BODY:
The most important foreign policy vote so far this year, the 237-to-197 House approval of the China trade deal, was no new affirmation of internationalism by an often provincial Congress, but a reaffirmation of one of its oldest truths: Members vote their districts.
That is, they vote their districts if their constituents have an interest, and a trade bill is a singular foreign policy measure because the question of jobs gained and lost commands attention from lawmakers and constituents ordinarily not much concerned about the rest of the world. 
 But other foreign policy matters have far smaller constituencies, and are much more subject to Washington's political influences, especially partisanship. To put it meanly, each party plays politics with foreign policy; to put it kindly, each trusts presidents of its own party but discerns grave weaknesses on the other side.
In any case, the "internationalist" Republicans who supported President Bush's Persian Gulf war in 1991 suddenly became "isolationist" Republicans who opposed President Clinton over military action in Somalia (where Mr. Bush actually had sent the troops), as well as in Bosnia and Kosovo. The Democrats, meanwhile, eagerly seized the labels the Republicans had dropped.
There are some members of Congress who take the "internationalist" view on trade, intervention abroad, United Nations financing and comparable issues regardless of party, at least most of the time.
But looking at a dozen key votes dating back to the gulf war, there are only 10 current House members who voted that way all the time. Several are Southern Democrats with no union pressure over trade to worry about. Two are Democrats from Washington State, where union desires to sell Boeing airplanes to China overcome all other trade questions. And one is a moderate Republican, Representative Constance A. Morella from the suburbs of Washington, D.C.
But most representatives rise or fall on domestic records, and for them "foreign policy is totally unimportant most of the time," said Barbara Bardes, a political scientist at the University of Cincinnati. "They are available for those swing votes as long as it doesn't hurt them."
And more of them are available these days because two factors encouraging instinctive support of a president no longer matter.
One was the cold war, which drew the argument that the United States would seem weak to the Soviet Union if the president could not enforce his foreign policy views, even in areas of no concern to Moscow.
A second is the departure of the World War II generation from Congress. Only nine veterans of that war now serve in the House. The Senate has lost the voice of Bob Dole, who could tell his colleagues that once the president had made a decision, even a weak one, he must be supported.
The "sort of 'president knows best' attitude is gone," said another student of Congressional behavior on foreign policy, James McCormack, an Iowa State University political scientist.
Indeed, that generation has been replaced by the skeptical veterans and nonveterans of the Vietnam era, for whom "the commander-in-chief thing doesn't work," Dr. Bardes said. "They are worried about becoming too involved."
That attitude produces resolutions demanding withdrawal of troops from Bosnia and Kosovo, delays in appropriations for drug wars in Colombia and, at its most intense level, Senate rejection of the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty.
The consequence is that, "given the polarization of the parties, almost any major initiative requires a major effort" by the president, said Bob Pastor, a political scientist at Emory University in Atlanta.
This China trade bill got that intense effort, not just from the administration, but from business and House Republicans, too.
But without outside allies of the weight of the business interests that backed this bill, the administration lost the nuclear test treaty and faces continual difficulties in getting the money to pay back dues to the United Nations.
That effort was required because even if this was fundamentally a trade bill, where most of the votes depended on jobs gained for Florida fertilizer mills or lost to textile plants in North Carolina, it also carried the baggage of a foreign policy measure about a Chinese government that no one in Congress will defend. This was not a pure trade measure, like the question of extending lower tariffs to Chile.
The 57 Republicans who voted no were primarily motivated by China's treatment of Christians and political dissidents, plus its reported espionage activity against the United States. And others were tempted, doubting the argument that trade would broaden Chinese society.
Representative Tom Tancredo of Colorado dripped with sarcasm: "We have been told wonderful things will flow from expanded trade with China. Workers' rights will be respected, religious freedom will be enhanced, and probably Jeffersonian study groups will be popping up all over China."
But supporters like Representative Nancy L. Johnson, Republican of Connecticut, disagreed. She quoted a clergyman, Rev. Daniel Baida Su, who told the Ways and Means Committee that the deal and membership in the World Trade Organization obliged "China to play by the rules."
"In the process, China will need to strengthen its legal institutions, train more legal professionals, learn to follow international legal procedures, and educate its people about the concept of rights, law and international norms," Ms. Johnson quoted Mr. Su as saying. "This process alone is a breakthrough with important philosophical implications for China as a nation. When a Chinese realizes he has rights as an investor that government should not violate, then more likely he will also realize that he has other rights as a human being."
But her argument would not have prevailed without the sense in Congress that more jobs were to be gained than lost, and without the labor opposition suffering from the label of "protectionism," concerned about saving the jobs of union members at the expense of the American economy in general.
John J. Sweeney, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., called that label "very unfair." He said in an interview: "We realize the value of trade with any country. We recognize the expansion of globalization. But in this new global economy, we must strive for rules that protect human rights and workers rights and the environment and not just profits."
It was the bill itself that was protectionist, he said, as an "outright attempt to protect profits without any concern for human rights and workers' rights."
That argument was often heard on the House floor. Representative Janice D. Schakowsky, an Illinois Democrat, said the bill encouraged United States companies to take "advantage of the nearest slave labor conditions and wages." That sort of attack went largely unchallenged.
But arguments like those of Representative Marge Roukema prevailed. The New Jersey Republican saw huge opportunities for American energy, gas, construction, telecommunications and engineering companies in China. "Not only for New Jersey," she said, "but for the nation, the bottom line here is that this is a jobs bill."

HEADLINE: Almost an Energy Alternative;
FuelCells Hold Promise, but Problems Remain

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

DATELINE: CARLSBAD, Calif.

 BODY:
Jeff Colborn plunged into fusion energy research in the late 1980's, first at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory and then at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, filled with idealism about fusion's potential for revolutionizing nuclear power generation.
"I wanted the toughest challenge," said Mr. Colborn, recalling the goals he had after studying engineering and physics at the University of California at Berkeley. 
 But the entrepreneurial Mr. Colborn, who founded a business during high school selling decals for the motorcycles he and his friends raced, fretted that it could take 50 years before anyone could build a business on fusion. No wonder he is more at home these days as founder and chief executive of Metallic Power Inc., a little-known entrant in the intense race to design and manufacture fuel cells, low-pollution devices that generate electrical current from chemical reactions.
Although they are similar in many ways to batteries, fuel cells can be quickly regenerated by pumping in new chemical fuel. And unlike fusion, they are teetering on the edge of becoming big business. Several hundred units have been sold already, and some analysts predict a billion-dollar market by 2005.
The last steps are not coming easily, though. No one is making money yet, and the technology is not ready for potential home-run markets, like power for vehicles.
The fuel cell companies' slow path highlights the difficulties of innovating for the nuts-and-bolts dimension of the economy. Though this is not the fusion world it is also not the Internet world, where new services can be up and running within weeks and barriers to entry are low.
"People have gotten used to the pace of change of information technology," said Vincent R. Shiely, a vice president who oversees new ventures -- including a research partnership with Metallic Power -- at the Briggs & Stratton Corporation, the largest manufacturer of nonautomotive gasoline engines. "But this is pushing the frontier of materials, and there are still basic technology and reliability questions."
Fuel cell companies are developing everything from replacements for tiny batteries like those used in cell phones and hearing aids to highly efficient power plants big enough to fit the needs of electric utility companies.
The challenge is to come up with answers to conflicting demands for, among other things, lightness, reliability, durability and low cost.
Metallic Power has been slowed down by annoyingly mundane problems like troubles making its early designs leak-proof. But there have also been scarier roadblocks, as when Mr. Colborn and Stuart I. Smedley, his chief technology officer, reached the painful conclusion that a system they had adapted from other researchers for converting wastes back into recyclable fuel was hopelessly unreliable.
Mr. Smedley, a former university professor from New Zealand, eventually came up with a new design that was much simpler, one-tenth the size, and, perhaps best of all, something that Metallic Power's lawyer say he believes is patentable. But it took many months.
"Multiplying the ideal time for each stage by two has turned out to be a pretty accurate predictor of what actually happens," Mr. Colborn said. "Our schedule has stretched."
Metallic Power was founded in 1995 but did not produce its first primitive prototype until late 1997. The company faces steep challenges. Not only is it a relative newcomer with far less capital than many others; it is also using zinc as its fuel, a radically different approach from what nearly everyone else uses.
Several venture capitalists unfamiliar with the energy business got cold feet after looking closely at Mr. Colborn's plans. Among them was a restaurant owner. "I spent a lot of time driving to L.A. and eating in his restaurant," Mr. Colborn said, but the prospect dropped out when it came time to sign a check. "Everybody thinks fuel cells are cool, but when they get into it they discover they know nothing about it."
Mr. Colborn got a better reception from energy-focused investors like Robert W. Shaw Jr., president of the Arete Corporation, an investment firm based in Center Harbor, N.H., that manages money for utilities. "Every fuel cell company is struggling with similar problems," said Mr. Shaw, whose company's fuel cell investments include $2 million of the $8.6 million Metallic Power has raised in two rounds of financing. "At the end of the day, this company is going to make something, and it could have a long-term, sustainable advantage."
The payoff for fuel cell innovators could be breathtaking, especially if someone can create products that meet the performance needs of the auto industry. "As soon as someone has a system that operates in all environments at the cost of combustion engines, which is about $50 per kilowatt, it will take over the world," said Patrick Grimes, an energy consultant in Scotch Plains, N.J. "Some ell system will get there."
Mr. Colborn's company is focusing first on market niches that can afford far higher prices per kilowatt and are more likely to generate near-term profits, starting with portable generators for homes and small businesses.
History supports a cautious approach. Fuels cells were described in concept as far back as 1839, but when it came to designing products, other power sources -- from batteries to internal combustion engines to steam turbines -- always seemed to have a better cost-benefit mix.
So far, fuel cells' only big success has been on space missions, where cells have been used for more than 30 years and cost has been a negligible concern. But there has been renewed interest in recent years, bolstered by new electronic controls, better understanding of which chemicals would make the best fuel cells and, perhaps most important, government research grants and stricter environmental regulations.
A lot of the interest has been focused on hydrogen-based designs. Most hydrogen cells extract hydrogen from hydrocarbons like gasoline, natural gas or methane. The purified hydrogen reacts with oxygen drawn from the air to create electricity and water vapor.
Metallic Power, however, is working instead with zinc, which produces electricity and zinc oxide, a harmless powder used in cosmetics, when suspended in an alkaline liquid and then exposed to oxygen. Zinc/air cells, as they are called, are in theory simpler and cheaper than their hydrogen counterparts, according to Mr. Colborn. Other companies experimenting with zinc/air fuel cells include zinc/air battery makers like EVonyx Inc., a subsidiary of Reveo Inc., in Elmsford, N.Y., and Electric Fuel Ltd. of Israel.
Zinc's biggest disadvantage is that nothing can match the infrastructure already in place for distributing hydrogen. Automotive fuel cells based on hydrogen, for example, could be refueled by today's gas stations with relatively modest changes.
Hydrogen-based fuel cells are the only commercially available products, and numerous new variants are well down the development path.
The company most in the Wall Street spotlight is Ballard Power Systems Inc., a publicly traded Canadian company that is 25 percent owned by DaimlerChrysler. In recent months, Ballard has shipped a stationary 250-kilowatt fuel cell generator to European utilities for testing; introduced an improved, compact version of its first automotive cell, which Ford Motor is testing; and announced a partnership with the Sunbeam Corporation's Coleman Powermate unit, a big distributor of portable electric generators, to develop a co-branded fuel cell.
A newer entrant, Plug Power Inc. of Latham, N.Y., is developing refrigerator-sized cells that run on natural gas or propane for use as home power sources. Plug Power went public in October at $15 a share and soared to a high of $149.75 on March 10. But investors fled after a dose of reality about the pace of development: the company passed a deadline without meeting design requirements of the General Electric Company, a joint venture partner, which was to buy 485 cells. The shares ended Friday at $39.4375.
Multinational companies have largely been participating as investors and partners but some multinationals are more directly involved. The United Technologies Corporation owns International Fuel Cells of South Windsor, Conn., the developer of the fuel cells used on space missions and a stationary power system that has been installed in more than 200 commercial and institutional sites. And Siemens of Germany, with support from the Department of Energy, is field-testing a high-temperature hydrogen cell that could operate in tandem with gas turbines at power plants.
Metallic Power, by contrast, is not scheduled to deliver its first testing prototypes to partners like Briggs & Stratton and potential customers like the Army until the end of the year. Its more immediate goal is to complete a demonstration unit by July that will show how a portable cell for backup power can be kept running when fuel runs out simply by popping a new fuel cartridge in place. The target audience is venture capitalists; Metallic Power hopes to raise an additional $10 million to $15 million by the end of the year.
At a recent staff meeting, Mr. Colborn and three other senior managers pored over a chart showing the breakdown of the fuel cell into scores of components. They pondered where weight could be cut by design changes. Weight was not a concern for the July goals, but promises had been made to Briggs and others about the year-end prototypes, and Mr. Colborn wanted assurances that the July unit could be finished without compromising delivery of the prototypes.
Mr. Colborn is also juggling the demands of raising capital, nearly doubling his work force to about 50 by the end of the year and moving to larger quarters. He is determined to move methodically, arguing that in the turbulent world of fuel cells, Metallic Power is not as far behind the hydrogen companies as it looks if the finish line is defined as profitability.
"They are ahead of us in what they've put in the field, but they are too expensive," he said, predicting that Metallic Power will be among the first to become profitable if it meets its goals of commercial sales in 2002.
Mr. Colborn is quick to acknowledge, though, that the hydrogen cell designers are bringing down costs. "Realistically," he said, "the best thing that could happen for us is that they succeed -- but not a whole lot sooner than us."

HEADLINE: A Land Use Struggle Over a Forest Bounty

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: SITKA, Alaska

 BODY:
Carved by ice and washed by as much as 12 feet of rain a year, the Tongass National Forest stretches across Alaska's panhandle, full of coastal fjords and majestic strands of spruce, cedar and hemlock, which John Muir described in 1879 as a seemingly "indefinite, on-leading expansiveness."
Indeed, at 17 million acres, the Tongass is more than three times the size of any other national forest. But as the Clinton administration promotes its far-reaching plan to safeguard the forests by banning new road building throughout much of the system, the Tongass has a curious distinction: it is the one national forest specifically exempted from such a ban. 
 There are already more than 4,000 miles of logging roads snaking through the rain forest here, built as part of the nation's most heavily subsidized logging program, one that costs taxpayers about $30 million a year but is fiercely defended by Alaska's tiny but powerful Congressional delegation.
With 400 miles of new federal logging roads slated to be built in the Tongass rain forest over the next four years, the exemption has already set off a battle between national environmental groups and the timber industry.
And here in southeast Alaska, where the tourism industry now outpaces timber as a source of jobs, the debate over whether to build more logging roads in the world's largest remaining stretch of temperate rain forest is also surprisingly spirited, in a way that would have been unthinkable a generation ago when logging was firmly seen as the great spur to jobs in the sparsely populated area.
While logging interests complain that environmental restrictions have already cost the region hundreds of good jobs over the years and closed down two big mills, many of those who make their money by guiding tourists and sport fishers through the spectacular inlets and past the emerald forests favor more protections, and even an end to any clear-cutting in the Tongass.
And while just about everyone here agrees that America's largest, wildest national forest holds great resources, the core question in the debate is this: just how much of an economic resource is untouched wilderness?
"A lot of Alaskans don't like what we are inevitably becoming -- a place where people come to see it, rather than to exploit it," said Richard Nelson, a writer and cultural anthropologist who is on the board of the Sitka Conservation Society, an environmental group that wants to include the Tongass in President Clinton's ban on new road building.
"The whole frontier philosophy, the whole conquest-of-wilderness mentality, is certainly alive and well here," Mr. Nelson said. "But there is a whole opposite ethic that is growing fast."
There is no question that much of the battle over what to do with the Tongass will be fought in Washington.
For environmentalists, "leaving the Tongass out of this plan is like deciding to protect all national parks except Yellowstone," said Matthew Zencey, the Washington-based manager of the Alaska Rainforest Campaign, an umbrella coalition that hopes to have much of the forest protected by a road ban.
The timber industry is similarly animated, saying the Tongass is already subject to a federal "management plan" that balances wilderness protection in the area with a prudent amount of logging. The administration, in fact, cited that plan in exempting Tongass from its road restrictions, although other areas also have management plans. But critics of the exemption have suggested that the administration was merely trying to avoid picking a fight with Alaska's senators, who both lead committees that have authority over the forest service.
But as the land use struggle ensues thousands of miles away, people who live here are also clearly divided over whether the forest is chiefly useful for timber, or tourism, or both in equal measure.
In Sitka, for instance, the onetime capital of Russian America that is ringed by forests, sea and a snow-covered volcano on a nearby island, the city split a few years ago (1,702 against, 1,068 for) when a nonbinding measure was put on the local ballot to make it the city's official policy to oppose clear-cutting in the nearby national forest.
Both tourism and fishing now outrank the timber industry as a source of jobs in southeast Alaska, according to the state's Department of Labor and Workforce Development, a situation that is radically different from the case 25 years ago and that logging officials attribute to protections that environmentalists have already secured for the Tongass.
One came in the Carter administration, setting aside more than five million acres as wilderness, and another in the Bush administration, when Congress agreed to phase out much of a subsidy that was allowing two major timber companies to pay as little as $2 for huge Sitka spruce logs that would fetch about $300 on the open market. The subsidy dated to the 1950's, when the United States Forest Service agreed to provide a steady supply of timber at low prices to two companies that agreed to build pulp mills in the area.
Both of those mills are closed now -- one near here may be reconverted into a privately owned water-bottling plant, under a plan that is still being negotiated -- and the area now welcomes about 700,000 tourists every summer, more than double the number a decade ago. Many come in the cruise ships that glide by the magnificent scenery and dock in and around the coastal towns. Others come to fish with one of the dozens of guide companies that advertise their services in what many call "the salmon capital of the world."
Tourism is all well and good, but there is no reason for that industry not to coexist with continued logging, said Senator Frank H. Murkowski, the Alaska Republican who is chairman of a committee that oversees natural resources.
"So a tourist in Alaska comes in on a boat, and he gets off in Ketchikan or Juneau, and maybe spends a little money here, spends a little money there, and gets back on the boat," Mr. Murkowski said in a telephone interview from Washington. "That's important. It's a significant contribution. But it's not sufficient. What we really do well is, we grow timber and we grow fish. And they're both renewable if you do it correctly."
Besides, he added: "If we've done such a bad job with this forest in Alaska, then why is it still so scenic today for tourism? Why do so many people still want to come here?"
Under the president's plan, the Forest Service would ban road building in areas of the national forests where there are currently no roads. The plan would protect about 43 million acres that could be logged, roughly one-quarter of the 192 million acres in the national forest system. That would reduce planned timber harvests, now at about 3.6 billion board feet a year, by about 700 million board feet. (There are about 10,000 board feet of lumber in an average-size American home.)
But under the administration's recently announced preference, no such ban would apply in the 17-million-acre Tongass forest, and a decision on whether to impose a ban would not be made until 2004.
The Forest Service's program in the Tongass already operates at a deficit of about $30 million a year, meaning that the federal government pays that much more to build roads and maintain the forest than it takes in from timber companies, which grind most of the trees to a pulp that is sold for export.
That subsidy used to be even larger, and the program remains popular in some quarters here.
"Yes, we manage forests at a net loss for the taxpayer," said Bob Weinstein, the mayor of Ketchikan, a timber town at the southeastern tip of the state. "But that doesn't bother me until such time as the United States government eliminates every direct or indirect subsidy for any business."
Mayor Weinstein, a visceral opponent of a road building ban in the Tongass, said logging areas were typically well out of the view of tourists anyway.
"If there are cuts," he said, "the Forest Service has made sure they can't be seen from passing cruise ships."
The lush growing areas most prized by logging companies, however, are precisely the same areas that are most critical for wildlife habitat, conservationists say. The region, roughly the size of West Virginia, has one of the largest concentrations of bald eagles and grizzly bears anywhere in the world and is also considered one of the largest stretches left of temperate (as opposed to tropical) rain forest.
James Lyons, the assistant agriculture secretary in charge of the Forest Service, said the Tongass was exempted from a road ban under the recent proposal because it had already been subject to an intensive, yearslong review process that resulted in a 1997 "management plan" aimed at balancing wilderness protection with continued logging.
Total logging in the forest now amounts to about 150 million board feet annually, having steadily dropped from a high of 590 million board feet in 1973. Environmental groups said that areas served by existing logging roads already provided enough land for a sustainable timber harvest, and that the road ban should be extended here.
But Senator Murkowski said the logging statistics indicated that environmentalists had already gotten the upper hand in the Tongass.
"Now they want it all," he said. "Have you ever met with an environmental group that's satisfied? If they were satisfied, they wouldn't have a cause. They'd have to shut up shop and retire."
Logging industry officials also said they were extremely skeptical of environmentalists' claims that tourism would be the economic lifeblood of the area.
"When they get finished shutting down logging, they're going to go after the cruise ships," said Jack Phelps, executive director of the Alaska Forest Association, a trade group based in Ketchikan. "They think there're too many people coming here."
And, indeed, there is evidence that some Alaskans feel they are overrun with tourists: Juneau has slapped visitors' fees on those who arrive by boat, and Sitka residents voted down a proposal to build a dock that would have allowed more cruise ships to moor in town rather than out in the bay. (Many cruise ships offload their passengers onto smaller boats to bring them into town.)
But Eric Jordan, a second-generation fisherman here in Sitka who also runs a guide business, said the local economy was stronger today than when the mill went out of business. The air and waters are much cleaner too, Mr. Jordan said.
"When the mill actually closed and that cloud of smoke was lifted, both psychologically and literally, an amazing thing happened," he said. "Property values shot up, and they've been going up ever since. The reality was more palatable than dealing with this constant threat that the economy would collapse if the mill went. I really think the psychology of the town has brightened in a lot of respects."

HEADLINE: COST OF INSURANCE FOR CARS IS RISING ACROSS THE NATION

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
After falling for two years, car insurance premiums around the country are climbing once again, resuming a steady quarter-century rise.
Several big insurers -- including Progressive, Geico, State Farm and Allstate -- have begun imposing higher prices, and analysts say that by the end of the year most other leading companies are likely to follow suit. The insurers said they were forced to act because of rising expenses for repairs and treatment of injuries. 
 "The trend is clearly upward," said Thomas V. Cholnoky, who follows auto insurance for Goldman, Sachs.
While the size of the increases has varied widely -- and some companies are still cutting prices -- rises of at least 4 to 5 percent have not been uncommon. And a few companies have raised prices in some states by more than 10 percent. Analysts and industry executives say they expect more of the same next year.
In New York and Connecticut, the first signs of the shift are appearing. But the situation is less clear in New Jersey, where spending on car insurance -- averaging $1,150 a year a car, compared with $700 nationally -- has been the highest in the country. Last year the legislature took the unusual step of ordering a 15 percent cut in prices.
While expenses for insurers may well be rising in New Jersey, as elsewhere, industry executives said it was difficult to predict whether those costs would be offset by legislative changes aimed at reducing fraud and litigation and, if not, to what extent political leaders would permit price increases.
Consumer advocates say the increases may not be justified. J. Robert Hunter, director of insurance at the Consumer Federation of America, said that while some costs were rising, expenses for insurers, over all, were still declining.
Americans spent an estimated $126 billion last year on car insurance, which is mandatory in all states. That was nearly four times what they paid to insure their homes. There are many more claims involving cars and passengers than for homes, though, and liability claims in the hundreds of thousands of dollars are much more common in car crashes than in incidents related to homes.
Besides raising prices, insurers are reducing or eliminating discounts and screening applicants more carefully so that they apply the highest rates to the riskiest drivers and simply refuse to sell to some. Several companies have also been hacking away at administrative expenses, with layoffs in some cases.
Consumer advocates say that to make sure of getting the best deal as prices are rising, people should review their bills and check prices with several companies. But rather than basing coverage decisions on price alone, the advocates advise people to talk with friends and insurance regulators to learn how various companies treat customers.
Prices for auto insurance had risen steadily since 1973, and in theyears through 1997 they rose more than twice as fast as inflation, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
But in 1998 they fell 2.8 percent and last year 3.2 percent, said Robert P. Hartwig, chief economist at the Insurance Information Institute, an industry group in New York. Insurers said they had cut their prices to reflect falling costs for claims.
Fewer and less serious accidents were occurring, partly because of safety features like air bags and antilock brakes. There had also been declines in drunken driving and auto theft, and signs that aging baby boomers were becoming safer drivers. Mr. Hartwig said body shop costs and medical expenses had leveled off.
While many of those trends are continuing, Mr. Hartwig said, their financial benefits are being eclipsed by a resurgence in costs for repairs and treatment of injuries. He said repair costs are up partly because many companies stopped using generic replacement parts after State Farm was sued by consumers last fall and ordered to pay $1.2 billion for not using original manufacturers' parts.
Randy Stoddard, a top executive at Safeco, the nation's 15th-largest insurer, said that while the number of accidents was still declining, "the severity is up."
Moreover, he said: "The new cars are smarter and more expensive to repair. And people are more expensive to repair; we call that medical inflation."
Mr. Hunter said he had no doubt that the insurers' costs per accident were going up. "But," he said, "the number of accidents is falling faster than the increase in costs."
Safeco, which reported a nearly $40 million loss in its auto insurance business in the first quarter, has increased rates in 20 states so far this year, from just under 1 percent in Colorado to 8.2 percent in Michigan. Last year it cut prices in 18 states.
The two biggest companies -- State Farm and Allstate -- are still cutting rates in more states than they are raising them, but they, too, are showing the early signs of a shift. Last year, State Farm cut rates in 48 states and increased prices in only one, Massachusetts. So far this year, State Farm says it is cutting rates in 15 states and increasing them in 10, including a 5.6 percent rise in Montana.
State Farm is seeking a decrease of nearly 5 percent in California, the state with the most drivers. But Mr. Cholnoky said that an analysis of rates in California showed that State Farm's prices were among the highest in the state, 31 percent higher than Allstate's and 55 percent higher than Progressive's.
So far this year, Allstate has raised prices in two states -- Louisiana and South Carolina; last year there were no increases. While it trimmed rates in 10 states last year, only 4 states have had cuts this year.
In New York, where regulators have taken steps to ease costs for insurers, just as they did in New Jersey, one of the largest companies, Progressive, has raised rates 4.3 percent. Nineteen small companies have put in place increases ranging from less than 1 percent to 18.6 percent; six other small companies cut prices. In Connecticut, one of the largest insurers, Nationwide Mutual, increased prices 4.9 percent and six other insurers have come in with smaller increases. Five small insurers cut prices. Last year price decreases outnumbered increases nearly 3 to 1.
One small New Jersey company, GSA, raised premiums 15 percent, and several New Jersey insurers are asking regulators for even higher increases. But John Tiene, executive director of the Insurance Council of New Jersey, said these increases had been requested two years ago and did not reflect current expenses. The increase for GSA, however, had the effect of nullifying the 15 percent legislative rollback.
Geico, Progressive, Safeco and several other major insurers do not operate in New Jersey, saying that it is difficult to do so profitably.
Across the country, Progressive and Geico have been leading a price war and gaining market share at the expense of companies like State Farm and Allstate, which have been either losing market share or merely holding even as the number of drivers has been growing.
Now, both Progressive and Geico, after suffering significant losses in earnings, are shifting toward higher prices. Since last year, for example, Progressive has increased prices by an average of 7.4 percent in 41 states, according to Charles B. Gates, an insurance analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston. Progressive has raised rates about 4 percent in Missouri and is asking for an increase of 9.9 percent in Florida.
As it announced an underwriting loss of $86 million in the first quarter of this year, Geico said it expected to increase rates in many states, but gave no details. Geico is a unit of Berkshire Hathaway.
Mr. Gates said the increase in prices by Progressive and Geico, which have been the fastest-growing big insurers, were likely to be taken as a sign by other insurers that it was safe to raise prices. Previously, he said, the others may have feared that price increases would drive customers to Progressive and Geico.
Several analysts said they expected State Farm and Allstate to raise prices more slowly than other big companies because over the previous two years they had reduced their prices less than many competitors.
Mr. Hunter said that in their zeal to capture market share, Progressive and Geico might have cut prices too much for their own good. "Those companies might have to raise rates," he said. "But some companies may be taking advantage of this opportunity to raise their rates. I'm saying, 'Wait a minute. You don't need to raise your rates. You should be continuing to lower them.' "

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

New Wave of Growth in Asia Is Reminiscent of 1980's
Less than three years after a plunge in the value of Thailand's currency set in motion a devastating economic crisis across much of Asia, the region is riding a wave of growth reminiscent of the Asian miracle of the 1980's.
The latest evidence of the resurgence came with a report that Hong Kong's economic output rose 14.3 percent in the first three months of the year. It was the territory's fastest quarter of growth since 1987, and seemed to make the Asian crisis a distant memory. Page A1. 

Demand for Big-Ticket Goods Falls
Demand for big-ticket goods in April registered its steepest decline since late 1991, and consumer spending rose at its slowest pace in nine months, the government said, indicating that the economy may be slowing. Durable goods orders fell 6.4 percent; economists had been expecting a 0.5 percent drop. Consumer spending rose 0.4 percent, while consumer income climbed 0.7 percent; both figures matched forecasts. B3.
 
Car Insurance Premiums Edge Up
After falling for two years, car insurance premiums around the country are climbing once again, resuming a steady quarter-century rise. Several big insurers have begun imposing higher prices, and analysts say that by the end of the year most other big insurers are likely to follow. The insurers said they were forced to act because of rising expenses for repairs and treatment of injuries. A1.
 
Push for Prescription Drug Coverage
Bill Thomas of California, an influential Republican member of the House, and Ron Wyden of Oregon, a Democratic senator, announced that they would collaborate on a bipartisan effort to add prescription drug benefits to Medicare this year. The effort alters the politics of the issue in this election year, at least marginally increasing the chances that Congress can break the deadlock on Medicare coverage of prescription drugs. A10.
 
De Beers Seizes Angolan Diamonds
De Beers has begun seizing shipments of Angolan government diamonds after the Angolans scrapped a 10-year-old agreement with De Beers to market stones from an Angolan concession. De Beers officials said they were acting in part because of a $50 million debt owed to the company by Angola. B2.
 
Boeing's Satellite Deal Is Delayed
Boeing's proposed purchase of the satellite unit of Hughes Electronics faces an extended investigation by European antitrust officials, which may delay the deal. B2.
 
Toshiba Faces Complaints in China
Toshiba's settlement of a class-action lawsuit in the United States last year has backfired in China, where consumers are charging discrimination because the Japanese electronics maker has not offered them the same deal. Masaichi Koga, a vice president of Toshiba, went to Beijing this week to try to repair the damage. B2.
 
Markets Closed Memorial Day
United States financial markets, government offices and banks will be closed Monday in observance of Memorial Day. Financial markets will be open in other countries.

HEADLINE: Clinton Offers Plan to Protect Nation's Shorelines

BYLINE: By MARC LACEY 

DATELINE: ASSATEAGUE ISLAND, Md., May 26

 BODY:
Using the sand and surf as a backdrop, President Clinton announced new initiatives today intended to preserve the nation's fragile shoreline and threatened coral reefs.
Mr. Clinton directed the Commerce Department and the Department of the Interior, as well as the Environmental Protection Agency, to strengthen ocean protections through administrative steps similar to the ones applied to large tracts of land protected as wilderness areas. Coming in the final months of his presidency, Mr. Clinton's protections would not require approval by Congress but could be undone by his successor. 
 "Beachlines and coastlines are now our No. 1 tourist destination," the president said as he strode onto the sand on this barrier island.
"Our oceans, however, are far more than a playground," Mr. Clinton continued. "They have a central effect on the weather, on our climate system. Through fishing, tourism and other industries, ocean resources -- listen to this -- support 1 out of every 6 jobs in the United States of America."
The president, who spoke over a roaring surf as sea gulls flew overhead, directed the Interior and Commerce Departments to set up a system of "marine protected areas" to coordinate the hodgepodge of federal protections now in place for beaches, reefs and other marine habitats.
His order did not specify any areas, but it requested recommendations on shorelines in need of limits on activities like fishing, offshore oil drilling, mining and dumping.
As it is, the National Park Service protects 54 marine areas, which cover more than three million acres of water, including Glacier Bay in Alaska, the Everglades in Florida, and here on Assateague, an island renowned for the wild horses that roam its marshlands. Other marine areas have been set aside as wildlife refuges under the supervision of the Fish and Wildlife Service or the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.
"These different protections have all been fragmented," said David Hayes, deputy secretary of the interior. "And for the first time under the executive order, there's going to be a requirement that the agencies work together and look together at the protections that we have, and determine whether we need new protections or not."
Although the details remain to be worked out, some commercial fishermen were nervous that their favorite spots might be declared off-limits.
"The whole world is against watermen, and now you have the world plus the president," Freeland Mason, past president of the Virginia Watermen's Association, told The Associated Press. "The conservationists want to cut out all commercial fishing. They don't want any fishing except by hook and line. The waterman is an endangered species these days."
Mr. Clinton also directed the environmental agency to adopt tougher water pollution standards to protect beaches and coastal areas, and to identify areas where additional protections are required.
"They're going to go back and look at their permitting process for all of the ocean discharges that could have an impact in ocean areas, and make sure that those are fully scientifically based, and if necessary, to increase the protection," said James Baker, administrator of the oceanic and atmospheric agency.
As it is now, thousands of beaches are closed every year as heavy rains cause sewers and drains to overflow, washing sewage into the surf. That polluted runoff can cause a variety of health hazards, including dysentery and hepatitis. It also leads to the growth of toxic algae and threatens marine life.
Without better protections, polluted shorelines can only get worse as nearly half of all development in the United States is along coastlines.
Mr. Clinton also ordered the development of a plan within the next 90 days to protect the coral reefs off a 1,200-mile string of uninhabited islands in northwestern Hawaii. Coral reefs, which harbor an abundance of marine life, are threatened worldwide from pollution, overfishing and rising ocean temperatures.
The Hawaiian reefs, first protected when President Theodore Roosevelt created the Hawaiian Islands National Wildlife Refuge, make up nearly 70 percent of the coral in United States waters and support threatened sea turtles, monk seals and other marine life.
Mr. Clinton's plan, which will probably increase the zone of protected coral off Hawaii, would be developed in cooperation with the Hawaiian authorities, officials said.
In announcing the initiatives, Mr. Clinton made both environmental and economic arguments.
"The old idea that we can only grow by putting more pollution into our lakes and rivers and oceans must finally be put to rest," he said. "Indeed, it is now clear that we can grow our economy faster over the long run by improving our environment, and it's really not enough for us just to try to keep it as it is. We have to do better."
Although the president has used his executive authority to impose an array of environmental protections, Congress is in charge of the purse strings, and Republican leaders have been reluctant to spend money for all of what Mr. Clinton considers critical environmental priorities.
Pete Jeffries, communications director for Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois, said the president was acting unwisely by expanding protected areas without giving sufficient resources to the ones already on the books.
"Republicans want to take a responsible, common-sense approach to our environment," Mr. Jeffries said.
