SECTION: Section 6; Page 11; Column 3; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 1120 words

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 5-28-00: Word & Image;
Who Wants to Be a Monopoly?

BYLINE: By Max Frankel 

 BODY:
Until a few weeks ago, I expected to live out my life without adopting a firm theory of monopoly. The subject, confounded by the obfuscation of economists and lawyers, always struck me as impossibly difficult. Fair competition in capitalism seemed to be like the strike zone in baseball -- a matter of considerable discretion and best left to the regulation of umpires.
I even thought that some monopolies were useful; securely profitable newspapers obviously behaved more responsibly than economic weaklings. And big was not automatically bad: corporate giants needed giant rivals to feel challenged and checked. I pronounced flexibility a virtue and relied on government umpires to protect our markets and the public interest. 
 No longer.
When the Time Warner cable monopoly in Manhattan chose on May Day to deny me Peter Jennings, Regis Philbin and Ted Koppel merely to squeeze some more millions out of the Disney Company, I realized that the umpire had been much too lax, refusing even to demand payment for use of the broadcast spectrum or to get some free television time for decent election coverage. All this was proof that the media monsters will never put a public interest ahead of their own. Time Warner had for too long controlled not only the cables into my home but also many of the channels and programs passing through its wire. It was hogging both my medium and my message, and the combination virtually guaranteed anticompetitive behavior.
Now Time Warner wants to merge with AOL and control my cable access to the Internet as well. And still the umpire seems distracted or asleep.
Not that the May Day blackout was entirely Time Warner's fault. It pulled the trigger but not without provocation from the Mickey Mouse moguls. Because Disney, too, had been allowed to grow too fat and to swallow up media properties like ABC and ESPN, it felt directly threatened by the AOL Time Warner combine. Disney had also threatened me with a blackout, showing equal disregard for my prepaid viewing rights.
To be sure, the ambitions of Disney and Time Warner are so complementary that they are bound to find an eventual accommodation. But their peace, like their war, will be at my expense. If not soon reduced in size, all the overgrown media monsters will follow in the path of Microsoft, abusing their control over both the conduits and contents of communication to destroy competitors and elude regulation.
The media news in recent weeks confirms the trend. Viacom swallowed CBS to gain control of 41 percent of the broadcast market (and began maneuvers to overcome the frail regulatory limit of 35 percent). AT&T moved to complete its acquisition of MediaOne so as to seize command of more than one-third of the nation's cable industry. And the five major American music companies virtually confessed to having colluded to cheat their disc customers of more than $500 million with various price-fixing schemes.
Some newspapers were also caught up in these antics, an uncomfortable reminder that the monopolistic arts antedate the Web. The Hearst Corporation was shown at trial to be finagling to kill its own San Francisco Examiner so that it could acquire the paper's more profitable partner, The Chronicle, and dispense with even nominal competition. Testimony revealed the use of crude promises of editorial support for Mayor Willy Brown if he would drop his opposition and help to gain federal approval for the scheme. (The Examiner and The Chronicle had already been merged for all functions except news gathering under an antitrust exemption that the newspaper industry pushed through Congress 30 years ago. These "joint operating" deals have done much less for journalistic enterprise than for profits. But in any case they only disguise and delay the drift toward print monopolies. Even before the Hearst trial ended, a famous rivalry between The Post and The Rocky Mountain News in Denver ended in yet another such "joining.")
So I have learned three things about the evolving media business:
1. The commendable but all-consuming prosecution of Microsoft by the Justice Department seems to have exhausted or distracted the umpire and left the rest of the field unguarded.
2. The Clinton administration's repeated claim that the lure of monopolistic profits can stimulate giant corporations to innovate is unproved and probably wrong. As William Safire observed with an African proverb after the May Day blackout, "When elephants fight, it is the grass that suffers."
3. The hope that the new technologies will democratize the commerce of communication is, on present evidence, nave. The world's half-dozen conglomerated merchants of information and entertainment control so many conduits and so much content that they will inevitably rig the market to favor their own transmissions and services and to disadvantage all others.
In some distant future, it may become possible for Americans to get their Web-based news, fun and education by many competing routes, including interactive cables, telephone wires, wireless radio and satellite dishes. But for the foreseeable future, the path of choice will be the cables that already carry TV images into three of every four homes.
It is the lure of owning cables that inspired AOL to offer billions to acquire Time Warner and AT&T to mortgage itself to buy MediaOne. They well understand, even if the umpires don't, that the complex "architecture" by which small packets of data travel to and from the Web now permits the owners of cable lines to enhance the speed and quality of their own messages and to shortchange rivals.
Just months ago, when America Online had reason to fear that AT&T's new cable prowess would be used against it, AOL begged the courts and Congress to intervene to forbid all discrimination. Yet now that it hopes to own Time Warner's cables, AOL no longer begs; it actively opposes government regulation. To facilitate Washington's approval of their marriage, AOL and Time Warner promise fair access for "multiple" -- if not all -- Web services. As an alert White House should know, this all depends on what "all" means.
It was fear of cable discrimination that drove Disney toward the May Day shootout. Similar disruptions are inevitable if the media's quasi-monopolies go unchecked.
By far the best way to achieve openness would be to require media corporations to choose between the business of conduit and the business of content, between managing the lines of communication and designing the messages and services to be transmitted. Hoarding both functions confers monopolistic power to rig the market and to diminish competition. The emerging concentrations of power risk a May Day every day.

SECTION: Section 14CN; Page 13; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1283 words

HEADLINE: Old Wethersfield Streets Offer a Glimpse of the Past

BYLINE: By BESS LIEBENSON 

 BODY:
BETWEEN Rocky Hill and Hartford there is a time warp and it is called Old Wethersfield. Founded in 1634 as Connecticut's first permanent English settlement, Wethersfield was described as the state's "most auncient" town by the General Court of the Colony of Connecticut in 1650.
"It's a town of pristine preservation with the largest historic district in the state," said Brenda Milkofsky, director of the Wethersfield Historical Society. "Unlike Williamsburg and Sturbridge, which are recreated communities, Wethersfield is an authentic landscape." 
 The approximately two-mile rectangular strip called Old Wethersfield (listed on the National Register of Historic Places) offers visitors an easy way to lose themselves without getting lost.
A get-acquainted drive past old houses, farms, barns and warehouses, about 150 predating 1850 is an easy way to begin; then visitors can simply walk the short distances. Wethersfield has a rich vocabulary of architecture ranging from early English style to suburban houses built at the turn of the century.
A logical first stop along the tree-lined brick walks is the Wethersfield Museum in the Keeny Memorial Cultural Center, built of local brown brick and stone in 1893 with splashing front fountain. It is a place to relax on new benches, pick up pamphlets, learn about walking tours and view an orientation exhibit. "Legendary People, Ordinary Lives" offers an overview of the town's architecture, furnishings and prominent residents as well as its early economy, which was rooted in maritime and agricultural industries. (For those with children in tow, there is a special guide to help them.)
One driving loop can take motorists up Broad Street and back down Main, past the Broad Street Village Green, mariners' and merchants' homes of various vintages and one of two early farms still in operation. The Anderson Farm, circa 1837, with weathered wagon in front announces flowers as well as produce in season.
Cove Warehouse, a 17th-century post and beam warehouse at the north end of Main Street, sits on a lonely crest overlooking the water. If visitors push open a shutter-like window they can be transported to the middle of the 1600's, when vessels were being built in the area and the harbor, now called the cove, was a center for shipping animals, flax, seed and the region's major crop, red onions, to places as far away as the West Indies. Story panels and artifacts recreate a warehouse alive with business activity among farmers, merchants and shipmasters. Outside the old warehouse there are picnic tables that offer a place to rest and soak up the view, in summer a sea of boats.
On Main Street, gardening-minded visitors and others simply interested in the beauty of flowers can head to Comstock Ferre & Company, a four-story red barn dating from the 1820's and one of the oldest garden centers in Connecticut.
Today, original tin signs and blazing nursery display of perennials and roses stop traffic. But their indoor row-on-row old rocker bins and tin-lined oak drawers displaying seed stock and bright bouquets of original lithographed packets might be the real scene stealers. When the onion trade (1730-1830) expired, "Wethersfield farmers were charged with finding a new outlet," Ms. Milkofsky said. "Eight seed companies developed trial and seed gardens in plots that had previously been onion patches."
Wethersfield's centerpiece may well be the Webb-Deane-Stevens Museum, a trio of mustard, red and blue houses from the 18th century. Their newest attraction is the Colonial revival-style garden. It was installed behind the Webb House last year from long-lost plans; now old-fashioned flowers, archways and paths lead to a barn, sometimes a setting for weddings. Inside the houses, furniture and decorative arts from 1690 to 1840 reflect the life styles of the merchant Joseph Webb, the diplomat Silas Deane and the leather worker Isaac Stevens. In the Webb house's front parlor it is said that George Washington met with Comte Rochambeau to outline plans that led to the final victory of the Continental Army in Yorktown. The Rev. Wallace Nutting -- renowned as a philosopher, maker of reproduction furniture and Colonial restorationist -- bought the house in 1916.
The Greek revival circa-1830 Chester Bulkley House, next door to the Wethersfield Museum, is a bed and breakfast and the only overnight lodging in the restored district. A steep flight of steps leads to a sitting room and guest rooms (there are five guest rooms, three with private baths, priced from $65 to $85 plus 12 percent tax). In one room, two white four-poster beds crowned with pineapple finials overlooked a white antiqued bombe chest bearing a bouquet of tulips. White lace swags hang at the windows and floral rugs rest on wide planked floors.
Just down the block is the circa-1787 Standish House. The gracious white Colonial -- which has served as inn, stagecoach stop, post office and restaurant -- offers dining downstairs and up.
The brick Georgian Hurlbut-Dunham House, on the other side of the Wethersfield Museum, is typical of many New England houses. It was updated in the 1860's with porches, a colonnade and a commanding belvedere. Much of the last owner's furnishings and collections remain, and a center-hall bombe breakfront is aflow with blue and white china.
A tour of the Ancient Burying Ground can be a treat if one is fortunate enough to be led by the Historical Society's education coordinator, Betty Arnold, a feisty, knowledgeable 85-year-old woman who has lived in the community since she was in the third grade. Ms. Arnold can prod even weary visitors up the hill among gravestones that tell stories going back to the 1630's. The stones range from simple slabs with crude letters to ornate tables and tombs boasting carved heads and cherub faces. A slave dying a freed man, a fever sweeping the town and sailors perishing at sea are among the historic glimmers.
And Ms. Arnold can offer fairly direct commentary as well: "The Puritans were people of the upper sort who believed in a hierarchy," she said, pointing out the more prestigious hilltop, where, she added, "People were buried on the hill according to their place in society."
Across the street is the meeting house of the First Church of Christ (1761). A glass corridor overlooking the Ancient Burying Ground is enthralling, and inside the sanctuary are red velvet pews, mustard, red and green candelabras and a dramatic raised pulpit and canopy. Two blocks south is Temple Beth Torah, housed in a former Methodist church dating to 1689, its double blue doors adorned with raised gold stars.
"We like to say Wethersfield is 10 minutes and 200 years removed from Hartford," said Ms. Milkofsky of the Historical Society. "It's very much removed from the hustle and bustle."
 
If You Go
 
 Old Wethersfield can be reached by taking Exit 26 from Interstate 91.
Among attractions to look for this summer are the exhibition "Lost Gardens of New England and Wethersfield," June 8 through Sept. 4 at the Wethersfield Museum in the Keeney Memorial Cultural Center (200 Main Street; 860-529-7656).
For a get-acquainted tour, call the Wethersfield Historical Society (860-529-7656); a "Welcome to Wethersfield: Home and Garden Tour" will be given on June 10.
Among places to stay are a bed and breakfast, the Chester Bulkley House (184 Main Street; 860-563-4236), and the Ramada Inn (1330 Silas Deane Highway; 860-563-2311) .
Places to eat include Standish House (222 Main Street; 860-257-1151), the Spicy Green Bean Deli (285 Main Street; 860-563-3100) and Mainly Tea (221 Main Street; 860-529-9517). BESS LIEBENSON

HEADLINE: FILM;
The Blockbuster Can No Longer Live By Muscle Alone

BYLINE: By NANCY HASS; Nancy Hass writes frequently about the business of entertainment.

 BODY:
LIKE death, taxes and those sprayed helmets of hair sported by many women on the Upper East Side, some things never seem to change. Like summer movies. Always the same: fiery explosions, knockout special effects, thin plots, well-muscled stars. Add to that nonstop television commercials, toys on the shelves, action figures in the Happy Meal. It seems so formulaic.
Despite appearances, however, the summer blockbuster has changed plenty since its birth -- widely acknowledged as June 1975, when "Jaws," the first movie to be treated to a full television ad campaign, began systematically terrorizing the nation. But the changes have been subtle and cumulative. 
Cooking up such a film may still look as simple as following a recipe, but with the escalation of technology, the proliferation of movie screens and a steadily increasing number of films, the path to official blockbusterdom has become as complicated as a quadratic equation, and as hard to calculate. "There's just an ether in the world when a movie breaks through," said the director Barry Sonnenfeld, whose "Men in Black" (a successful 1997 blockbuster) was followed last summer by "Wild Wild West" (a bust). "You can't predict it, you can't market for it. You just have to breathe it in."
If that is true, then this summer's contenders could use an oxygen tent. The sound you have been hearing in the pre- and early summer season air is conspicuous silence. Remember, as early as April 1999, "Star Wars: Episode I -- The Phantom Menace" and its product line were being flogged so relentlessly that the Force was with us even in our dreams.
Not to mention that by then teenagers across America, primed by the publicity machine for "Austin Powers: The Spy who Shagged Me," were already greeting pals in the mall with a rousing "Shagadelic!" (Blockbuster Rule No. 1: the average number of times that teenagers see a summer blockbuster is 2.8. Repeat customers are the secret to racking up $100 million in ticket sales.)
Many would have been hard-pressed to name the five most anticipated films for the summer of 2000. (Among the top contenders are the "Mission: Impossible" sequel, "M:i-2" (which opened on Wednesday); "X-Men"; "The Patriot," with Mel Gibson; "Gone in 60 Seconds," with Nicolas Cage and Angelina Jolie; and Wolfgang Petersen's adaptation of Sebastian Junger's "Perfect Storm.")
The contrast between the last two seasons illustrates how complex the making and marketing of summer movies has become. Some Hollywood insiders say preseason buzz has been light this time around because the films simply aren't very good. Studios, they say, are no longer willing to promote a mediocre movie heavily in the hope that marketing alone will push it to blockbuster status. "Godzilla," said one producer, referring to the 1998 film that was heavily promoted and disappointingly received, "changed everything."
Others counter that the relentless hyping of "Phantom Menace" simply tired the public out. Besides, they argue, there is no reason to spend lavishly on publicity when overall ticket sales rose more than 65 percent during the 1990's, to $7.4 billion last year. If you release it, the conventional wisdom goes these days (cadged, of course, from an April release, "Field of Dreams"), they will come.
Another reason for the lack of prerelease hoopla is that many in this summer's crop of films don't lend themselves to licensing, which has in the last decade become a crucial source of profit and promotion (sorry, kids, no Tom Cruise "M:i-2" action figure). "The most important thing about licensing isn't really the money you make," said Danny Simon, president of the Licensing Group, which puts together deals between manufacturers and movie studios. "It's the promotional value of having those products on the shelves, the excitement it generates for the film in the hearts of every kid who passes by."
So far this season hasn't even seen the usual overhyped product-placement deals, an important element of summer films since the 1982 hit "E.T." (The decision back then by the M &M Mars Company not to pay the filmmakers for using M & M's as a crucial plot point in Steven Spielberg's film led to the makers of Reese's Pieces' gaining an avalanche of publicity.)
Fresh in many executives' minds is the memory of last summer's surprise: the extraordinary success of two modestly financed films, "The Sixth Sense" and the "Blair Witch Project." A few executives said they were advising their studios to hang back, hoping to ride the trend toward such smaller movies that turn into blockbusters by word of mouth.
"A few years ago, people were totally focused on getting big budgets and promotional commitments," said one producer with several large-scale blockbusters under his belt. He called it the "Independence Day" mentality. "Now you think to yourself, is there any way I can make a small film that hits huge, which works out so well for everyone. You think that, even though you know it's ridiculous. You can't plan for something like that."
The good news for moviegoers is that as filmmakers and studios seem to be casting about for the next wave, the movies themselves seem to be getting smarter, or at least less cartoonish.
Not all of them, of course, but a significant number. Gone, for now, are pure testosterone-driven vehicles of the sort that Arnold Schwarzenegger and Sylvester Stallone specialized in during the 1980's and early 1990's. In their place is a more balanced palette of offerings, including last year's "Notting Hill" and this June's "Me, Myself and Irene," a comedy with Jim Carrey and Renee Zellweger. There is also a golf story directed by Robert Redford, "The Legend of Bagger Vance," which stars Will Smith and Matt Damon and is due out in August.
Although this year will have plenty of slam-bang adventure and science-fiction films, including Paul Verhoeven's "Hollow Man" (opening Aug. 4), with Kevin Bacon as an invisible man, and this month's "Battlefield Earth," adapted from an early novel by L. Ron Hubbard, the founder of Scientology, the trend seems to be toward real-life, character-driven suspense. For example, the history-based "Gladiator," with Russell Crowe, which earned more than $102 million in its first three weeks, and "The Patriot," a Revolutionary War drama opening June 28. Instead of aliens, the most fearsome enemy seems to be the elements, as battled by George Clooney in "The Perfect Storm." Even "X-Men," adapted from a popular comic book, is said to emphasize the humanness of its superheroes.
This summer's movies feature polished but decidedly unpumped stars like Mr. Cruise, Patrick Stewart, Chris O'Donnell and Mr. Cage. "As compared with some of the action stars of the past, these guys take a very active role in making sure their characters aren't just stereotypes and that the movies aren't overmarketed," said Brian Grazer, who produced the 1995 hit "Apollo 13," among others. During the making of that film, said Mr. Grazer, Tom Hanks insisted that the marketing plan avoid imitating the classic over-the-top campaigns of the 1990's: "How he handled it really made an impression on me."
This season it was Mr. Cruise himself who rejected the idea of big licensing tie-ins to "M:i-2," said Mr. Simon of the Licensing Group.
BUT star control is only one way in which the economic infrastructure of the summer blockbuster has changed. Even the very definition of a blockbuster has metamorphosed since "Jaws," which set the benchmark at $100 million. That stayed pretty stable until the 1990's, when the grosses started climbing. Since 1997, the cut-off seems to be $200 million. And that's just in domestic ticket sales. Add to that overseas sales, licensing, video, soundtracks and product placement, most of which didn't even exist when "Jaws" hit the beach.
Unfortunately for the studios, production budgets have swelled even faster. "E.T." made $399 million and cost $10 million. (The film is part of summer movie lore; even though ticket prices at the time were about $4, it remains the fourth-highest-grossing picture of all time.)
For studios, the stakes are enormous. Pressured toward profitablity by the entertainment conglomerates that now own them, they have become increasingly dependent on summer revenue. Last year, 40 percent of the studios' $6.9 billion annual take came in the weeks between Memorial Day and Labor Day. Jerry Bruckheimer, producer of "Armageddon," said: "Some people like to dismiss summer movies as just entertainment, but the truth is that they are hugely important to the health of studios. In summer every night is Saturday night and there is a lot of pressure to perform, more than ever before." Mr. Bruckheimer is also the producer of "Gone in 60 Seconds" and "Coyote Ugly," both coming this summer, as well as the highest-budget film ever approved -- the $135 million "Pearl Harbor," due next summer.
Although directors like Mr. Sonnenfeld insist it's impossible to plan for a blockbuster, some producers say there is now no choice but to try. Kathleen Kennedy, who produced "E.T." for Mr. Spielberg, said that back then no one had enough foresight to fully exploit the merchandising possibilities of the cuddly alien. This year, she said, long before she started filming the third "Jurassic Park," she found herself in studio meetings focusing solely on cross-promotion and licensing.
Of course, not even the definition of summer has stayed the same. Forget the calendar; as far as Hollywood is concerned, summer started weeks ago with the opening of DreamWorks' "Gladiator," Sony's "I Dreamed of Africa" and Universal's "Flintstones in Viva Rock Vegas"
Underlying these changes are two developments: the proliferation of films being released and the multiplexing of America. Both are good news for theater owners, but treacherous for moviemakers and moviegoers.
With more than 40 pictures to open in just three months this year, summer scheduling has become a Hollywood obsession. The trick is to find a weekend when there is no formidable competition. To that end, studios now announce release dates long before the first frame has been shot (though to add confusion, those dates are often shifted).
"Opening big" has always been crucial to summer movies, but now, with the average multiplex offering 6 screens (some have as many as 25), the fate of each film is decided 45 minutes into the first showing on Friday night. While there has been some reversal of the trend toward snap judgments in fall and spring films -- inspired by slow-growing hits like "American Beauty" and "Shakespeare in Love" -- the pressure has escalated in summer.
These days, if the audience isn't laughing or gasping enough by 7:45 p.m. on that first night, theater owners can easily decide to boot the film and replace it with additional showings of the action-adventure flick next door. "You're out literally by the 9:30 p.m. show," Mr. Bruckheimer said. "It can be brutal." For moviegoers, it can mean being faced with the same four rock-'em-sock-'em movies playing in a 12-screen cineplex.
With competition fierce for those summer teenage dollars, filmmakers increasingly employ high-tech effects. There may be fewer jacked-up physiques on screen, but there are more gadgets and cinematographic sleight-of-hand. What allowed "Jaws" to chomp its way into the public consciousness was the realism of the mechanical great white. That lesson has grown into a mantra in the intervening decades.
From the doe-eyed extraterrestrial in "E.T.," which now looks so primitive, to the dinosaurs of the 1992 "Jurassic Park" and the pyrotechnics of last year's dizzying "Phantom Menace," computer technology has become a cornerstone of summer films. Animated films, which were once limited to a single Disney picture every few years, are now made by several studios using innovative techniques. (This year, "Dinosaur," which opened on May 19, "Chicken Run" (June 23) and "Titan A.E." (June 16) are among the entrants.)
The Internet has also had a profound effect on the making of a blockbuster. Its democratizing nature has led to unexpected hits like the "Blair Witch Project," which was marketed almost entirely online through the filmmakers' own efforts. But the Internet has also made it very hard for filmmakers to stop the leaking of information -- especially negative market research and focus-group feedback -- before the film is ready to be released. Such bad word of mouth, instantly communicated to millions of teenagers, is a sure killer for summer films.
"When you're doing a big movie, you try a lot of things -- the last thing you want is your process to be reviewed before you're done," said Gale Ann Hurd, a producer of "Terminator," "Aliens" and "Armageddon." "It's frightening."
Mr. Sonnenfeld believes that one of the reasons "Wild, Wild West" did so badly on its opening weekend was that "misinformation" got out on the Web and was picked up by journalists. "It becomes a self-fulfilling prophecy," he said.
Still, Mr. Sonnenfeld, a master of combining computer effects with quirky stories, looks forward to another technological leap that will be a great boon to him and other filmmakers. The way he sees it, digital transmission, in doing away with the costly process of striking thousands of prints, will change everything. Within a couple of years, he suggested, a filmmaker whose blockbuster is starting to fade a bit at the box office could easily zap in some additional footage to lure teenagers back for another viewing. "That," he said, "would stand summer on its head."

HEADLINE: HEALTH;
Health Chief Faced Trouble in Previous Post

BYLINE: By KATE STONE LOMBARDI 

 BODY:
A LITTLE more than a year ago, Dr. Joshua Lipsman left Alexandria, Va., where he had been health commissioner for seven years, to become executive director of the Manhattan-based Gay Men's Health Crisis, the nation's oldest and largest AIDS services agency.
But after just 10 months on the job, marked by severe budget problems and political infighting, Dr. Lipsman has returned to the field of public health as Westchester's new health commissioner. 
 "I just plunged into this maelstrom of discontent and unhappiness, on top of the already sad and hard situation called AIDS," Dr. Lipsman said.
The agency had already gone through three downsizings -- eliminating programs and laying people off -- when Dr. Lipsman discovered a $2.5 million budget shortfall. The staff became disillusioned at the prospect of further cuts, and Dr. Lipsman said he became "the lightning rod" for criticism.
The financial crisis was caused by the changing demographics of AIDS, Dr. Lipsman said. It no longer strikes primarily gay white men -- traditional donors to the group -- but has moved into poor minority groups. At the same time, new drugs are prolonging the lives of many people with AIDS -- increasing demand for the agency's services.
There were also political problems. Dr. Lipsman angered members of the gay community by supporting a state law requiring AIDS patients to report the names of their sexual partners. He said the issue was one of the few on which activists and public health officials disagreed. The decision for Dr. Lipsman to leave was mutual, he said.
Dr. Lipsman, who is gay, said he was pleased that his new post is in "a politically progressive community." But he added that working in the public sector was different from working for an agency.
"As someone who is in charge of the health department for the entire county of Westchester, it's important that I remain neutral in terms of my personal identification," Dr. Lipsman said. "I am the health commissioner for everyone, male and female, gay and straight, black and white."
Susan Tolchin, a spokeswoman for County Executive Andrew J. Spano, said of Dr. Lipsman: "His life style was never an issue. He was hired because of his background in public health. We did a nationwide search, and he was at the top of everyone's list."
Dr. Lipsman said one of his first priorities as commissioner would be working on the West Nile virus. He also intends to focus his efforts on preventing smoking, which Dr. Lipsman said was the single most preventable cause of death and disease.
"My philosophy," he said, "is that we need to pay attention to the diseases that are either the most deadly or affect the greatest number of cases."
The West Nile virus, which is carried by mosquitoes, is frightening because it is unpredictable and can be lethal. Dr. Lipsman said he hoped to avoid aerial spraying of pesticides. Instead, he plans to focus his department's efforts on prevention -- by educating the public about emptying standing water on their property and using larvicide in catch basins.
He said that since the West Nile virus is so new -- it was only seen in this hemisphere for the first time last year and there has yet to be a full season of it in Westchester -- he wanted to proceed cautiously. "We could have an outcome which ranges from a very relaxed summer with little, if any, activity, or we could have a case number that is larger than last year," he said. "We have no way of knowing." As with other diseases carried by insects, like tick-borne Lyme and Erlichiosis, the Health Department will urge traditional precautions like the use of insect repellent and covering exposed flesh.
Dr. Lipsman said it was a particularly exciting time to be working on antismoking measures, because money from the tobacco settlement is trickling down to the county.
Environmental health will also be a focus, with special attention given to reducing the use of pesticides. "You can make people as healthy as you want, but if you're living in an environment that is unhealthy, it kind of undoes all that good work," he said.
Dr. Lipsman, who began his new job this month, runs a department of 400 employees with a budget of $125 million this year. He replaced Dr. Harold N. Adel, who retired in January. Though now living in Manhattan, Dr. Lipsman plans to move to the county, where he hopes to indulge his love of sailing. He said he also likes exercising, reading and attending plays and the opera.
"Working in Westchester is tremendously exciting and appealing," he said. "It has all the key ingredients -- public health problems that are complex and challenging, as well as the financial resources and the will to address these needs."

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 1; Column 3; New Jersey Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: The Second Great Wave;
Hispanic Immigrants Are Changing the Face of Central Jersey

BYLINE: By RICHARD BRAND 

DATELINE: PRINCETON

 BODY:
IT is 6:30 p.m., and there isn't an empty seat at St. Paul's Catholic Church at the church's busiest service on the holiest day of the year. Father Javiar Diaz, reading from a Bible written in Spanish, gives the Easter Mass while hymns are accompanied by Mexican guitars.
The parishioners -- many dressed in worn jeans and mud-stained sweatshirts -- line the pews at the stolid brick church on Nassau Street. They come from places like Oaxaca, Mexico; Santa Rosa, Guatemala; and Havana, Cuba. 
 There weren't always standing-room-only crowds at St. Paul's. Two years ago, only a third of the pews were filled on Easter Sunday. And less than a decade ago, there was no Spanish-language Mass at all.
"This is a growing community, one with many needs," Father Diaz said. "They are people who work very much and make very little. The majority don't have social security or medical security. Yet they pay their taxes, because they have enough problems in their lives."
It is in church that Hispanic immigrants find the pervasive Roman Catholic culture they left behind, one in which the priest and the church are the center of private and community life.
The crowd at the service is just one reflection of the recent flood of Hispanic immigrants to central New Jersey, one that immigration experts say rivals the great wave of European migration of the late 19th century. And Newark International Airport, where about 55,423 international flights land each year, has replaced Ellis Island as the port of entry.
From Bound Brook to New Brunswick to Princeton, the state's Hispanic communities are larger and more vibrant than ever before. The United States Census Bureau says the state's Hispanic population grew to more than a million people in 1999 from 739,861 in 1990.
More startling, perhaps, is the bureau's prediction that Hispanics will surpass blacks as the largest minority group in the state by 2004. Puerto Ricans and Cubans now make up the largest Hispanic groups in the state, though most immigrants in the last five years have come from Central and South America.
"We are going through the second great wave of immigration in the history of this country," said James Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers. "New Jersey has always been an immigration gateway, and it is getting a large share of what is a far more heterogeneous immigration boom."
As was the case in the late 19th century, when European migration underpinned the rise of New Jersey's urban manufacturing economy, most of today's immigrants are drawn by the prospect of better-paying jobs in towns like Princeton, where help-wanted signs are ubiquitous.
The boom in central New Jersey's economy has been fueled by the growth of electronic, biotech and information industries. Indeed, Route 1 has become a busy corridor of steel and glass office parks; and to the west, a number of luxury housing developments have helped the "Wealth Belt" earn its nickname.
With such prosperity, professionals in the area have more money than ever, and unemployment in the state is below 4 percent. As a result, service-level jobs in kitchens, automobile repair shops and landscaping companies are abundant in an area where Mercedes Benzes and BMW's are almost as common as stop signs.
But with so many opportunities, there are also major risks. Practically all of the undocumented immigrants seized by the Immigration and Naturalization Service will be sent back to the countries they came from, losing the investment of many years' wages to make the journey.
So far 38-year-old Pedro Sanchez Rodriguez, who has been here for less than a month, has not yet found a job. No reason to worry, though said Mr. Sanchez, because "there are many places to work."
Instead, he worries about his undocumented status and repaying the relatives who scraped together $3,000 for him to make the journey from Oaxaca, Mexico. He worries about his wife and two children still there, to whom he will send money when he gets some.
"It was a risk to come here," he said in Spanish. "I don't speak English. I have $20 in my pocket, a friend with a house and the clothes I am wearing. I know there is work, even though I have not found it yet."
Lynn Durko, a spokeswoman for the immigration office in Newark, says there are an estimated 143,000 undocumented immigrants in New Jersey, although she cannot not say how many are Hispanic.
The growth of the Hispanic community in central New Jersey is rooted in several historical processes. Hispanic immigration first became a significant trend in the New York metropolitan area when Puerto Rico became a Commonwealth of the United States in 1952. In addition, the effects of regularized air travel combined with aftermath of the Cuban revolution in the 1950's led to the expansion of Cuban and Puerto Rican neighborhood in North Jersey, most of them in Hudson County.
In 1965, a revised immigration law gave preference to immigrants seeking to reunify families in the United States, and it increased quotas from non-European countries that in the past had been excluded.
"At some point by historical accident, these communities provided a comfortable, transitional environment where newcomers felt comfortable,"
Mr. Hughes said, explaining why Hispanics were drawn to this area. "You always have newcomers coming to a node and expanding it."
In the same way that Union City developed a large Cuban community in the 1950's, towns in central New Jersey like New Brunswick, Hightstown and Bound Brook have recently been the destination of choice for Mexicans and Guatemalans.
Moreover, the overwhelming majority of these newest immigrants are men. Some are like Mr. Sanchez: heads of households taking a gamble on America. Others are young men seeking a better life.
Mario Barias, 22, remembers being a migrant farm worker in Guatemala, a country with an annual per capita income of less than $675. "Depending on the season, we would pick beans, corn and coffee," Mr. Barias said. "It was very difficult."
Mr. Barias is now cleaning dishes at a restaurant in West Windsor, making the minimum wage of $5.25 per hour.
"The jobs here are much easier and more relaxed," he said. His one regret is that he has not spoken to his parents or brothers since he left his hometown of Santa Rosa four years ago.
While some new immigrants intend to earn some money and return home, many others come to settle in the United States and start families.
Less than a mile from Nassau Street's tony boutiques and restaurants one recent night, Flabio Cortez Gonzalez, 30, ate dinner in a parking lot outside the one-bedroom apartment where he lives with his wife, nephew and two children.
"It's cooler out here," he said as he spooned from a bowl of rice, chicken and frijoles.
Inside, his wife, Venoria Gonzalez Cortez, prepared soft tacos, boiled peppers and grilled chicken. Smells of grease, plantains and burnt cheese hung over the stove. The hot oven inside and relentless heat outside caused Ms. Gonzalez, a native of Oaxaca and no stranger to warm weather, to sweat heavily.
"We turn the air-conditioner on only when we are sleeping," Ms. Gonzalez explained. "Electricity is very expensive."
Mr. Cortez says he and his wife can barely afford the rent of $975 a month for the apartment behind a small bodega; he works at a nearby stable, feeding horses and cleaning stalls, and she at a restaurant.
The apartment is decorated with a giant stuffed Tweety Bird, Porky Pig, and Sylvester the cat. "The children like them from television," Mr. Cortez says.
Their two children, Flabio, 5, and Lizbeth, 2, are American citizens born in Princeton, where the family hopes to stay because of the highly regarded public schools.
Luxury comes in the form of large Sunday-night dinners and three annual trips to the Six Flags amusement park.
Mr. Cortez says the couple came to the United States in 1988 from Oaxaca "because of the need to do something with our lives, to have money to buy a house, buy a car and help my parents economically."
Not all of New Jersey's newest Hispanic immigrants came merely to tap the employment opportunities on the bottom rung of the ladder. To be sure, engineers, academics and entrepreneurs make a significant portion of the new immigrants, especially since the immigration agency now gives preference to those with high-tech skills.
A handful of New Jersey companies recruit abroad, and a growing number of Latin American-born people with doctorates are streaming into the New Jersey work force after graduating from Rutgers and Princeton Universities.
In 1993, the New Jersey Department of Labor reported that a survey had found that 30 percent of the state's Hispanics earned from $25,000 to $50,000 a year, and almost 15 percent earned more than $50,000.
Indeed, a good number of Hispanic earners chose to start their own businesses. The 11-year-old Statewide Hispanic Chamber of Commerce of New Jersey says it represents 30,000 businesses.
"Without the Latino entrepreneur, New Jersey's cities would be falling into urban decay," said Guillermo Beytagh-Maldonado, the executive director of New Brunswick's Puerto Rican Action Board and a board member of the chamber, which says it represents 30,000 businesses. "If you go through New Brunswick, you'll see that that Latino entrepreneurs are the owners of the mom-and-pop shops."
Many of the state's middle-class Hispanics are second-generation Americans whose immigrant parents had struggled to make ends meet.
Jeffrey Vega, 33, is the vice president of New Brunswick Tomorrow, one of the most active Hispanic community organizations in the state. He remembers how his Peruvian-born mother worked at a Revlon factory in Irvington even though she barely understood English. She encouraged him to study hard, and he became the first in his family to attend college.
Now Mr. Vega, a graduate of Rutgers, is the family's main breadwinner, and he just bought a house in Highland Park that he shares with his mother, sister and nephews, and he regularly sends money to relatives in Peru.
"It's really the experience of the Latino family in the U.S. that you have somebody who has gone to college, become educated and has a career while the rest of your family still lives somewhat in poverty and is still struggling," Mr. Vega said.
Most economists agree that the influx of immigrants to New Jersey has helped sustain the state's recent economic growth by providing labor in a tight market.
"We are a labor-short nation and New Jersey is a labor-short state," Mr. Hughes said. "So absent immigration, we'd be in trouble."
He added, "Immigrants push forward the economy through their labor and tax revenue contributions, and immigrants that are both documented and undocumented give to taxes more than they get from government benefits."
While their ability to pay taxes has indeed been tapped, their potential political clout has not.
Mr. Beytagh-Maldonado asserted, "Hispanics can be a swing vote in close elections nationwide, and it behooves politicians to pay attention to us."
Only recently have politicians have taken note of the swelling Hispanic vote in the region, saying that what the community lacked in its ability to donate money to campaigns it made up for in turnout.
In the 1996 Presidential election, for instance, about 248,000 Hispanics voted in New Jersey, accounting for 7.6 percent of the state's total turnout, the Census Bureau said. The National Association of Latino Elected and Appointed Officials projects that almost 328,000 Hispanics will vote in the 2000 election, comprising about 10.2 percent of the overall turnout.
Although Hispanics actually have lower voting rates than non-Hispanic groups, the lag is attributed to the fact that the median age for Hispanics in the country is about 26 years, compared with 36 years for non-Hispanics. In addition, noncitizens -- who make up about 25 percent of the Hispanic population -- are not allowed to vote.
Still, most of the Hispanics who can vote ultimately do.
"In many cases it is because they left countries where they lost that right, and they are very conscientious of it," said Representative Robert Menendez, whose Union City constituency includes a large Cuban population. "Or they came from countries where political activity is very high. This is where the community has used the power of its votes to maybe offset the power of donations. And it has done that quite significantly."
More and more frequently, Hispanics themselves are running for office in the state -- and winning.
"In 1986, I became the first mayor of Hispanic descent in the state's history," Mr. Menendez said. "Now you have several Hispanic mayors. Where I was the only Hispanic legislator in the state at one time, you have now five and literally dozens who are councilmen. In less than a decade, you've gone from one in all those categories to something like 30 to 40. There may be even more."
As the November election draws near -- at stake is the presidency, a Senate seat and the House seats -- the ability to woo the Hispanic vote will be crucial.
"Hispanics are becoming a real focus for political actors on both sides of the aisle," Governor Whitman said in a recent interview, citing a growing number of Latino political action groups in the state.
Although politicians are beginning to seek out Hispanic voters, financing of programs to improve their plight has been slow to come.
"We are contributing to society more than we get out," said Mr. Beytagh-Maldonado.
In 1994, the Urban Institute, a research organization in Washington issued a report, "Immigrants and Immigration, Setting the Record Straight," which said that for every dollar a recent immigrant pays in taxes, he or she receive 37 cents in government benefits.
Over all, it said, annual taxes paid by immigrants to all levels of government offset the costs of services received, generating a net annual surplus of $25 billion $30 billion.
Most federal and state social services are not available to noncitizens, even to those who are in the country legally. Part of the problem is that the government cannot provide services to populations that it does not officially acknowledge.
Hispanic community leaders charge that in 1990 the census undercounted Hispanics, and because of that that funds allocated for community programs are insufficient.
"There were a lot more than 700,000 in 1990, and there's a lot more then a million now," said Mr. Beytagh-Maldonado. "There is a major undercount problem."
Even though the census bureau has invested tens of millions of dollars in advertisements encouraging Hispanics to fill out census forms, Mr. Beytagh-Maldonado said he was concerned that an undercount of Hispanics in 2000 was inevitable. "Many are here undocumented, and they won't allow themselves to be counted," he said.
New Jersey's Center for Hispanic Policy, Research and Development, which was founded in 1975 to distribute funds for community-based projects, has an annual budget of $1.625 million to divide among almost 80 programs statewide. "It's not enough," said Mr. Vega of New Brunswick Tomorrow. "It's not a lot of money."
Mr. Vega, who is the chairman of the center's advisory board, said: "But I don't want to criticize the government because the Whitman administration has been more open to help the Hispanic community than any other administration. Our budget before Whitman was $1.25 million and she was the one who advocated the increase."
The Hispanic community has pulled together to do many of the jobs the government does not finance.
"We are the organizations that are taking care of the newly arrived immigrants," said Mr. Beytagh-Maldonado, who is also the president of the Hispanic Directors Association, a coalition of 27 Hispanic community-based organizations across the state that run preschools, health clinics, youth volunteer groups, housing services and English classes.
While most of today's immigrants are seeking the same opportunities as the Europeans of generations ago, community leaders fear that the American Dream may now be more difficult to achieve. They cite Hispanic dropout rates in some school districts as high as 38 percent, a growing illiteracy problem and efforts by lawmakers to exclude immigrants from welfare benefits.
"A lot of people that talk about immigration issues really use their own experience as a basis to make judgment about those that are now coming," Mr. Vega said. "They say, 'Well, my grandfather migrated to this country and he was able to make it. Why can't you?' And that's a view that tends to blame the victim. Back several generations ago if you didn't have an education, that was fine. You could make a decent earning. You could make a living wage. Today, if you have no technical training or hard skills, you can't survive."
He added, "Will the community advance and be equal to other communities? I don't know if it will happen in my lifetime, but I like to think that it will, but it's not going to be at the same rate as the immigrants of the past."

HEADLINE: Looking for the Right Man in Bridgeport

BYLINE: By FRED MUSANTE 

 BODY:
MANY Roman Catholics of the Diocese of Bridgeport were proud that their bishop, Edward Michael Egan, had been chosen as archbishop of New York to succeed Cardinal John O'Connor, but there were also sighs of regret.
Bishop Egan is widely popular among many parishioners and clergy of the diocese, which consists of Fairfield County, for what they say are his gifts as a homilist, his support of Catholic charity and education, his attention to spiritual matters in the parishes, and for improving the financial condition of the diocese. 
 According to several parish priests and church officials, what the 360,000 Catholics of the diocese want the most in their next bishop is a man who possesses many of the same qualities as Bishop Egan and is able to expand on his record.
"The concern is that we continue the programs that we have," said Monsignor Alan Detscher, ecumenical officer for the diocese, "and most bishops, when they come in, don't try to make too many changes right away."
Fairfield County is geographically small, but complex, said Dr. Anthony Cernera, president of Sacred Heart University. Some parishes are poor and others wealthy, and throughout the parishes are enclaves of immigrants. "It defies simple answers," he said.
Dr. Cernera said that the next bishop would have to be "someone who's going to understand the needs of that struggling immigrant in Bridgeport and also the corporate executive who's also a member of the diocese."
When Bishop Egan arrived in the diocese in 1988, he was fluent in Latin and Italian, but he soon learned Spanish and would frequently preach in Spanish and English when celebrating Mass at predominantly Spanish-speaking parishes, said Monsignor Aniceto Villamide, the diocese's vicar for Hispanics. "People were very happy with that," he said.
The next bishop won't have to deal with many of the difficult problems that the diocese faced when Bishop Egan arrived. At that time, the economy was moving into recession and many of the parishes in poorer neighborhoods, and their schools, were feeling the pinch.
Bishop Egan closed some Catholic elementary schools that were poorly attended or dilapidated, and regionalized the school system so that the remaining 33 elementary schools were supported by all the diocese's 88 parishes, not only by each one's individual parish.
Along with his streamlining and reorganization of diocesan operations, this eventually put the diocese on firm financial ground.
"Financially, he straightened the place out," said the Rev. Michael Jude Fay, pastor of St. John's Church in Darien.
Bishop Egan also started the Inner City Foundation, a semi-autonomous fund-raising organization, to raise money in support of the parish schools and Catholic Charities of Fairfield County. The foundation's director, Richard Stone, said that since 1992, it has raised $9.5 million to help the poor in Fairfield County. The money has been used to open health clinics and job-training programs, and grant scholarships to families to send their children to Catholic schools.
"People usually think of Fairfield County as a very wealthy county, but there are many needy people in the cities of Bridgeport, Norwalk and Stamford," Mr. Stone said.
The reorganization of the diocese's parish schools made a big difference, and coming, as it did, just ahead of a resurgence of the school-age population in the state, it was fortuitous. In addition, Bishop Egan also raised a $55 million endowment for the diocese's five high schools and implemented improvements in school budgets.
"He changed the paradigm from parochial to regional," Armand Fabri, the diocese's superintendent of schools, said. "The demand was always there, but affordability was an issue."
As a result, the next bishop can look forward to leading the diocese's Catholic schools in an expansion drive. Mr. Fabri said plans are being made to reopen some of the schools that had been closed and to build additions on others to meet the demand for Catholic education.
Another area in which Bishop Egan was very successful, and where there is a high interest in seeing a continuation, is in priesthood vocations. Six months after his appointment as bishop of the Diocese of Bridgeport, Bishop Egan started the St. John Fisher House, a residential seminary in Stamford, and he was responsible for attracting many of the seminarians who have trained there.
Since 1965, said the Rev. Chris Walsh, the spiritual adviser at the seminary residence, there has been a 21 percent decline in the number of Catholic priests in the United States. The Diocese of Bridgeport has stayed even, but even at the current rate of increase Father Walsh said it doesn't have enough priests to meet the expansion of parish services that is foreseen in the coming years, something the next bishop will face. "I hope for someone who will be identical in terms of his dynamism and commitment toward vocations," he said.
Monsignor Villamide said Bishop Egan's success attracting men to the priesthood has been particularly helpful in expanding Catholic ministry to Hispanics and other immigrants in the cities in the diocese. When Bishop Egan came to the diocese there were only three Hispanic priests and seven parishes with Spanish ministries, and now there are eight Hispanic priests and a number of non-Hispanic, Spanish-speaking priests, and Spanish ministries at 12 parishes.
He said three new Haitian priests were ordained in the last three years to preach to Haitian immigrants, and a Vietnamese priest was newly ordained as well .
Until a new bishop is appointed, Monsignor Greg Smith, director of the Institute for Religious Education and Pastoral Studies at Sacred Heart University, said Pope John Paul II will probably appoint an administrator to run the diocese.
Monsignor Smith said he doubted a new bishop would be appointed before September, because decisions like that are usually not made during the summer.
Meanwhile, a Vatican official will consult with American bishops to compile a list of names to submit to the Pope for consideration, Monsignor Smith said.
He said he thought that the church's hierarchy would look for someone who is a leader, has shown loyalty to Pope John Paul, had demonstrated spiritual qualities, and has pastoral and administrative ability.
But continuing those programs that Bishop Egan started, particularly with regard to Catholic education and the priesthood, would weigh heavily in Rome, he said.

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Taking Inspiration From Brecht

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN 

 BODY:
IT'S all in the title. "The Good Person of New Haven" reflects the best of intentions: To be a good person in a bad world. You can't get much better than that. Talk of what's in a name: New stands for redemptive change, saving grace, hope eternal. And doesn't everyone hope for a safe haven? As for person, the word is human, gender-free.
What better notion than to adapt time-honored traditions of classical theater to the immediate concerns of a contemporary urban community? And the thrust of arts in education, with an emphasis on diversity, is on the minds of every concerned artist and educator. 
 It is no wonder that the Cornerstone Theater Company, based in Los Angeles and traveling everywhere, is applauded for its effort to make the classics fit time and place. And the company is welcomed by communities that need the reinvigoration and enlightenment that theater does best. Think live, interactive, collaborative, participatory, all terms that transcend ego and personal gain. Cornerstone puts such ideals into practice, moving into cities and setting up workshops involving students, elderly people, community leaders, business executives, volunteers of all stripe -- and, for example, resetting Shakespeare to nourish dreams and lift spirits.
At this time the company and its specialists are exploring New Brunswick, N. J., attempting to design a theater piece for the George Street Playhouse and neighboring Crossroads Theater Company. Such work does not happen in a flash. In August 1998 the much-talked about New Haven Project was born. "The Good Woman of Szechwan," by Bertolt Brecht (1898-1956), was the chosen classic, to be adapted by Alison Corey and directed by Bill Rauch, Cornerstone's founders. Participants in the work were selected from Fair Haven, the Hill, West Hills, Wooster Square and Newhallville.
A workshop production took place at Long Wharf Theater's Stage II last June. Every theater student knows that a Brechtian ground rule is epic theater and one of Cornerstone's missions is to make possible that impossible dream in the world of corrupt economics, in and out of theater. By casting non-professional actors with Actors Equity performers, "Good Person" was put on with a cast of 34, 10 of them professional.
So far, so good. But the place, however purposeful, of "Good Person" in the Long Wharf main stage season's repertory seems dubious. Brecht's plays are rarely performed, not just because of cast size, but because they have seldom been popular or understood (with the obvious exception of "Three Penny Opera").
"Good Woman" was produced only twice in 50 years in New York, and not since 1970 at Lincoln Center. Both times, the play served more as a display piece for a great actress -- Uta Hagen in 1956, later Colleen Dewhurst -- than as effective theater or political message piece. Brecht's detractors have referred to his plays as tracts sermonizing worn-out ideas. But the theatrical credo of the playwright cannot be entirely overlooked.
Conveniently, the New Haven production uses the epic part and reinvents the political and the moral for the purpose of raising the self-esteem of a city and making its people -- consequently, one presumes, all people -- count.
Musical interludes, a great Brechtian device, are superbly interwoven here in calypso, rock and jazz. So is narrative, in the striking person of Quinn, the can man, first seen pushing a supermarket cart on the New Haven Green. His litany of good will groups (Latino youth, all the AIDS programs, Community Gardens, City Kids) and local lures (the pizza) is terrific bravura stuff, performed by Christopher Liam Moore, the star of this occasion.
Also true to Brecht, as translated from the German by Ralph Manheim, is Ms. Carey's fitfully arousing attempt to alternate slang and lyric language. But the ideas and techniques are simplistically reiterated.
The playwright's global view was deliberately set in mythical territory and colored by supernatural forces, in order to stimulate objectivity; theater of alienation is the phrase and it is rarely workable. In New Haven, plot line is otherwise followed, the other worldly in the guise of stereotypical white tourists with very bad taste: a terrific notion.
But site specificity is antithetical to Brechtian beliefs. And the specifics would not be quite so bad if they weren't so often gratuitous and contrived. One script reference, however, is dead on: a visitor from another planet asks when Yale's next Black Panther rally is going to happen; he wants to be there. That would have made Brecht look away and smile.
Otherwise, there is no reason why angels cannot descend upon New Jersey, seeking the good person of New Brunswick. The set designer Lynn Jeffries' multipurpose backdrop, an artistically striking overview of the Interstate 95 overpass, is a fine Connecticut detail, though it must be added that David Zinn's costumes for the working class are either appallingly unsuitable or patronizingly appalling.
The saint (read good person) of New Haven is the golden-hearted prostitute Tyesha. With virtuosic intentions and variable results, Patrice Johnson is double cast as the good person and as her cousin, Taiwo Highwater, a capitalist. Taiwo exploits; Taisha recycles.
Throughout, the acting is uneven at best, except for the thoroughly excellent Christopher Liam Moore. And throughout, sermonizing and moralizing do not stop. Sample: "No one has a right to prevent a person from being useful." It is all for the possibility of doing good in this worst but changeable of all possible worlds.
"The Good Person of New Haven," Long Wharf Theater, 222 Sargent Drive, New Haven (203-787-4282). Performances through next Sunday.

HEADLINE: ZONING;
The City's Shapers

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Can Mr. Muschamp honestly believe that the city's real estate interests and officialdom concocted this revision to the zoning law in response to a fear that power in New York is shifting to the "cultural plane"? I would hope that one of the more public-spirited developers will invite him to sit in on a project meeting so that he can view firsthand what scant influence the self-referential world of academic architecture has on building in New York, or, for that matter, anywhere in the country.
Nearly 40 years since the 1961 zoning resolution was crafted to make New York safe for Modernism, perhaps half a dozen buildings of real architectural quality have benefited from its provisions. Countless others have cluttered the skyline and streetscape with cheap imitations of Corbusian models. A change in the resolution has long been overdue. 
 The purpose of zoning is to regulate the 99.9 percent of building which must relate to the city as a whole and which is, for good or for ill, driven primarily by economic and functional forces. All the Frank Gehrys of the world in fact rely aesthetically on background buildings to play off their experimental forms. Citizens and architects need to care about these background buildings as well as the monuments. Unfortunately, since too many architects and architectural writers seem only to be concerned with the five buildings per year that stretch the boundaries of formal language, it must fall to others to shape the development of our cities.
 
KEVIN M. SMITH
Westport, Conn.
 
The writer is an architect practicing in New York. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: A Building Transformed, Inside and Out

BYLINE: By CAROLYN BATTISTA 

 BODY:
WHEN people in New London say "Hygienic," they're usually not speaking of scrubbing their hands. They're referring to the Hygienic Building, a downtown landmark that dates to 1844.
Thanks to a remarkable grass-roots effort, the old building is now the Hygienic Artist Cooperative and Galleries. There, on a recent Saturday morning, volunteers briskly changed exhibits, while the six artists who live upstairs in co-op apartments gathered for a meeting. 
 A. Vincent Scarano, the president of Hygienic Art Inc., took a visitor around. After checking the second floor, which has two apartments, he kept climbing, to reach the four third-floor apartments with their sleeping lofts and bathrooms in what was once the attic. He pointed out features of the apartments, from original fireplace surrounds to brand new kitchens, in apartments that rent for $400 to $475 a month.
 The freshly renovated Hygienic (which got its name from a restaurant that opened there in 1929) is a place where artists can afford to live and work, and where galleries aim to draw all kinds of people, not just regular gallerygoers.
"It could be a model for other cities," Mr. Scarano said. But a while back, he recalled, "Nobody ever thought it would happen."
 Local artists used to hang out at the grubby (but welcoming) Hygienic Restaurant, and in 1979 they held the Hygienic Art Show there. The show had the motto "No judge, no jury, no censorship, no fees!"
When the lively anti-establishment show turned into a popular annual event, the artists organized into Hygienic Art Inc. to run it. After the restaurant closed in 1985, they moved the show to other spots around the city, but they always treasured the old building, with its distinctive flatiron front. So did preservationists.
In 1996 a bank announced plans to buy the Hygienic, which was by then a boarded-up eyesore, and to demolish it to create parking space. Horrified admirers rallied to gain an injunction, and, in 1997, after much negotiating, Hygienic Art members made a deal to buy and rehabilitate the building.
Up until then, the group's treasurer, James Stidfole said, "We had an annual budget of $2,200. For developing a building, we had the credibility of a gerbil."
Hygienic Art signed a contract with Christopher Widmer, an architect and the executive director of Alderhouse Residential Communities (who had already developed a limited-equity cooperative nearby) to renovate the Hygienic for nonprofit galleries and affordable apartments for artists.
 The Hygienic's four galleries include three on the first floor and one in what was the basement. The main gallery still has the restaurant's 1950's lunch counter and stools, where visitors often sit and talk.
"This is not intimidating space, like a stuffy gallery," Mr. Scarano said. "It's part of the community, common ground. It makes art accessible."
 The apartments, each about 1,000 square feet, have features for artists: big doors for ease of moving art, lots of light, extra sinks and easy-to-clean wooden floors.
"I love the fact that I have a good place to work," said Broderick Price, a painter who has been making tables of varied sizes for his apartment out of materials left from construction. "The whole building is a work of art."
 The completed renovation cost about $800,000, including $105,000 to buy the building. The state contributed $250,000; the city of New London, $142,000; the Fannie Mae Corporation, $10,000. Private foundations, businesses and groups contributed, and Hygienic Art raised about $275,000, including $100,000 in tax credits from the Connecticut Housing Finance Authority.
The group even held an auction where people bid not only on art but also on Mr. Stidfole's mop of gray hair, which was sheared off for $5,500.
 From the start, ordinary people in and around the city contributed time, money, materials and elbow grease.
Actual renovation began in January 1999, under the construction manager Paul McMasters. But the regular carpenters, sheetrock workers and other crews couldn't start until volunteers spent six weeks cleaning everything, from old furniture to dead pigeons, out of the building.
"Six weeks, eight big Dumpsters, 190 cubic yards," Mr. Stidfole said of the clean-up. He noted that volunteers worked throughout the project, doing whatever was needed. Some people, he said, "just walked in off the street and said, 'Can I help?' "
Volunteers are still coming forward to help, he said, and others offer gifts.
Last summer brought one of the most notable features of the renovation project, the women on the wall. Working on scaffolding on the south wall of the building, Terry (Davo) Davis, a Hygienic artist, and his assistants, Sarah Warda and Wendy Kuklinski, painted a 30-by-50-foot mural featuring five women, partially draped, who represent caryatids, sculptured female forms that appear to serve as architectural supports.
The galleries opened in late January with the annual Hygienic Art Show, back at the place where it started. As usual, it allowed one work per artist and included a wide variety, from sensitive watercolors to toilet bowls as art. A more conventional show came next.
 The most recent show was called "Handkerchief Art from Prison." Mr. Stidfole explained that inmates can buy handkerchiefs cheaply at prison commissaries, draw or paint on them, then fold them (without making lasting creases) and mail them to people outside. Such work is attracting academic attention, he said, and the Hygienic displayed more than 100 examples, some with matching envelopes.
 Hygienic Art Inc. will soon turn the building (its only debt is a $105,000 mortgage and a $90,000 low-interest bank loan) over to a new corporation, Hygienic Art Cooperative Inc. Each of the six residents will be a voting member; Hygienic Art Inc., which operates the galleries, will be a voting member.
Mr. Scarano noted that all too often artists move into affordable areas that soon become unaffordable. In New London, downtown property is becoming more expensive, but under the co-op arrangement, participants can manage the Hygienic, set rents, and not be squeezed out, he said.
 The resident artists, who moved in in February, must have incomes under $29,500 when they move in, put cash and sweat equity into their apartments, participate in a co-op training program, work some hours in the galleries, and exhibit their work in group and individual shows. They sign no lease but agree to follow the co-op rules for as long as they reside there. The residents all needed to finish and paint their apartments, as part of their sweat equity, before concentrating on their art.
Tekla Zweir, a sculptor who graduated last year from the Lyme Academy of Fine Art, pointed out the woodwork that she had just stained, with the help of a friend. "Now I've started working on this quilt-and-figure series," she said, describing her plans for relief sculptures with smooth figures against textured quilts.
 The artists will have a group show in June and individual shows at later times. Mr. Price, the table-making painter, is already planning his December retrospective, which will cover some 30 years of his work and include written pieces as well.
Life-drawing classes are under way, with still more activities being considered, such as a playwriting workshop and a drumming group. Jenn Collins, a Hygienic resident, has suggested a fall show of installations by and about the women of New London, women of all ages, races, social and economic levels.
"It's cool to live here," said Ms. Collins, who designed and made decorative elements for the recent renovation of the Garde Theater, just a few blocks away. "We've got an opportunity to create the scene."
 The Hygienic Galleries, 79-83 Bank Street, New London, are open Thursday and Friday, 4 to 7 p.m.; Saturday, noon to 10 p.m., and Sunday, noon to 6 p.m. The galleries' Web site is www.hygienic.org.

HEADLINE: Keeping an Eye Out for Beetles

BYLINE: By SAM LIBBY 

 BODY:
BECAUSE the Asian long-horned beetle has been found to be spreading in the New York metropolitan area, Connecticut state scientists are urging property owners to inspect their trees, particularly their maple trees, for the beetles.
"The extremely destructive beetle has been found in the New York metropolitan region, on Long Island and in Chicago," said Dr. Louis A. Magnarelli, of the Connecticut Agricultural Experiment Station. "Over 6,000 trees have been destroyed in those places in an attempt to stop the spread of the beetle, but it could have already spread to Connecticut," he said. 
 For now, the beetles are 50 miles from the Connecticut-New York border and have yet to be spotted in Connecticut.
"If the beetles were to become established in the state's forests they have the potential to leave large swaths of dead maples," said Dr. Jeffrey S. Ward, a station forester whose job is to monitor the health of the state forests. "The impact would be as devastating as the loss of American elm and chestnut during the past century," he said.
Dr. Ward said 40 percent of the state's trees are maples and their destruction would "even more dramatically alter the forests and cities that depend on the trees for landscaping and shade." "The brightest most vibrant colors of the fall foliage come from the maples," he added. "Without maples fall foliage would be vastly diminished."
In New York State the beetles have been attacking maple species including Norway, red, sugar, silver, boxelder and sycamore maples. Other known hosts are other hardwood trees such as horse chestnut, black locust, elms, birches, willows, poplars and green ash.
"There is no effective insecticide for the beetle," Dr. Magnarelli said. "The only way of controlling an infestation is to destroy affected trees by chipping or burning. The only chance we have to stop this is to have as many informed alerted property owners as possible looking for infested trees."
The Asian long-horned beetle is about an inch long, shiny black with bright white spots. The beetle has long, curved antennae that are longer than the beetle's body. In May the adult beetle emerges from deep inside an affected tree. When the beetles emerge from the trees they leave visible exit holes. The diameter of the hole ranges from a quarter-inch to a half-inch.
Beneath the exit holes, or in the branch crotches, piles of frass (insect waste and sawdust) may accumulate. The exit holes often bleed large amounts of sap. Defoliation and leaf damage appear when the juvenile beetles deep in the tree bore through the trees' tissues that carry water and nutrients to the trees' crowns. (Trees die from the crowns down.)
Station inspectors equipped with binoculars are searching for beetle-damaged trees throughout the state and this month they are doing surveillance almost every week day. Other inspectors are viewing aerial photos that would show a pattern of leaf damage indicating the beetles' presence. "We're looking in areas that have high concentrations of maple trees," said the deputy state entomologist, Carol R. Lemmon. "We're looking for any signs of defoliation or leaf damage particularly in the crowns of trees.
"I'm really scared this beetle will establish itself in Connecticut and take off," Dr. Lemmon said.
But Dr. Magnarelli said the situation isn't hopeless. "We have some things going for us," he said. "Although the beetle can fly as much as half a mile when it emerges in May, it usually re-infests the tree it emerged from or infests a nearby tree. It won't spread as fast as a gypsy moth infestation. It seems like the beetle only infests trees that are already stressed."
But for the last 20 years the Connecticut forest has been subjected to a series of harsh environmental stresses, Dr. Lemmon said. In the 1980's, gypsy moths defoliated trees throughout the state, there was a record drought during the summer of 1995 followed by the heavy snows of the winter of 1995-96. The warm winters and wet springs of 1997 and 1998 produced fungal blights on leaves, which further stressed the forest and resulted in muted fall foliage. Then there was last summer's record drought, she said.
Dr. Ward continued: "Trees in cities are always subject to high level of stress and may be particularly susceptible to the beetle. If the beetle were to become established, the cost of removing and replacing the trees and the decline in real estate values will have a severe economic effect in addition to the severe esthetic effects."
Maple, beech, hemlock and birch are known as the old-growth species. They are tree species that in many ways define the forest as we know it, Dr. Ward said. "Beech trees are presently being attacked by beech bark disease complex, the hemlocks are being devastated by the woolley adelgid," he said. "If the beetle were to establish itself in the state's maple trees, three of the four old growth species will be greatly diminished. What a mess this would cause."
Dr. Lemmon said the beetle has no known predators in China. There is some evidence that the beetle came from somewhere else and arrived in China relatively recently. (The beetle came to the United States in wooden crates sent from China.) Although the beetle was found to be in the United States in 1996 there is evidence that it has been in the United States since 1989. The beetle has been found in the New York metropolitan area, Amityville, N. Y. and Chicago. It is possible, Dr. Lemmon said, that trees are infested elsewhere but the beetle has not yet been detected.
In the end, dying infested trees can be dangerous to life and property, Dr. Ward said. The trees become weak and brittle as they are being eaten by the beetles and large branches can break away, especially during wind storms. For those reasons, Dr. Ward said it is important to find infested trees as soon as possible and destroy them.
If someone finds an Asian longhorned beetle, he or she should keep the specimen for identification and call the Department of Entomology (203) 974-8474 or 974-8600. An inspector will respond to the call.
