HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT;
A Short Leash For Camden

BYLINE: By LAURA MANSNERUS 

DATELINE: CAMDEN

 BODY:
Never has the state taken so firm a hand with an errant city. Last week, the Whitman administration dispatched yet more expertise to Camden, introducing a local-government expert from Cleveland as the newest member of the team settling in here to take control of the city's troubled finances.
After two years of limited fiscal oversight, the Local Finance Board in Trenton voted on May 10 to impose the highest level of supervision allowed by law. In the event that that is not enough, administration officials said last week that they want legislation enacted this summer to allow a full state takeover. 
 "I am afraid that without that authority in our hip pocket, we won't get the kind of cooperation we need out of some of the local officials," Govewrnor Whitman said on Friday. In the meantime, at a news conference Tuesday to introduce Prof. Sylvester Murray of Cleveland State University, the Commissioner of Community Affairs, Jane M. Kenny, promised "to get to the heart of where the issues and problems are."
But while television lights still hovered over Mr. Murray, city officials wondered aloud whether he knew what he was walking into or whether efficiency and integrity could change the reality of a city depleted of both resources and spirit.
Camden's city government had already been stripped of many functions: the state took over the parking authority in 1994 and put the police under the county prosecutor's supervision in 1998. The housing authority is under federal control. And a state-appointed task force has been overseeing the school board because of low test scores.
The pressure for a fiscal takeover notched up when Mayor Milton Milan, who had resisted the review board, was indicted March 31 on federal corruption charges.
"You can lower the deficit, which is treating the symptoms, but at some point you've got to treat the disease, and that's macroeconomic," the city clerk, Luis Pastoriza, said. 'Eighty percent of the people in Camden are on some form of government assistance. These people have got to be realistic."
Emphasizing that point, Angel Fuentes, vice president of the City Council, walked out before the news conference ended. "I left in frustration,"' Mr. Fuentes said later.
Like many here, Mr. Fuentes said the review board that has monitored Camden's finances since 1998 had been a failure. "People say, 'Look how those incompetent public officials waste taxpayers' money,' " he said. "We want to tell them we're struggling."
Mr. Fuentes tried to make the point to the review board, which held meetings here. He has kept the big color photographs -- a gallery of crumbling brick -- he had once presented to the board. "I told them, 'None of you live here. None of you would have your children play on these streets.' "
Professor Murray, a former city manager in Cincinnati and San Diego, does plan to live here, at least through the summer. Although he had never been in Camden before last week, he said: "I don't know that the city is lost, is dead. I believe in cities, I believe in people. I believe in communities."
A board member of the National Academy of Public Administration, an organization chartered by Congress, he will be working with its president, Robert J. O'Neill Jr., under a contract authorizing fees up to $500,000. For its part, the academy will advise the Local Finance Board, which has set up its operation in City Hall.
For now, the team is deciphering the city's books and management systems, which local officials concede are in disarray. While the state has the authority to replace department heads, Ms. Kenny said there were no plans "right now" to do so.
Still, the Local Finance Board chairman, Ulrich Steinberg, must approve any expenditure of more than $4,500, meaning that the city cannot install a traffic light or replace a police car without permission.
With such tight reins has come some chafing. Yet the ill will between city and state appears to be receding. After a meeting with Mayor Milan two weeks ago, Mr. Steinberg described it as "very positive."
But local officials continue to plead for attention to the still-bleeding tax base, which urban experts acknowledge cannot possibly support Camden. Already the city, New Jersey's poorest, receives 70 percent of its revenue from the state, up from 57 percent three years ago.
Howard Gillette Jr., a history professor at Rutgers's Camden campus who is writing a book on the city, said reliance on local property taxes -- which account for only 20 percent to 25 percent of Camden's revenue -- was starving the city.
Nor is the state likely to commit the kind of money needed "to get Camden back into the economic mainstream," Professor Gillette said.
Jeffrey L. Nash, the Camden County freeholder director, said, "We've been trying to convince the state for years to take a more active role."
Mr. Nash and state legislators from the area, all Democrats, have pushed for a recovery plan enlisting experts from Rutgers to rebuild Camden's crumbling infrastructure.
"The administration doesn't want to have to answer to the 85,000 residents as to why there is not enough police protection, why the streets are not being cleaned, why not enough houses are being renovated," Mr. Nash said. "The state of New Jersey has that responsibility but does not want to invest those dollars in Camden."
Gwendolyn A. Faison, the City Council president, said she and other city officials had no idea what the state's intentions were. While welcoming Mr. Murray at the news conference, Ms. Faison directed a faint scolding at the officials from Trenton for giving her short notice of the appointment.
"This is my city," she said. "This is my home. I want to know who youre bringing into my home."
At a City Council meeting that afternoon, she introduced Mr. Murray and the state team. In her office later, Ms. Faison sighed. "We do need the help," she said. "We can't afford to pay for it."

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
A Speedier Cleanup Sought at Brookhaven

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
A federal cleanup at Brookhaven National Laboratory should be accelerated to reduce its cost by about $18 million and remove contaminants sooner, Senator Charles E. Schumer said at a news conference at the laboratory.
Mr. Schumer said he would lead efforts to convince Energy Secretary Bill Richardson of the economic and environmental advantages of halving the cleanup, to three years. 
 The $18 million saving, Mr. Schumer said, would give the Energy Department more for cleanups at other laboratories while assuring that "different plumes that are moving toward different water sources" at Brookhaven were cleaned up more quickly.
But it was unclear whether other labs engaged in cleanups, including Hanford, Wash., and Oak Ridge, Tenn., would support a plan that initially increased financing at Brookhaven. The 5,300-acre Brookhaven property is contaminated by radionuclides, metals and chemicals in the soil and ground water. The laboratory has been a federal Superfund site since 1989.
The Energy Department budget currently includes nearly $261 million for the six-year cleanup, officials said. The cost of the three-year cleanup would be about $242 million, they said, with savings from lower overhead and management costs.
The laboratory director, John H. Marburger, said the faster cleanup "gets an issue off our backs that I think has been hampering us from making progress with the community and with our many constituents." The plan is also supported by a citizens advisory panel.
But a laboratory critic, Scott Cullen, the legal counsel for Standing for Truth About Radiation (STAR) of East Hampton, said contamination was too extensive to be cleaned up in three years "no matter how much money they get."
"It's a good idea to do the cleanup faster," he said. "But if after three years they referred to the site as being cleaned, it won't be the case." JOHN RATHER

HEADLINE: Bell Atlantic Stumbles, And Competition Suffers

 BODY:
Re: "Lots of Blame Going Around in (631) Glitches" May 7 .
Long Islanders' inability to call across Route 110 is the most damning evidence yet that Bell Atlantic's arrival in the new world of deregulated telecommunications has not only hit a shoal, but has succeeded in hurting virtually anyone who depends on the telephone. 
 There is no small irony that Bell Atlantic's crisis comes as the company has enlisted seemingly every telemarketer in North America to phone us during dinner to insist that its new long distance service is where we want to be.
In the last several months, the Public Service Commission fined Bell Atlantic for failing to permit viable local phone competition when it secured permission to go into long distance service. Now communication companies are filing complaint after complaint regarding a broad range of Bell Atlantic disconnects, 631 being just one of them. The commission should get Bell Atlantic's attention by levying a fine that is heavy enough to convince consumers that this is not how the telecom business is to be done in the 21st Century.
Genuine competition is supposed to be mean that utilities like Bell Atlantic work leaner, smarter, faster and better. Instead, they have created the Long Island Expressway of telephone paths.
 
ELIZABETH GALLAGHER
Executive Director
New York Consumers
for Economic Competition
Manhattan 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: COUNTERINTELLIGENCE;
Judith Krantz, Cinderella In Chanel, Shares the Plot

BYLINE: By Alex Witchel 

 BODY:
JUDITH KRANTZ may live in Bel Air, but she's a New York girl by birth and by temperament.
When she still lived in Manhattan, in 1962, she despaired of being able to glimpse John Glenn, the first American to orbit Earth, in a Fifth Avenue parade being held in his honor. So, she went to Saks, secured a corner dressing room with windows in the maternity department, and bought a king's ransom worth of clothes she didn't need in order to eyeball her idol. But when she returned her enormous purchase a few days later, Saks balked and canceled her account. 
 "I couldn't possibly do without a Saks charge," she said last week, back at Saks, whipping through racks of Yves Saint Laurent. "I wrote them and told them I had a miscarriage."
Mrs. Krantz, 72, recalls the fib in her new memoir, "Sex and Shopping: The Confessions of a Nice Jewish Girl" (St. Martin's). She writes: "Another step toward fiction? What's a short girl to do?"
This short girl -- 5 feet 2 1/2 inches, she says -- has done just fine. (Yes, her credit was reinstated.) Although she waited until her two sons were grown before publishing her first novel, at 50, the best-selling "Scruples," she has published nine more best sellers in the last 22 years, most of which I've read. They are my vacation indulgence, what I really read when I've righteously packed Thackeray. Her books transcend the Hollywood gloss of a Jackie Collins, the smarmy heat of a Danielle Steel. Rather, this Wellesley graduate does diligent homework on all aspects of the fashion business, and often the art, antiques and jewelry trades, spinning intricate plots jammed with industry details, which also offer inside looks at worlds of high-octane glamour. Though I've traditionally savored her books poolside, as pure escapism in today's runaway economy they've taken on a practical dimension: a woman's guide to rubies and Renoir.
If Ms. Krantz's books celebrating Porthault sheets and the women who love them seem oddly in style right now, their timeless appeal lies in their compelling Cinderella stories. A Judith Krantz heroine is beautiful (of course) but also smart, smart, smart. She learns a business along with the reader as she works night and day, overcomes emotional hardships (which only add depth to her natural beauty), and eventually, with the aid of a handsome, powerful man and the perfect Hermes bag, triumphs. No one whines. They act. The world bursts with possibilities.
It's a winning formula. Her books have sold 85 million copies in 52 languages. "The boys gang has always resented me," she said. "Sidney Sheldon, Irving Wallace, Harold Robbins. It was like 'How dare she do that?' And being from Hollywood, the press would describe my house as a mansion when it's a perfectly normal house. They made me the glamorous character from my novels, but those characters were written by someone in J. Crew sweats who's not glamorous at all."
 Well, maybe not when she's writing, but she was certainly turning heads at Saks. Though she said she was "out of uniform" by not wearing Chanel, she was flawlessly dressed in a pink and gray tweed pantsuit with a matching coat, custom made by a Milanese tailor. The Van Cleef & Arpels Bois de Rose, a white coral pin in the shape of a flower with diamonds at the center, reflected the luster of her South Seas pearl earrings and -- just as they do in her books -- seemed to add a glow to her ivory complexion. As she tore through the meager offerings of Gucci and Fendi with the sharp eye of a military commander, the sales staff instinctively stood back. They, not to mention their merchandise, were distinctly outclassed.
"Now look at that," Mrs. Krantz fumed, holding up a transparent lime green Fendi skirt and top. "Tell me, have you ever seen a woman in a restaurant in a transparent top? Well, me neither."
Gucci fared no better. "That is the worst knocked-off thing," she said, fingering a python print dress. "And the length is wrong. The fitter at Chanel will always say, 'Mrs. Krantz, hemlines are going down.' But I don't care. My skirts stay 19 inches from the floor. That's what looks best on me."
Though Mrs. Krantz is a clothes connoisseur, it is a mistake to think her books are about shopping, even though "Scruples" was the name of a fashion boutique. They are instead about the transforming power of clothes.
"I always use clothes for manipulation, to create an effect," she explained earlier at lunch at Le Cirque 2000. "With the right clothes, the character suddenly appears. In many cases, the clothes reveal a personality that was obscured by poverty. I write about clothes as magical things that can change you. I feel that women are comforted by having clothes and accessories. I have every scarf I've ever bought."
These days, Mrs. Krantz rarely goes shopping. "I can't stand it," she said of going to malls. "Anyway, California is not a dressed up place. At every dinner party people wear black, which annoys me. I don't wear black at night. I want to be more visible."
Among her other fashion dictums, Mrs. Krantz says, she has never worn jeans or a bikini (unflattering), swears by Hanro lingerie (no seams) and thinks that as an accessory "burgundy is the best neutral." She also declares that she doesn't "believe in plastic surgery below the neck" because people should diet and exercise. What about breasts? She shrugged. "So they droop," she said. "Certain things just happen."
Perched on a banquette in the restaurant, her coat bundled behind her, the writer in Mrs. Krantz took over from the strident fashion expert. She appeared small and tentative as she watched other women parade past, bedecked and bejeweled, as if they were characters in her books. The closer she observed, the smaller she seemed to become. You can see why she says that it is the character of the best friend that reflects her in her books, not the heroines.
"The heroine bears the burden of the plot and always has dramatic things happen to her," she said. "Her mother dies, her father dies, some guy leaves her. The best friend is along for the ride having a wonderful time, wearing crazy clothes that wouldn't be becoming to a heroine, who must have a certain dignity and gravitas. The heroines I create are all bigger than life. But the best friend is a life-size person." She smiled. "Usually short."
Her own outfit matched neither description; rather, it belonged to the grande dame character, the doyenne who long ago learned the value of quality. She kept talking as she ate her shad and bacon -- possibly the only woman in the room not picking at a salad -- and said that flying lessons had prompted her to start writing novels.
"I was always so afraid to fly, and when I finally learned how, I think it made me write 'Scruples'," she said. "I thought, What else am I terrified of doing? Writing fiction. I'm not sure why. I think I was a victim of a very good education. I majored in English literature and said, 'I know I can't do that, so why do it at all?' But there is a real place for a book that's not George Eliot but is still for intelligent women."
Another reason Mrs. Krantz may have waited, she said, was because of her mother. Mickey Tarcher sounds like a nightmare in Mrs. Krantz's memoir, though her independence was certainly exemplary. She dropped out of school at 14 to work in a candy factory to help support her family. After she married J. D. Tarcher, who became a successful advertising executive, she earned her college degree, a master's in economics and a law degree. She spent her career at the Legal Aid Society and her time at home raising, and often criticizing, her daughters, Judy and Mimi, and her son, Jeremy. She also endured a lifetime of cheating from her husband; when he died in 1960, she sold the weekend home he loved and its contents within two days. She dressed her children cheaply, withholding material rewards as consistently as she withheld emotional ones.
"My dream was that my mother would come home with a big package from Best with cashmere sweaters for me," Mrs. Krantz said, her voice growing full. "That's where I got the magic of clothes, because my mother didn't give them to me. If she had, I never would have known the power, magic and mystery clothes could have. Out of that yearning you get fiction."
It is probably no accident that in 10 Judith Krantz novels, six of her heroines have mothers who die when their daughters are younger than 8.
In her real life, Mrs. Krantz has been married to the film and television producer Steve Krantz for 46 years. Their son Nick is a stockbroker, their son Tony is the chief executive of Imagine Television, and the couple have two grandchildren.
For the first time in years, she hasn't started her next novel. "I have a crazy plan not to do anything and see what happens," she said. "I'd love to do something different, have a life change. There are so many things I don't know yet."
As she spoke, her blue eyes sparkled. And the air filled with the unmistakable sense of possibility.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Sallie Vest, Hassan Youssef Hassan

 BODY:
Sarah Benson Vest, the daughter of Lee Vest Mack of New Canaan, Conn., and the late George G. Vest, is to be married this afternoon to Hassan Youssef Hassan, the son of Noel Fahmy and Youssef Hassan of Alexandria, Egypt. Gail Noble, a justice of the peace of New Canaan, is to officiate at the home of the bride's mother and stepfather, Charles L. Mack.
The bride, 36, who is known as Sallie, is a geologist for Metcalf & Eddy, an environmental engineering company, working until last month on a water-management project in Gaza. She graduated from Franklin and Marshall College and received a master's degree in geology from Oregon State University. Her father was a partner in Cummings & Lockwood, a law firm in Stamford, Conn. Her mother, who is retired, was an agent at New Canaan Travelworld. The bride's stepfather retired as a vice president for operations at Citibank, in Long Island City, Queens. 
 The bridegroom, 36, is the deputy director of the commercial department of the Arabian International Construction Company, in Cairo. He graduated from the University of Alexandria and a received a master's degree in computer science from American University in Cairo. His mother retired as the principal of the Rushdy Secondary School in Alexandria. His father retired as a general in the Egyptian Police Force.
The couple met in Alexandria in 1996, when both worked on a United States Agency for International Development project to improve wastewater treatment.

HEADLINE: In Silicon Valley, Loyalty Means Paying a High Price;
Cultural Strengths Help Offset Loss of Paper Wealth

BYLINE: By ALEX BERENSON 

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif.

 BODY:
IN November, more than 100 employees of Calico Commerce were millionaires, at least on paper.
Today only 20 are. As Calico's stock has fallen 80 percent from its November peak, the rest have watched their fleeting wealth burn away like fog in the California sun. In April alone, Calico shares lost nearly half their value. 
 In Silicon Valley, where job hopping is a way of life and even robust companies regularly lose workers to start-ups dangling chances at instant wealth, a stock meltdown like Calico's might seem a recipe for disaster, prompting top employees to flee and crippling morale among those who remain.
But Calico, which makes software that helps companies sell products over the Internet, has weathered the storm so far, thanks to an intangible commodity that is supposedly even scarcer around here than out-of-work software engineers: the striking loyalty of its workers.
So far this year, only 15 of Calico's 330 workers have left the company. That translates into an annual rate of 12 percent, barely half the typical turnover at Silicon Valley companies, according to Steve Radford, who has surveyed salaries and turnover at high-technology companies for more than two decades.
Calico's stability is no accident, employees say. While many Silicon Valley companies depend largely on the promise of riches to attract and retain workers, Calico has gone a different route, using more than money to keep employees happy. The company tries to combine the openness and workplace perks common in Silicon Valley companies with the very uncommon understanding that employees sometimes have lives outside the office.
So far, the mix seems to be working. From Alan Naumann, Calico's chief executive, to Aleida Kolodzieski, an administrative assistant, employees interviewed at Calico's headquarters in San Jose last month said they believed in their company, whatever the stock market might think.
Of course they say that, a cynic might interject. But many Calico employees have put their money where their mouths are.
In March, five months after the company went public, restrictions on insider stock sales expired and Calico workers were free to sell shares and turn their paper wealth into cash. Few did. In fact, Mr. Naumann actually spent more than $2 million in late April to buy 150,000 shares on the open market, building his total stake in the company to 1.65 million shares.
Joe Schwartz, a 29-year-old manager who was Calico's 13th employee and has been with the company since 1995, said he shared that confidence. With more than 5,000 options, Mr. Schwartz lost more than $300,000 in paper wealth as Calico's stock price shriveled. Yet he remains a believer. "I would encourage my parents to buy, my best friends to buy," he said.
A strong company culture only goes so far, and even Mr. Naumann admits that his company will eventually start losing people if the stock price remains depressed. And it is hard to forecast what the immediate future holds for the company. Its products compete in a hotly contested market niche against offerings from specialists like FirePond and giants like Oracle. Though Calico's sales have grown steadily at 70 percent annually or better, reaching $35.6 million in the year ended March 31, its losses have widened as well, to $27.8 million -- a new-economy story that investors used to shrug off but now have little patience for.
Still, Calico's efforts to make its employees feel like partners seem for the moment to have cushioned the blow of the stock slump.
"The difference between good and bad management teams in the valley is their ability to manage through the natural ebb and flow of the business," said Roger McNamee, a venture capitalist whose investment funds own more than 5 percent of Calico. "This is a management team that understands the business that they're in. They made a conscious choice to run the business for the long term."
That choice makes Calico unusual -- and could help the company prosper over time, management consultants said.
The notion that employees and companies have a social contract with each other that goes beyond a paycheck has largely vanished in United States business. In its place is a free-agent culture where workers are expected to look out for themselves and switching jobs regularly is seen as normal.
BUT a few big companies, like Cisco Systems, Southwest Airlines and Men's Wearhouse, have found success by going out of their way to make employees feel valued, according to Charles O'Reilly, a Harvard professor who is writing a book about the cultures of successful companies.
"The average point of view is that loyalty is for chumps, that the longer you stay on the job, the stupider you are," said Fred Reichheld, a fellow at Bain Consulting who is writing a book about loyalty. "Most business leaders cannot tell you why their people should be loyal. They get it confused with obedience, or just staying there, or fear."
Instead, companies often try to combat turnover with big salaries and option grants. But Mr. Reichheld said that approach is self-defeating, because it works only as long as times are good and an organization can afford to pay a fairly small roster of stars above-market salaries.
Being honest with employees and giving them a chance to grow at their jobs builds loyalty in a way that money cannot, he said.
Mr. Naumann appears to have taken that lesson to heart. He shares lots of information with employees, holding monthly company-wide meetings to discuss where Calico stands relative to its competitors and internal goals. In addition, he hosts a monthly group breakfast for employees whose birthdays have fallen that month and solicits feedback from the group. That level of disclosure and communication is vital to building loyalty, Mr. O'Reilly said.
"The all-too-typical M.B.A. response is that people can't be trusted, and they're not very smart, so why would you give them this information?" he said. But companies that keep workers well informed find that employees come to feel they have a stake in the company, even if they own only a little stock. "Then people feel like owners, and they stick around even if the stock price dips," Mr. O'Reilly said.
OF course, Calico is not alone in fostering an atmosphere of openness. Young companies often share more information with their employees than bigger, older businesses; the gulf between management and the rank and file tends to widen over time. And some of Calico's other perks, like allowing employees to telecommute twice a week, are typical at young Silicon Valley companies where employees put in long hours.
But Calico does differ from its young cousins in some crucial ways. With weak or nonexistent human resources departments and a culture that puts work first, many young companies stumble when dealing with employees having personal crises. Not at Calico, said Rob Devine, a 32-year-old consultant who joined the company in June, six months before his wife died of ovarian cancer.
"Leadership two and three levels above was completely fair" in its treatment of him, Mr. Devine said. As his wife's health worsened, he said, the company arranged his work to minimize travel and offered him extra time off, an offer he declined because, he said, "it's important when you're in a situation like that to have something where you feel you're contributing."
Shelly Begun, Calico's vice president for human resources, said the company allowed an employee whose wife gave birth prematurely more than two months' leave to help care for the baby. "It is a huge deal for people that, when they have these types of situations, Calico will help to deal with them," Ms. Begun said.
Nancy McDermand, a manager whose grant of more than 10,000 options has just begun to vest, said she had recently turned down a job at a start-up that offered her "lots of shares" and more money, preferring to remain at Calico for its collegial atmosphere. "If it weren't like that, I could leave tomorrow," she said.
To maintain that spirit, Calico has made a concerted effort to seek out employees considered likely to fit into its culture, placing a premium on recruiting graduates directly from college or business school.
Hewlett-Packard and other successful technology companies "do superaggressive college hiring, because it's the only way to get people who fit in," said Mr. Naumann, an Iowa native who worked for Hewlett-Packard for five years after graduating from college. "We're trying to do the same thing."
Make no mistake, though, this is still Silicon Valley, the overnight-millionaire factory. Most Calico employees acknowledge forthrightly that tantalizing stock windfalls like those that were briefly within their grasp are a large part of what brought to Calico to begin with.
"The potential money that could be made getting into a company pre-I.P.O. really was a big consideration," said John Driver, Calico's director of field marketing.
So too, for many people in Silicon Valley, are bragging rights, and Calico's stock no longer yields employees much of those. "There is a gold rush mentality" in the new economy, said Barry Obrand, managing director of Russell Reynolds Associates, the executive recruiting firm. "For people who haven't made it in some way, shape or form, there's a sense that you haven't done as well for yourself or your family."
YURI SMIROV, an engineer who joined Calico last year after two years at a privately held start-up, looks at Calico's prospects through that lens. Working for a company that does not succeed is extremely costly in Silicon Valley, he said, because "time is becoming the most expensive resource."
"Time is something you lose and it doesn't come back," Mr. Smirov said.
Mr. Smirov, who emigrated to the United States from Russia in 1992 and earned a doctorate in computer science at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh, said moving from Russia to Pennsylvania was a smaller adjustment for him than moving from Pennsylvania to Silicon Valley. The people he met in Pittsburgh were white and middle-class, with "the same income, with the same interests," he said. "Here, people are stratified much more."
As for the stock, he said, "the hardest part is mismatching your expectations." Mr. Smirov, who will receive more than 25,000 options between now and 2003, used to think he would be able to buy a house large enough for his two children to have separate bedrooms. That prospect is now remote, but Mr. Smirov remains hopeful.
Housing is on the mind of Ms. Kolodzieski, the administrator with only "a couple of thousand shares," as well. She and her husband hope one day to move out of the condominium apartment they rent. "We want to have a family, and part of that equals buying a home," she said.
Mr. Naumann knows his staff's patience will not last forever. "Our total compensation packages have to be competitive, or we won't retain people," he said. But for now, the stock woes have, if anything, pulled the company closer together, he said. "The market's got it wrong, and we're just going to have to prove them wrong."
 
For a New Insider, It Was a Risk Worth Taking
OF Calico Commerce's 330 employees, John Driver might have the best reason to be upset with the company's plunging stock price.
Mr. Driver joined the San Jose-based software company as director of field marketing two weeks before it became a public company last October, scrapping a thriving business as an independent consultant. His take-home pay at Calico came to only half what he had been making in fees; to compensate, Calico promised him more than 25,000 stock options, a potentially huge payoff. (Typically for Silicon Valley, Mr. Driver will receive his options over four years -- one-quarter of the grant on his first anniversary with the company and the rest in equal monthly installments thereafter.)
When Calico shares soared to $75 in November, Mr. Driver's decision to join the company looked brilliantly lucrative. Even if the stock failed to rise any farther before 2003, he stood to reap more than $1.5 million from his options.
Not so now that Calico's stock has plunged by 80 percent, right back to the initial offering price of $14 a share. At that price Mr. Driver's options are worthless.
So does Mr. Driver, who has an 18-month-old daughter and another child on the way, regret his career decision now?
No, he said, for lots of reasons. First off, his stock wealth does not yet really exist, even on paper; it will only accumulate over time as his options vest. "I have a very practical view of the stock," he said. "Even if the stock was trading at 100 today, I don't vest until September."
Mr. Driver, who said he is a fan of Warren E. Buffett, invests for the long haul and has "actually never sold a stock," is optimistic that by the time the options are actually his to exercise, Calico shares will have rebounded.
"I think Calico at the moment is actually undervalued," he said. "We have a good strategy, a good management team. There's a market there, and Calico is going to get some of it."
Even if the stock does not recover, Mr. Driver said, he is glad he joined the company. He enjoys working there, and even on half his former pay he and his wife will be able to support their family, he said. And the chance to be a part of the action, instead of on the outside looking in, was too exciting to pass up.
"It was a gamble," he said. "It was a risk, and if things don't work out, you've really got to be okay with the outcome. I have a great life the way it is -- I have a great house, I have a little kid, another on the way. If I wind up making millions of dollars, it's a bonus. If it doesn't happen, I have a really good life." ALEX BERENSON

HEADLINE: AT THE GATE;
Uncertain Market Appetite For Dean & DeLuca Offer

BYLINE: By SANA SIWOLOP 

 BODY:
WHEN it comes to Dean & DeLuca, the Soho retailer of fine food and gorgeous kitchenware, New Yorkers are happy to spend $15 for a pound of rugelach or $2 for an Asian pear.
But will investors prove as eager to put money into Dean & DeLuca stock when the company offers shares in its initial public offering, expected in five to six weeks? 
 As of Friday, Dean & DeLuca -- which hasn't turned a profit in seven years -- had not set a price for the offering, nor had it announced how many shares it would sell. But the company hopes to raise about $69 million to finance a major expansion.
One of the first things an investor is likely to glean from the prospectus is that Joel B. Dean and Giorgio G. DeLuca, the company's founders, are no longer minding the store. Leslie G. Rudd, who holds 64 percent of Dean & DeLuca's shares, has been chairman since September 1995. And while Dean & DeLuca's flagship venue on lower Broadway remains one of Manhattan's culinary temples, the company has been opening stores nationwide for the past decade, and channeling money into its catalog and Internet businesses.
Today, Dean & DeLuca operates four other stores, in Washington; Charlotte, N.C.; Leawood, Kan. (a suburb of Kansas City); and St. Helena, Calif.
The company wants to open one or two specialty stores next year, and three or four stores in each of the five years thereafter.
Dean & DeLuca's expansion has not come cheaply. The company has not been profitable since the end of February 1993, a fact that must leave purchasers of Dean & DeLuca's $5 horned melons scratching their heads. And because of its expansion plans, the company expects to report sizable losses for the foreseeable future.
Last year, it lost $8.9 million on sales of $59.6 million, compared with a loss of $5.7 million on sales of $49.3 million in 1998, and a loss of $9.3 million on sales of $34.4 million in 1997. As of Jan. 30, it had $17.1 million in cash. Total debt stood at $3.2 million.
Still, the market for specialty foods -- Dean & DeLuca's largest business -- is growing, as is demand for premium-priced wine and upscale kitchenware. The prospectus forecasts United States sales of specialty foods alone to reach $54 billion by 2002, up from about $38.8 billion in 1997. And Forrester Research, a market research firm in Cambridge, Mass., estimates that sales of specialty foods online will rise from $248 million in 1999, to $6.3 billion in 2003.
So the company's expansion makes sense, industry analysts say. "Specialty food customers are the best food customers," said Phil Lempert, the editor of the Lempert Report, a newsletter in Santa Monica.
But competition is increasing. The Internet gives consumers access to the Web sites of food manufacturers, not just retailers. Evie Black Dykema, a Forrester analyst, cautions that online grocers like Webvan Group and general retailers like Amazon.com are expanding their specialty food offerings, too.
Others, like Ron Paul, president of Technomic Inc., a Chicago consulting firm, question whether it makes sense for a specialty food store to open so many outlets.
Mr. Lempert, for one, isn't surprised by Dean & DeLuca's losses. He thinks the future of specialty food retailing lies in companies either creating strong, content-filled Internet sites that keep customers coming back for more products, like Amazon, or building 40,000-square-foot superstores that can generate high sales. Dean & DeLuca's new outlets will average just 10,000 to 15,000 square feet.
And like a number of other food analysts, Mr. Lempert thinks the retailer's Web site needs a makeover. Dean & DeLuca is planning such an overhaul, according to the prospectus. It also plans to use its catalogs to promote its Internet business more vigorously by sending out about 13 million this year, compared with 4 million in 1999.
Still, the climate for new issues is tepid. And according to Steven Tuen, director for research at IPO Value Monitor, a research firm in New York, food-related initial offerings historically have not fared well, with many eventually sinking below their offering prices.

HEADLINE: MIDSTREAM;
A Sound Sleep and a Good Return

BYLINE: By JAMES SCHEMBARI 

 BODY:
MY PARENTS have long told me their stories of growing up during the Great Depression. I heard how my dad delivered groceries for a dollar a week and how his family ate meat once a week with the leftovers stretched, thinner and thinner, into the next few meals.
For my father, James, 76, especially, the Great Depression has had a lasting effect. He's eating much better now, but he refuses to put his money into any investment where he isn't guaranteed to get his principal back. 
 He's not stuffing money into mattresses, but his insistence on safety has meant he has sat out the bull market. Several of them, actually. My lectures on the dangers of inflation and the historical return of the stock market have not had as much effect on him as those sparse chicken dinners. He puts his money almost exclusively in certificates of deposit and savings bonds, and that's that. The man will just not listen to me.
"Dad," I say, "don't put all your money into C.D.'s. Diversify. Try some mutual funds."
"Too risky," he says. "I wouldn't be able to sleep at night."
The sleep indicator is as important to my father's generation as the G.D.P. is to mine. We get frustrated seeing our parents' life savings invested at 6 percent, but they expect to sleep very soundly when it comes to their money. Although our parents are very fond of us, often those feelings don't run deep enough to take investment advice from their reckless children.
Giovanni S. Testa, 43, of Livingston, N.J., said he has tried for years to get his father, Marino, 75, also of Livingston, to invest more wisely, but to no avail.
"With stocks, my father thinks he'll lose all of it," he said. "I try to explain risk to him, but he didn't understand it. Forgetaboutit. It was like talking to a wall, talking to my father."
Richard J. Nemec, 54, of Hinckley, Ohio, never could get through to his father, but he understood why.
"He tended to be quite nearsighted and ultraconservative," Mr. Nemec said. "Let's face it, when a man has gone through the Depression and World War II and then lived in a nice suburb, he gets very comfortable with his station in life. My father was a blue-collar worker and money came hard. He didn't want to take a chance on losing it."
Mr. Nemec's father died in 1992, and his mother, Lillian, 79, was more open to change. He had her meet with his planner, Paul A. Hrisko.
"It was a big change for her and she asked an awful lot of questions," said Mr. Hrisko, a certified financial planner who owns Paul Hrisko & Associates in Cleveland Heights, Ohio. "Is it safe? Is it guaranteed? What are my chances of losing my money? It didn't take one meeting. I had to come back several times. She was a bit nervous. The more I discussed it with her, the more she was willing to take the next step to a more aggressive portfolio."
Mr. Hrisko said children must explain the investments, and their risks, fully and clearly. Children should also help their parents clarify their goals to determine how much risk is acceptable: is the money for them, their children or their grandchildren? The key, Mr. Hrisko said, is the parent must trust the child.
The senior Mr. Testa moved slowly into mutual funds after his son persuaded him to see an investment adviser and he saw how diversification could keep his risk low but increase his return. Gail Rosen, 41, of Martinsville, N.Y., talked to her father for years about leaving savings bonds behind. He resisted at first, but he trusted her enough to move some money into mutual funds. Now he's hooked.
"My dad has a computer and watches his funds online," said Ms. Rosen, an accountant. "Now he tells me how I'm doing on my investments. He's so addicted that my mother hates it that he's on the computer all the time. Like some wives lose their husbands to golf, she's lost him to the computer."
HER father, Irving Horowitz, 72, of Monroe Township, N.J., said he changed after his daughter showed him how much money he was losing to inflation and taxes.
"She's an accountant, so I listened," he said, eventually moving money into funds and individual stocks. "Since I retired, I have made a hobby of it."
My father's hobby is his garden. And keeping his principal safe. I know his greatest concern is not for his children or his grandchildren, but for my mother, Mary. He wants to leave her secure and comfortable if anything happens to him. If his principal is safe, he knows she will be, too.
He could have a better strategy, but that's not a bad one. It's a heartfelt plan that this son is going to stop arguing with.

HEADLINE: BOOK VALUE;
Will Managers Relate To This Gripping Tale?

BYLINE: By FRED ANDREWS 

 BODY:
A DECADE or so ago, Dennis N. T. Perkins, president of the Syncretics Group in Branford, Conn., brought us "the moose on the table," the disarming metaphor that companies use to mention the unmentionable. He devised that impish but effective image as a way of coaxing business people into talking openly about the sensitive issues that hang heavy over a discussion but that no one dares mention.
Now Dr. Perkins, a management consultant whose clients include American Express, Bose, Citibank and Marriott, is back with bigger game in mind. He is a connoisseur of leadership in circumstances of great peril. His new book offers lessons in leadership "at the outer limits of human endurance -- the place I call The Edge." 
 This thoughtful work has the feel of a lifelong obsession. An Annapolis graduate, Dr. Perkins woke up to genuine leadership in Vietnam, a brutal and unforgettable academy. At one point he found himself in command of a Marine convoy running a bloody gantlet along Route 1 from Chu Lai to Da Nang. Caught in a withering ambush, shaken and confused, he urged his column forward, concluding that the risk of crossing an open field of fire was better than sitting tight in the bull's-eye of the killing zone. ("A man sits as many risks as he runs," Dr. Perkins quotes Henry David Thoreau.)
Dr. Perkins builds his corporate leadership text around the astonishing story of the British Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition, led by Sir Ernest Shackleton. In December 1914, Shackleton and 27 others sailed from South Georgia, an island in the Southern Ocean, bent on becoming the first to cross Antarctica on foot, a trek expected to take three months.
Instead, Shackleton and his troop endured more than 600 wretched days of endless cold, near-starvation, scanty shelter, misery and despair before they struggled back to South Georgia. Their ship became icebound and was eventually crushed.
For months, the party clung to an ice floe, but as the floe melted, the desperate men took to the frigid sea in open boats. They found a toehold on a small island, but that proved untenable, so Shackleton and five others struck out in a lifeboat for help 800 miles away across the world's most storm-swept seas. Barely surviving that ordeal, they then clawed their way across New Georgia's icy mountain ranges to safety.
Dr. Perkins offers us Ernest Shackleton as the model leader, a captain obsessed with the welfare of his men. Cautious or daring as circumstances required, Shackleton was a rock. An inventive and insistent cheerleader, he refused to let the enfeebled company give up. He insisted on maintaining equity and mutual respect, and he saved the most onerous tasks for himself. Incredibly, not a man died.
So far, so good, but what does all this have to do with meeting a payroll?
Dr. Perkins has distilled 10 principles from these survival experiences, and he offers them as a guide for business leadership at the edge (though it's never entirely clear what, in business, "the edge" means). The 10 principles, the backbone of the book, are expounded in the Shackleton saga. Taken out of that adventurous context, they seem mostly unexceptionable, if not routine.
"Never lose sight of the ultimate goal, and focus energy on short-term objectives." "Set a personal example with visible, memorable symbols and behaviors." "Minimize status differences." "Find something to celebrate and something to laugh about." "Reinforce the team message constantly: 'We are one -- we live or die together.' "
"Leading at the Edge" reads like two different accounts -- a gripping adventure story and an orthodox management manual -- that never really marry. To stitch the two together, each chapter on the Shackleton expedition concludes with questions and some "lessons for leaders." The lessons tend to be shopworn episodes from management lore, like Andy Grove's pivotal decision to get Intel out of memory chips or James Burke's handling of Johnson & Johnson's Tylenol tampering scare or Scott McNealy's resourcefulness at Sun Microsystems.
Dr. Perkins does include four business cases where he applies his principles in detail. Abstract and dry, lacking pertinent detail, the case studies cannot measure up to the survival saga. They tend to depict executives who obtained outstanding results by greatly improving communications with the rank and file. Jack Creighton revived Weyerhauser from mediocrity. Pat Russo led a turnaround at AT&T's Global Business Communications Systems. These executives' efforts, as impressive as they were, pale in comparison to Shackleton's: Ms. Russo gave subordinates her home telephone number. Shackleton led a terrifying sail across polar seas.
The only case that comes to life involved loyalty and devotion. It is the tale of Aaron Feuerstein's rebuilding of Malden Mills after its disastrous fire in December 1995. At 70, his life work consumed in flames, Mr. Feuerstein could have pocketed the insurance proceeds and retired. Instead, he vowed to rebuild his mill and save his employees' livelihoods. Struggling against enormous odds, Mr. Feuerstein and his loyal workers managed to get Malden's Polartek lines back in production within months.
Why do the two halves seem so out of kilter? In truth, precious few business decisions are made "at the edge," with life or limb in peril. Dr. Perkins argues that "the edge" of endurance can be subjective. "I've seen people more upset about missing deadlines or giving presentations than Marines under automatic-weapon and mortar fire." But we all know that business teams do not "live or die together." It is romantic (or foolish) to frame the stakes that way.
When a business fails, it is dismantled or reorganized; people lose jobs but most find other ones. Failure is a cleansing of the economy. If a chief executive falls short, typically he or she is given a comfortable departure, and a new aspirant comes in to tackle the job. Business problems are serious but not lethal.
One wonders how the valiant Shackleton would fare in today's business world. In his circumstance, the ultimate goal -- survival -- was indisputable. In today's bewildering environment, reaching agreement on fundamental goals may be half the battle. And though Shackleton's people might grumble or bicker, they were hardly free to listen to a headhunter and depart for a more promising enterprise.
SHACKLETON is the leader as father figure, a heroic provider who shouldered the weight and made the decisions. He had loyal lieutenants but not equals. He listened to others but chose the path himself. Today's business leader is less a hero than a first among equals, an enabler who inspires commitment and exists to bring out the best in his or her people. The talent is unwilling to rely so heavily on someone else.
"Leading at the Edge" has a wistful air. The lessons are shaped for warriors and adventurers but directed at managers, who are neither. At some level Dr. Perkins is looking for the ideal company commander. Only in the recounting of miraculous survival does the writing come alive -- not only the tale of the Shackleton expedition, but also of Steven Callahan, who, with indomitable ingenuity, survived 76 days in a five-foot rubber raft in the Atlantic, warding off sharks and spearing fish for food. Or the Navy patrol plane that crashed in the North Pacific, consigning the crew to two small life rafts. (Five of 15 died, but the survivors buoyed their spirits by chanting, "Toga, toga, toga," after John Belushi in "Animal House.") Or the Texan who, bitten by a coral snake, bit off the snake's head and used the snake's skin for a tourniquet.
Put that one in the office manual.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
Trading More Now For Less Later

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
BECAUSE it is so contentious, the debate over reforming Social Security draws plenty of attention. So it is easy to overlook that Congress has just reformed Social Security -- enacting a change that should have been contentious but somehow wasn't.
For the first time, workers in their late 60's have the choice of collecting a full pension regardless of what they earn. That can backfire. What America's senior citizens decide to do with this choice will affect their level of income -- or poverty -- in deep old age. Because of the way the new law plays to human nature, many might make the wrong choice, taking too much pension now and not enough later. Some already have. 
 "Waiting to collect benefits is basically betting that you will live beyond the average life expectancy," said Peter Orszag, an economist and Social Security expert at the University of California at Berkeley. That average for people who are already 65 is 81 for men and 84 for women, and rising for both. "When you give people in their late 60's the choice of collecting their Social Security benefits now, then you raise the odds of their being poor in real old age."
The mechanics are simple enough. Previously, people between 65 and 70 who earned more than $17,000 a year had their Social Security pension benefits reduced, and those who earned $52,000 a year or more had them postponed entirely, until they turned 70. As a quid pro quo, the monthly pension checks they ultimately received were higher.
Now people in their late 60's can earn any amount and still draw full pensions. But the old quid pro quo survives: people can still voluntarily wait until 70 to get larger checks thereafter. Those who take their pensions at 65 get a head start in total benefits paid, but those who wait will overtake them in their 80's, and the longer they live, the wider the gap will grow.
The monthly payment at 70, for example, would be $1,300 for someone who passed up $1,000 at 65.
Congress had been moving gradually in this direction, but the new legislation, signed by President Clinton April 7, completed the process in one leap. As a byproduct in this election year, the Social Security Administration expects to deliver $6 billion in extra pension money.
But that is politics. The real issues are work incentives and adequate income in very old age, particularly the latter. It is still possible to postpone collecting pension benefits until age 70, but hardly anyone has chosen to do so. Of 419,000 registered wage earners in their late 60's who were collecting either reduced benefits or none at all when the new law took effect, only 800 are still holding off until age 70.
WHAT does not mean the others have all actively chosen not to wait; many were probably swept passively onto the benefit rolls. To minimize its clerical work, the Social Security Administration sent out letters announcing that all 419,000 would receive full benefits automatically, unless they called a toll-free number and specifically opted to wait. Getting through on the often-busy phone line was not easy.
People who wanted to wait could also have sent back their first checks. But in defiance of a main tenet of mainstream economics, that people make rational decisions in their best interest, hardly anyone returned the checks. "People in their 60's in good health whose parents lived long lives should rationally choose to defer," said Henry Aaron, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution. "But there is a tendency to want your money now." Particularly when it is in hand and substantial; the first checks averaged $3,500, retroactively covering the first four months of the year.
There is a second irrational tendency among people drawing both paychecks and benefit checks: to spend the pension rather than save for future retirement, increasing the odds of poverty later. But Congress gave in to an irrational outcry from working people in their late 60's who complained with growing frequency that withholding benefits was an unjust "tax" on work.
"There is a real misperception out there that when the money is withheld it is gone; they will never see it again," said Kenneth S. Apfel, commissioner of Social Security. "The number of seniors who perceive this is not insignificant."
So Congress acted. Federal surpluses helped to make the action politically palatable. So did another misperception: that in a robust economy suffering labor shortages, removing the earnings limits would encourage senior citizens to work a lot more. The most optimistic studies fail to support this contention. Hours worked will rise 5 percent at most, or roughly the equivalent of 50,000 full-time workers a year. That is what today's strong economy absorbs in a week.
Maybe there is a lesson here for judging the Gore and Bush proposals for Social Security reform: Look for the misperceptions.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
Too Much, Too Soon Halts Assisted-Living Boom

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
FUELED by favorable demographic trends, strong consumer demand and a robust economy, the assisted-living industry was supposed to be mounting record profits this year while expanding rapidly and reaching new stock market peaks. That, at least, is what analysts were predicting three years ago.
It has not exactly worked out that way. One publicly traded company -- Grand Court Lifestyles Inc., in Boca Raton, Fla. -- filed for bankruptcy protection in March. Several others are under financial strain, and most have seen their shares recently plunge to record lows. 
 New construction has all but stopped. The Alterra Healthcare Corporation of Milwaukee, the nation's largest assisted-living operator, has abandoned plans to build 100 new homes. Last year, the industry's publicly traded companies, which account for 10 percent of the homes, lost 68 percent of their value, according to Philip J. Martin, an analyst with First Union Securities.
What went wrong? The answer is a binge of overinvestment and overbuilding, with too many companies trying to seize a trend.
The elderly are the fastest-growing segment of the population; the number of Americans 85 or older is expected to increase by one-third in the next decade, to about six million. Most dread the prospect of being confined to the hospital-like setting of a nursing home.
Privately paid assisted living is viewed as an appealing alternative for people who need some help but do not require skilled nursing. Residents have their own apartments with kitchens, eating communally and taking part in social activities only when they want to. Public areas are designed to evoke a comfortable hotel rather than an institution.
Experts in senior housing say the industry's poor financial performance has not discredited assisted living, any more than the slide in dot-com stocks has undermined the Internet. They cite a gold-rush fever that led some companies to grow too fast and to use creative (though legal) accounting methods to hide their losses.
The concept of assisted living has existed for about two decades, but as recently as 1994, the industry had only two publicly traded companies. As capital became widely available, about 20 more public offerings followed, including some for companies operating both assisted-living and nursing homes. That resulted in pressure to produce quick increases in earnings.
In contrast to nursing homes, assisted-living homes face few regulatory barriers. New residences often went up with little market research.
But many companies did not anticipate how long it would take to fill their buildings. The costs are beyond many people's means. Monthly fees start at $3,000 in lower-cost regions and climb sharply, depending on the services needed -- with medical care usually extra. Also, many elderly people are reluctant to give up their independence.
Some companies failed to foresee that they would be serving an increasingly older, and therefore more frail clientele (the average age is now 84), forcing them to add staff, which cut into profits. "There wasn't a lot of discipline on the part of the companies," said Christos Kuliopoulos, a senior consultant at Ernst & Young who specializes in senior housing. "They weren't doing their due diligence."
And so the building boom has tapered off. The 164 homes now under construction are just a third as many as were completed in 1998. There are about 7,000 professionally run homes nationwide, with about 520,000 units, according to the American Seniors Housing Association in Fairfax, Va.
DURING the building boom, many markets quickly became saturated, prompting several states to require certificates of need before a home could be built. North Carolina has declared a moratorium on new construction, an action that backfired when many companies rushed into the state to beat the deadline.
Confidence in the industry was also shaken when many companies chose to engage in so-called off-balance-sheet financing. Abraham Gosman, the chairman of the Care-Matrix Corporation, a publicly traded company based in Needham, Mass., used a private but wholly owned company, the Chancellor Senior Housing Group, to buy property and absorb start-up losses. Chancellor paid CareMatrix a fee for developing the homes and running them in the early stages. As the homes filled up, CareMatrix would either lease them or buy them back.
"They were moving money from one pocket to another pocket," said James J. Kumpel, an analyst at Raymond James & Associates, who called attention to this financing arrangement at several companies. "It was a cynical financing vehicle to promote hypergrowth in what is generally not a hypergrowth industry."
However, Louise T. Major, director of investor relations for CareMatrix, said this type of financing has been standard in the hotel industry for many years.
Not all of the industry's problems have been of its own making. Changes in Medicare reimbursement methods for nursing homes also affected the prices of assisted-living stocks, because many investors do not distinguish among various forms of senior housing, analysts say. Last year, the stocks tumbled after an analyst reported -- incorrectly, as it turned out -- that the Government Accounting Office was about to recommend federal regulation of assisted living.
The industry is generally not opposed to regulation (it is easier to market government-certified homes), but it prefers to have it imposed by state lawmakers, who are easier to lobby.
As the industry faltered, even the better-managed companies saw their shares drop precipitously. These included Sunrise Assisted Living, Brookdale Living Communities and the American Retirement Corporation. The pioneer in assisted living, Sunrise, based in Fairfax, Va., opened its first home in 1981 and now has 148 homes in 23 states and one in Britain.
Companies like these own their real estate, choose their locations carefully, usually in densely populated areas, and focus on their operations, said Kathryn A. Sweeney, a vice president at AEW Capital Management, a Boston company that invests in privately held assisted-living companies. "Those firms that succeed as good operators will live in this business," she said. "Those that entered the business as real estate developers -- for opportunistic reasons -- will not."
For these reasons, a shakeout could benefit consumers in the long run. It would force companies to shift their attention from development to management, said Don Redfoot, a senior policy adviser to AARP.
But for now, families may want to exercise an extra measure of caution when choosing a home. "The intense pressure to show profit margins created enormous pressures to keep staffing to a minimum," Mr. Redfoot said. "You want to make sure that the place is adequately staffed."

HEADLINE: May 21-27;
Pay First, Drive Later

BYLINE: By RICHARD A. OPPEL JR.

 BODY:
Filling up for the Memorial Day weekend, drivers paid as much for gasoline as they did at the height of the oil price spike in March.
This time, though, it's not OPEC's fault. Low inventories of gasoline and a scramble to introduce a cleaner-burning reformulated fuel across much of the nation have tightened supplies -- especially in the Midwest -- just at the start of the summer driving season. 
While $1.53 a gallon is the highest average gas price ever, adjusted for inflation, it is still cheaper to fill up the family sports utility vehicle than it was to top off the Model T, noted Daniel Yergin, author of "The Prize," a history of the oil industry and president of Cambridge Energy Research Associates. In 1918, using today's dollars, gasoline approached $3 a gallon.
"Everybody is going to notice it this weekend," Mr. Yergin said of the rising prices. But he added, "On an inflation-adjusted basis, it's still cheaper than it's been in most of the last 80 years." That sort of historical perspective may be small comfort to drivers paying 40 cents a gallon more than last year.
Mr. Yergin, like most experts, believes prices may rise higher this summer. RICHARD A. OPPEL JR.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: Antitrust Annals;
The Uncertain Art Of Legal Remedies

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
IN a court filing last week Microsoft called the government's proposal to break the company in two "the antitrust equivalent of the death penalty."
Lawyerly hyperbole, it seems, but in the old days -- the very old days -- antitrust offenders couldn't afford to take any chances. In 388-386 B.C., a group of Athenian grain dealers formed a corn monopoly and manipulated prices, according to research by Spencer Weber Waller, a professor at the Brooklyn Law School. The dealers were caught, prosecuted and put to death. 
 Ever since, the issue of the appropriate punishment in antitrust cases has been a conundrum, if not a lethal one.
"We kill companies occasionally, but we've never killed any people with antitrust enforcement in America," said Herbert Hovenkamp, a professor at the University of Iowa law school.
Antitrust is a flexible doctrine intended to prohibit "anticompetitive behavior" -- a concept whose definition shifts according to the economic and political thinking of the day. So the remedial steps, too, have varied widely over the years.
There are two broad approaches: "structural" remedies, which involve breaking up the offending company; and "conduct" remedies, which involve prohibiting certain kinds of corporate behavior, like threatening rivals or writing contracts that restrict competition.
Both approaches have drawbacks. Breaking up a company is drastic, irrevocable and runs the risk of doing more harm than good. Restraints on a company's behavior can be easily sidestepped, may do little to curb its market power and may require constant policing by a court or government.
In the Microsoft case, Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson appears to be seriously weighing a breakup of the company. In his court in Washington last Wednesday, Judge Jackson pointedly asked the government why it did not go even further and recommend breaking up Microsoft into three companies instead of just two. The judge may issue his remedies order as soon as this week, but no matter what he decides, Microsoft will appeal both his sanctions and his legal ruling, which found the company to be a monopolist that used its market power to stifle competition.
THE track record of antitrust remedies is decidedly mixed, even humbling. For decades, from Standard Oil in 1911 through United Shoe Machinery in 1968, the courts tended to look approvingly on structural remedies, says Mr. Hovenkamp, editor of the 18-volume treatise "Antitrust Law," begun in 1978 by Philip Areeda of the Harvard Law School, who died in 1995.
United Shoe Machinery is the classic cautionary tale for skeptics of the structural approach. The government sued the company and in 1953 a district court in Boston found that it had violated the law but declined to break it up. In his opinion, Judge Charles Wyzanski explained that federal judges are not experts in economics or politics and "their prophecies as to the economic future are not guided by unusually subtle judgment."
YEARS later, the government asked the Supreme Court to modify Judge Wyzanski's remedies order so that United Shoe could be broken up. In 1968, the Supreme Court agreed with the government and United Shoe was split up, even though United Shoe's share of the shoe-making machinery market declined from 85 percent to 48 percent between 1953 and 1968.
United Shoe eventually collapsed, though the role of the government's misguided ministrations is unclear. Among antitrust scholars, however, "A lot of people who have studied it since believe that the courts got it wrong," Mr. Hovenkamp observed.
Maybe, but 1968 was the height of the "big is bad" bias against business and for the notion that government should step in to restrain corporate power. That changed by the late 1970's, as international rivals began to challenge America companies and as free-market academics, led by University of Chicago theorists, influenced antitrust thinking.
The courts, in general, have been skittish about splitting up companies in antitrust cases since the 1980's. A qualified exception was the AT&T breakup in 1984, but that was unusual, a consent decree applied to a government-sanctioned monopoly.
Antitrust experts say the structural approach to antitrust remedies is gaining renewed respect. One reason, they say, is that the consent decree the Justice Department signed with Microsoft in 1994 is widely seen as a failure.
The decree, antitrust experts say, was a backward-looking remedy that did little to restrain Microsoft's market power in an industry moving ahead at a rapid clip. "The government was shooting at a moving target, and it aimed, shot and missed," noted William Kovacic, a professor at the George Washington University law school.
The cases in which breakup remedies will now receive serious consideration by the courts, according to antitrust experts, involve "durable" monopolies (at least five years old) for which there is "no reasonable prospect" that the market will become competitive unless the monopolist is split up.
So much for theory. In the Microsoft case, what are the chances that the company will be broken up after all the appeals are over? A straw poll of six antitrust scholars who are not affiliated with either side in the case rated that probability at 20 percent to 50 percent.
Significantly, all six wanted to do their handicapping anonymously. There have been too many surprises already, they say, in the antitrust soap opera formally known as the United States of America v. the Microsoft Corporation.

HEADLINE: The World;
Yes, Trade Brings Freedom. Except When It Doesn't.

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE arguments that finally persuaded wavering members of Congress to grant China permanent trade status last week had very little to do with tariffs or even whether China's state-run industries would finally allow American farmers to deliver beef and wheat directly to the world's largest market.
Instead, it came down to one of the biggest bets in geopolitics: Most of the members of Congress who voted "yes" said they believed President Clinton's oft-repeated assertion that the faster the Chinese people are enmeshed in Western markets, legal systems and technology, the faster they will be tempted to cast off the one-party rule of the Communists. 
 "When over 100 million people in China can get on the Net," Mr. Clinton argued in a commencement speech days before the vote, which he won by a surprisingly wide margin of 237 to 197, "it will be impossible to maintain a closed political and economic society."
Really? Who knows. Mr. Clinton may be well into a second career as an investment banker or a third one as a movie producer before anyone has the foggiest sense of whether last week's decision to end the annual Congressional review of China's trading rights, and usher the country into the World Trade Organization, has any real effect on political freedom in China.
Yet recent history suggests it is not an entirely wild gamble. Look around the rest of Asia, where there is a clear -- if sometimes tenuous -- connection between the growth of market capitalism and the growth of some kind of democratic institutions.
Taiwan and South Korea are the success stories that everyone points to, places where the arrival of high technology, commercial legal systems and a gradual opening of the market was followed by an end to autocratic rule. But economists and political theorists have spent years arguing over the precise connections between freer markets and freer political systems and -- no surprise -- they can't agree on much.
And for every success story there are exceptions like Singapore and Malaysia, which have managed to embrace free enterprise while maintaining strict one-party control. Or Russia, where political liberty has preceded the introduction of a real market economy. But there are a few common themes:
Free markets don't equal freedom. But they make it a lot harder for the government -- or corrupt bureaucrats -- to rule over everyday choices.
Before China began to embrace market principles, a Communist Party official would get up at 5 a.m. in cities like Shanghai, go to the market and decide who got what. As in the old Soviet Union, the system worked for a while -- goods and services got produced, and people didn't starve. Usually. In short, the apparatchik played the role that pricing plays today, allocating scarce resources. And since handing out goodies was the local official's main source of power -- to say nothing of an opportunity to have his pockets stuffed with bribes -- the arrival of a market economy means the diminution of the party's arbitrary power. Entry into the W.T.O. promises to reinforce this process. "The arrival of foreign competition means the local party officials will lose their control over what the big factory in town produces, or even how many people it employs," says Nicholas Lardy, a China expert at the Brookings Institution. Chang Lin Tien, the former chancellor of the University of California at Berkeley, just returned to Taiwan a week ago to witness the swearing in of the new president, and he says it got him thinking about what prompted the change from the martial law of his youth to the election of the opposition leader, Chen Shui-bian, earlier this year. "We had some ruthless leaders," he said, "but as the economy came up, and Taiwan became part of the global market, it ended up giving more and more influence to the local Taiwanese and less to the party. State-owned enterprises just couldn't compete."
A rising middle class first demands a decent apartment, then a car, and sooner or later a vote.
Well, sometimes. In South Korea, American efforts to push a series of authoritarian leaders toward greater freedom failed before the country's workers began making decent wages. "When I think about our first efforts to convince South Korean leaders to liberalize, well, we saved the life of Kim Dae Jung," said William H. Gleysteen Jr., the former American ambassador to Seoul, referring to the onetime dissident who is now president. "But a lot of the other efforts didn't amount to much. Then people started to buy cars, to travel, and to demand a bit more political space. They became less compliant with the government." By 1987 the movement had become unstoppable.
The I.M.F. may be much reviled, but sometimes it aids and abets a democratic coup.
Suharto did not found the Indonesian state, but he ruled over it for 35 years. For years the Central Intelligence Agency speculated how his regime would end -- heart attack, coup, assassination. "We forgot about economic chaos," says one of the agency's old Asia hands. Once the Asian economic crisis began, the International Monetary Fund began demanding changes -- including the dismemberment of Suharto's family enterprises, which were skewing the government's budgets. And that unleashed political forces that Suharto couldn't withstand. The I.M.F. made a lot of mistakes, and the Indonesian bailout was not intended to oust Suharto. In retrospect, though, the world got a more open Indonesia and one less authoritarian ruler. "Of course there was no plan," says Jeffrey E. Garten, a former senior official in the Commerce Department. "But from the beginning of the Clinton administration there was a sense that economic liberalization and political liberalization would somehow go together. Of course, no one envisioned how this dangerous cocktail would come together."
The Internet will change this. But no one knows how.
Mr. Clinton is probably right that the Chinese will never be able to control discourse on the Internet (which doesn't stop them from trying). And while it may be a force for democracy, it may also prove a spur for anti-market, anti-American feelings. No sooner had the House passed the trade bill last week than Chinese scholars like Han Deqiang were on the Web preaching the dangers. Mr. Han told China Online, an electronic newsletter for executives, that through the W.T.O. "American economic hegemony could easily control China." Oh, and he added: "There are 133 W.T.O. members. Look at some of the African countries, the corruption there is much worse than in China."
