HEADLINE: THE WORLD: CORRESPONDENCE/A SLAIN JOURNALIST;
Reports From Faraway Places That Brought War Home

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: BERLIN

 BODY:
JOURNALISM, it is said, provides a first draft of history. It is a cliche, yet sometimes an unlikely combination of war and a witness illustrates the hallowed truth that lurks behind a hollow phrase. I write this sitting in Berlin, dreaming of Bosnia, and thinking of Kurt Schork, the Reuters correspondent whose dispatches from Sarajevo helped shape the world's view of a war that was as morally indelible to my generation of correspondents as Vietnam was to another.
Mr. Schork, 53, was killed on Wednesday in an ambush in Sierra Leone. A dispatch from his news agency described the scene: the armed men in T-shirts bursting out from behind a bank on a dusty road 50 miles from Freetown, the volley of automatic-rifle fire, a bullet through Mr. Schork's head. Another quick, senseless death of a foreign correspondent: what more is there to say? 
 But in this case, more must be said. For in nobody else did the conflicts of the first post-cold-war decade find a witness so driven or so able to write the accounts on which history will draw. With vivid declarative sentences this American journalist hammered out the discomfiting truths of a bloody decade. Lucidity of mind and economy of expression combined to penetrating journalistic effect.
I knew him in Sarajevo, a besieged city I covered for two years as a correspondent for The New York Times. Mr. Schork, compact, bespectacled, precise and insatiable, had a passion for truth and a gift for evoking it that made him a Bosnian reference. Wherever the post-modern wars of fractured or disintegrating states broke out -- Afghanistan, Chechnya, northern Iraq, Kosovo and finally Sierra Leone -- he was to be found. I believe he intuited, earlier than anyone, that the pieties of the new world order, postulating a Western triumph and even the end of history, were largely empty. What he saw, in his remorseless way, was that the end of the superpower confrontation had in fact unleashed a new violence, and that the killing would pose an unavoidable challenge to supposedly victorious Western values.
For a deep moral conviction guided this unusual newsman, who came to journalism late after a career that included running Bill Bradley's first Senate campaign. It backed his stubborn belief that his words would ultimately count and perhaps even right wrong. The truth is, he changed things, and with his death an era has passed: that of a gradual awakening to the fact that distant war and genocide could not be ignored by America and its allies.
When Yugoslavia began its protracted disintegration in 1991, precipitating the latest round of Balkan wars, the West's instincts were those of Neville Chamberlain on Czechoslovakia in 1938: these were conflicts "in a faraway country" involving people "of whom we know nothing." Not knowing amounted to the best excuse for not acting, especially when the imperative to do something was accentuated by the daily Serb bombardment of Sarajevo that began in 1992 and by an archipelago of Serbian concentration camps for Bosnian Muslims uncovered that year. Mr. Schork was driven by a desire to ensure that nobody could claim ignorance.
In these days of databank journalism and infotainment as news, he wrote what the great war correspondent Martha Gellhorn famously called "the view from the ground." In so doing, he brought journalists back to the basics: to see, to listen, to remain, to reflect, to report. His copy was so lapidary that the oft-repeated claims of muddle in Western capitals -- the repetitive talk of 1,000-year-old conflicts between indistinguishable Balkan tribes -- became largely preposterous in the gleam of Mr. Schork's clear-eyed observation.
H ERE, at the beginning of one of his best-known dispatches, so descriptive of the ideological insanity unleashed, is Mr. Schork on the killing of a Serb man and a Muslim woman, both 25, joined by love but hounded by the politics of ethnic hatred: "Two lovers lie dead on the banks of Sarajevo's Miljacka River, locked in a final embrace. For four days they have sprawled near Vrbanja bridge in a wasteland of shell-blasted rubble, downed tree branches and dangling power lines." He continued: "Bosko is face-down on the pavement, right arm bent awkwardly behind him. Admira lies next to her lover, left arm across his back."
For all his fierce competitiveness, Mr. Schork could never hide an overriding humanity, which once impelled him to drop his notebook and rescue Sarajevans as Serbian shells fell on a funeral. It was this combination of professionalism and moral clarity that made him a beacon for many journalists seeking to untangle the wars of recent years. And what could have been more important, for these conflicts have already involved two genocides -- in Rwanda and Bosnia -- and the death of more people in European violence than in the entire 44-year cold-war era?
These facts have only recently moved toward the center of political consciousness, spurring the West's first "humanitarian war" in Kosovo, intensifying its diplomatic quest to quiet the killing fields of Africa. Mr. Schork's work must take a large share of credit. As Hannah Arendt observed of acts of courage that may seem futile in the light of early death: "The holes of oblivion do not exist. Nothing human is that perfect and there are simply too many people in the world to make oblivion possible. Hence nothing can ever be practically useless, at least not in the long run." No other journalist I know did so much in recent years that will resist oblivion.

HEADLINE: The World: U.S.-Europe Relations;
Tiffs Over Bananas And Child Custody

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN

DATELINE: BERLIN

 BODY:
ACLOSE aide to Chancellor Gerhard Schroder was recently astounded to find a cabinet meeting devoted to the divisive issue of child custody in German-American relations. Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer weighed in; so did Mr. Schroder himself. There was much agonizing as they reviewed the family difficulties of Lady Catherine Meyer, who is the wife of the British ambassador to Washington.
Welcome to the new trans-Atlantic relationship, one that is bereft of an overarching mission yet so intimate that issues long considered domestic or secondary become major irritants. Lady Meyer has two sons from a previous marriage to a German doctor. The boys live in Germany with their father. Because of the vagaries of German custody laws, the children have had limited access to their mother, who is indignant. President Clinton, moved by this and other similar cases, is expected to raise the issue during a visit to Germany this week. 
 The cold war, whose heart was in Germany, has been over for a decade, and the big questions -- Euromissiles, Soviet divisions, global peace itself -- have disappeared from Washington's relations with Berlin and other European capitals. Beyond the intermittent flaring of Balkan crises, their place has largely been taken by genetically altered food, banana trade, the death penalty and even child custody. America's apparent determination to build a national missile defense system could still spur a major confrontation with Russia that would be deeply troubling to Washington's European allies. But, in general, how to live, what to eat and whether to accept the death sentence seem to have become the stuff of trans-Atlantic tiffs.
The recurrent rows over such questions are sometimes viewed as a sign of the fraying ties between Western Europe and the United States. A voguish band of French intellectuals predict a coming clash with the all-devouring, all-knowing "hyperpower." But there is another way of looking at these issues, many of which are essentially moral. Their prominence demonstrates the unprecedented closeness of European and American societies linked through business and cultural bonds intensified over the Internet.
"What we now have with the United States is a relationship so close that it is quasi-domestic," said Karsten Voigt, a senior German foreign ministry official. "The distinction between foreign and domestic policy has blurred as our societies have interwoven. That is why emotional issues like genetically altered food or the way we treat the children of international divorces rise to the surface. In a way, foreign policy was easier when it dealt with interests rather than emotions and morals."
Emotions being what they are, discussion of the new issues can get heated. An overwhelming majority of Germans consider the death penalty as unconscionable as the slave trade. Lady Meyer and others see Germany's child custody laws as barbaric.
But Europeans and Americans are now divided by how they run their domestic societies even as they are bound by a shared international goal: enlarging the areas of the world with a functioning market economy governed by the rule of law. Such enlargement, in turn, opens new avenues to prosperity.
"The pressures on all advanced nations are similar in the global economy," said Sidney Blumenthal, an adviser to President Clinton. "So what we find ourselves discussing are values -- how open we should be to immigration, how to educate people for an information society."
Of course, divisions of substance do persist. President Clinton will hear much criticism in Europe of the proposed national missile defense system, which European governments view as a risky recourse to an unproven system against an unproven enemy -- so-called rogue states like North Korea whose inclination or ability to attack the United States is doubted here. Many European officials are not happy about the new isolationism they see in the House of Representatives, which tried to end the deployment of American peacekeepers in Kosovo. Europeans are uncertain about the American view of the old continent's determination to forge a more united Europe with its own credible military force; they also wonder what America thinks of a European federation -- a kind of United States of Europe -- suggested as a long-term aim by Foreign Minister Fischer this month.
But even these issues seem to be about preserving a bond, and not about confrontation. True, the French argue for the euro or a proposed European rapid-reaction force as means to counterbalance the United States, but such talk is de rigueur. As Karl Kaiser, a German political scientist, noted, "The first to scream if American troops upped and left Germany would be the French, because of their lingering fears of German hegemony."
AT a profound level, America has become an essential European power. Hence the concern here over possible isolationism and a missile system that poses the question: what happens when Americans have protected themselves and their European allies are sitting ducks? "Our militaries have gotten in the habit of working together and that gives us something people don't want to give up," said John Roper, a British security expert. "So problems will be finessed."
No doubt they will. For in some senses, the deepest concern of European governments today is that the United States is not paying Europe enough attention. "Americans think Europe's problems are largely solved," said John Kornblum, the American ambassador to Germany. "They are not thinking about the structures of Europe any more, they are thinking about why they can't sell their beef. Europeans, however, see themselves at a critical and rather treacherous juncture and would like America to pay more attention."
At that juncture stands the question of what "Europe" should be. The continent is at a crossroads. It feels a historic obligation to expand the 15-member European Union to include the former Communist states of Eastern Europe, but fears hordes of poor immigrants pouring in. It knows that this larger union would become ungovernable unless moves begin toward Mr. Fischer's federative United States of Europe, but the end of the nation state in places like France or Britain is a deeply divisive idea.
Here, in these intra-European differences, the most painful and substantive clashes of the coming months and years may well emerge. Meanwhile, Europe and the United States, ever closer, will bicker over Texan executions and the fate of children whose mothers and fathers separated.

HEADLINE: Retiring Debt Clock Could Be Put to New Use

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your article "Debt Clock, Calculating Since '89, Is Retiring Before the Debt Does" (May 14) was sad news. Strong economic growth during the 90's provided excess tax revenue that the federal government has begun to use in making a down payment toward paying off our national debt. When economic recession inevitably returns, watch how debt reduction resumes its position on the back burner of political priorities.
The debt clock has been a beacon to remind us of the terrible inheritance that could destroy the financial security of future generations. 
 Why not use the debt clock to keep an eye on our city and state long-term financial borrowing?
 
LARRY PENNER
Great Neck, N.Y.

HEADLINE: Connecting Rural India to the World

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER 

DATELINE: EMBALAM, India

 BODY:
In this village at the southern tip of India, the century-old temple has two doors.
Through one lies tradition. People from the lowest castes and menstruating women cannot pass its threshold. Inside, the devout perform daily pujas, offering prayers. Through the second door lies the Information Age, and anyone may enter. 
 In a rare social experiment, the village elders have allowed one side of the temple to house two solar-powered computers that give this poor village a wealth of data, from the price of rice to the day's most auspicious hours.
"If I can get a job through this, I'll be happy," said V. Aruna, 14, who pestered her father, a farmer, until he agreed that she could come here each day to peck at a computer keyboard, where she learned Word and PowerPoint. "I want to work instead of sitting in the house."
At a time of growing unease about the global gap between technology knows and know-nots, India is fast becoming a laboratory for small experiments like the one at the temple that aim to link isolated rural pockets to the borderless world of knowledge. Local governments and nonprofit groups are testing new approaches to provide villages where barely anyone can afford a telephone with computer centers that are accessible to all.
To be sure, these experiments are still small and there are many obstacles. The vast majority of Web sites are in English, a language that more than 95 percent of Indians do not speak. Routine power failures and overloaded telephone lines make connecting to the Internet a frustrating proposition. And there are serious questions about whether countries like India, weighed down by high rates of illiteracy and illness, should spend heavily to provide villages that desperately need schools and health clinics with what most would consider a luxury.
But others say a well-placed computer, like a communal well or an irrigation pump, may become another tool for development.
Information from the computers in this area, where people live in thatched mud huts, has saved the life of a milk cow named Jayalakshmi, prevented the blindness of an old woman named M. Minakshi and routinely warned fishermen of stormy weather that can claim lives.
While Internet cafes have sprung up quickly in even small Indian cities, it is in rural areas, where most people live, that computers must spread if developing nations like India are to close the yawning technology gap with rich countries.
North America, with less than 5 percent of the world's population, has more than half of its Internet users. South Asia -- home to more than a fifth of humanity -- has less than 1 percent, according to the 1999 Human Development Report sponsored by the United Nations Development Program.
But how to make computers available to villagers has led to divergent approaches. Two of the most intriguing efforts are in the former French colony of Pondicherry and in the central state of Madhya Pradesh.
The Pondicherry project was created by the Madras-based M. S. Swaminathan Research Foundation, a nonprofit organization that uses science and technology to tackle poverty, with a $120,000 grant from the Canadian government. The foundation provides villages with free technology and information in exchange for the villages' promise to house the computers and staff their operation.
The spread of this approach to more of India's 600,000 villages would ultimately require government money and manpower, with support from nongovernmental organizations and philanthropies.
In contrast, the Madhya Pradesh approach is more entrepreneurial and market-driven. Villages have bought computers with money from their own budgets, then franchised their operation to a local person who charges fees of 10 to 35 cents for government records and other services available at the click of a mouse. The operators, who receive no salary, keep most of the money but give a portion back to the village and state governments.
The story of the cow and the computer is a parable showing that sometimes the simplest information is the most valuable.
Some months back, Subrayan Panjaili, a round-faced woman who cannot read or write, sat in the courtyard of her small home in the village of Kizhur, in Pondicherry, with the family's only milk cow, Jayalakshmi. For five days and nights, the cow moaned while in labor. Something had gone wrong and she was unable to deliver her calf. Mrs. Panjaili grew ever more fearful that the cow would die.
"This is the only good income we have," she said, explaining that the four gallons of milk the cow produced each day paid the bills.
Word of Mrs. Panjaili's woebegone cow soon spread to Govindaswami, a public-spirited farmer who uses one name. The village's computer, obtained through the Swaminathan Foundation, is in the anteroom of his home. The computer is operated full time and for no pay by his 23-year-old, college-educated daughter, Azhalarasi, who used it to call up a list of area veterinarians.
One doctor arrived that night and, by the light of a bare electric bulb, stuck his arm into Jayalakshmi, pulled out the calf's spindly leg and tied a rope to it, then dragged the calf into the world.
The Swaminathan Foundation has sought to give the four villages in its network other practical, highly local information, which is distributed through the village computer network in the local language, Tamil. Generally, that kind of information is not on the World Wide Web.
They distribute the dates that roving medical camps will be set up in various villages. M. Minakshi, 70, who said she felt as if a sari had been draped over her right eye, went to one and discovered that she needed cataract surgery.
Each day, the project's staff also download a map from a United States Navy Web site that shows the wave heights and wind directions in the Bay of Bengal.
On a recent afternoon in the fishing village of Veerampattinam, loudspeakers fixed to tall poles along the broad beach blared out that daily weather report. Bare-chested fishermen in loincloths who were mending nets, repairing homemade wooden boats or just snoozing in the sultry heat perked up to listen.
The four villages taking part in the project are linked to the foundation's hub through an ingenious wireless system. It was dreamed up by V. Balaji, a graduate of the Indian Institute of Technology at Kanpur, who oversees the project for the foundation.
While the foundation's model is relatively costly and may prove difficult to replicate on a large scale, the government of Pondicherry nonetheless plans to expand the project to 50 more villages.
One immediate obstacle, as Mr. Balaji notes, is that local bureaucrats have often been reluctant to give up their monopoly on information, which can be a source of power used to extract bribes.
"We're hoping the bureaucrats will become public servants," said M. S. Swaminathan, the internationally known geneticist who leads the foundation.
One such public-minded civil servant is Amit Agarwal, the creator of the model computer project in the state of Madhya Pradesh. It is Mr. Agarwal who has taken power out of the hands of bureaucrats and given it to village entrepreneurs.
Mr. Agarwal, 29, the chief executive of the Dhar district council, said he believed that while low-level bureaucrats might be tempted to demand bribes, an entrepreneur being paid to provide the records retrieved on a computer would be more inclined to work hard.
He has set up a model project in his district, one of India's poorest, where young men have a franchise from the state to distribute daily crop prices and commonly needed state records for a small fee.
Mr. Agarwal predicts that revenue-generating computer projects like his will spread more quickly than those that depend on scarce state funds. "This is the paternalistic welfare model that the country has been slowly discarding over the past decade as not having worked," Mr. Agarwal said.
Since the project was set up in January, 22 villages have each bought a computer, a modem, a printer and a battery for $1,500 with their own money and agreed to provide a small booth to house the setup.
In each case, the state then picked a young person from the village with at least a 10th-grade education to operate the computer and gave him a franchise to sell information from the state's computer network.
For 25 to 35 cents, villagers buy printouts of documents that they might have spent days trying to get from local bureaucrats: land records, caste certificates and proof of income, among others.
For another 25 cents, any citizen can send a complaint to the state by e-mail -- my pension didn't arrive, my child's teacher didn't show up, my village hand pump doesn't work -- and the state guarantees a reply within a week.
And for 10 cents, a farmer can get a printout listing the prices of any agricultural commodity sold at surrounding markets.
At Bagdi village, wizened, sun-beaten farmers filed in to collect the day's price lists for wheat, garlic and whatever other crops they had to sell. They all said their knowledge of the rates improved their negotiating leverage with middlemen.
"If the price he offers suits me, I'll sell it to him," said Satya Narayan Khati, who grows wheat on his three acres. "Otherwise, I'll take it to market myself."
In Bagdi, the computer booth is operated by Deepak Patel, 20, a gaunt, lanky son of a farmer. Mr. Patel still helps milk the cows and bring in the harvest, but he prefers his computers. After just a few months, he is already making a good living from the long hours he spends selling printouts.
When people come in to e-mail a complaint to the state, Mr. Patel writes out their grievances for them, since most residents of the district are illiterate.
In his booth, as in every computer center visited in Madhya Pradesh and Pondicherry, children crowd in, clamoring for a chance to play on this machine that their elders call a magic box.
"It's better than farming," Mr. Patel said. "Through this you feel connected to the rest of the world."

HEADLINE: Holiday Motorists Face Soaring Prices at Pump

BYLINE: By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. 

DATELINE: DALLAS, May 27

 BODY:
By now, most of Eddie Slack's customers are accustomed to paying $30 or more to fill their gas tanks. "The big sticker shock was several months ago," said Mr. Slack, owner of the Delwood Chevron service station in Austin, Tex.
After falling a good bit following a decision by the petroleum-exporting countries in March to increase oil production, gasoline prices have soared to the highest levels of the year in many parts of the nation. 
 Drivers now filling up are paying record prices for the Memorial Day weekend. And analysts say tight supplies, particularly in the Midwest, could push prices higher as demand increases with the beginning of the summer driving season and as parts of the country struggle to meet a June 1 deadline for using a cleaner-burning reformulated fuel as required by the federal government.
The average national price for regular unleaded is $1.53 a gallon, the same level reached in March and almost 40 cents higher than last year, federal officials said. In New York City, drivers are paying $1.64 a gallon, compared with $1.27 last year, according to AAA, the automobile association.
Adjusted for inflation, of course, gasoline is still cheap, even with the sharp rise of the last year. The 30 cents a gallon that Americans paid in the early 1960's translates to about $1.75 today, according to Cambridge Energy Research Associates. And the $1.25 a gallon that drivers paid in the early 1980's is equivalent to $2.50 today.
In April, prices around the country fell almost a dime a gallon, on average, after OPEC ministers voted in late March to increase production. But the decline turned out to be short-lived, as drivers everywhere learned this week when they gassed up for the holiday weekend.
"It costs so much that I don't even fill up the tank anymore," Tadd Balfour, a 25-year-old computer network engineer, said as he added $10 worth of gas to the 20-gallon tank of his Montero sport utility vehicle at Mr. Slack's station on Friday. Mr. Balfour, who commutes more than 20 miles each day, says he has considered buying a smaller car. "If gas goes up another couple of points, I may have to make a change," he said. "But I'm closely watching what prices do. Right now, it's out of control.".
Mr. Balfour and other customers at Mr. Slack's small but busy service station on Interstate 35 near downtown Austin paid $1.41 a gallon for regular gasoline this week, $1.52 for midgrade and $1.61 for premium. That is less than in most other parts of the country, but that did not stop customers from complaining about recent increases. "They were really hollering," Mr. Slack said.
Despite the high prices, holiday driving is expected to eclipse last year's rates. AAA said it expected more than 34 million Americans to travel at least 100 miles from their homes over the weekend, 3 percent more than last year and 31 percent more than during the 1991 Memorial Day weekend.
Much of the blame for the recent price increase lies with the low inventories of gasoline around the country, a factor that played a big role in high prices earlier this year. But the latest run-up has been accelerated by the scramble to introduce a new reformulated fuel in most large metropolitan areas. Prices have also moved higher because of worries that a legal dispute involving the Unocal Corporation's patents for certain reformulated gas is holding back production at some refineries.
The cleaner-burning fuel is being sold in the Boston-to-Washington corridor, including much of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, as well as in much of California and in Chicago, Milwaukee, Houston and Dallas. Worries over tight supplies of the fuel have been particularly acute in the Midwest, where prices are soaring. In Chicago, for example, drivers are paying an average of $1.85 for regular unleaded, up 30 cents in the last month and more than 60 cents over last year, according to AAA. Some of the city's service stations have already raised prices above $2.00 a gallon. Milwaukee drivers are paying $1.74 a gallon.
State lawmakers in Wisconsin have authorized the filing of a lawsuit to block adoption of the new fuel rules there. And in St. Louis, officials won a waiver from the Environmental Protection Agency allowing use of the old gas until June 5.
Late Friday, the E.P.A. denied requests from both Chicago and Milwaukee for waivers there. The agency said there was enough of the reformulated fuel to make waivers unnecessary.
The reformulated fuel is harder to blend, and Midwest refiners are unlikely to be able to increase production soon, said Philip K. Verleger, a senior adviser to the Brattle Group, a consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass. Absent an E.P.A. waiver, gas prices in Chicago and Milwaukee could go much higher, even well above $2 a gallon, before the situation stabilizes, Mr. Verleger said. "There's no real way out of it for the next three or four weeks," he said.
On top of pressure to meet the new fuel requirements, inventories are low even for regular gasoline, and that leaves the nation exposed to price spikes, said Daniel Yergin, president of Cambridge Energy Research Associates. Stocks are so low, he said, that "any change in supply will reverberate in the markets right away -- there isn't much of a normal cushion."
Concerns about a shortage of reformulated fuel helped push gasoline futures to $1.026 a gallon on Friday, their highest level since the Persian Gulf war, before settling back a few cents in the shortened preholiday trading session at the New York Mercantile Exchange. Oil futures closed at $30 a barrel, only a few dollars short of the high for the year and at the top end of a trading band in which OPEC ministers want crude to remain. Should oil prices stay at these levels, or rise, analysts say the cartel could act to increase production once more.
Oil prices have more than doubled since early last year. OPEC decided in March 1999 to cut back production, and cartel members largely adhered to the new limits on output, which, combined with stronger demand from Asia, caused prices to soar.
At Mr. Slack's service station, Edward Wyndham, a 64-year-old carpenter and part-time minister, remembers when gas stations gave away glassware to attract customers. Now he says he and his friends just seek the cheapest prices.
"It's outrageous, what they've done," Mr. Wyndham said as he finished putting gas in his pickup truck. "It's the poor people who are suffering. I'm mad about it."

HEADLINE: THE AD CAMPAIGN;
Some Timely Help From Friends of Florio

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

 BODY:
This 30-second commercial, titled "Wall Street," was released by the Camden County Democratic Committee, which has endorsed former Gov. Jim Florio in his bid for the Democratic Senate nomination in New Jersey against Jon S. Corzine. It is a classic "soft money" ad, in that it does not explicitly advocate voting for or against anyone. The commercial began running on Wednesday on television stations in New York City.
 
PRODUCER -- Murphy Putnam Media. 

ON THE SCREEN -- New York's financial district -- introduced with the caption "Greed is good" -- is made to look as sinister and intimidating as possible. Photographed looking up from street level, through a blue filter, the New York Stock Exchange and other imposing Wall Street buildings roll by. An unflattering photo of a squinting Mr. Corzine takes up one corner of the frame, as printed warnings sidle across the screen: "$250 Million Penalty for Raiding Pension Funds." "Supports Republican Plan to Privatize Social Security." "Good for Goldman Sachs, Bad for Seniors." The commercial ends with the admonition to "Tell Jon Corzine to Leave Our Retirement Funds Alone," along with the phone number of Mr. Corzine's campaign headquarters.
 
THE SCRIPT -- Narrator: "Wall Street. A place where some say greed is good. A place Jon Corzine feels right at home. When he was chairman of Goldman Sachs, the firm paid a $250 million penalty for raiding employee pension funds. Now, Jon Corzine supports the Republican plan to privatize Social Security. Good for Goldman Sachs. Bad for seniors. Raiding pensions and privatizing Social Security. Tell Jon Corzine to leave our retirement funds alone."
 
ACCURACY -- As Mr. Florio has done less artfully in his own ads, this commercial flatly misrepresents Mr. Corzine's position on Social Security. In fact, it brazenly cites as a source a Business Week article that actually makes clear Mr. Corzine's opposition to individual investment accounts, the heart of the Republican plan. Goldman Sachs did pay $253 million in 1995 to settle charges that it had conspired with Robert Maxwell, the British publishing magnate, to defraud pensioners of hundreds of millions of dollars. It is debatable whether a settlement of a lawsuit, under which Goldman did not admit wrongdoing, amounts to a "penalty."
 
SCORECARD -- Mr. Florio's campaign, which began running $900,000 worth of commercials on Wednesday, is now essentially out of money, and the former governor's friends in Camden County, his political base, have done him a tremendous favor by buying $500,000 in television time to run this commercial. Conveniently, because it does not explicitly urge voters to back Mr. Florio or reject Mr. Corzine, the ad can be paid for with soft money, which has much larger individual contribution limits. The ad is arguably more effective than any of Mr. Corzine's attack ads and is as polished as his positive ones. It manages to paint Mr. Corzine as a pension robber out to cheat the elderly, and a New Yorker running for office in New Jersey -- all in an economical half-minute. DAVID M. HALBFINGER

HEADLINE: The Fresh Air Fund;
Lessons for Life (Nachos, Too) at Weekend Camp

BYLINE: By AARON DONOVAN 

 BODY:
About 15 minutes after a group of a dozen teenagers began cooking the vegetables and meat for a heaping plate of nachos, a dispute arose.
On one side was Daniel Mercado, 17, a Bronx resident who is in the culinary arts program of Park West High School in Manhattan. He wanted to fry the onions, mix them in with the beef and put the melted cheese on the side. On the other hand, his fellow chefs noted that the directions called for raw, diced onions to be sprinkled on top and for the cheese to be melted directly onto the tortillas. 
 "I prefer to keep the chip dry -- you take the chip and dip it in the bowl," Daniel said in a way that indicated he knew his nachos. "If you melt the cheese on the chips, the chips will be moist."
The teenagers were engaged in an exercise in food preparation and teamwork that was part of a weekend retreat at Camp Mariah in Fishkill, N.Y. The camp is one of five run by The Fresh Air Fund, a nonprofit agency that provides free summer vacations in the country to economically disadvantaged children from New York City.
Darcel Serapio, 17, of the East New York section of Brooklyn, a cheese-on-top proponent, reminded Daniel that the group was being judged according to a 19-point list of instructions, one of which was to carefully follow the recipe. "It says: 'Follow each step in the recipe,' " she said, holding a printout from the Food.com Web site that contained the recipe.
"We're a group; we can change the rules if we decide," Daniel countered.
While the group debated, groups of teenagers elsewhere at the camp learned about balancing a checkbook, keeping credit card debt from skyrocketing and budgeting a household's resources.
All the teenagers are members of the PreOccupations Club, a program for teenagers who have attended Camp Mariah. The camp prepares boys and girls 12 to 14 for work and careers by helping them set educational goals and get a summer job.
"Having some experience in the summer is a great indicator of future career success," said Miriam Seidenfeld, the director of Camp Mariah and the PreOccupations Club program. "And when you have a summer job, you get paid. The rewards are not so far in the future -- they're very here and now, which is important for that age group."
There are 56 high school students in the PreOccupations Club this year. They meet once a month at the Fresh Air Fund's office in Midtown and two weekends during the school year to continue the training and friendships that began at Camp Mariah.
"I really like the camp," said Dionne Letts, a 15-year-old from the Bronx who attended Camp Mariah for three years and decided to continue on to the PreOccupations Club this year. "It helps you to accomplish your goals and keeps you focused and stable."
While the students learn how to fill out a job application and how to impress an employer during an interview, the club also helps them build and maintain confidence.
"We remind them that they have problem-solving skills, they have communications skills," Ms. Seidenfeld said. "They don't need to be scared when they first go to a job."
One thing the former campers learn is how to resolve conflicts.
"We want them to look at not just your favorite person's point of view or your own point of view, but anyone's point of view," Ms. Seidenfeld said. "We teach them how to compromise or find alternative, creative solutions, to speak through problems, and how to handle them by deciding what you'll accept or be able to live with."
The group in the kitchen eventually chose to saute the onions and melt the cheese directly onto the nachos. Though they departed slightly from the instructions, they received a stellar review from the volunteer judge, Hortense Noble, vice president for global corporate events at Credit Suisse First Boston.
"In the end, they all learned to work together and to resolve the conflict that comes from within the group," she said. "They're going to encounter a lot of that when they start working."
Families wishing to inquire about registering children for a Fresh Air summer vacation can call (800) 367-0003. Anyone interested in making a tax-deductible contribution to the fund can send a check to: The Fresh Air Fund, 1040 Avenue of the Americas, New York, N.Y. 10018.

HEADLINE: After 40 Years, Israel May Be Losing Its Outsider Status at U.N.

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

 BODY:
After decades of exclusion from all regional groups in the United Nations, Israel has been accepted on a temporary basis by the Western Europeans, ending its virtual disenfranchisement in the organization.
Israel's ambassador to the United Nations called the long-sought invitation, issued on Friday, a turning point in his country's relations with the organization, where a voting bloc of Arab and third world nations has perennially attacked and isolated the Israelis in the General Assembly and other bodies. 
 Only two nations, Israel and Estonia, have never belonged to one of the regional groups, formed 40 years ago to decide on candidates for many council and committee positions at the United Nations and its agencies and programs around the world.
Estonia chose not to join the Eastern European group, holding out for membership in the Western European caucus, which also includes Australia, New Zealand, Canada and sometimes the United States. But Israel has been barred by Arab and other opposition from the Asian group, covering all nations from the eastern shores of the Mediterranean to the Pacific. Membership in the Asian group is still Israel's goal, diplomats say.
The United States has been lobbying hard over the last year to get Israel into the Western Europe group. The decision was bumped from one level to another in the 15-member European Union for months before the Netherlands, which now holds the rotating chairmanship of the group at the United Nations, pressed for closure.
On Wednesday, American diplomats said, the Dutch ambassador to the United Nations, Peter van Walsum, circulated a letter to the group's members saying that if there were no objections raised by Friday, Israel would be invited to join the group, under certain conditions.
One is that temporary membership will be extended initially for only four years, after which Israel's relationship with the group would be reviewed. Israel would also have to forgo seeking elected positions for two years. American officials say intense competition for contested posts was a major factor in keeping Israel out of the Western European group. Other positions in the United Nations system will be closed to Israel for longer periods because of past agreements. Israel must formally accept the limited invitation.
There are five regional groups at the United Nations -- Western Europe, Eastern Europe, Asia, Africa and the Western Hemisphere, which covers Latin America and the Caribbean.

U.N. Patrols Border
 
FATIMA GATE, Lebanon, May 27 (Reuters) -- United Nations peacekeepers patrolled this border flash point between Israel and Lebanon today and pushed back Lebanese civilians trying to taunt Israeli soldiers across barbed wire.
The United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon sent four armored troop carriers and dozens of peacekeepers to Fatima Gate, the scene of daily gatherings by Lebanese since Israel pulled out of southern Lebanon this week. Hezbollah guerrillas moved into the border zone after Israeli forces withdrew.
Today, the peacekeepers turned back Lebanese who were heading to the fence to jeer Israeli soldiers and wave Hezbollah flags at them.

HEADLINE: A Commencement For a Classmate Beloved by Many

BYLINE: By JULIE FLAHERTY 

DATELINE: PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 25

 BODY:
Instead of caps and gowns, the graduates wore basketball and soccer jerseys. Instead of "Pomp and Circumstance," the crowd swayed to "Stand by Me." And instead of conferring 1,000 degrees, Brown University presented only one today, to Casey Shearer, a beloved member of the senior class who died less than a week before he was to graduate.
Mr. Shearer, 21, suffered a sudden shutdown of his heart, brought on by an undetected viral infection, after a basketball game with friends on May 19, his family said. He never regained consciousness and died four days later. 
 His classmates, determined that Mr. Shearer should still graduate with plenty of fanfare, organized this commencement four days before their own, which is Monday.
There were as many laughs as tears at the gathering, as friends and family praised Mr. Shearer's quick smile, poked fun at his penchant for giving everyone a nickname (his was "Case," or "Case Dog"), and maligned his mediocre jump shot.
Despite his magna cum laude degree in economics, Mr. Shearer was remembered foremost as a sports lover who covered games for Brown Student Radio and wrote a sports column for The College Hill Independent, a weekly college newspaper.
His father, Derek N. Shearer, a longtime friend and economic adviser to President Clinton, said he was amazed by the 80 friends who kept vigil at the hospital while his son was in a coma. He said the service typified all the things his son loved about Brown.
"He chose Brown because it was his sense that this was the most friendly and diverse mix of kids," said Mr. Shearer, a fellow at the Woodrow Wilson International Scholars Center in Washington.
Casey Shearer's network of friends stretched from Providence to southern California, where he grew up, to Finland, where he attended high school while his father was ambassador. Through his father, he made friends in the White House, as evidenced by Mr. Clinton's attendance at the service.
His arm around the first lady, Hillary Rodham Clinton, the president recounted how Mr. Shearer had tried to tutor him in rap music before an appearance on "The Arsenio Hall Show" in 1992.
But politics was not in his game plan. Nearing graduation, he had already mailed out tapes of his broadcasts of Brown games, in hopes of landing a broadcasting job.
Politics did not seem to matter much to his friends, either, who remembered him more for his ability to memorize the statistics of every Brown athlete and his inability to eat his usual morning bowl of Cheerios without dribbling milk down his chin.
"Those of you who belong with Casey to the Class of 2000 will know that he marches by your side on Monday," said Sheila E. Blumstein, the interim president of Brown. "You will hear his laugh and see his smile."

HEADLINE: Behind Success Of Tour Buses, Troubled Trail

BYLINE: By C. J. CHIVERS and JUAN FORERO 

 BODY:
It seemed an almost comic gamble, bringing red double-decker buses from Britain and setting them loose on New York.
Not only was the man behind the idea, Harry Grant, a New Jersey developer, in bankruptcy proceedings, but New York in 1991 was saddled with a staggering crime rate and a sour economy. Times Square, where the buses were to pick up passengers, was a haven for vagrants and sleaze. 
 Mr. Grant's leap across the Hudson River turned serendipitous. Crime rates fell. The economic downturn reversed itself. Times Square was transformed from grit to gaudy commercialism. As more tourists came to the city, the company, New York Apple Tours, prospered, growing from two used buses to an operation with $10 million in annual income.
But as tourists flocked to the used British buses, so did city, state and federal regulators. The company amassed hundreds of thousands of dollars in fines for falsifying records and sidestepping inspectors, and drew the ire of neighborhood groups and politicians.
No matter how intense the scrutiny, though, the company survived, even thrived, until last Monday, when a bus operated by a driver who the police said did not have a proper license turned onto a crosswalk at West 45th Street and fatally struck Randolph Walker, 71.
By week's end, Apple Tours was in the fight of its life in an administrative hearing at the City Department of Consumer Affairs, facing a city effort to immediately suspend its license. Susan Kassapian, a department lawyer, contended that the company had shed even the veneer of decency and accumulated a list of civil and criminal violations that was remarkable for its scope and scale.
Company officials have strenuously objected to the hearing, calling it a naked violation of due process. "What they're doing to us here is completely unacceptable," said Hayim Grant, the company's president and Harry Grant's son.
But hearing the city's case, critics were left to wonder how a company of that description could have survived for so many years in the law-and-order climate established by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
"I've never seen a company flagrantly violate the law on this scale," said John Kaehny, executive director of Transportation Alternatives, a watchdog group. "How much evidence do they need?"
Lawyers and business associates offer a two-word answer as one possible explanation for the bus company's resilience: Hurricane Harry, the nickname given to the company's patriarch and organizing force.
They say Apple Tours is a company made in Mr. Grant's image, and that Hurricane Harry is a man undeterred by adversity, even embarrassment.
Mr. Grant, who immigrated from Israel to the United States with his wife and three children in 1975, penetrated New Jersey's construction industry and was a quick success, so quick that after building upscale houses in Bergen County, he began proposing projects of an enormous scale.
Harry Grant said he would build the tallest building in the world, a 121-story office tower in Newark. He never did. He proposed digging a tunnel from Bergen County to the Bronx. It never happened. He said he would open the Newark Renaissance Mall. All that remains of that venture is an uncompleted shell.
In 1990, a bank started foreclosure proceedings on two of Mr. Grant's properties, saying his companies had defaulted on loans in excess of $17.5 million. The federal Environmental Protection Agency was pursuing another of his companies for 119 violations of the Clean Air Act stemming from the illegal demolition of asbestos-laden buildings in Hoboken, N.J. The case eventually resulted in a $60,000 fine.
That summer, under pressure from banks and regulators, Mr. Grant filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection for at least four of the companies under his control. But he insisted he was not done. In bankruptcy court, he promised he would recover within three years.
His resurrection came through Apple Tours.
Walter F. Timpone, one of his lawyers, said the idea for the company came to Mr. Grant when he saw double-deckers on a trip to London.
In August 1991, New York Apple Tours was incorporated. Mr. Grant built the company in his vision of salting the city with stops, giving riders the chance to hop off one bus and, whenever they wished, board another.
"This opened it up to tourists and let people see places around their city at their leisure," Mr. Timpone said. "It was, and is, fantastically successful."
Lawyers and business associates say that if Harry Grant was stung by his long run of setbacks in New Jersey, he did not show it. He was driven, they say, and resourceful. No job was beneath him. He turned wrenches in the motor yard. At times he flew to London and returned with luggage crammed with spare parts.
Lee Gelber, who was with the company in 1993 and is now manager of tour services for a rival, Gray Line, recalled Mr. Grant's work ethic: "Harry would do everything. He'd be up to his elbows in grease."
Under Mr. Grant's leadership, the business flourished, growing from a fleet of 2 double-deckers to 63 today, according to state records and the company's office. Mike Alvich, vice president of marketing and development, said that as the company grew, it provided a public service.
"We've helped the city in a number of ways," he said. "Tourism is a big part of the New York City economy, and we think that we've contributed to the growth of that."
But as the company grew, it attracted doubters, then enemies, who said its problems were pervasive, affecting all aspects of the business, from environmental compliance and public safety to record-keeping and customer service.
Apple Tours also angered residents and community leaders, many of whom said it illegally took empty buses down residential streets, made curb-side stops in unauthorized places, idled buses under apartment houses, irritated residents with diesel smoke and routinely double-parked, clogging byways already inundated with traffic.
In 1995, residents from West 22nd Street protested the company after discovering that it was using a rented parking area as a repair yard without proper permits. Under pressure from the city, the company moved its repair operations to Long Island City, Queens.
Tom Kirkland, who lives on West 22nd, said neighbors concluded that Mr. Grant and Apple Tours deliberately played outside the rules. "He didn't do anything by the book," he said. "The idea was to do it his way. Do it as long as he could. Do it until he gets chased out of the neighborhood."
In August 1995, the Department of Consumer Affairs accused the company of switching licenses on 43 occasions, apparently in an effort to use buses that had not passed state safety inspections or might not be insured. The entire fleet was temporarily taken off the streets. A settlement agreement required that the company pay a $100,000 fine and, among other things, remove Harry Grant as an officer in the company.
Friends and lawyers say that although Harry Grant may have severed his formal ties with the company, he has remained a presence.
"He's very much involved," said Frank Lucianna, one of Mr. Grant's lawyers and friends. "He's the guiding light."
Harry Grant, who lives in Alpine, N.J., did not return three phone calls last week. In an interview Friday, Hayim Grant declined to comment on his father's role in the company, except to say that the company had grown more responsible since 1995.
"Our record is very good," he said. "The company has really developed into a mature, professionally run, deep-management company. It's not a fly-by-night operator."
Whatever that role, Harry Grant's troubles, and the company's, did not stop after his removal as vice president. During the late 1990's, new problems mounted.
In 1998, an inspection team audited the company's compliance with a state law that mandates driver fitness and training and found more than 200 discrepancies, according to testimony on Thursday from Thomas Fullington, an assistant director of the State Department of Motor Vehicles. Apple Tours was fined $6,500, Mr. Fullington said.
Mr. Fullington also said the department was investigating Apple Tours again. According to his testimony, its initial review found similar problems, including an absence of documentation for driver training and medical exams.
Also in 1998, Harry Grant was indicted on charges of first-degree sexual abuse, accused of attacking a female employee at the company's bus yard in Queens. He pleaded guilty to third-degree assault and was sentenced to counseling and one year of probation, a law enforcement official said.
And in December of that year, a group of employees filed a class-action lawsuit against the company, claiming it had failed to pay overtime to as many as 700 workers from 1992 to 1998. The suit is in settlement negotiations, said Adam T. Klein, a lawyer for the employees.
By this time, inspectors from the State Department of Transportation began noting that the company's fleet had safety problems. In a series of inspections in 1998 and 1999, Apple Tours buses failed 42.5 percent of the time, according to state data. The state sets an inspection failure goal of less than 10 percent.
The state's data also show that the company's most frequent violations were in the most serious category, including deficient brake systems, steering or suspension components and emergency exits. Subsequent inspections have found that the company's inspection failure rate is improving, to 24.5 percent, but that is still two and a half times the state's compliance goal.
Hayim Grant said the failures did not affect safety or the accident last Monday. "There's no bus that's on the road operated by us that has not passed New York State Department of Transportation standards," he said. "Our safety record is excellent. This is the first serious injury that we've ever had."
But Judy Shotwell, vice president of the Midtown North Precinct Council, a neighborhood organization that works with the Police Department, said that for a long time, she and others also thought that it would take a pedestrian fatality to force the city into the current fight. "We all knew it," she said. "It was going to take a catastrophe."
In fact, it was a federal case that set in motion the city's efforts to close the company. Last week's fatality merely accelerated the action.
Last fall, Apple Tours pleaded guilty in Federal District Court in New Jersey to falsifying documents submitted to three federal agencies to avoid meeting federal safety and environmental standards on 70 buses it imported from 1991 to 1995.
By admitting to a sustained deception, city officials said, Apple Tours gave the Department of Consumer Affairs the evidence it needed to try to revoke the company's licenses. "They were convicted of a crime of essentially dishonesty," Mr. Giuliani said, adding that the evidence allowed "the extraordinary step of trying to remove their license for reasons that would usually be considered beyond the Department of Consumer Affairs."
With the death last week, the city filed an emergency motion asking Administrative Law Judge Judith Gould to suspend the company's license immediately, pending the outcome of the case. And as Judge Gould was beginning her hearings, the company faced another action.
On Thursday, the board of NYC & Company, the city's tourism agency, voted unanimously to terminate the membership of New York Apple Tours. Cristyne Lategano-Nicholas, the agency's president, said the board had acted with knowledge of the pattern of problems, but had based its vote primarily on letters from disgruntled tourists.
"The complaints against this company exceed those against any of our other members," she said.
With the licensing fight still undecided, Hayim Grant remained resolute as the hearing ended on Friday. The tourists were pouring into the city for Memorial Day weekend. And though Hayim Grant said the police were cracking down on its buses, the company that Hurricane Harry founded was still in the fight.
"We're not looking to hurt this city," Hayim Grant said. "We love this city. We show it to thousands of people."

HEADLINE: RISK OF ARMS RACE SEEN IN U.S. DESIGN OF MISSILE DEFENSE

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
As President Clinton nears a decision on whether to build a limited national missile defense, American intelligence officials are warning that such a system could set off a cold-war-style arms race between China, India and Pakistan, administration officials say.
While the American officials have repeatedly said an antimissile defense is not aimed at Beijing, even they acknowledge that the system being designed could significantly undercut or even neutralize China's small nuclear force. 
 That could lead China to add to its nuclear arsenal. And if China built up its force, its regional rival India could do the same, as could India's rival Pakistan, heightening tensions along the world's newest nuclear frontier.
Such a scenario, which officials are expected to outline for Mr. Clinton in an official intelligence estimate due in June, has raised questions about the administration's own efforts to try to slow the spread of nuclear weapons and the ballistic missiles needed to launch them.
"If China increases the number of missiles it has, would India think it has to increase its missiles?" said a senior United States official familiar with the analysis being prepared. "And if India increases its missiles, then Pakistan does."
President Clinton has said he plans to decide later this year whether to proceed with a missile defense based on four criteria: the missile threat, technological viability of the program, the effect on arms control and cost. The response from China and Russia is an important factor in Mr. Clinton's decision.
While newly disclosed defense documents indicate that the Pentagon was researching ways in the mid-1990's to counter a limited Chinese missile attack, defense officials say that is no longer the American policy. The system under consideration, they insist, is intended to counter relatively small, unsophisticated missile threats from countries like North Korea, Iran and Iraq.
Samuel R. Berger, President Clinton's national security adviser, says Beijing's concerns may be eased not only by reassurances about the intent of the system but by general progress in economic and political relations.
"There are other dimensions to the relationship with the Chinese that are of far more long-term importance than national missile defense," Mr. Berger said in an interview.
The administration has expended enormous diplomatic energy -- unsuccessfully so far -- trying to persuade the Russians that a missile defense system would not threaten its much larger strategic forces. It has made even less headway with the Chinese.
There are several reasons why. Unlike Russia, which still maintains a force of more than 5,000 warheads from the cold war, China has deployed a minimal nuclear force, primarily 18 single-warhead land-based CSS-4 missiles.
The argument that the Clinton administration has used with the Russians -- that a limited missile defense is not a threat because it could be easily swamped by an overwhelming Russian missile attack -- does not apply to the Chinese.
China's old liquid-fueled CSS-4 missiles are kept on low alert with the warheads stored separately from the missiles. China also has 12 missiles on a submarine that rarely strays far from its port, from which it cannot reach the United States. And China seems convinced that the system would come closer to neutralizing its current nuclear force than has been publicly acknowledged.
"We don't deny to the Chinese that the system has some capability against Chinese missiles, but that is not what it is designed to do," said the under secretary of defense for policy, Walter B. Slocombe, said in an interview.
Another factor is China's apprehensions about the future course of relations with Washington.
American defense officials make plans according to a rival's perceived capabilities, not its intent. The Chinese make the same point, and complain that despite the assurances of the Clinton administration, they cannot be certain that a future administration would not use a missile defense against it, especially since China has often been cast as a threat by conservative Republicans.
A Clinton administration official said: "The Chinese tell us, 'You may not be directing the system against us, but what about the next guy? How can we be confident that the next administration may not have a different policy? It could use the system against us, just as it does against North Korea.' "
The Chinese also fear that the United States could adjust and expand a limited defense, which in its first phase will consist of a battle-management radar site in Alaska and 100 interceptors. And George W. Bush, the Republican candidate, has said the United States would develop a far more ambitious defensive system if he is elected president.
Another reason for the Chinese suspicions is that the Pentagon has previously worked on defensive systems to counter the Chinese arsenal.
During the Bush administration, the Pentagon instructed the TRW Corporation, an American military contractor, to develop ground-based interceptors that would stop "limited attacks by China" using CSS-4 missiles, according to a 1993 document prepared by the United States Army.
The Pentagon insists that countering China is no longer a goal, and its Ballistic Missile Defense Organization declined to say whether it is still studying ways to intercept Chinese warheads.
But defense officials acknowledge that the planning documents are constantly updated with the latest science and intelligence estimates of ballistic missiles.
Beyond a direct threat from China, there are other reasons why the Pentagon might want to develop the means to thwart its missile systems. American intelligence officials cautioned in a 1999 analysis that Russia and China might sell countermeasures like decoy warheads to developing nations the United States wants to defend against.
The Pentagon's missile-defense organization has also acknowledged that the new American defense would have the "residual capability" to defend against the "unauthorized launch by an established nuclear power of a few missiles with simple countermeasures," a definition that includes the Chinese.
"The system has to be able to respond to more than just North Korea," a defense industry official said.
Seeking to ease China's concerns, the Clinton administration has argued that while an antimissile system may be effective against China's current arsenal, it would be less so against the updated arsenal China has long planned to build.
Even before the Clinton administration began seriously considering antimissile defenses, the Chinese were planning to deploy a solid-fueled land-based missile of intercontinental range that could be moved around on a truck, as well as a new submarine-launched missile.
American intelligence officials project that the Chinese will have "several tens" of new and old missiles that can reach the United States by 2015 under Beijing's current modernization plan.
A missile defense, then, would have little effect on the Chinese strategic modernization, Pentagon officials assert. China, they add, is more anxious about the provision of antimissile technology to Taiwan than it is about a defense to protect the United States.
Despite these arguments, however, Pentagon officials acknowledge that they know very little about the missiles, warheads and countermeasures the Chinese plan to deploy.
"We assume the Chinese plan to modernize their force," a senior Pentagon official said. "It's impossible to say how much it would be affected by a national missile defense of the kind we're talking about."
Some senior intelligence experts nonetheless believe that a missile defense will prompt the Chinese to build up their strategic force beyond what they had previously planned, in order to ensure that it remains viable.
Such a response by China would be consistent with orthodox arms control theory, which holds that the construction of a missile defense prompts an adversary to build more missiles in the hope that at least some can get through the defense.
The American intelligence community's assessment will be contained in a new official intelligence report on the responses of foreign governments to a United States missile defense. The White House asked in December that the report be prepared so that Mr. Clinton could consider it in making his decision on a missile defense. Officials caution that the estimate is still being prepared.
"We would expect them to continue and perhaps even enhance countermeasures," a senior United States official said. "We have projected that they will have several tens of missiles by 2015. National Missile Defense might prompt them to do more than that."
"That would be likely," the senior official added.
One way for the Chinese to extend their build-up would be to add new warheads to their old 18 CSS-4, transforming them from single-warhead missiles into four-warhead missiles. They might also double the size of their projected land-based mobile missiles.
As a result, the Chinese could have more than 100 warheads by 2015, which is more than the 100 interceptors the United States plans to deploy in the first phase of its missile defense. The Chinese, the administration official said, might even deploy more than 200 warheads if the United States continues to expand its missile shield.
China's expanded force of nuclear-tipped long-range missiles might not be directed at India, they say. But it would be a capability that the Indians could not ignore, and as a result India might build up the short-range missiles it used to defend against China.
Administration officials are divided over whether India would respond in such a way, but the emerging analysis has dramatically raised the stakes.
Seeking to balance its concerns over stability in South Asia with its interest in missile defense, the Clinton administration is likely to redouble its negotiating efforts with the Chinese and perhaps even explore new forms of arms control with Beijing. By all accounts, however, Washington has a difficult job ahead.
"The basic point we have made is that a missile system is not aimed at them, that we are comfortable with deterrent relationship with China," a senior Clinton administration official said. "But we have not been able to overcome their suspicions."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Martinez's Spirit Is Very Special, Too

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
In the first week of November 1993, general managers were meeting in Naples, Fla., and the Yankees' general manager, Gene Michael, was there in quest of a starting pitcher. Among others, Michael had an eye on a young right-hander employed by the Los Angeles Dodgers.
"Gene Michael was one of the guys most interested in Pedro," recalled Fred Claire, who was then the Dodgers' general manager. "He really was the only one who was inquiring. He had a great interest. I said: 'Gene, I don't want to talk to you about who you might offer. I'm not going to trade him. He's a great young man and has a great upside.' " 
 No pitcher ever had a greater upside than Pedro Martinez, the dominating pitcher who is scheduled to start for the Boston Red Sox against the Yankees tonight. Had Michael been successful in prying Martinez from the Dodgers, he could have been pitching for the Yankees.
As the Dodgers' plans developed, they did trade Martinez, less than three weeks after Michael expressed his serious interest. They traded him to the Montreal Expos because the Expos offered them a second baseman, Delino DeShields. Jody Reed, who had been Los Angeles's second baseman in 1993 and had become a free agent, rejected an offer he shouldn't have refused. To his great regret, Reed said no to a three-year, $7.8 million contract and later had to accept a contract with Milwaukee for $350,000 for one year. As much as Reed's decision hurt him economically, it hurt the Dodgers competitively.
"Looking back, it turned out to be a terrible deal for us," Claire said. Had they not needed a second baseman, he added, he would, as he told Michael, not have traded Martinez. But even given that need, Claire said: "What I didn't put enough weight on was the spirit of Pedro. I recognized it but didn't put a high enough value on it. This young man has something that few people I encounter has and I should have recognized that."
Dan Duquette, the general manager who acquired Martinez for the Expos, left Montreal about two months later and became the Boston general manager. He reluctantly left Martinez behind but was intent on getting him again. He did, four years to the day after he obtained him from Los Angeles.
"Pedro has always been my favorite player," Duquette said, "because of his unique skills and his personality and his competitiveness. We are so lucky to have him. We owe a great debt to the Expo organization. He was a gift to the franchise."
Jim Beattie, Duquette's successor in Montreal, didn't want to trade Martinez, but explained why he did.
"We probably could have paid him," Beattie said, "but he wasn't going to sign with us until we did other things to show we were going to be competitive. We couldn't afford to do those other things. We couldn't convince him, so we felt the best thing to do was move him before he became a free agent."
Boston won the arm of the right-hander by offering Carl Pavano, a good young pitcher, and Tony Armas Jr., a minor league pitcher they had received from the Yankees for Mike Stanley three months earlier.
"A couple clubs turned us down when we asked for their players," Beattie said. "I'm sure some of those organizations look at it now and say, 'How could we say no?' "
The Yankees wouldn't trade Eric Milton for Martinez (they sent him to Minnesota for Chuck Knoblauch less than three months later). Cleveland declined to give up Bartolo Colon, who is in their starting rotation now.
Beattie can still feel the pain from trading Martinez. "I definitely would have loved to have kept him," he said. "He's got quality pitches, he's a great competitor, he's an intelligent player and he works hard."
Duquette credited Martinez with turning the Red Sox into a legitimate contender. The Red Sox have reached the postseason in each of the pitcher's first two seasons with them and appear to be headed there again this year.
Martinez, who has won the Cy Young award in each league, gained a permanent spot in postseason lore last October by pitching six hitless innings of relief against Cleveland in the fifth and deciding game of their division series. He followed that remarkable performance by holding the Yankees to two hits in seven innings after the Yankees had won the first two games of the league championship series. The Yankees, however, won the next two games, assuring that they wouldn't see Martinez in Game 7.
"That was a situation we certainly wanted to do everything we could to avoid," David Cone said. "I don't think any team in baseball would want that scenario."
Martinez's playoff performance wasn't even his best against the Yankees last year. In September he struck out 17 and allowed just 1 hit, a home run by Chili Davis. That gave him a two-start record of 29 strikeouts and 3 hits allowed in 16 innings.
"He could've won without any fielders behind him that night," Paul O'Neill said of the September game.
Martinez enters tonight's game with the lowest earned run average (1.19) and the lowest opponents' batting average (.167) in the major leagues. Last season he had the majors' lowest e.r.a. and was three points away from having the lowest batting average against.
"I don't know what Sandy Koufax was like during his incredible five-year run that everyone talks about," Cone said, "but Pedro's having that type of run, maybe even better. He's having arguably one of the best runs of all time. One year, two year, three year."
Jason Giambi of Oakland, one of this season's most productive hitters, called Martinez's pitches "electric." Larry Rothschild, the Tampa Bay manager and a former pitcher and pitching coach, said Martinez's fastball, curve and changeup are outstanding individually and collectively.
"In an at-bat against him," Giambi said, "you get one pitch to hit and if you don't hit it, you're heading back to the dugout." Yet Giambi said that he likes to face Martinez. "It's such a challenge," he said.
Rothschild, too, acknowledged that he enjoyed watching Martinez work even if he beats the Devil Rays.
"I almost hate to admit that," the manager said, "but he's so good at what he does you have to sit back and realize you're watching one of the best there is and take solace from that."
 
Making Baseballs
 Major league officials were in Costa Rica last week touring the Rawlings factory that makes major league baseballs. Orlando Hernandez was there two years earlier.
"I visited twice, once before I signed and once after I signed," said the Yankees pitcher, who lived in Costa Rica immediately after defecting from Cuba. "I've never seen anything like that. I saw it in Cuba, but it wasn't the same. The quality of the materials is better in Costa Rica.
"What impressed me the most was the way they make a baseball. It took me 35 minutes to make a baseball myself. The boss said to me, 'You may be a good ballplayer, but you don't know anything about making baseballs.' "
Hernandez, who apparently is the only major league player who has visited the factory, was asked if the ball he made was juiced.
He laughed and said through a translator, "If the baseballs were made the way I made it, there would be no home runs."
 
Indians' Pitching Woes
 For several years the Cleveland Indians tried unsuccessfully to secure a No. 1 pitcher. Last winter they finally succeeded, luring Chuck Finley into the fold as a free agent. The pitching gods, however, are still laughing at them.
On the same day earlier this month, two starters, Charles Nagy and Jaret Wright, and a reliever, Ricardo Rincon, went on the disabled list. Last week another reliever, Paul Shuey, joined them. Wright returned last night but lasted only 12 batters and one and one-third innings as he gave up seven runs to the White Sox.
Nagy had bone chips removed from his right elbow and is expected to be out for eight weeks.
The Indians used two rookies in their place last week.
Paul Rigdon dazzled the Yankees, shutting them out on two hits in his seven-inning effort, but Tim Drew, brother of J. D., lasted only three batters into the second inning against Detroit, giving up five runs (three earned).
Rigdon's trouble came later. He strained a muscle in his left side Friday and was placed on the disabled list yesterday.
 
Vidro's Hitting Soars
 When Jose Vidro first reached the major leagues, in 1997, he replaced an injured Vladimir Guerrero on the Montreal roster. Last week he supplanted the highly talented Guerrero as the Expos' leading hitter.
The unheralded second baseman, who in his first full major league season last year batted .304, reached .399 last week and then entered last night's game in San Diego at .391 to Guerrero's .381. "I've always liked him as a hitter," Jim Beattie, the Expos' general manager, said. "He reminds me of Edgar Martinez in his knowledge of hitting."
 Noting that Vidro had hit eight home runs, Beattie added: "Edgar didn't have a lot of power when he came up, but he developed it at the big league level. Jose has a chance to hit 20 to 30 home runs depending on how hot he gets. He has a great approach to hitting and he's a smart player."
The 25-year-old switch-hitter also was leading the league in hits (70) and multihit games (22) and was tied for the lead in doubles (17).

HEADLINE: NEW YORK ONLINE;
Brownstone Soup

BYLINE: By DAVID KIRBY 

 BODY:

Taste of Brooklyn
www.tasteofbrooklyn.com
 
 O.K., so Brooklyn is not exactly the land of milk and honey. But there is plenty of other yummy stuff on the menu, so much that it is getting hard to keep track of it all. But don't despair. There is a Web site dedicated solely to monitoring, rating and sometimes ranting about the mushrooming restaurant scene in Brooklyn, U.S.A. 
 "The scene just exploded," said Lenny Karle-Zenith, who, with his wife Anne, founded the Web site, Taste of Brooklyn%%cq%%, last year. "Nobody really expected it." Why such gastronomic growth? "Like everything else in Manhattan, rents were out of control," he said. "It was much cheaper to open new places in Brooklyn." He added, "Many people were getting tired of the Manhattan food grind. And some restaurateurs tired of it, too. They saw Brooklyn as a prime market, especially the area around Smith Street, with all the young professionals moving into Carroll Gardens."
 The Karle-Zeniths moved to Carroll Gardens five years ago, "when there was nothing but a pizza joint," Mr. Karle-Zenith said. "But we're real foodies, so we began searching out little places in Brooklyn." The couple first encountered Patois, a top-rated bistro in Carroll Gardens. They soon found more culinary gems amid the boroughs' brownstones, and when more restaurants like Victory Kitchen began opening, "we decided it was time to create a directory and put it online," Mr. Karle-Zenith said.
WHAT YOU SEE -- The site is well organized and easy to navigate. But Brooklyn is a very big place. So far, the site covers only epicurean hot spots in Brownstone Brooklyn -- Carroll Gardens, Boerum Hill, Park Slope, Brooklyn Heights, Cobble Hill and Fort Greene. Bay Ridge, Williamsburg and other neighborhoods will be added soon.
 Sections include "Find A Restaurant," which allows searching by neighborhood, cuisine or price; "Main Ingredient," describing one dish that is fairly Brooklynesque (this month, pasta) and providing local recipes; "Taster's Choice," with reviews written by neighbors called "taste buds," and "What's Cooking," almost daily updates on Brooklyn openings, closings, promotions, wine tastings and more.
 There is also a regular feature article (for example, an in-depth look at rice balls), a "Tastemaker" interview with a local chef or owner, a "Wine Lady" column and one called "Percy Speaks," a highly opinionated review of life, politics and eating out in Brooklyn, written by the Karle-Zeniths' downstairs neighbor.
 LINKS -- To several sites covering local food, art, culture and economic development.
 WHAT YOU GET -- A cross-referenced, constantly updated culinary excursion through the place that Ed Norton, of "Honeymooners" fame, once called "the garden spot of the world." DAVID KIRBY
