HEADLINE: SCHOOLS;
A School District Under a Microscope

BYLINE: By ANITA DENNIS 

DATELINE: MAPLEWOOD

 BODY:
"It's like astronaut camp for teachers."
In any word association game, that would hardly be the way most residents here would think of their school district. 
 Yet that is precisely the opinion one Harvard researcher has of schools run by Marilyn Davenport, who last year became director of elementary education in the South Orange-Maplewood School District and principal of the Seth Boyden Demonstration School.
Since the book "Frames of Mind" was published in 1983, school districts throughout the country have been influenced by the work of Howard Gardner, a Harvard University professor who developed the theory of multiple intelligences -- which simply means different people can be smart in different ways. And recently Ms. Davenport, an educator recognized as having had great success in implementing the theory, came to this district with its history of high achievement and is trying to maintain it.
"When we work with a child, we must think, 'I don't know how this child is smart, but I'm going to find out,' " she said.
In her previous job as principal of the Governor Bent Elementary School in Albuquerque, test scores consistently placed in the top 5 among the district's 80 elementary schools even though similar schools with many children from lower socio-economic groups might have typically placed in the bottom quartile.
Ms. Davenport's approach appealed to this district, which has about 6,300 students, and homes that range from modest to mansions. Like her school in Albuquerque, the towns have seen a rise in students from lower socio-economic groups.
In the first year of testing, in 1999, under the Elementary School Proficiency Assessment, 76 percent of the district's fourth graders scored proficient or above in math, compared with 60 percent average statewide. In language arts, 55 percent were proficient or higher (compared with 42 percent statewide) and in science, 93 percent showed proficiency or above (compared with 86 percent statewide).
"We have a diverse community makeup and high expectations," says Peter Horoschak, the South Orange-Maplewood district superintendent who worked with Ms. Davenport in Albuquerque. "To me, that meant we had the makings for demonstrating that students from different kinds of backgrounds and ethnicities can really succeed."
One main focus for Ms. Davenport in her new job is the Seth Boyden Demonstration School, an elementary school where teachers can best develop educational practices to be used throughout the district.
The school, which has more than 450 students, this year accepted about 70 transfer students from other district schools as part of a continuing districtwide effort to achieve racial and economic balance. At an open house this month, about 200 people came to learn about the school and its open enrollment plan.
It is hoped that these efforts will help to reinvigorate schools with the district's lowest test scores, including Seth Boyden.
"If one or more of our elementary schools are perceived as being laggards, then as a community, we're going to fail," said the board of education president, Brian O'Leary, who chose to send his kindergartner to Seth Boyden in Maplewood instead of to the Marshall School in South Orange, his neighborhood school. "We can't say, well, two-thirds of our schools are really good. All of them have to be uniformly excellent."
Ms. Davenport is not alone in her embrace of the theory, but she is considered an exemplar of its practical application. After Dr. Gardner first visited Ms. Davenport's school in Albuquerque in the early 1990's, he told an associate that it reminded him of the finest prep schools.
In his groundbreaking book, Dr. Gardner questioned the idea of intelligence as a uniform capacity that can be measured in something like an IQ test. Instead, he has identified several kinds of intelligence: linguistic, musical, logical-mathematical, spatial, bodily-kinesthetic, inter- and intrapersonal and naturalist. Everyone shares these intelligences, the idea goes, but people are stronger in some areas than others. Once teachers have identified each child's strengths and weaknesses, they can better understand how the child can achieve.
"Children come to you thinking they're smart," Ms. Davenport said, "but sometimes in school we convince them they're not. Intelligence is not fixed. If you believe that, you don't think much can be done in school."
To achieve excellence, Ms. Davenport "feels that it's important for children to have a sense of competence and a feeling that they belong," noted Mindy Kornhaber, a Harvard researcher who works with Dr. Gardner and has investigated the practical use of multiple intelligence for the last nine years. Ms. Davenport's convictions provided the foundation for implementing the theory successfully, Dr. Kornhaber believes.
"Sometimes the theory is adopted because it sounds good," she said. "There's not a lot of prior thinking about why it sounds good or what it might do."
When Dr. Kornhaber studied Ms. Davenport's school in Albuquerque, she found that "the work that the children and the teachers were doing was spectacular."
"They had no art teacher and yet the classrooms were like children's museums," Dr. Kornhaber said. "The artwork was all project-oriented. If they were doing a project on the lifecycles of animals, they didn't just show you what a horse looked like. They built beautiful three-dimensional models of horses, and wrote an elaborate book about its lifecycle. They were able to do wonderful presentations about their work."
Although Dr. Gardner's work hasn't described how to implement the theory, Dr. Kornhaber thinks Ms. Davenport's work in Albuquerque was a good model because teachers called on children to use a variety of different abilities.
"They weren't just putting pencil to paper to produce a report on a horse. They were using their aesthetic sensibility," she said. "They had to communicate with each other to produce the work. There was even a logical-mathematical piece to it because they had to think about how to use multiple sources of data, how make points and use research."
As part of how to practically apply what the children have learned, Ms. Davenport says she has developed a list of intelligent behaviors for students, which range from understanding how they learn, to being joyful in school, to taking the time to celebrate their accomplishments.
In the South Orange-Maplewood district, Seth Boyden will be used to develop teachers districtwide.
As Dr. Kornhaber said, "For anyone who is interested in being at the top of their game, that's the school to be in."
Although Ms. Davenport has been in her new district only briefly, Dr. Kornhaber has no doubt she will leave her mark.
"The school will change in ways that are in line with her thinking, philosophy and experience, because she doesn't let go," she said.
While test scores will most likely not immediately reflect Ms. Davenport's work, the towns seem ready to stay the course.
"The key thing for a political figures like me is to make sure we hold the district to high standards and not back away from the importance of using public measures like test scores," Mr. O'Leary said. "At the same time, we have to give people time to make the substantial changes required to make sure we get good scores for the right reasons. We're not simply looking for good scores, but for quality education."

LENGTH: 630 words

HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.;
Whispers of Recession Are Growing Louder

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
"IT comes up in every meeting," said Jeffrey M. Applegate, chief United States strategist at Lehman Brothers. " 'Jeff, what is the risk of a hard landing?' "
Thomas M. Galvin, chief investment officer at Donald Lufkin & Jenrette, and Douglas R. Cliggott, United States equity strategist at J. P. Morgan Securities, are both hearing the same question, one that has been popping up in client meetings since the Federal Reserve raised its short-term interest rate target by half a percentage point, to 6.5 percent on May 16. 
 "There is a growing minority that believes the Fed could prove to be too heavy-handed, too aggressive," said Mr. Galvin.
"It's a question that is being asked a lot more and it makes sense," Mr. Cliggott added. "It's going to be tough to land this thing gently," he said, referring to attempts to slow America's rapid economic growth without triggering a recession.
A recession? Yes, a recession. The mere fact that the big clients of these equity strategists are asking the question shows just how quickly the mood in the stock market has changed.
Mr. Applegate, Mr. Galvin and Mr. Cliggott do not think that a recession is likely, but they acknowlege that the risk has risen. Real signs of inflationary pressures and the refusal, so far, by the American economy to slow down appreciably are already forcing the Fed to be aggressive in raising interest rates. And that just increases the risk of a mistake, that is, a recession.
This mood change has helped fuel the market selloff since the Fed's rate increase. The Nasdaq index is off 13.1 percent since then, while the Dow Jones industrial average has fallen 5.8 percent and the Standard & Poor's 500 index has dropped 6 percent.
Edward McKelvey, senior economist at Goldman Sachs, said the mood change was "all rooted in an increasing amount of evidence that the labor market is too tight for comfort," which forced the Fed to be more aggressive.
He said there were two modes that Fed policy makers might be in when they raise their benchmark Federal funds rate on loans between banks. They might be trying to slow growth to a manageable, noninflationary pace before inflation becomes a problem. That is what the Fed did in 1994 and 1995, with its last big series of rate increases. And it is what the group appears to have aimed for since last June, with five moderate, quarter-point increases in the Fed funds rate.
The Fed's other mode is to be intent on stamping out rising inflation, Mr. McKelvey said. If the Fed were to enter this mode, he said, the central bank would probably slow growth to below the 3.5 percent sustainable pace in order to subdue inflation. But that is risky. Mr. McKelvey says that the Fed has rarely shifted into that mode without the economy ending up in a recession.
He does not know what mode the Fed is in now. And he speculates that one would get "10 different answers" at the Fed, a reference to the 10 members of the Federal Open Market Committee, which sets the central bank's interest rate policy.
But Mr. McKelvey notes this interesting -- and possibly not irrelevant -- fact: Since World War II, when the three-month moving average of the nation's unemployment rate rose more than 0.3 of a percentage point, the economy wound up in a recession within a year.
The three-month moving average now is 4.03 percent, down from 4.07 percent the previous three months and the lowest it has been since February 1970. If this indicator held to historic form, a move up to 4.4 percent would be a really bad signal.
So, can the policy makers avoid a hard landing and push up the unemployment rate without tripping into a recession? This expansion has already broken many rules economists have long lived by. So maybe this time will be different. Maybe.

HEADLINE: Rewriting of Rent Regulations Gives Tenants and Landlords a New Battle Cry

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
There is a new battlefront between tenants and landlords. It is 200 pages of dense legalese quietly created by New York State officials to rewrite the rent regulations that cover 2.4 million residents, most of them in New York City, and that document has caused a furor.
The State Division of Housing and Community Renewal says that it is simply updating the rules to conform to laws, court decisions and regulatory directives since the last codification, in 1987. 
 But tenant groups accuse the state of making changes that favor landlords and undermine key protections for renters; changes for which, they say, there is no statutory authority. They say the changes will enable owners to raise rents improperly and to evict tenants.
But the housing agency's general counsel, Marcia P. Hirsch, denies those claims. The updating is required by law, she said, and the proposal clarifies numerous issues, including some that are being contested in court.
Although the state has not yet formally adopted the revised regulations, tenant leaders say they are preparing to challenge them in court. "There's no question that we're going to be suing to stop this," said Michael McKee, associate director of the New York State Tenants and Neighbors Coalition, which represents 17,000 individuals and 144 affiliated groups.
Sharp debate characterized public hearings on the issue Thursday in Manhattan, White Plains and Manhasset. Most of the rent-regulated apartments are in New York City, but about 70,000 are in Nassau, Westchester and Rockland Counties.
Landlords gave qualified supported to the proposal, but called for additional modifications.
"For both owners and tenants, this codification is an extremely valuable and useful process" because it consolidates all the rules in one place, said Joseph Strasburg, president of the city's largest landlord group, the Rent Stabilization Association, which represents 25,000 owners and managers. "The bottom line is that there is nothing new here."
But Mr. Strasburg urged several changes, including removing the time limit on when an owner can challenge whether the tenant whose name appears on a lease is really living in an apartment, and allowing owners to charge more than one month's rent as a security deposit.
Tenants' advocates adamantly opposed the changes in the revision, and accused the state of pushing the changes through without sufficient public review.
Mr. McKee linked the state agency's changes to an effort three years ago by the State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, to eliminate rent stabilization. Gov. George E. Pataki eventually forged a compromise between Mr. Bruno and tenant groups that was perceived as a defeat for Republicans. But Mr. McKee called the latest move an attempt "to achieve pro-landlord changes that George Elmer Pataki could not win from the State Legislature in 1997."
The tenants' advocates said that the hearings were not well publicized, that the proposal was not advertised and that copies of the draft were not available at the hearings. "How can I comment on your proposed code when I don't have a copy?" asked Pat McGovern, a tenant from Manhattan. "I asked for a copy at the desk, and they said they would mail me one."
Despite the proposal's length, speakers were limited to five minutes each and were barred from proposing further changes, although that rule was ignored.
"This is a landlord's wish list," said David Robinson, a lawyer for Legal Services for New York City, a nonprofit advocacy group. "I looked through 125 pages and found one page of protection for tenants."
City Councilman Stanley E. Michels, a Democrat from Manhattan, said: "This is a travesty. You are trying to destroy what's left of rent control and rent stabilization."
One surprise speaker at the Manhattan session was the head of the union that represents the housing agency's 475 employees in New York City, Ralph F. Carbone, president of Local 1359 of District Council 37. Mr. Carbone said that he was impartial in disputes between between landlords and tenants, but that he felt compelled to speak.
"I found that the proposals were slanted significantly toward owners," he said, "going beyond what I believe the current state law and judicial precedents are."

Because of an editing error, an article on May 28 about proposed rent regulation changes drafted by New York State officials referred incorrectly to comments by a tenant advocate, Michael McKee. Mr. McKee accused Gov. George E. Pataki and his administration of trying to undercut rent regulation but did not link the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, to the proposals.

HEADLINE: SOAPBOX;
Building Character

BYLINE: By TOM O'NEILL; Tom O'Neill is executive director of the Partnership for New Jersey and co-chair of the steering committee of the Coalition for Our Children's Schools.

 BODY:
NEW JERSEY today has a once-in-a-century opportunity. When the state Supreme Court ordered the construction and rehabilitation of schools in the poorest districts, it opened the way to the largest public works program in the state's history, even bigger than building the New Jersey Turnpike two generations ago.
The Legislature and the governor appear to be drawing closer to approving legislation to start these sorely needed projects. But so far the debate in the State House has failed to produce a program that can make the most of this enormous opportunity. With a little vision, this program could not only rebuild urban schools but also help revitalize entire communities. 
 A well-designed school construction program can improve educational outcomes and strengthen neighborhoods and families. Each school project can be planned with community development as a cornerstone. Schools can include spaces that might be a school nurse's office by day and a community health clinic during nonschool hours. Preschool centers should be included as a matter of course. Recreational, library and meeting space should serve students and the community, year round. California now requires that school planners consider these community-building features. Chicago's new school construction program also emphasizes community schools. Across the country, schools have built banking or food-shopping space into their buildings for job training or located in department stores or hospitals to provide exposure to careers and reinforce educational experiences.
New Jersey has not grasped the importance of gaining this potential leverage because it has not tapped the creativity of local communities in planning schools. The State House wants to centralize the financing, fiscal oversight and construction of schools into a single state agency. While the Economic Development Authority surely could provide financing and fiscal oversight and accountability, it lacks experience in actually managing construction programs of this range and scope. More seriously, it lacks familiarity with local schools and neighborhood needs. To maintain public confidence that huge sums are being spent wisely, New Jersey needs a sound system of state-level financing and fiscal control. But it also needs to harness the creativity and responsiveness of local planning and management.
New Jersey's cities do not lack for community organizations, businessinterests and concerned parents who want to improve their schools and neighborhoods. It is at the local level that coordination and community involvement will produce the synergies needed to improve both school and neighborhoods.
To enjoy even greater leverage from this investment, each project should incorporate job training, apprenticeship opportunities and local hiring goals for young men and women in the neighborhoods. The school construction program can start thousands of young people in good jobs where they can develop the traits and habits crucial to success in any career. But such programs are not assured under the currently debated legislation.
It is past time for the other two branches of government to abide by the Supreme Court's order and provide 100 percent funding for school construction in the Abbott Districts, those cited by the court. But many poor communities not covered by the court order should also be helped. Aid to those districts should be based on need, and provided through a rational formula to avoid further delaying new schools in the poorest districts while this contentious issue is resolved.
Through the recently formed Coalition for Our Children's Schools leaders from business, government, education and the nonprofit community are working to raise the level of awareness of this opportunity. If New Jersey does this right, our children, our communities and the entire state will benefit. If we dont, the chance might never come again, and we will fail to make the most of this enormous public investment.

HEADLINE: It's Futile to Put a Price on Slavery

BYLINE: By Glenn C. Loury; Glenn C. Loury is an economics professor and director of the Institute on Race and Social Division at Boston University.

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
A visit to any courthouse, public hospital emergency room or welfare office in a large city confirms that our society is still marred by the social and economic disadvantage of African-Americans.
Yet, with overt racial discrimination less prevalent nowadays, many Americans are asking why a concern about social deprivation should take particular notice of race. This is a fair question. 
 One answer is that black disadvantage remains a special problem because it originates from slavery, to which there is this conservative retort: "So what? Slavery ended a long time ago."
This has prompted a new demand from advocates of African-American interests: reparations, a money settlement that is to be given as compensation for past racial injury.
Of course, the reparations issue has been around since the end of slavery, starting with "40 acres and a mule." But lately the issue has gathered steam. Representative John Conyers, a Michigan Democrat, has sponsored a bill that would establish a commission to study the issue. Randall Robinson, president of TransAfrica, a lobbying group, eloquently argues for reparations in his book, "The Debt: What America Owes to Blacks."
Prominent intellectuals, including Charles Ogletree, a professor at Harvard Law School, and Henry Louis Gates, chairman of Harvard's Afro-American studies department, were considering a class-action lawsuit asking for reparations, according to a March article in The Boston Globe.
Although I am not without sympathy for this position, I believe that framing the argument in these terms is a mistake. We need some reckoning with the racist past, but reparations encourage the wrong kind of reckoning. Winning compensation would, in the end, allow conservatives to get away with their "so what?" retort.
Let me illustrate with a rough analogy. In South Africa, after the transition to majority rule, a Truth and Reconciliation Commission was empowered by the new government to pardon those who had committed political crimes during the long years of apartheid -- as long as the perpetrators of the crimes testified fully and truthfully to what they had done. Pardons were granted even to those who had killed blacks for the white regime.
In return, the undisputed truth of what had transpired under apartheid was established, and it is impossible to revise or challenge the record. The "so what?" retort is easily answered in South Africa -- now and in future generations.
Yes, the United States and South Africa are vastly different. But the South African case shows why compensation can never be the foundation for a satisfactory reckoning with the racist American past. Debts are things that are calculated and (sometimes) paid off. But the oppression of millions of human beings, orchestrated and abetted by national and state governments, is an atrocity of an altogether different order.
The heirs to this atrocity -- long established Americans and newly naturalized citizens alike -- should be confronted continually with the horrors of what their country wrought. They should be challenged to understand the contemporary consequences of these historic crimes.
The tort-law model underlying reparations advocacy -- he who causes damage to another is obliged to make the injured party whole -- is hopelessly insufficient here. It relies heavily upon being able to demonstrate in quantitative terms the nature and extent of injury.
How would one even begin to arrive at a sum for the reparation payments?
Who can say what the out-of-wedlock birth rate for blacks would be, absent chattel slavery? How does one calculate the cost of inner-city ghettos, of poor education, of the stigma of perceived racial inferiority? The severity of slavery's "injury" is far more profound than any cash transfer will be able to reverse.
Moreover, reparations would allow the majority of Americans to look at the situation as one where "we" do something for "them"-- alleviate their suffering, solve their problems, quiet their protests and then, once the debt is paid off, wash our hands of society's inequities.
Instead, we should follow another model, one that decrees that "we," meaning all Americans, should right the inequity for the sake of our country. We must attend to this matter so that our national fellowship and comity will not be emaciated, so that our moral pronouncements on the world stage will not be made into a hollow mockery.
As in South Africa, the deepest and most relevant "reparation" would entail constructing and inculcating in our citizens an account of how we have come to be as we are -- one that avoids putting the responsibility for the current problems of African-Americans wholly on their shoulders.
The "so what?" retort is historically naive and morally obtuse, but it is very American. So, too, is the clamor for reparations. After all, we are a problem-solving people who do not sit easily with the ghosts of our past. But the tragic legacy of slavery is a problem that simply will not yield to another application of American ingenuity. It will be with us for some time.

LENGTH: 793 words

HEADLINE: We Are All Spendthrifts Now

BYLINE: By Mary Gordon; Mary Gordon is the author of "Spending," and, most recently, "Seeing Through Places" and "Joan of Arc."

 BODY:
It has become increasingly difficult to read a newspaper or magazine without encountering the details of extravagant, conspicuous consumption, usually on the part of new millionaires, or billionaires, usually under 30. Stories of $1,000 spent on a bottle of wine. Reports of a dish of boiled sole and a roasted new potato that costs $60, not counting, of course, tips and taxes. Apartments in New York City formerly considered marginally uninhabitable snapped up at the price of half a million dollars.
Our imaginations are drawn to these stories; they have the allure of soft porn, at least for those of us who congratulate ourselves on not jumping for the bait, those of us who believe ourselves capable of the statement, "It isn't worth it." 
 But what do we mean by "worth"?
When we use the word, we are talking about a system of equivalencies -- a transaction between the symbolic and the actual which many people believe is the most real thing there is, but which is, in fact, a sheer act of imagination. Whose idea was it that a hard, inedible and unprotecting substance (stones, shells, metal) could be traded for food, clothing, shelter?
The use of money is the purest act of faith; no anchorite who has followed a vision into the desert has acted on an idea as far-fetched as our belief that if we put a dollar in a machine we will be drinking a Diet Coke in a minute. Of course, we don't think of this strangeness all the time, but sometimes, when the numbers seem to have reached the fantastical, we question the idea of worth: how much should be handed over for what things?
These decisions are often based on personal history or biography. My mother's sense of worth, for example, was much different from mine. She had been a young woman during the Depression and was always haunted by the specter of real poverty, even during the prosperous 50's and 60's. She supported us on a secretary's salary, so we were never able to live luxuriously, but she suspected all expenditure, almost for its own sake.
She saved wrapping paper and tinfoil and Saran wrap. Closets and drawers were full of discolored papers and crinkled squares of foil and ill-smelling plastics. She usually waited for someone to die before replenishing her wardrobe: wearing the clothes of the dead seemed to her a superior choice to a purchase in a store. She deprived herself of the real pleasures of consumption: we never ate in restaurants or stayed in hotels.
My cousin and I (he was the son of her sister) feel that every time we buy something that gives us pleasure, we are undoing an old curse. We refer to such activities as "mental health purchases."
The flexibility of a sense of worth was brought home to me last week when my oldest friend and I sent our children shopping in Harvard Square. Thirty years ago, we had spent the summer in Cambridge, she studying physics (she later became a doctor), I working as a secretary in an insurance company (I later became a novelist). That summer, we made a weekly decision about whether we would share a frankfurter at a German restaurant, or a piece of apple cake.
Half a lifetime later, we dropped our teenage daughters off, shoving bills at them through the car window.
"How much did you give them?" my friend asked.
"Fifty dollars," I said.
"Me too," she told me.
Neither of us believed we had been extravagant, but we noted the difference 30 years and increased prosperity had made. Fifty dollars was liberal, it made us happy that we could offer our children an ease we hadn't had ourselves.
But what if we had given them $500? Is there ever a point at which it is important to say, "this far and no further"? Isn't there a moment when we question the relationship between what we paid and what we got?
Was the plate of sole really worth $60? Was the studio apartment really worth $500,000?
We use the word "disposable income," but shouldn't we consider what's being disposed of?
Is it only hypocritical or absurd to question what the poor could do with the money?
The fact that I have to fear that mentioning the poor will induce only yawns or groans, as if I'd questioned the propriety of sleeveless dresses, tells us something about what seems important, even discussable, to us now.
In these cloud-cuckooland times, there seems to be a gap between price tag and worth. Shouldn't we consider, without fearing that we've turned into Puritans or killjoys, taking a deep breath before speaking sentences whose language is made up of numbers that seem incomprehensibly distant from what once seemed reasonable?
Is this a real question, or just my version or my mother's shouted admonition: "Don't rip that wrapping paper off that box so fast! Do you think I'm made of money?"

HEADLINE: NEW ECONOMY;
Convergence, the nextstage in technology, may wind up being a different creature than expected.

BYLINE: By Seth Schiesel 

DATELINE: DANA POINT, Calif.

 BODY:
OF all of the buzzwords in the technology industry, perhaps none is invoked as blindly, reflexively and totemically as "convergence."
Talk to a senior technology executive these days and you will probably hear about how television, the telephone system and the Internet are converging to create an interactive world of information and entertainment. 
 But, in fact, convergence is not really happening, at least not yet. And when it does, it will probably take forms much different than those generally envisioned today.
That is not a conclusion a visitor might have expected to bring away from the annual Vortex conference that ended on Friday here on the Pacific Coast. Vortex is about convergence, and it may be North America's most concentrated gathering of top communications investors and executives. But according to an automated polling service at the conference, the Vortex attendees gave convergence an overall letter grade of D-plus for now.
They recognize that even though billions of dollars are being spent on convergence, immense obstacles remain. And in the end, convergence will be far less than universal.
At the first Vortex conference two years ago, the mood about convergence was positively giddy. "Two years ago here I remember people looking at the new carriers, the Qwests and Level 3's, and thinking that they were just going to make convergence happen," said a senior technical executive for a big local communications carrier. "I think what's impressing me this year is a new sense of maturity -- sobriety even."
A 21 percent drop in the Nasdaq will sober up just about anyone in the technology business. And it has. But beyond the financial picture, the emerging sense of realism about convergence seems based on a simple and renewed appreciation of the mundane technical obstacles that stand in its way, and on some newly creative thinking about what sorts of services will best embody it.
Technically, convergence is the last mile. That sounds obvious, but the last few years, at least some technology pundits, executives and investors have drooled over the exponential increases in bandwidth capacity in the nation's long-distance fiber optic networks and mistaken that for convergence.
But for all of the leaps in long-haul capacity, no more than 2 percent of the nation's 100 million or so homes currently log on the Internet with anything more powerful than an analog modem. The last mile of the nation's communications networks -- or the first mile, depending on who's holding the mouse -- is the part that actually touches homes. But this crucial link has not kept pace with the rest of the network.
The digital subscriber line technology that local phone companies want to use to deliver torrents of Internet data over traditional copper phone lines has had a particularly tough time living up to expectations. D.S.L. is far more difficult to put in place than was originally thought. And the bandwidth, or speed, it delivers is far less than was first contemplated.
In early 1998, when many of the nation's leading computer, software and local communications companies formed an alliance to support D.S.L., they thought it would generally deliver 1.5 million digital bits a second to consumers' homes. Today, it is unlikely that more than a quarter of the few hundred thousand households with working D.S.L. are consistently receiving more than a million bits, or a megabit, a second. Industry experts say that most D.S.L. households probably get only around 500,000 bits a second, at best. (Cable modems, the main alternative to D.S.L., more frequently deliver megabit-plus speeds, but in some ways those communications pathways are less reliable than D.S.L.)
Of course, even 500,000 bits a second is still an order of magnitude faster than the 53,000 or so bits a second that can be delivered by today's fastest analog modems. But consider that a single channel of TV-quality video, using compression technology, requires at least 2 million bits a second and often requires more than 5 million bits a second; it becomes quite clear that for the great majority of consumers, television as they know it is not going to be converging with the Internet soon.
But then, merging TV with the Internet is probably the wrong goal, anyway. Television is a one-way, centrally created and distributed medium. It is not the killer application for the Internet because the Internet does not operate like TV.
And yet, most demonstrations of converged applications that include video, including those at Vortex, are essentially television with some interactive buttons, like "buy now," or "chat about this program," tacked on the side of the screen.
"The trap is when people think about this new media strictly in the context of the old," said Michael O'Dell, chief scientist for Worldcom's Uunet operation, the No. 1 Internet carrier. "I have a problem believing that the future of the Internet is a bad version of cable TV."
Rather than take the form of merely repackaged traditional media, the most successful converged services will probably be cut from wholly new cloth to take advantage of the specific characteristics of cyberspace.
Napster, the service that allows users to swap digital music files, is a perfect example. And some technology experts believe that Napster is already consuming more of the Internet's bandwidth than is the leading Web site, Yahoo. Rather than simply selling compact discs online or putting radio stations online (the aural equivalent of adding a "chat now" button to a TV program), the very nature of Napster's service emerged from the Internet.
In fact, Vinod Khosla, the venture capitalist from Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, said trying to repackage traditional media online was actually hindering the deployment of broadband communications and converged services in general.
"When you're trying to migrate old services to a new medium, the barriers are high and the payoffs aren't that great," Mr. Khosla said. "But when you have a new service, maybe the barrier is high but I'll climb over it because the payoff is higher."

HEADLINE: A Commercial Makes Canadian Self-Esteem Bubble to the Surface

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: CALGARY, Alberta

 BODY:
Over the din of a multi-screen sports bar, Dallas Hyde recalled the magical moment at a Calgary Flames hockey game, when "he" stood up in the crowd.
"Everybody in the crowd went nuts," Mr. Hyde, 24, an oil change supervisor, recalled of the moment when Jeff Douglas stepped before a microphone to deliver The Rant. 
 "I'm not a lumberjack or a fur trader; I don't live in an igloo, eat blubber or own a dogsled," the Nova Scotia actor said, repeating lines from a Molson Canadian beer commercial that has become a nationalist mantra for 30 million Canadians this spring.
Addressing an invisible American audience, "Joe Canadian" patiently continued his lesson: "I have a prime minister, not a president. I speak English and French, not American."
"I can proudly sew my country's flag on my backpack," he said, uttering patriotic lines that now are recited in bars and high school hallways from Vancouver to Halifax. "I believe in peacekeeping, not policing; diversity, not assimilation."
By now the television version is flashing images of maple leaves and beavers as Joe Canadian reaches his climax, bellowing: "Canada is the second-largest land mass, the first nation of hockey and the best part of North America. My name is Joe and I am Canadian."
Canadian hockey teams struck out in the Stanley Cup for a record-breaking seventh year in a row, the Canadian dollar is stuck at two-thirds of the United States dollar, a southern brain drain is cherry-picking this year's crop of college graduates, but Canadians have found a powerful spine-stiffening elixir: a nationalistic beer commercial.
Tired of being measured against the eternal American yardstick, Canadians are doing something uncharacterically Canadian: beating their chests with patriotism.
The Rant, as the 60-second commercial is known, has won cheers in movie theaters, endless debate on talk radio, fist-pumping ovations by fans at National Hockey League games and 14,000 e-mail messages to a special Web site created by Molson, www.iam.ca.
"We were taken aback by how much it struck a chord with everybody," said Paul Thomson, a Molson spokesman, who quickly put the "Joe Canadian" actor on a national tour of hockey rinks. "There was a lot of Canadian pride that was below the surface, exploding the myth that young adult Canadians are not proud of their country."
At Schanks Athletic Club, the sports bar here, Kim Anderson said of the ad, "It's kind of neat for him to yell it out," though adding, "After all, everything here is American."
Indeed, in a nation with the highest level of foreign economic ownership in the developed world -- 23 percent of company assets -- the beer-drinking patrons of Schanks were sitting in the electronic wash of ESPN.
From British Columbia, long a liberal bastion, Lisa McCaskill, a sales manager, said, "I saw it in a movie theater in Vancouver, and people were cheering -- real patriots."
Glen Hunt, 35, a Toronto advertising executive, wrote the ad after returning to Canada last fall from a three-year stint in New York.
"We sent people out on the street to see how young people felt about being Canadian," said Mr. Hunt, a creative director for Bensimon Byrne D'Arcy. "They started pretty quiet, but once they got going it was a dormant volcano ready to erupt.
At the same time, this flag-waving surge has collided with two forces that historically have deflated chest-pumping patriotism here: English Canada's cutting humor and the nation's unity-defying regionalism.
"I can proudly sew my country's flag on my backpack," Mark Steyn, a National Post newspaper columnist, wrote recently. "That's because even though I am a beer-guzzling hockey fan, I took sewing classes in Canada's non-gender-stereotyping school system."
He noted that many Canadians feel squeamish about reciting the national oath of allegiance to Queen Elizabeth II. On one hand, they gripe, pledging allegiance seems so American. On the other hand, swearing allegiance to the queen seems so British. Mr. Steyn concluded: "If you drink enough Molson, eventually even Canada makes sense."
In a country where east-west links are tenuous, comedians quickly deconstructed The Rant into a series of regional mini-rants.
From this western province, an "I am Albertan" parody hails John Deere for making "the best hats" and then rants, "I speak flawless English and gripe to the store manager about French labels on cereal boxes."
From Quebec an English-language radio station aired this satire that contradicted any notion of unity there: "I believe in language police, not equal rights," the announcer says in a heavy French accent. "I believe Club Supersex is an appropriate place for my wife and I to celebrate our anniversaire."
"The land where everybody is shacking up and the legal drinking age is just a suggestion," he continues. "Je m'appelle Guy -- and I am not Canadien."
From Newfoundland a regional rant concludes: "Newfoundland is the second island province, the first nation of drinking and the best party in North America! My name is Baz, and I am Newfie!"
Despite the inability of some Canadians to take patriotism seriously, The Rant is believed to have prompted the government of Ontario, Canada's most populous province, to announce that starting in September, each student will start the day by standing at attention, singing the national anthem, "O Canada," and pledging allegiance to the queen.
Here in Alberta, governing Conservative Party lawmakers are considering legislation that would require schoolchildren to sing "O Canada" at least weekly. In Quebec, which has been governed by the separatist Parti Quebecois since 1994, Canadian symbols like the national flag and anthem are officially ignored and Molson Canadian is not marketed.
The new nationalist mood has won applause in Ottawa, the national capital.
"Someone has decided nationalism sells," Charles Gordon, a columnist for The Ottawa Citizen wrote approvingly in Maclean's magazine. "If that's true, it's good. It means that a unique culture, in art and music and theater and writing, can survive in this country, survive in the face of a powerful culture pouring over our border every day."
Recently, Canada's heritage minister, Sheila Copps, went to Boston and showed the commercial to an International Press Institute panel, "American Culture -- the People's Choice or a Form of Imperialism?"
But unless a giddy new nationalism can really bubble out of a beer commercial, The Globe and Mail of Toronto offered this sobering cup of expresso. A few years ago the Charles R. Bronfman Foundation, a private cultural group, tried to spoon-feed history to the Canadian masses with a series called "Heritage Minutes."
"All they sparked," the newspaper editorialist recalled, "was a series of parodies on the Comedy Network called 'Sacrilege Moments,' financed by -- wait for it -- Molson."

HEADLINE: As Homicides Rise, New York Faces Return of Fear

BYLINE: By JAYSON BLAIR 

 BODY:
New York preceded most cities in experiencing the historic drop in crime that has swept across America's urban areas and spurred an economic renaissance in many once-devastated neighborhoods.
But while crime in New York remains at a 30-year low, city officials have worked hard in the last year trying to allay fears that the city may be headed back to the days when more than 1,500 homicides a year were not uncommon. 
 By the end of 1998, the city's murder rate had dropped to its lowest point since 1964. But after a decline in homicides to 629 in 1998 from 2,245 in 1990, New York is beginning to record a slight increase, police statistics show.
Although all other major categories of crime have continued to decline, there have been 269 homicides this year, compared with 248 at the same point last year, police records show. And several recent crimes -- a woman attacked by a man with a brick in Midtown last fall, a spate of killings of cabdrivers and the slayings of five people last week at a Wendy's restaurant in Queens -- have drawn intense attention, suggesting that the perception, if not the reality, of a dangerous city may be returning.
Homicides, in fact, are down 62 percent compared with 1993, police records show. "When things are going well, sometimes the shock is so large because you have told people they don't have to worry about crime," said Thomas A. Repetto, chairman of the Citizen's Crime Commission, a police watchdog group in New York City.
While some law enforcement officials say domestic violence, gang killings and a growth in the juvenile and young adult population most often linked to murders are responsible for the two-year spike in homicides, Andrew Karmen, a sociologist at John Jay College of Criminal Justice in Manhattan, said, "There is nothing you can point to and say that 'this is the culprit.' "
Mr. Karmen said economic, demographic and other factors are playing a role in the murder rate's increase, leading to questions about the extent to which law enforcement has suppressed violence. In New York, officials have credited smart and aggressive police work for the crime rate's decline.
Most experts agree that in many respects, the New York police have become victims of their own success: the declining crime rate has raised expectations and created statistical lows that will serve to highlight any future increases.
"There is a tremendous amount of fear," Mr. Repetto said, "because you've told yourself crime is not a problem."
But Yolanda Jimenez, the deputy police commissioner who handles community affairs, said city officials have been educating people about crime trends. "We have had a challenging four years," she said. "But in spite and despite all that, the large crime reductions have really paved the way for people to deal with issues like quality of life and programs for young people."

HEADLINE: Asia's Tycoons Prepare to Join Rush to Internet

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, May 28

 BODY:
In this densely packed city, where property is the coin of the realm, Raymond Kwok is as close as one gets to royalty.
Mr. Kwok's 46th-floor office looks out on a forest of skyscrapers, dozens of them built by his family. Across the harbor in Kowloon are sawtooth rows of apartment houses, also built by the family. The Kwok's real estate empire is one of the largest in Asia, making Raymond, 46, and his two brothers fabulously wealthy, even by Hong Kong's baroque standards. 
 These days, however, Mr. Kwok is worried about something that has little to do with concrete, glass and steel. "We always follow closely what is happening in the U.S.," he said. "In America, we see how technology is changing business, how technology is creating a lot of new businesses."
As the Internet sweeps across the Pacific, Mr. Kwok believes technology will unleash the same frenzy of sudden wealth and disorienting change in Asia. If his family wants to keep its place among Hong Kong's commercial elite, he says, it must join the revolution. So Mr. Kwok, a Harvard M.B.A., has devised one of the most ambitious Internet strategies of any old-line Asian company, creating a diverse portfolio of Internet start-ups related to his family's business.
The Kwoks are one of several wealthy Asian clans determined not to be left behind. From Taiwan to Thailand, the region's most powerful families have started a blizzard of online ventures. Whether their core businesses are in property, telecommunications or banking, Asia's tycoons are seizing on the Internet in hopes of expanding their reach.
In the process, the Internet is transforming the way business is done here and elsewhere in East Asia. With its emphasis on speed, openness, and collaboration, the Net is challenging traditional Asian values of prudence and family control. Decisions, which used to be made by the patriarch behind a veil of secrecy, are being pushed down the ranks as Asian companies embrace Silicon Valley-style management.
"The classic Asian family dynasty probably isn't the best suited to succeed on the Internet," said Peter Yip, the chief executive of Chinadotcom, one of Asia's first publicly traded Internet companies. "But I've been amazed by how quickly they've learned the business."
Not everyone is so sanguine. Despite their chameleon-like adaptability, Asia's tycoons may have trouble making the leap into cyberspace, critics say. For the last quarter-century, the tycoons rode a wave of double-digit growth. In countries like Indonesia, Thailand and Malaysia, cozy ties with governments sheltered them from market forces.
"These guys think the Internet will bring them prosperity for the next 25 years," said Jimmy Lai, a Hong Kong publisher who is putting his media properties online and starting an Internet shop-from-home service. "But to unlearn the lessons of the last 25 years is impossible."
Over time, Mr. Lai (pronounced lie) predicts, the culture of the Internet will erode the dominance of family dynasties in Asian commerce. By making information widely available, the Web will gradually devalue the networks of personal contacts -- known in Chinese as guanxi -- amassed over decades.
Mr. Kwok, though, thinks he can ride the technology tidal wave. He spent much of 1999 in the United States, roaming around conferences and quizzing entrepreneurs.
He discovered some online businesses that play to the strengths of property owners. One is providing specially outfitted office space to house computer servers. Another is creating Internet sites, including chat rooms and bulletin boards, for the residents of the apartment complexes owned by the Kwok family's company, Sun Hung Kai Properties.
Soon, Mr. Kwok packaged his collection of start-ups into a holding company, Sunevision, which went public on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange. While Mr. Kwok is the chairman, he has recruited an outside executive to run it.
"The mind-set of a technology company is very different from a property company," Mr. Kwok said. "We needed to remove a lot of baggage."
For Jeffrey Koo Jr., the challenge was persuading his elders that the Internet was more than a fad. Mr. Koo, 35, is a fourth-generation member of a family that controls a vast empire in banking, telecommunications, cement and cable television.
In talking with classmates from the Wharton School in 1997, Mr. Koo became convinced that his family had to lash its future to the Internet. As president of the family's Chinatrust Commercial Bank, Mr. Koo began taking baby steps online. But his father turned down his first request for $10 million to finance an Internet service provider.
"My father and his brothers were against me doing this because they thought of it as a form of gambling," Mr. Koo said. "When I would talk excitedly about a new venture, they would look at me blankly."
In Mr. Koo's case, the elders came around when Microsoft bought a 10 percent stake in his start-up, GigaMedia, an entertainment and information service. Earlier this year, GigaMedia became the first Taiwan Internet company to go public on the Nasdaq exchange. Although it was caught in Nasdaq's downdraft, it is still worth well over $2 billion.
Now, Mr. Koo is developing online banking and a regional e-commerce service to complement the family's 75 percent stake in GigaMedia. Less than two years after his father gave the Internet the cold shoulder, Jeffrey Jr. said, he now talks constantly about the cyberworld.
To some students of Asian business, this is merely a new chapter in an old story. Ethnic Chinese families have traditionally prospered by adapting to new circumstances. Kwok Tak-seng, the patriarch of the Kwok family, started as a trader in southern China. By the 1950's, he had migrated to Hong Kong and become the local agent for the Y.K.K. zipper company of Japan.
Sensing more opportunity in property than zippers, Mr. Kwok began building apartment houses. By the 1980's, he was a leading real estate developer. Mr. Kwok died in 1990, but under his three sons, Sun Hung Kai grew into a conglomerate with interests in toll roads, cargo handling and mobile telephones.
"One good thing about old-economy companies is that they have profits and cash flow," said Raymond's older brother, Thomas, who oversees Sun Hung Kai's real estate business. "But old-economy companies need new-economy ideas to survive."
For all their rock-solid stature, however, Asia's tycoons face challenges from a host of upstarts. Mr. Lai, the publisher and a self-styled maverick, offers himself as an example. Last year, he started a venture that lets customers order groceries and other goods by phone or over the Internet. The company, adMart, delivers from its warehouses, cutting out the middleman.
In Hong Kong, the middleman for many of these goods is Li Ka-shing, a billionaire who owns one of the two local supermarket chains. When Mr. Lai's delivery business began to pinch Mr. Li's stores, he canceled his company's advertising in Apple Daily and Next magazine, the outspoken newspaper and weekly magazine at the heart of Mr. Lai's company.
For Mr. Lai, the lost revenue has hurt. But after years of tweaking Hong Kong's establishment in his newspaper, Mr. Lai relishes mounting a frontal assault on its most powerful local businessman. "I could never take on Li Ka-shing before," Mr. Lai said. "But if I'm riding on the back of a huge market force like the Internet, then even he can't stop me."
In a sense, the Internet is the second revolution to rumble through Asia recently. In 1997 and 1998, the regional financial crisis brought many family empires to the brink of ruin. Even in Hong Kong, property prices plunged by more than half, and are only now recovering.
In the aftermath, many Asian governments took steps to clean up their banks, tighten commercial regulations and force companies to improve their disclosure.
"Before the crisis, Asian firms regarded financial disclosure and minority shareholders as a necessary irritant," said Peter Churchouse, co-head of research at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in Hong Kong. "Now they know they can't get away with that."
But if Asia's tycoons were humbled, the crisis did not dull their entrepreneurial instincts. Watching start-ups like Amazon.com become sensations in America, the tycoons saw a chance for a quick score. Virtually every conglomerate rushed out an Internet unit.
Li Ka-shing started e-commerce ventures through his two companies, Hutchison Whampoa and Cheung Kong Holdings. He also backed a Chinese-language portal, Tom.com, which prompted a near-riot among investors when it went public last February. Tom.com tumbled in the global technology sell-off. But thanks to Mr. Li's gold-plated reputation, it still trades above its offering price.
"You've got to hand it to the conglomerates, they've maintained their position in a radically different economy," said Mark Duff, the founder and chief executive of Boom.com, an online stock-trading company here.
Indeed, Mr. Duff and other entrepreneurs fear that the tycoons are colonizing Asia's cyberspace. They say that the family companies can soak up money and talent that could have gone to more daring ideas.
It is true that the tycoon-backed ventures are often unimaginative. Sunevision's concept of providing warehouses for Web servers was pioneered in the United States by Exodus. Tom.com promoted itself as a mega-portal for Chinese audiences around the world. When it went public, its Web site consisted of a home page and links that went nowhere.
"Some of the initiatives in Asia are extremely shallow," Mr. Duff said. "But the brand names of the families are so strong that it doesn't matter. They get funded."
A few executives are trying to force deeper changes in Asian culture. Richard Li, the son of Li Ka-shing, is building an office park here. The 64-acre complex, known as Cyberport, is supposed to offer tenants a campus-like environment where ideas can be swapped and new businesses hatched.
Just 33 years old, Mr. Li is the brashest Internet entrepreneur in Hong Kong and a symbol of Asia's headlong flight into cyberspace. His two-year-old company, Pacific Century Cyberworks, recently won a $36 billion takeover battle for Hong Kong's main telephone company. Mr. Li is also building a satellite-delivered Internet service.
Mr. Li epitomizes the contradiction in Asia's version of the Internet. A scion of the Li dynasty, he has created a cyberage company crackling with the energy of employees hoping to strike it rich on stock options. The company's latest conquest has been likened to America Online's acquisition of Time Warner.
Yet Mr. Li would never have triumphed without a $12 billion syndicated loan arranged by the Bank of China to finance the deal. And analysts agree that Mr. Li would never have landed such a loan without his father's connections.
Likewise with the Cyberport. It may plant the seed for a fertile technology culture in Hong Kong. Yet rivals of the Li family have criticized the project because it was awarded to Pacific Century by the Hong Kong government in a back-room deal.
These days, the tycoons stop short of extolling Asian values, but they make no apologies for their privileges. "There's a blend of Western and Asian elements here," said Alex Arena, Mr. Li's top lieutenant. "It's not a question of being like the U.S. It's a question of cherry-picking from the U.S."

HEADLINE: Campaigning on Social Security

 BODY:
Social Security has emerged as a critical issue in this year's presidential campaign, but neither candidate seems prepared to address the system's long-term financial problems. Instead, Gov. George W. Bush wants to let individuals invest a small part of their Social Security contributions in the stock market, where he thinks they will earn a better return, and Vice President Al Gore proposes to keep the system largely intact with an infusion of general tax revenues. Neither proposal would really stabilize the system in the long run. In truth, though Social Security is projected to become bankrupt in four decades, the system is not all that far out of kilter. It would not be hard for bold politicians to devise a fix.
Social Security may well be, as Governor Bush has said, "the single most successful government program in American history." It was created in 1935, during the depths of the depression, to provide a guaranteed income to retired workers for as long as they live. Unlike private pension plans, Social Security benefits keep pace with inflation and, unlike 401(k)'s and other popular private plans, Social Security benefits do not fluctuate with stock and bond markets. Social Security provides the majority of income for most retirees and all the income for about a fifth of the elderly. 
 From its inception, the system has taken in payroll taxes from the working generation and turned almost all of them over to retirees. At the core of Social Security are the notions of social insurance -- everyone participates in a common plan -- and redistribution -- the program tilts in favor of low-paid workers. The benefits for low-paid workers are about 80 percent of their average lifetime earnings, while benefits for high-paid workers are about 30 percent of average earnings. The progressive formula has cut the poverty rate among the elderly by two-thirds, reducing their poverty to below that of the general population. That is a remarkable triumph.
The question before voters is whether a program born out of depression -- when poverty was rampant, few married women worked for pay and no one had 401(k)'s or I.R.A.'s to provide for retirement -- needs to be revamped.
One reason for thinking so is the projected bankruptcy -- a sobering but manageable situation. The system will run surpluses for the next 15 years, building a large reserve. But in 2010, the first wave of the baby boomers -- the nearly 80 million people born between 1946 and 1964 -- will begin to retire and collect retirement checks. The number of people in the work force for every retiree will fall from about five today to about three in only 30 years or so. That, and the fact that people are living longer, will put a strain on workers to support the retirement needs of the elderly. The system will begin to run deficits around 2015. By 2037, the trust fund is expected to be empty.
But for all the talk of bankruptcy, the system is not facing irreparable financial crisis. Even after 2037, payroll taxes will cover about 70 percent of promised benefits. Deficits over the next 75 years, the planning horizon for the program, will equal less than 2 percent of total payrolls -- hardly a catastrophic shortfall. If the economy were to grow only slightly faster than the actuaries at the Social Security Administration now project, the deficit would disappear.
One proposed remedy for financial imbalance is partial privatization, the approach favored by Governor Bush. Under current law, workers and employers pay a 12.4 percent payroll tax that goes into a public trust fund. Under partial privatization, workers could divert, say, two percentage points of that tax to private accounts that the worker could then invest in stocks and bonds. Workers would collect less money from the trust fund when they retired, alleviating financial strain on the system. But they would expect to more than make up for the loss by drawing from their private accounts.
Mr. Bush's sketchy proposal fails to answer where he would find the money to pay retirees as payroll taxes were diverted into private accounts. But there are other fundamental problems with the proposal as well.
Proponents of private accounts say that investors, based on data going back to the early 20th century, can expect to earn about 5 percent annually above inflation on a diversified portfolio of stocks and bonds. By contrast, the taxes they "deposit" in the trust fund will earn an implicit return -- measured in future retirement benefits -- of only 1 to 2 percent above inflation.
But that comparison is highly misleading. Private accounts invested in stocks and bonds may well earn less than 5 percent because the economy is expected to slow over the next several decades as the population ages and because stock prices are now overvalued.
More important, the advantage that proponents cite on behalf of private accounts is an optical illusion. The trust fund faces the burden of paying trillions of dollars beyond what payroll taxes raise over the next 75 years to provide the benefits the system is obligated to pay current and future retirees. The sole reason that private accounts look like a better investment than the trust fund is that proponents assume the private accounts would be relieved of the burden of helping to pay that obligation. But that just deflects the burden onto someone else, requiring Congress to slash retirement checks or other government spending, or to raise taxes.
Mr. Bush cites as an advantage that private accounts can be invested in stocks whereas the trust fund by law cannot. But if the law were changed to let the trust fund itself purchase stocks, as President Clinton has proposed, it could invest in the markets far more cheaply than could private accounts. The cost of administering 150 million individual private accounts would be huge, eating away 20 percent or more of worker deposits. Private accounts could also subject individuals, including the poor, to unacceptable investment risk at the most vulnerable time in their lives. Worse, they undermine the principle of social insurance, setting individuals off to fend for themselves without looking out for the needy.
Vice President Al Gore proposes to leave the basic system unchanged and would use general revenues to extend the life of the trust fund to about 2050. He ducks proposing tax hikes or benefit cuts that would be needed to solve the system's problems after that date. Indeed, he does the opposite by proposing new benefits for stay-at-home mothers and for widows and widowers, thereby increasing the financial strain on the system.
The wiser solution is for Congress to cut benefits and raise taxes modestly, which is all that would be needed to close the system's financial gap. Congress could require all state and local government workers to join the system, boosting its tax revenues. Congress could also raise the cap on earnings subject to the payroll tax, now set at $76,200, to keep pace with the rising earnings of high-paid workers. It could invest Social Security surpluses in private, high-paying bonds, or allow the trust fund itself to invest in stocks.
Raising the payroll tax by, say, a half percentage point in 20 or 30 years or transferring a small fraction of general tax revenues into the trust fund would go a long way toward solving the problem. If these and similar measures do not close the entire gap, Congress could hasten the transition to the higher retirement age, 67, that Congress passed in the 1980's. The Social Security "crisis" is less drastic than it seems, and can be fixed with relatively modest changes. 
http://www.nytimes.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: High Hopes, Backed by Investments

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
For many years, Robert Simmons would drive past a vacant lot near the eastern edge of Bedford-Stuyvesant and dream of opening a restaurant there. Subsidized homes were going up all around that area, but the people living in them had no place to go if they craved a sit-down meal.
Now they do. In July, Mr. Simmons opened Choices, an immaculate plant-filled family-style restaurant at the corner of Fulton Street and Ralph Avenue. It has purple awnings, floor-to-ceiling windows, roomy booths, a menu offering "soulful, West Indian, Caribbean and other cuisines," and long lines when Bedford-Stuyvesant's many church services end on Sundays. 
 And this is not the only new enterprise in the neighborhood displaying Mr. Simmons's signature purple awnings. He also owns the laundry next to the restaurant, a beauty parlor across the street and several businesses farther west on Fulton Street, including a health club, a billiards parlor, a smaller restaurant and a second laundry.
Altogether, Mr. Simmons says, he's plowed $3 million of his own money into Bedford-Stuyvesant, the proceeds from selling seven McDonald's franchises, two of them in the neighborhood.
Mr. Simmons, 52, was raised in St. Louis and worked for McDonald's for seven years before the company asked him to move to New York in 1988 to take over a franchise at Fulton Street and Throop Avenue. McDonald's arranged the financing that enabled him to get started.
Ultimately, Mr. Simmons said, he felt the need to strike out on his own. "I wanted to see if I could use my talents somewhere else," he said. "I no longer wanted to be boxed in to limited menu items or pricing structure -- the corporate thing."
Kathryn Wylde, the chief executive of the New York City Investment Fund, a private company that seeks to stimulate job growth, describes Mr. Simmons as a "pit bull personified."
Ms. Wylde helped Mr. Simmons get space for his Choices restaurant in a new strip mall developed under the Anchor program, a joint venture between the city and the New York City Partnership, a major civic group, that was financed by Chase Manhattan Bank.
"He saw the diversity of the market needs in his own community," Ms. Wylde said. "He has the focus and ability to execute that has allowed him to deliver businesses to meet those needs in very creative ways."
As an African-American, Mr. Simmons belongs to a group that is vastly underrepresented among business owners in New York. In a survey conducted two years ago, the New York City Investment Fund found that blacks owned only 2.9 percent of the businesses in the city with employees, even though they make up about 25 percent of the population. (Asians, by contrast, constitute about 7 percent of the population and own 7 percent of the businesses with employees.)
But Mr. Simmons is not the only entrepreneur with high hopes for Bedford-Stuyvesant. For five years, Monique Greenwood, the editor in chief of Essence magazine, and her husband, Glenn Pogue, a freelance broadcast engineer, have operated a bed-and-breakfast, the Akwaaba Mansion, on McDonough Street.
In 1998, they opened a restaurant, the Akwaaba Cafe, around the corner on Lewis Street. Since then, they have acquired all the properties adjacent to the cafe. They plan to operate a coffee lounge in one of the spaces. Their tenants will include Bedford-Stuyvesant's first bookstore and an antiques shop.
"We hope that we're providing the inspiration for other people to invest in businesses here," said Ms. Greenwood, who has lived in Bedford-Stuyvesant for a decade. "We have incredible homes, but we don't have the kinds of services that other people in other communities take for granted."
