HEADLINE: In Bedford-Stuyvesant, The Boom Remains a Bust;
Neighborhood Development Unit Under Fire

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
It has been more than three decades since Senator Robert F. Kennedy cast a spotlight on the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn by making it the focus of a bold new economic development program. By uniting "the best of community action with the best of the private enterprise system," he said, a model urban neighborhood could arise from the ashes of "physical decay and human despair."
For a while, the plan worked. Its most visible achievement was the conversion of an abandoned milk bottling plant in the heart of the neighborhood into a shopping plaza and cultural center. But there was more: hundreds of homes were rehabilitated, thousands of jobs were created, the neighborhood got its first large supermarket in years (a Pathmark that is still operating), and I.B.M. brought in a computer cable production factory that once employed 450 people. 
 A generation later, however, the predominantly black New York neighborhood that is reaping the benefits of a robust economy is Harlem, not Bedford-Stuyvesant.
Far from being central to current political and economic plans for reviving neglected areas, Bedford-Stuyvesant has receded into the shadows, community leaders say. Some blame the perception of rampant crime, even though crime is down. Others say Harlem has more political clout in Washington.
But many people both inside and outside Bedford-Stuyvesant also say that the organization that was intended to help bring prosperity to central Brooklyn -- the Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation -- has served as an impediment to progress, an entrenched and sluggish bureaucracy instead of a spark plug for local entrepreneurs and nationally known merchants. Even the organization's new board chairman, Albert C. Wiltshire, says that Restoration needs to be put back on course.
The lightning rod for some of the criticism is Roderick B. Mitchell, the president and chief executive of Restoration for the last 12 years. His detractors call him prickly and arrogant, incapable of working cooperatively with other community leaders and unwilling to endorse any proposal that does not give Restoration joint ownership. Some local business owners say he has opposed efforts to bring new jobs to the area.
But Mr. Mitchell, who has a master's degree in business from Columbia University, contends that the Restoration has grown steadily stronger under his stewardship, having weathered the crisis that almost killed it during the Reagan years, when its financing dried up.
He cited several new businesses in Restoration Plaza -- among them Score, a computer learning center for children, and a Sterling Optical Center -- and the organization's continuing support of several longstanding cultural programs, including an art gallery and two theaters. He also pointed to a long-term $9.8 million project, which is nearing completion, to make the fortresslike Restoration Plaza more inviting.
"Restoration was always intended to be a catalyst to improve the quality of life, and we have held true to that mission," Mr. Mitchell said. "We have not deviated one bit. There's no question about it, that Restoration's achievements over the past 30 years have been extraordinary. And when you look at the amount of money that we have had available to us, it's even more extraordinary."
Restoration, a nonprofit corporation, oversees 11 subsidiaries. In its early years, Mr. Mitchell said, an estimated 80 percent of the company's revenue came from government sources, but in more recent years, it has received most of its money from rent and other earnings, he said. Last year, according to documents filed with the state attorney general's office, Restoration received $1 million in government grants and raised $1.3 million privately.
But the organization's glory days seem to have ended. Once a model for about 2,000 community development corporations across the country, Restoration is now running large deficits ($990,000 this past fiscal year, and $1.6 million the year before). Restoration-sponsored construction has ceased, and the organization has managed to attract only a few new businesses to the neighborhood in recent years.
When I.B.M. moved out in 1993, the company was replaced by an employee-owned computer repair business, where only 30 people now work. During the last fiscal year, Restoration reported that it spent $2.6 million on its programs, only $130,000 of which was used for economic development.
"I don't want to say that Restoration has outlived its usefulness," said Carlton A. Brown, a developer and a Bedford-Stuyvesant resident. "But they are stuck in a time warp. The organization under Mr. Mitchell has just not been that effective."
Mr. Brown, who is developing a commercial and residential project in Harlem that is also sponsored by the City Department of Housing Preservation and Development and the New York City Housing Partnership, said that Mr. Mitchell had failed to take advantage of similar opportunities in Bedford-Stuyvesant. (Mr. Mitchell, however, said that building housing was not part of his organization's mission.)
Some of Bedford-Stuyvesant's problems are apparent on Fulton Street, the bustling main commercial thoroughfare. It has street vendors, 99-cent stores, beauty and nail salons, jewelry and liquor stores, but few essential services like dry cleaners and sit-down restaurants. There are no movie theaters, bookstores or record stores.
"Recently, I needed to get an antenna for my television set," said Joanne Jeffrey, a neighborhood resident who works for the Police Department. "I'm driving all over the place just to find an antenna. To me, that's ridiculous."
There are, of course, many other explanations for the slow pace of commercial development in Bedford-Stuyvesant, a community of about 140,000 people. Central Brooklyn, home to about 300,000 people, has no politician to match Charles B. Rangel, the Harlem congressman who was instrumental in freeing up hundreds of millions of federal, state and city dollars for the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone. Unlike Harlem, Bedford-Stuyvesant never had a glamorous aura. Nor does it have the high density that many retailers seek.
To out-of-town retail executives (and many New Yorkers), Bedford-Stuyvesant is a still a scary place. Crime has decreased considerably in recent years, but not as much as elsewhere in the city, according to a study sponsored by the Local Initiatives Support Corporation, an organization that assists community development corporations.
Some merchants remain fearful. Nadi Ali, the owner of a men's clothing store on Fulton Street whose name he did not want published, keeps three German shepherds in back of his store as protection against break-ins. "They need more security in the streets," he said.
But Felix Liz, the manager of Town of Bargains, a furniture store on Broadway, said the neighborhood had become far safer in the last six years. "You could not walk on the street like you're walking today," Mr. Liz said.
Bounded by Flushing Avenue on the north, Broadway and Saratoga on the east, Atlantic Avenue on the south, and Classon Avenue on the west, Bedford-Stuyvesant (then known simply as Bedford) was once a fashionable district and home to retail magnates like Abraham Abraham and F. W. Woolworth.
With its hundreds of blocks of beautifully tended turn-of-the-century brownstones, Bedford-Stuyvesant has better housing stock than Harlem, a higher degree of home ownership and a larger proportion of middle-class residents. Property values in Bedford-Stuyvesant are rising, fueled by an influx of professionals seeking the kind of space and architectural details that are priced beyond their means in more gentrified Brooklyn neighborhoods.
Bedford-Stuyvesant could support some of the amenities that are cropping up in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn: coffee bars, art galleries and other urban "eye candy," said Colvin W. Grannum, the chief executive of the Bridge Street Development Corporation, a church-affiliated group in Bedford-Stuyvesant that has worked closely with the New York City Housing Partnership to develop affordable housing.
But first the community has to advertise its strengths, he said. "Forty percent of the people are poor, and business people look at that and say, 'There is no way this is going to work,' " Mr. Grannum said. "But the other 60 percent is solid, working-class families, and there is even some affluence."
Mr. Mitchell of Restoration, who is paid $135,000 a year, said there was a "red line that still circles this community," making it very difficult to get financing for economic development. He said it was practically impossible to get national retailers to return telephone calls, much less tour the neighborhood.
But a number of people who have tried to work with Mr. Mitchell, in the financial community and nonprofit world, say he himself makes the job harder. Most, however, are afraid to take him on in public.
People who are willing to speak on the record fault Mr. Mitchell in particular for failing to exploit opportunities to create more of the small businesses that can begin to turn around a neighborhood's image. Robert Simmons, a former McDonald's franchise owner who operates seven small businesses in Bedford-Stuyvesant -- all financed with his own capital -- said Mr. Mitchell rejected his proposal to develop long-vacant property at Fulton Street and Albany Avenue into a restaurant. Mr. Simmons said that Mr. Mitchell was "contributing to the negative look of the neighborhood by letting that building stay vacant."
Mr. Mitchell acknowledged that he told Mr. Simmons he had other plans for the parcel. "I can understand why Robert would be disturbed or even upset because he had a plan and that was a potential site," Mr. Mitchell said. "But then, we have a potential plan and a strategy also that we want to put in place. It doesn't mean that what Robert is doing I don't value."
Mr. Mitchell declined to disclose how he would use the site. "Our strategic plan is for internal purposes," he said.
Other people say Mr. Mitchell is wasting an asset right in Restoration Plaza: a recording studio in the basement that was once known as the Platinum Factory. Mr. Brown, the Harlem developer, said he got the brush-off when he tried to help a music producer lease the studio. Kevin A. Griffith, a former engineer at the Platinum Factory, filed a lawsuit contending that Mr. Mitchell reneged on a deal to revive the recording studio and never returned a $25,000 investment.
Mr. Mitchell said he planned to move the recording studio, because the A train runs below it. He had no comment on the lawsuit.
Mr. Mitchell has also come under attack for resisting a union drive by handymen, porters and superintendents employed by Restoration. In March, the employees voted to become part of Teamsters Local 966.
Maintaining that he has been a friend to local entrepreneurs, Mr. Mitchell said that Restoration had lent more than $500,000 to small businesses in Brooklyn since 1995, including $150,000 to finance the Sterling Optical store (which is jointly owned by Restoration). One of the beneficiaries of the loan program was Howell Petroleum, a company that distributed automotive lubricant but was seeking to expand and become a general contractor.
Nevertheless, Bill Howell, the president and chief executive of the company, now known as Howell Industries, and a Bedford-Stuyvesant resident, said that Restoration had failed to take a leadership role in bringing the community better retail services, a shortcoming that was underscored when no one from the organization showed up at a recent "economic summit meeting" made up of numerous church and neighborhood groups.
Mr. Mitchell said he did not know of such a meeting.
"I always viewed Restoration as the center of the community for economic development," Mr. Howell said. "I think it's falling short. A lot more can be done."
Mr. Howell said he expected Restoration to turn around under Mr. Wiltshire, who was elected board chairman in March. Mr. Wiltshire, the manager of government relations for Consolidated Edison and a board member of three other community organizations, also said that Restoration needed to work cooperatively with other groups.
Mr. Wiltshire said he planned to hire a consultant to subject Restoration to the kind of scrutiny it has not previously encountered. The organization's board, of which he has been a member of 13 years, "needs to be proactive, as opposed to reactive," he said.
"I don't think the board has lived up to its responsibilities," he said, "and that includes me."

In the 19th century, the entire neighborhood, then one of the most fashionable addresses in New York, was known as Bedford. Beginning in the early 1900's, the name was applied primarily to the western section; the eastern section, where some of the most elegant brownstones were situated became known as Stuyvesant. As newer suburbs opened up elsewhere in the city after World War I, Bedford attracted less-affluent residents with diverse ethnic backgrounds. The neighborhood soon took on the hyphenated name Bedford-Stuyvesant.

HEADLINE: In a Changed Texas, Ranchers Battle Oilmen

BYLINE: By JIM YARDLEY 

DATELINE: MIDLAND, Tex., May 24

 BODY:
For nearly a century, the compact between ranchers and oilmen created the huge wealth that built modern Texas. The ranchers owned the land, the wildcatters found the oil, and everyone got rich together. Oil money built universities and football stadiums, gaudy hotels and world-class art museums.
Even today, an estimated one million people in Texas receive some sort of oil or gas royalty check. 
 But oil is no longer king in Texas, and as the economy has changed, the state has grappled with a less glamorous legacy of the high-flying days. There are 25,000 abandoned oil wells in Texas, an additional 15,000 sitting idle and tens of thousands of others that could be leaking and threatening underground aquifers at a time when drought has made water the state's most precious natural resource.
Now, the ranchers and the oil producers, the mythic figures of modern Texas, are fighting over cleaning up the mess. A growing number of prominent ranchers, including former Gov. Dolph Briscoe and the caretakers of the fabled King Ranch, are organizing against the oil industry, seeking changes in environmental and royalty laws, and portraying state regulators as toothless. Oil producers, on the other hand, say the landowners are just grabbing for money as the industry is only now recovering from its latest downturn.
"Some of these guys are out here biting the hand that fed them," said John Bell, an independent oil producer.
In the Texas of old, what was good for Big Oil was considered good for Texas. But attitudes are gradually changing as industries like high technology and health care lead the state's thriving economy. In recent months, citizens' groups in central Texas have fought plans to reopen a 700-mile underground gas pipeline, fearing that a leak could pollute the region's water source. In Houston, a new generation of business leaders, alarmed by the city's smog problem, is calling for solutions that include sharp reductions in pollution from nearby refineries.
Here in the harsh mesquite desert of West Texas, where the underground sea of crude oil known as the Permian Basin once made Midland a boom town, the bravado of the bygone era is not yet gone. Thousands of oil pumps still bob slowly up and down in the surrounding flat terrain, where the average summer temperatures exceed 100 degrees. Hotels still decorate rooms with paintings of oil wells.
A huge white Cadillac rumbling down Big Spring Street summarized the enduring local sentiment with a bumper sticker: "Wake Up America: For Our Security We Need American Oil."
Inside his office at the Permian Basin Petroleum Association, the executive director, Morris Burns, brightened at the memory of the region's past influence. "This was what won World War II," Mr. Burns said, recalling that the Permian Basin produced 25 percent of the world's oil to keep the American war machine going.
But production peaked in 1972, the oil bust came in the 1980's, and in the 1990's oil production in Texas dropped by a third. The recent spike in oil prices has helped producers recover from the disastrously low prices of 1998, but the overall trend is the slow decline of what analysts describe as a "mature" industry. For more than a decade, the major oil companies have been pulling out of West Texas, and this week Mr. Burns wearily absorbed another defection, as ARCO announced it would close its local office, which employs 165 people.
The newfound public advocacy of the ranchers is only the latest blow. Like so many in the oil industry, Mr. Burns says he suspects that trial lawyers in search of a new source of fees may account for part of it. He acknowledged that a small number of "bad actors" in the oil industry had behaved irresponsibly, but he said many of them had left the business over the past decade as regulations tightened.
"Producers have become much more environmentally aware in the last 15 years," Mr. Burns said.
Yet drive an hour west of Midland, past tiny oil towns like Goldsmith and the aptly named Notrees, and the environmental legacy is evident on the 174,000-acre Frying Pan Ranch. The property's owner, D. K. Boyd, bought it four years ago, adding it to his five other ranches in West Texas and New Mexico.
In all, his properties contain more than 2,000 oil wells. But when Mr. Boyd hired a San Antonio environmental consulting company to audit his properties, it found about 1,000 contaminated sites, with environmental damage estimated at more than $25 million.
There is heated disagreement about who is responsible for the mess, and Mr. Boyd is tied up in fiercely contested litigation with several of the oil producers leasing mineral rights on his property.
But regardless of blame, a short tour of the Frying Pan reveals obvious examples of the problems that ranchers say exist across Texas. A tank where crude oil is separated from salt water has spilled into the surrounding soil. A pipeline that burst a few weeks ago has left a brown stain across a 50-yard section. Mr. Boyd's ranch foreman, Bill Warbois, said some oil companies did little more than dump dirt to cover up the problems.
"That's wet oil," Mr. Warbois said, pinching some of the brown sand between his fingers. "You can smell it. You can pick that dirt up and literally squeeze the oil out of it."
Mr. Boyd, who ran his own independent oil company for 20 years, said the city of Midland had approached him about water rights in recent weeks for an aquifer that extends more than 20,000 acres beneath the Frying Pan. He said that he had not thoroughly tested the water source, but that a handful of test wells had shown some evidence of contamination.
"Water is more valuable than oil and gas, and becoming more so every day," Mr. Boyd said.
Vince Matthews, director for the Center for Energy and Economic Development at the University of Texas of the Permian Basin in Midland, said many of the wells on ranches like the Frying Pan had been drilled by the major oil companies more than 50 years ago and were now inevitably showing signs of deterioration. Mr. Matthews said smaller independent oil companies eagerly bought the properties with the exodus of the major concerns, but they did so as federal regulation tightened and environmental awareness started to take hold.
"The large oil companies saw this coming," Mr. Matthews said. "They said, 'We don't need this. We can go to plenty of places around the world, find bigger reserves, and we don't have to put up with this litigious society.' "
Environmental complaints have grown steadily in the past decade. Richard Lowerre, an environmental lawyer in Austin, said lawsuits over the contamination of ground water had become more common, particularly in West Texas. Oil companies often settle cases with an agreement requiring landowners not to disclose the terms, Mr. Lowerre said.
In 1997, the Texas Railroad Commission, which regulates the oil industry, reported 77 cases of ground water contamination from oil and natural gas activities, the majority of them in the Permian Basin, the most drought-stricken section of the state. In 1998, the commission received 976 complaints of oil field pollution from landowners.
In November, a number of prominent ranchers and large landowners founded the Texas Land and Mineral Owners Association. The approximately 500 members, who control millions of acres, include many from the ranching families that helped found Texas.
"This has never happened before in Texas," said Doug Beveridge, who manages land and oil leases for the King Ranch in South Texas. "You have never had landowners come together like this, exclusively. It should have happened 10 years ago."
Property rights are a passionate political issue in Texas, and in broad terms, the landowners are concerned primarily with pollution cleanup and royalties and their belief that the regulatory and legal landscape favors the oil and natural gas companies.
In Texas, unlike in many states, land ownership is severed between the surface and the minerals below. As a result, a landowner may or may not control the rights to any oil or natural gas below the ground. The oil companies sign leases with mineral owners, which grant them rights to drill wells and build pipelines. The mineral owners are paid royalties on any oil or gas production, while the landowners usually receive only a one-time payment of several thousand dollars for the use of their land.
In many cases, including that of Mr. Boyd, landowners also hold most of the mineral rights on their property. Usually, a company will sign a surface damage agreement with a landowner that stipulates cleanup responsibilities. But many landowners say there are companies that disregard the agreements or refuse to sign one.
The state requires that oil companies seal a well with cement plugs once production has stopped in order to prevent contaminants from escaping. The cost of plugging a well usually runs as much as $4,500. But some companies have just abandoned wells unplugged, particularly since 1998, when low prices drove many smaller independent companies to bankruptcy.
The landowners' association is lobbying for new laws addressing concerns about royalties and the legal rights of landowners in disputes over property damage, Mr. Beveridge said. The group is also proposing a bill to block oil and natural gas companies from abandoning wells.
The Texas Legislature has sporadically addressed the problem of abandoned wells by, among other things, passing a law that imposed a fee on oil and natural gas production to pay for plugging them. Last year, the state plugged about 1,600 wells. But declining production has meant fewer dollars coming into the cleanup fund. Oil companies also benefit from a state program that allows them to pay $100 for annual extensions on plugging wells. In some cases, companies have used these extensions to delay plugging for years. Officials estimate that 15,000 wells remain idle and unplugged because of this program.
Public attention to the problems was heightened in September when The San Antonio Express-News published a series of articles detailing the full scope of the problem. The Express-News series also explored the historically friendly relationship between the railroad commission and the oil industry. The commission's three members are elected and often receive large contributions from oil producers.
"Historically, there has been a great deal of cynicism, and people have characterized the railroad commission as a captive agency," said Tony Garza, a Republican member of the commission since 1998. "From time to time, their concerns have been extremely borne out."
In recent months, Mr. Garza has pushed the commission to be more aggressive in addressing abandoned wells and has met with resistance. At last month's commission meeting, Mr. Garza's proposal to curtail the $100 program was never brought to a vote. In the coming days, the commission's chairman, Michael Williams, is expected to make a recommendation on the fee program based on the findings of a commission he appointed to address the issue.
Just as the oil industry is declining, so, too, are many cattle ranches across Texas. Jan Wheelis, whose family has owned the McFaddin Ranch in Victoria County in South Texas since 1840, said she must find every way imaginable for her land to make money. She is considering harvesting mesquite trees, and she has leased hunting rights.
"You can make more money off hunting than oil in this place," Ms. Wheelis said.
Ms. Wheelis still keeps 250 head of cattle, but she has found that the drought makes it increasingly difficult to do so.
And so, she said, does the legacy of oil. Many of the 57 wells on her land are abandoned. Last month, she filed a suit against two companies, claiming that their failure to mend broken pipelines and other problems had created an environmental mess. In all, Ms. Wheelis said, she had lost 40 of her 2,664 acres to contamination.
Driving toward a lake of old cypress trees recently, Ms. Wheelis stopped her truck and listened to a metallic sound coming from a neighboring property.
"They're drilling another well," she said, and she drove away.

HEADLINE: Tax Incentive Approved For 'Green' Buildings

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
New York State has taken the lead in making commercial and residential buildings more efficient and more in harmony with the environment by adopting a "green building credit" against state income taxes.
The credit, which was included in the state budget signed into law by Gov. George E. Pataki on May 15, is intended to encourage building owners and developers to use advanced technologies like fuel cells and photovoltaic panels to generate electricity and to use materials that improve air quality inside buildings. 
 "This is a huge deal," said Robert F. Fox Jr., a partner in Fox & Fowle Architects, which specializes in environmentally sensitive design. "Basically, the state is offering to pay developers for the excess costs of doing green buildings."
Green buildings are generally defined as those that use energy more efficiently than those with conventional designs and that provide workers with well-lighted spaces furnished with an abundance of clean air. One of the objectives of designing a green building is to avoid using carpets, paints or other interior materials that can release harmful chemicals after being installed.
The credit is limited to a total of $25 million for all projects over five years. It was advocated by an unusual alliance, including the Real Estate Board of New York, which represents owners, developers and brokers, and the Natural Resources Defense Council, a major environmental advocacy group. Similar bills are in the works in Maryland and California, but New York's law appears to be the first, according to the council.
"This collaborative effort is a prototype for other states and eventually the federal government to follow," said Deborah B. Beck, the executive vice president of the Real Estate Board.
The legislation provides a credit of 5 percent of the capitalized cost of a project -- up to $3.75 per square foot for interior work and $7.50 per square foot for exterior work -- to builders who meet energy goals and use nontoxic materials in construction. To qualify, a building must meet requirements for energy use, indoor air quality, waste disposal and water use.
There is also a credit equivalent to 10 percent of the cost of new air-conditioning equipment that uses refrigerants that do not harm the ozone layer. There are additional credits for tenants who build their interior space to conform with the goals.
Builders using fuel cells and photovoltaic panels, which produce electricity without the pollution associated with conventional power sources, are eligible for special additional credits. Both technologies also have the potential to produce power more cheaply than conventional methods, but they tend to be more costly because they are less developed.
"The point of the legislation is to jump-start industries," Ms. Beck said. "We want to go from custom installations to mass production. We want to bring more people into the marketplace and make it more competitive."
Fuel cells produce electricity by consuming natural gas in a catalytic process that does not burn the fuel. The only emissions are carbon dioxide and water, in contrast to the mixture of chemicals flowing from the stacks of plants burning fossil fuels. The technology is evolving rapidly, Mr. Fox said. "In five years, fuel cells will be able to provide power at one-third the current cost," he said.
Photovoltaic panels convert sunlight directly to electricity with no emissions at all. Although individually they do not produce much power, they can replace conventional materials in the skin of a building, and when wired together they can produce usable amounts of power without any expenditure for fuel.
Douglas Durst, whose Conde Nast building at the corner of 42nd Street and Broadway incorporates both fuel cells and photovoltaic panels, welcomed the legislation, but had some reservations. Because there is a yearly limit on the total tax credits that can be claimed, he said, there should be a way of preventing one big project from absorbing most of one year's allotment.
Participants in the discussions about the legislation said the five-year limit of $25 million was inserted to demonstrate fiscal prudence. But they said the cap might be raised or the time period extended if the program is successful.
Mr. Durst also said a mechanism needs to be developed "to help smaller builders who do not know to apply these technologies."
He said his company, the Durst Organization, would continue to incorporate green technologies in future projects despite a delay in financial benefits other developers find unacceptable. "We are a family business that is building for the next generation, so we don't mind long paybacks," he said.
Investments in advanced technology in the Conde Nast building at 4 Times Square allow the company to operate it more economically than conventional structures, Mr. Durst said.
William Rudin, whose Rudin Management Company is building a headquarters for Reuters at Seventh Avenue and 42nd Street, said the building incorporated technologies included in the legislation.
He said that the wiring in the building can use power from fuel cells and photovoltaic panels and that space has been allocated to install the cells.
The Reuters building also includes filters to improve indoor air quality and glass that resists ultraviolet rays, reducing the amount of power needed for cooling.
Daniel R. Tishman, the president of Tishman Construction, which managed the construction of both buildings, was part of a group of businessmen and environmentalists who helped draft the tax credit. "Since it costs a bit more up front," he said, "we wanted to design an incentive -- like an investment tax credit -- to encourage developers and landlords to do what's right for the environment."
Mr. Fox, who was the architect for both buildings, said the tax credits would pay 30 percent of the cost of buying fuel cells, less federal or state grants. And, he said, they would pay for 100 percent of the cost of the solar power panels, minus the cost of building materials that would have been used otherwise.

HEADLINE: Blighted Areas Are Revived As Crime Rate Falls in Cities

BYLINE: By PAM BELLUCK 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, May 26

 BODY:
With the historic drop in violent crime beginning to take hold in even the most blighted urban areas, cities across the country are being transformed, as neighborhoods that had become frightening wastelands are showing glimmers of renaissance.
From Boston to New Orleans and Los Angeles to Miami, neighborhoods where drug gangs controlled the streets, commandeered empty houses and terrorized residents are beginning to seem safer and more livable, according to interviews with people in nine cities that have seen sharp drops in violent crime. 
 New homes are being built, stores are opening, subway and bus lines are adding service, and banks and shopping strips are breaking ground. There is less graffiti and fewer abandoned cars and vacant lots. And, for the first time in years, people are sitting on their front porches and parents feel safe letting their children walk to school.
In the U Street neighborhood of Washington, the subway system is operating later at night, and an organic grocery store and a private jazz club with a $2,500 annual membership fee are to open soon. In the Oakwood section of Los Angeles, forbidding eight-foot fences are being replaced with lower picket fences and other inviting designs. And in the Overtown and Liberty City neighborhoods of Miami, textile plants, production studios and a food processing plant are opening.
Especially striking is that people are beginning to move to these neighborhoods from more stable urban areas and the suburbs, the interviews suggest.
"There is a sense that cities are safer," said Robert Sampson, a professor of sociology at the University of Chicago. "And there is a return to the city among not just empty nesters, but people with kids."
Most of these neighborhoods are still struggling with crime and poverty. But the improvements have taken on such momentum that they do not appear to be slowed by increases in some violent crimes in several cities last year, including Boston, Houston, New York, San Antonio and San Diego.
In Chicago, surveys conducted by a Northwestern University political scientist, Wesley G. Skogan, have found that in the sections of the city where crime has declined sharply, primarily African-American neighborhoods on the South and West Sides, there have been "extremely large increases in the quality of life," Professor Skogan said.
He said residents in those neighborhoods had reported a lessening of drug and gang activity, declines in public drinking, loitering and disorder in the schools and streets that were cleaner and had fewer abandoned buildings and cars.
Changes like that were clear last week in one neighborhood on the West Side of Chicago. In a city where neighborhoods are a source of strong local pride, this section about five miles west of the Loop did not even have a name until recently and had virtually fallen off the map, longtime residents say. Now they say the area has revived enough to be considered part of the Tri-Taylor neighborhood, which is near the University of Illinois.
"We were considered nowhere really," said Nancy Echevarria, 46, who has lived on Taylor Street almost all her life. "The neighborhood was taboo. It was like the O.K. Corral here. Gangs of 30 guys would position themselves right on the street selling drugs."
Ms. Echevarria and her husband, Fidel, who are raising two children, ages 7 and 9, and a granddaughter, age 3, used to call the police frequently, and in retaliation, she said, gang members put a bullet through her front door a couple of years ago.
But in the last few years, the rampant crime in the police district that includes the neighborhood dropped more than in any other section of Chicago, 36 percent from 1992 to 1998, police figures show. Ms. Echevarria said she sees far fewer drug dealers and there is only one vacant house left on her block. On Taylor Street, $350,000 condominiums are being built, and the value of three houses owned by Ms. Echevarria has skyrocketed, to more than $150,000 each from about $15,000 some 10 years ago.
Her children skate and bicycle on the streets, which have new sidewalks. "The other day," she said, "it was so nice to come out in the morning and just sit and hear the birds."
Experts say such progress results from a number of social and economic factors that have helped bring the decrease in crime and are benefiting from it. The booming economy has created so much urban development that builders and businesses are venturing farther away from well-established neighborhoods into ones that were on the edge of livability.
Cities are using budget surpluses to offer tax incentives to businesses that open in these areas. And in some places, like Chicago, other major changes are under way in these communities, including changes in schools and the dismantling of huge, crime-plagued housing projects, like Rockwell Gardens, not far from Ms. Echevarria's home.
With less crime, there have been more jobs. In Miami, Frank R. Nero, the president of the Beacon Council, a private, nonprofit economic development agency, said factories and other businesses had been moving into neighborhoods like Overtown and Liberty City.
"Investors are starting to feel more comfortable," Mr. Nero said. "The more investment you have in an area, the safer it is and the safer it will become."
In addition, as things improve and as new policing strategies concentrate on community outreach, residents have become more willing to cooperate with the police, which has helped reduce crime.
Henry Flack, who has lived in the Skyline Park neighborhood of San Antonio for 15 years, said he sees the police on patrol much more often and has developed more of a relationship with them.
"I know them, and they know me," Mr. Flack said as he sat on his porch the other day. "If they've got a problem, they let me know, and if I've got a problem, I know just who to call."
There was a shooting near his house several days ago, he said. "The police came by and told me that a kid had shot at another bunch of kids and I said, 'Oh, that would be so-and-so who lives in that green house over there,' " he said. "They had that deal wrapped up in a couple of hours."
In city after city, the changes are seeping into the fabric of neighborhood life.
In the Uphams Corner section of Boston's Dorchester neighborhood, an area known for crimes like the 1992 slaying of a man who was eating dinner with his wife at the Tasty Chicken restaurant, drug houses have been shut down and businesses have opened, including a children's clothing shop and a housewares store. Youth programs have sprung up, a park that used to be littered with used condoms and drug needles is being renovated, and the community has begun sponsoring a street festival.
"I see fewer bars on windows," said Jan Mattimoe, a middle-school teacher who helps organize a community improvement project. "This spring I've seen more flowers in this area than I've ever seen. There is real desire to get out there and make things look pretty."
In Washington's U Street neighborhood, Cici Mukhtar, the owner of a cafe, said she was glad to have a fancy organic supermarket and an exclusive jazz club moving in. That is all part of what has made the neighborhood more attractive, she said.
"It's amazing, just amazing what's happening here," Ms. Mukhtar said.
Myra Power, 28, who lived in the neighborhood from 1991 until moving to New York in 1997, was back last week, looking for work and a place to live. She said she noticed a huge change.
"When I lived here, I wouldn't leave home without my Mace," Ms. Power said.
Now, children stay out late playing basketball and waiting in line to use the playground swings. Construction crews are busy renovating old buildings and building new ones.
Ms. Powers said her friends now leave belongings out on their porches. "It used to be that the only thing they'd leave out was barbed wire," she said.
Instead of worrying about break-ins, she said, they fret over how to plant the most attractive garden.
In New Orleans, the crack houses and blighted buildings that choked the city's Irish Channel neighborhood are beginning to give way to avant-garde galleries, clothing shops and even a designer jewelry shop on Lower Magazine Street.
"There used to be a grocery next door that would sell one beer and one cigarette, and there was a pay phone there, so there was a lot of loitering," said Patty Spinale, who opened her lingerie shop, House of Lounge, on Lower Magazine Street two years ago. "The neighborhood has really significantly cleaned up in the last two years, in terms of people investing in it. More tourists are comfortable with venturing into the neighborhood."
And in Houston, Capt. Mark L. Curran, commander of the Eastside Division for the Police Department, said he hears evidence of improvement in the complaints he fields at civic club meetings.
"Back in the early 90's, it was rape and burglaries," Captain Curran said. "Now it's, 'I want you to take care of my neighbor's barking dog.' "
But as their neighborhoods have become more attractive, some residents have found themselves pushed out, along with the criminals.
The end of the gang warfare that had terrorized the Oakwood section of Los Angeles, just blocks from Venice Beach, meant safer streets in an area that had been the city's only black neighborhood near the ocean.
It has also meant that some people who had lived there for more than 30 years lost their leases, as landlords sold property to affluent newcomers or raised rents.
"Up and down the street you see whites walking these days," said Melvyn Hayward Sr., a neighborhood organizer and director of the Vera Davis Community Center. "In 20 years, you would never see that. They wouldn't come down here."
The changes are still quite new in most of these neighborhoods, and some residents are skeptical that the improvements will endure.
"There is still crime," said Cynthia Harris, a case worker for a health center, who lives in Uphams Corner in Boston. "My son finds needles in the driveway where he plays. And if I had an opportunity to move, I would."
In the Taylor Street neighborhood of Chicago, one developer, Senan Nugent, hires gang members to watch his properties so that other gang members will not steal plumbing pipes and supplies.
Still, Mr. Nugent and others say they would not be there if they were not convinced that it was a safe, promising place to invest.
Dr. Dave Williams bought a new three-unit condominium on Taylor Street for $367,000 this year, and he is renting it and three other buildings to students at the University of Illinois and employees at Rush Presbyterian Hospital. The renters are people who would not have dared live here in the past, Dr. Williams said. Many of the students come from the suburbs and drive sport utility vehicles, but they have no trouble getting their parents to co-sign their leases.
And although he put up high wrought-iron fences with electronic security systems at the condominium, he said that only 2 of his 12 tenants bothered to turn on their systems. "We were actually quite skeptical and nervous when we first invested," said Dr. Williams, an emergency room physician who lives downtown. "But things have gotten steadily better. It's really one of Chicago's new frontiers now."

HEADLINE: Words of Advice for Graduates on the Threshold of the Millennium

BYLINE: By JODI WILGOREN 

 BODY:
Legend has it that the longest commencement address, said to have been given in the early days of Harvard University, lasted six hours -- the first three in Latin, the latter in Greek. The shortest, alternately attributed to Andy Rooney or Woody Allen, was just two sentences: "We've given you a perfect world. Don't screw it up." 
 Every spring, they parade to the podiums of colleges and universities across the country, offering sage advice -- or at least a few one-liners. Poets and politicians. Athletes and artists. Diplomats and do-gooders.
This year seemed an especially auspicious opportunity for keynoters, as the Class of 2000, the first of the new millennium, switched their tassels from side to side.
They spoke of global responsibility -- to end poverty, fight disease, keep peace. They talked about technology, its gifts and its perils. They marveled at society's progress -- and questioned whether it has been swift enough in the field of human relations. They urged graduates to value time over money: "You must place interest in principle above interest on principal," Julian Bond, the chairman of the N.A.A.C.P., said at Washington University in St. Louis.
Many mentioned their own parents, and nearly all promised to keep their speeches shorter than the ones they could not remember from their own commencements. "I intend to stop speaking before you stop listening," George J. Mitchell, the former senator from Maine, told his audience at Washington & Jefferson College in Pennsylvania.
Following are excerpts.
 
Seamus Heaney
Nobel laureate. University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia.
There is a dreamlike quality to every commencement day. But the veil trembles more mysteriously if you are graduating in the year 2000. It makes you wonder if the date is a destiny or an accident. A turning point in your life coincided with a turning point in our era. It is like the moment when a tide has risen to its highest and then rests: everything is at the full and yet everything is volatile.
You stand at a boundary. Behind you is your natural habitat, as it were, the ground of your creaturely being, the old haunts where you were nurtured; in front of you is a less knowable prospect of invitation and challenge, the testing ground of your possibilities. You stand between whatever binds you to your past and whatever might be unbounded in your future.
 
Anita Hill
Professor. Simmons College, Boston.
 First question that I want to ask you is, and I want you to really seriously ponder this, are you happy with the person you are today?
Did you keep the promises you made to yourself and apply all of your energies and resources to soak up every ounce of learning and life at Simmons and Boston? And on your way to this degree, did you help a child learn to read or do long division or, more likely today, write a computer program?
Did you visit an elder, listen to her story and learn to see the world vividly through dimmed and failing eyes? Did you maintain, or in some cases develop, a sense of humor, especially about yourself and even more importantly about the difficulties life sometimes brings?
And finally, on your way to your current learned state, did you remember to keep those parts from birth that endeared you to your family -- the innocence, the wonder, the naivete? . . .
Now I'm sure you're asking yourself, "What's with all the questions? Classes are over!" Well, consider this the last exam that you will have, and it's one you don't even have to take. It certainly isn't going to be graded; it's a self-examination.
 
Julian Bond
N.A.A.C.P. chairman. Washington University, St. Louis.
If we can shrink the world's population to a village of only 100 people, keeping all existing ratios the same, that village would look like this: there would be 57 Asians, 21 Europeans, 14 from the Western Hemisphere -- north and south -- and 21 Africans; 52 would be female; 70 would be nonwhite and 30 white; 70 would be non-Christian and 30 would be Christian.
Six of the 100 people would own 59 percent of all the wealth in the world, and all 6 of those people would be from the United States. Eighty of the 100 people would live in substandard housing. Seventy would be unable to read and write. Fifty would suffer from malnutrition. One would have a college education.

Bill Amend
Cartoonist. Amherst College, Amherst, Mass.
For a graduating senior, it's got to be like music from heaven to hear that an Amherst education can actually lead to a job where you can wear sweats all day, sleep in late, play your stereo all you want, and get paid lots of money to draw silly little pictures in between games of Quake on your computer. . . .
Knowing you have an audience, especially one that matters to you, can be utterly paralyzing. The fear of failure, the weight of expectation, the indecision that comes from striving for perfection can transform even simple tasks into brain-melting impossibilities. But knowing you have an audience can also elevate you to do more than you might otherwise. And to do it better. To consider what you're doing from more that one view.
As a syndicated cartoonist, I have a huge audience. They tell me it's over 25 million readers. This might be cause for a little intimidation were it not for my handy science background reminding me that this is merely one 250-billionth the number of sodium ions in a single grain of salt. Trust me, anybody can write for salt.
 
Henry G. Cisneros
President of Univision Communications. Occidental College, Los Angeles.
Over the years I have learned that the people who are the most successful, the people I have admired the most, are not necessarily those who are the most brilliant, or witty, or have mastered a particular discipline, but those who had the stamina to stay the course over a long period of time. . . . It's like the difference between the shooting star that flashes across the sky and is gone -- you're not even sure it was there -- and the North Star that is there every night, night after night.
 
Desmond Tutu
Retired Archbishop of Cape Town, South Africa. Brandeis University, Waltham, Mass.
You know the story of the farmer who in his backyard had chicken, and then he had a chicken that was a little odd looking. . . . It behaved like a chicken. It was pecking away like other chickens. It didn't know that there was a blue sky overhead and a glorious sunshine until someone who was knowledgeable in these things came along and said to the farmer, "Hey, that's no chicken. That's an eagle." . . .
And this man took this strange-looking chicken and climbed the mountain and waited until sunrise. And then he turned this strange-looking chicken towards the sun and said, "Eagle, fly, eagle." And the strange-looking chicken shook itself, spread out its pinions and lifted off and soared and soared and soared and flew away, away into the distance.

George F. Will
Columnist. Lafayette College, Easton, Pa.
The demoralization of society is advanced when the word "values" supplants the word "virtues" in political and ethical contexts. When we move beyond talk of good and evil, when the categories virtue and vice are transcended, we are left with the thin gruel of values talk.
Unlike virtues, everyone has lots of values. Everyone has as many as they choose! Hitler had lots of values. George Washington had virtues.
Values are an equal-opportunity business. They are mere choices. In contrast, virtues are habits, difficult to develop and therefore not accessible to all. Therefore, speaking of virtues rather than values is elitist, offensive to democracy's egalitarian, leveling ethos, which I say is precisely why talk of virtues should be revived and talk of values should be abandoned.
The purpose of American higher education is not to serve as a values cafeteria where young people are encouraged to pick whichever strikes their fancy. Rather, the purpose of higher education for citizens of a democracy should be to help them identify excellence in its various realms and to understand what virtues make it so.
 
George J. Mitchell
Former senator. Washington & Jefferson College, Washington, Pa.
John Gardner put it best when he wrote: "An excellent plumber is infinitely more admirable than an incompetent philosopher. The society which scorns excellence in plumbing because plumbing is a humble activity, and tolerates shoddiness in philosophy because it is an exalted activity, will have neither good plumbing nor good philosophy. Neither its pipes nor its theories will hold water."
 
Madeleine K. Albright
Secretary of state. University of California at Berkeley.
During the century just passed, we humans learned how to transplant hearts, fly spaceships, clone sheep and squeeze a library's worth of data into a single slender disk.
But as world events reflect, we remain far from mastering the art of human relations. We have invented no technology that will guide us to the destinations that matter most.
After two world wars, the Holocaust, multiple genocides and countless conflicts, we must ask how long it will be before we are able to rise above the national, racial and gender distinctions that divide us and embrace the common humanity that binds us.
The answer depends not on the stars of some mysterious forces of history; it depends on the choices that you and I and all of us make.
 
Benjamin S. Carson
Pediatric neurosurgeon. Ursinus College, Collegeville, Pa.
How many of you remember your birthday? Can I just see your hands? . . . Now what did your brain have to do for you to respond to that question?
Give you an example of the sophistication of your brain: First of all the sound waves had to leave my lips, enter your auditory meatus, travel down to the tympanic membrane, set up a vibratory force, which traveled across the ossicles of your middle ear to the oval and round windows, setting up a vibratory force in the endolymph, which mechanically distorted the microcilia, converting mechanical energy to electrical energy, which traveled across the cochlear nerve to the cochlear nucleus to the pons-to-medullary juncture, from there to the superior olivary nucleus ascending bilaterally up the brain stem to the lateral lemniscus and the anterior colliculus and the medial geniculate nuclei across the thalamic radiations to the posterior temporal lobes, going through the frontal lobes, coming down the . . .
Anyway! You get the point. And that's the simplified version of what your brain had to do. It can do much more complex things than that and you barely have to think about it. So with a brain like that, why would anybody ever utter the words "I can't?"

John Wallach
Founder of Seeds of Peace. University of Southern Maine, Portland.
In a vastly expanding global economy with ever faster and faster communication, there is also a danger we'll lose touch with each other, with our own humanity. People may become pixels on a screen. William Julius Wilson

As a new millennium dawns, the eradication of extreme poverty ought to be one of our most urgent and important goals. Extreme poverty breeds disease and shortens life expectancy. Given the impact of modern technology, the unlimited growth and material resources and surplus wealth, it is possible to ensure that every man, woman and child experience a modicum of economic welfare.

LENGTH: 1443 words

HEADLINE: FUJIMORI IS VICTOR IN PERU'S RUNOFF AS PROTESTS GROW

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, May 28

 BODY:
In a runoff vote long on protest but short on suspense, President Alberto K. Fujimori swept to victory today against an opponent who had urged his supporters to abstain because of what he called vote fraud and an array of campaign irregularities.
Mr. Fujimori had hoped for a third landslide victory that would venerate his successes in defeating two terrorist groups and hyperinflation and making peace with Ecuador after decades of border tensions. Instead, the 61-year-old president won a hollow victory leaving the country badly polarized and facing possible economic sanctions just as it tries to emerge from recession. 
 The balloting capped a campaign full of dirty tricks, violent demonstrations and condemnations from Mr. Fujimori's opponent, Alejandro Toledo, who dropped out on May 18, although his name remained on the ballot. The United States, France, Britain, Canada, Argentina and Costa Rica echoed his criticisms.
Even before the voting drew to a close, demonstrations grew more intense, and downtown Lima was filled with the pungent smell of tear gas. Government helicopters buzzed overhead as tens of thousands of demonstrators assembled tonight. That scene was played out in cities across the country.
Speaking to the enthusiastic, chanting crowd, in which many were carrying lit candles, Mr. Toledo said he planned to lead a nonstop, nationwide movement to nullify the election.
"Dictatorship degrades people," the 54-year-old American-trained business professor said. "It silences people. Dictatorship is the impotence of reason that brings repression."
"We need to mobilize people across Peru peacefully," said Mr. Toledo, standing in blue jeans and a button-down shirt on a platform overlooking one of Lima's main plazas.
In a particularly provocative gesture, Mr. Toledo introduced a retired general, Francisco Morales Bermudez, who was the last military president of Peru, to speak to the crowd. "I've read many chapters of the history of Peru," said the general, who ruled Peru in the late 1970's, "but I have never seen such a shameful thing as this election in the history of our country."
Based on exit polls and most of the votes counted, Mr. Fujimori had more than 50 percent, while Mr. Toledo had about 16 percent. The rest of the ballots were left blank or nullified.
The Organization of American States released a report last week saying, "The Peruvian electoral process is far from one that could be considered free and fair." It said government funds were used in the Fujimori campaign, media access was dominated by the president, and there was not enough time to inspect new computer vote tabulation software to ensure a fair count.
Before a single vote was cast, election observers from the Organization of American States and the Atlanta-based Carter Center withdrew in disgust after they failed to persuade the government to postpone the election. Mr. Toledo, the only challenger on the ballot, did not vote and told reporters the election was as "fraudulent as a soccer game in which the field is tilted and one side chooses the referees and the reporters who cover the contest."
Mr. Fujimori's bid for a third term has stirred opposition here ever since Congress fired three judges more than two years ago for ruling that a constitutional ban on a third presidential term prohibited the president from running. Mr. Fujimori argued that he could run since the Constitution was written after his first term, meaning the ban would apply only if he ran for a fourth term.
Many voters appeared to be going through the motions of voting in an election that lacked drama after Mr. Toledo pulled out 10 days ago.
"There is no institution in this country that is free anymore," Enrique Fernandez, a 48-year-old folk music promoter, said before voting in the working-class neighborhood of Rimac in order to avoid a $35 fine for not voting or problems with the police. "The Justice Ministry and election authorities are totally controlled, and this is all a fraud."
Aides to Mr. Toledo predicted that protests around the country would continue to gather momentum. There have already been strikes and road blockades in the cities of Iquitos, Cuzco and Chiclayo in recent days, as well as several violent incidents in Lima, including stone and firebomb attacks by university students on the presidential palace.
The tainted Peruvian election will dominate a meeting of foreign ministers of members of the Organization of American States in Canada this week. The ministers could ultimately decide on sanctions, although in the past severe action has been taken only in cases of coups or other overt interruptions of democratic process.
It is more likely that sanctions will come from the United States, where Congress has already passed a joint resolution calling for a review of all political, economic and military relations. Still, it remains doubtful that Washington will cut very deeply into assistance that goes into Peru's efforts at combating terrorism and narcotics trafficking.
The Clinton administration pushed hard for Mr. Fujimori to hold a second-round vote during a questionable slow count in the days following the first-round balloting on April 9. But in recent weeks Washington has softened its criticism of Peru and allowed the Organization of American States, a usually cautious organization, to take the lead in pushing for democratic reform here.
Nevertheless, President Clinton had strong words for Peru on Friday, the day after the election authorities had decided to go ahead with the vote. "Free, fair and open elections are the foundation of a democratic society," he said. "Without them, our relationship with Peru inevitably will be affected."
Mr. Fujimori is counting on the United States to go easy on him, rather than jeopardize the cooperation of the two countries in economic, anti-terrorism and especially anti-drug programs that have halved this country's coca plant production in the last five years.
"It would be terrible if our anti-narcotics collaboration was upset, and we will continue to welcome U.S. investment," Mr. Fujimori said.
Mr. Fujimori used an assortment of carrots and rather sharp sticks on his way to a third five-year term. In a wave of populism, he raised the minimum wage and handed out land titles to 150,000 peasants during the campaign. But he was also besieged by criticism by international election observers for a range of campaign irregularities. Mothers dependent on government milk and food handouts were pressed to attend Fujimori rallies, for instance, and intelligence agents harassed opposition leaders.
Many tabloid newspapers that have connections to Mr. Fujimori's intelligence service and all television networks save one cable station either did not cover the Toledo campaign or tilted their coverage toward salacious and unproved allegations of financial fraud, sexual innuendo and claims that he had an illegitimate daughter.
Just this week, a journalist who said he had videotapes showing Mr. Fujimori's intelligence chief meeting with election officials was assaulted by three unidentified men. From a hospital bed, he said the assailants had cut his wrist to the bone with a saw as they demanded that he disclose his sources inside the intelligence agency.
Immediately after the April 9 vote, cries of fraud arose when ballots and tally sheets disappeared for several hours. The election authorities announced that Mr. Fujimori had not received the required majority to avert a second round only after three days of heavy international pressure.
Mr. Toledo ran a strong race in the April first round, promising to give the poor jobs and to disentangle the courts and congress from the tight grip of presidential control.
But he appeared to fumble badly when he suddenly dropped out of the race, claiming that he was not willing to lead his supporters into a fraudulent vote unless the election date was postponed several weeks to give international observers an opportunity to audit computer software designed to count ballots.
He slid in a variety of opinion polls, as voters either expressed disappointment in his apparent surrender or dismay that he was willing to incite unrest and damage the image the country.
A poll conducted by Datum Internacional between May 19 and 22, which only the week before showed a virtual tie between the two candidates, showed that 55 percent of voters disapproved of Mr. Toledo's decision to drop out of the race. The poll also showed Mr. Fujimori leading Mr. Toledo by a 54 to 46 percent, suggesting that Mr. Fujimori could win a clean, free election anyway.

HEADLINE: Repeal the Draconian Drug Laws

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"Drug Laws That Destroy Lives" (editorial, May 24) is on target. So many politicians and criminal justice experts privately admit that the Rockefeller laws are self-defeating and costly and should be repealed. Why the delay?
First, several upstate communities are prison towns. Their economies would be in a state of upheaval if the prison population decreased as a result of sensible drug laws. Jobs are at stake and alternative employment must be part of the planning. 
 Second, many products, from soap to steel, have lucrative contracts with the Department of Correction. They view a diminishing prison population as one that causes decreasing profits.
Your editorial's position must be accompanied by plans to incorporate the real needs of those who profit from prisons.
 
DAVID ROTHENBERG
New York, May 24, 2000

SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 4; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 164 words

HEADLINE: Repeal the Draconian Drug Laws

 BODY:

To the Editor:
It is indeed alarming that 22,300 largely nonviolent drug offenders are in New York prisons (editorial, May 24).
Rockefeller-era laws have not only clogged this state's prisons with low-level drug offenders, but also pull apart families and neighborhoods, leaving children without parents and communities economically and socially fragmented. 
 Legislative bodies must begin to rethink current drug sentencing laws. The criminal justice system can engage families as resources in their treatment of addiction. Once supported in working partnerships, families have been shown to play a positive and powerful role in treatment and long-term recovery.
Let us treat substance abuse by tapping into the inherent strengths of families and communities, rather than punishing those struggling with addiction.
 
CAROL SHAPIRO
New York, May 24, 2000
 
The writer is executive director, La Bodega de la Familia, a project of the Vera Institute of Justice.

HEADLINE: The Joy of Giving

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Charitable Giving Surged Again in '99, by an Estimated 9%" (news article, May 25): 
 It is positively heartening to know that American philanthropic endeavors have grown at such an incredible pace, outflanking the country's economic growth and continuing a tradition that has been apparent throughout our nation's history. In today's technological revolution, it is both joyous and remarkable to read that we still consider charitable endeavors a top priority.
As early as 1835, Alexis de Tocqueville commented on the extraordinary commitment this country had to good works. A hundred and sixty-five years later, this sentiment continues to resound deeply in the hearts and actions of the American people.
 
DONALD STEWART
New York, May 25, 2000

HEADLINE: Building Wealth For Everyone

BYLINE: By Daniel Patrick Moynihan; Daniel Patrick Moynihan is a senator from New York.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Social insurance began in Europe, principally in Germany in the Bismarck era. In 1911, Winston Churchill carried unemployment insurance in the House of Commons, representing the Liberal government. The Tories opposite said the workers would spend the money on drink; Churchill said it was their money. Whereupon a first principle was established.
The American Association for Labor Legislation, an academic group, was established in 1906. Workers' compensation laws began to appear. Soon, in Albany, Al Smith and Robert F. Wagner brought us "mothers' pensions" and the like. 
 In the 1930's, for the first time we enacted national legislation providing unemployment insurance, an old-age pension to be known as Social Security, and a mother's pension, Aid to Families with Dependent Children. The first two programs were presented as contributory insurance. I knew Frances Perkins, who was then the secretary of labor, and have talked with one of the experts involved, Luther H. Gulick of Columbia University. Both would go on about Franklin Roosevelt's insistence that each worker have a separate account, like a bank account. His or hers. As F.D.R. put it to Gulick, so that "no damn politician can ever scrap my Social Security program." (Observe that A.F.D.C. was not contributory. Soon it became known as "welfare," and it was repealed in 1996.)
President Eisenhower brought us disability insurance, expanding workers' compensation. Then came President Johnson with Medicare, a contributory health insurance plan, and Medicaid, a welfare measure. A once-a-generation sequence had evolved.
And now we have the opportunity for a grand culmination, starting this century with a system of voluntary, contributory savings plans such that Americans will end their working lives with a measure of wealth. An estate. And for the first time, an American idea!
A bit of background. In 1977, Social Security, the retirement program, was changed from a pay-as-you-go system to a partially funded system. The revered Robert J. Meyers, who was present at the creation in 1935 and still analyzes Social Security financing, records, "The underlying financing mechanism was to build up a reserve." No one noticed this. I was a member of the 1977 House-Senate Conference Committee that enacted the law, and I surely didn't notice. Nor was it reported.
We added two percentage points to the F.I.C.A. tax -- Federal Insurance Contribution Act -- such that today some 80 percent of American households that pay this tax pay more in Social Security than in income taxes. In time, larger Social Security surpluses appeared, enough to moderate the even larger federal budget deficits of the 1980's, and then to bring us into the overall budget surplus of today.
Now here is the point. If we will make a few, admittedly difficult but wholly defensible changes in the existing program, those two extra percentage points won't be needed. Workers could take back their half -- the employer keeps the other half -- or could choose to invest the two percentage points in a personal savings plan modeled on that available to federal employees since 1987. Let the magic of compound interest work its magic.
Here are the main changes.
Use an accurate cost-of-living adjustment. The consumer price index overstates inflation by about eight-tenths of a percentage point, even after recent improvements made by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Next, provide normal taxation of benefits, which are now only partially taxed. Then extend coverage to all newly hired state and local workers, a quarter of whom don't pay into Social Security from their primary earnings but get benefits through part-time jobs.
Finally, increase the number of years counted in computing benefits from 35 to 38. Of a sudden you are in 75-year actuarial balance and don't need those two percentage points of payroll taxes.
On March 18, 1998, Senator J. Robert Kerrey and I introduced the Social Security Solvency Act, with these benefit adjustments and a provision for a "voluntary investment of payroll tax cut by employees." In 1999 it became the Social Security Solvency Act of 1999, the first Senate bill introduced in the 106th Congress other than those reserved for the two leaders. We also included Senator Kerrey's proposal to provide every child with a nest egg of $3,500: $1,000 at birth and $500 on each of the child's first five birthdays.
With respect, this is where the coming presidential debate should begin. The numbers add up; they are from the actuaries at Social Security. There are some tricky details, including a far-off increase in retirement age. (But note that now most folk, 76 percent, retire before reaching 65, the so-called normal retirement age.) And of course the main debate will concern the personal savings accounts.
It would be unforgivable to label this "privatization." But it has already begun. These savings accounts are being referred to in New York Times reporting as "partial privatization."
The term goes back to the presidential campaign of 1964, in which Barry Goldwater made an offhand remark that Social Security should be made voluntary. In the definitive study, "Policy Making for Social Security" (Brookings, 1979), Martha Derthick explained that though the remark was "not the party's position and not even clearly the candidate's position," it was "transformed by media coverage and the ridicule of rival candidates (including other candidates for the Republican nomination) into a symbol of Goldwater's radical conservatism." As such, she wrote, "it figured conspicuously in the campaign."
Doris Kearns Goodwin, a distinguished historian of the period, recently described a Democratic ad of that campaign depicting scissors cutting a Social Security card in half.
The charge is hurled at every opportunity. Establishing personal savings accounts is described as turning Social Security over to Wall Street. Dock workers would become day traders. A market downturn could wipe out benefits.
The latter charge is obscene. The present progressive retirement benefit is fixed in our bill. There is no occasion to touch it. We add a savings plan modeled on the Thrift Savings Plan for federal employees, including senators. The government matches up to 5 percent of an employee's pay. The money is invested, at the employee's choice, in one of three plans, ranging from government bonds to a stock index fund. The employee can switch around from time to time. If there is an element of risk even in a 40-year stretch, at no time are basic Social Security benefits at risk. Those are funded and solid, just as they are today and have been for 60 years.
The Thrift Savings Plan was essentially an adaption for federal workers of various retirement plans, principally the 401(k), as it is known, which were passing the tax committees in the 1970's and 1980's. In the Senate it emerged from the Government Affairs Committee. Al Gore, then a senator and a member of the committee, said on July 30, 1985, "An employee savings plan with government matching funds will give every worker the opportunity to supplement a defined and predictable pension amount." He praised a Congressional Research Service report, "Civil Service Retirement: Capital Accumulation Plans for Federal Employees."
A parallel arrangement under Social Security would, at a 7 percent non-inflation-adjusted rate of return, provide an average worker (making $30,000 a year), with $350,000 of savings at the end of 45 years. A measure of wealth.
In 1944 the British came up with the slogan of "cradle to grave" protection. We propose something beyond: an estate! For doormen, as well as those living in the duplexes above.

HEADLINE: Pay Phone Companies Rush To Refit for the Internet Era

BYLINE: By DENNIS BLANK 

 BODY:
The pay phone is an endangered species. With cell phones seemingly in every pocket or briefcase, fewer and fewer people must rely on phones that are attached, quaintly, to a wall or booth.
There are still two million pay phones across the United States, but that is down by 300,000 the last two years alone. 
 In response, the companies that make or operate pay phones are rushing to reinvent themselves, working to change the perception that pay phones are nothing but black boxes for making calls. New technology will transform them into tools to provide communications access to the Internet, find local news and weather and even offer e-mail.
In the meantime, though, economic reality is forcing the removal of many phones. "For every five telephones we installed in North Carolina today, we're taking out six," said Glenn Lancaster, president of Triangle Telephone in Cary, N.C.
This shift hurts poor people the most. In many urban areas, including New York, at least 25 percent of low-income residents have no telephone -- cellular or otherwise. The pay phone can be their lifeline, providing the only way to get help in an emergency, hunt for a job or call friends.
But when phones do not pay, they may be removed. Nationwide, the average number of calls for each phone has declined from 712 a year, to 588. And once a given phone does not yield a profit, phone companies often eliminate it. The cost of operating pay phones is going up faster than revenue from them, Mr. Lancaster said. He and other operators in North Carolina want the price of a call raised from 35 cents to 50 cents.
"The coin-based revenue model is dying fast as pay phone operators see their coin revenue model drop 20 to 30 percent," said Michael J. Boyle, president and chief executive of Elcotel in Sarasota, Fla., one of the leading pay phone manufacturers in the United States.
"They need to find a way to reinvent themselves," said John Bain, an analyst at Hoak Breedlove Wesneski in Dallas.
Elcotel is breaking new ground with 27 software patents that would transformed the black box into a snappy unit with a five-inch video screen that provides ads, restaurant listings and access to "800" numbers.
"Our strategy is move our industry from coins to content," Mr. Boyle said.
After spending $8 million on research, Elcotel sold 45,000 of its new Grapevine models for $125 million to Canada Payphone, which began installing them in March.
In June, new software will be installed to make them Internet-friendly. Mr. Boyle said new revenue would be generated from advertisers, transaction fees and revenue-sharing agreements. The new phones can be used with a credit card.
Other manufacturers are also introducing new units. Intellicall of Dallas introduced units that play audible spots of six seconds to eight seconds before a call is made.
Andrew Suzuka, president and chief executive of Key Factors Advertising in New York, which is teaming with Intellicall, estimates that revenue from the average pay phone will rise $15 a month.
The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is installing 80 new touch-screen units with full Internet access at Kennedy Airport, said Dennis Novick, president of TCC Teleplex, an independent pay telephone supplier.
But he says the old-fashioned pay phone will not die. "There is a place for the public pay phone," he said -- for those unwilling, or unable, to join the cellular revolution.

HEADLINE: Most Stock Markets Rise in Europe and Asia

BYLINE: Agence France-Presse 

DATELINE: LONDON, May 29

 BODY:
European shares closed up in quiet trading today led by technology, media and telecommunications, while shares in Asia ended mostly higher.
In Europe, dealers attributed the low volumes to the closing of the London and Wall Street exchanges for public holidays. 
 In the 11-nation euro zone, the Euro Stoxx 50 index rose 1.4 percent.
The Frankfurt DAX climbed 1.13 percent, to 7,016.66 points, while the Paris CAC 40 added 1.24 percent, at 6,205.13 points. In Paris, France Telecom ended up 2.60 euros, or 1.8 percent, at 144.40, having earlier touched a high of 148, on investor enthusiasm for an expected bid of more than $37 billion for the British mobile phone operator Orange. The deal is expected to be announced today.
"People thought they would pay extra for that, so it's good news that it's included in the price," said one dealer. "It's still a huge expense, but investors see it as a good move for France Telecom."
Asian markets mostly climbed today as investors put aside worries about Wall Street's direction ahead of Memorial Day.
Those markets that did fall did so mainly on local concerns and a firmer performance from the Tokyo and Hong Kong markets helped to shore up other regional exchanges.
Share prices in Tokyo closed 1.5 percent higher led by hopes of bigger corporate profits and stepped-up demand for information technology issues, brokers said.
The benchmark Nikkei 225 index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange ended 237.30 points higher, at 16,245.44.
"Selling pressure has subsided as investors become more optimistic about corporate earnings and buy up high-tech shares," said Kazue Mayuzumi, a senior market analyst.
In Hong Kong, share prices rose 1.8 percent on short-covering ahead of the expiration of futures contracts.
"The rise is due to short-covering ahead of settlement of the May future contracts tomorrow," said Michael Ng, deputy managing director at Sassoon Securities.
The Hang Seng index gained 252.37 points, to close at 13,975.07.
Dealers, however, said trading was cautious with the outlook for United States interest rates uncertain.
