HEADLINE: Now, the Glass Is Half Empty;
Microbreweries in the Slow Lane

BYLINE: By JULIE FLAHERTY 

DATELINE: BOSTON, May 29

 BODY:
After 14 years in the beer-making business, Richard Doyle, a founder of the Mass. Bay Brewing Company, no longer pays much attention to the humid, bready scent of barley malt and yeast bubbling over into foam-topped buckets. But the smell is still comforting, reminding him that the brewery is running all out, producing nearly two million gallons of Harpoon beer a year.
Mr. Doyle recently added a sixth 24-hour production day to the brewery's workweek. Indeed, business is as good as it ever was at the height of the specialty beer boom in the mid-1990's. 
 But some of his colleagues in the Massachusetts microbrewing industry have not been so fortunate. Local brewers like Bristol, Middlesex, Pilgrim and Old Newbury have all closed their doors. Thinking back on the boom, Mr. Doyle, who is also chairman of the Brewers Association of America, described the rush to market as a busy intersection without a traffic light.
"There was so much product going through, it was just crashing," he said. "We needed time to kind of tow it all away."
The craze in the 1990's for craft-brewed beers with a variety of tastes (and names) suddenly jammed store aisles with fanciful brews like Laughing Skull Bohemian Pilsner, Long Trail Double Bag Ale, Rogue Shakespeare Stout and Pig's Eye Pilsner. For consumers used to basic labels like Coors and Bud, it was a bit much. Some microbrewers collided with distributors who refused to carry their products and financiers who clamored for profits even as sales slowed.
As a consequence, for the first time, more microbreweries in the United States closed last year than opened. And more bottles will head for the clearance shelves this year.
But those craft brewers that lived through the shake-up -- and there are many -- are telling a tale of leaner, more economical brewing, more conservative growth and more thoughtful business plans. They are taking a breather before making another, more sober run on the American beer market, which is dominated by three companies that have 80 percent of the market: Anheuser-Busch; Miller Brewing, a unit of Philip Morris; and Coors.
Above all, the independent beer makers say they are paying more respect to their roots. The craft beer industry grew at a euphoric rate of 50 percent in both 1994 and 1995, spurring some regional brewers -- heady as prom queens with their local popularity -- to rush their products into new markets. But when growth stalled in 1997 and 1998, many retreated to their home states and the comforting loyalty of customers in their own backyards.
Deschutes Brewery of Bend, Ore., stopped shipments to Colorado and San Diego. Pyramid of Seattle and the Breckenridge Brewing Company in Denver cut back on their out-of-state attempts as well.
What they found, said David Edgar, president of the Institute for Brewing Studies in Colorado, was that beer drinkers in Oregon had a special affection for their Black Butte Porter, and Alabamans stuck with their Red Mountain Red Ale.
"The industry will always be primarily about local beers," he said. "The lesson was learned that just because you were the cat's meow in Portland doesn't mean that automatically consumers are going to embrace your brand as strongly in Seattle."
The Shipyard Brewing Company in Maine, for one, began on the Kennebunk River in 1992, but within a few years expanded into New York, New Jersey, Maryland, Chicago, Florida and parts of Virginia. Then sales slumped. Shipyard retrenched to New England, where it currently sells 75 percent of its product. Fred M. Forsely, its co-founder, has not given up thoughts of going national, but meanwhile he is coping with "being able to accept a small piece of a very loyal market."
"If we go to Chicago again," he said with humility, "we won't expect to sell three trailer loads a month again."
There have been a handful of closings in New York as well. In upstate New York, where the trend was slow to dig in, there are about a dozen working microbreweries, including Brewery Ommegang in Cooperstown, which opened in 1998, and Flying Bison in Buffalo, which began brewing last year. All have set their sights on the local market, which gives them good odds of succeeding, said Bill Metzger, a trade publisher in Buffalo.
Many brewers call New York City a hard market to break into. But the Brooklyn Brewery built a loyal following by handling its own distribution. Sales have grown consistently since it began in 1988, said Stephen Hindy, president and co-founder. Last year, Brooklyn Brewery sold 32,000 barrels, 80 percent of them in the metropolitan area.
"It was a slow way to grow, but owning our own trucks and doing our own deliveries has taught us a lot about the beer business," Mr. Hindy said. "We know a lot about what our customers are saying."
At the Sunset Grill and Tap in Boston, which offers about 60 American craft brews from its 112 taps, beer enthusiasts still sample the occasional seasonal Summer Wheat Ale or Octoberfest brew. But instead of jumping on the new brand of the month, drinkers generally stick with established products from Sam Adams (made by Boston Beer and the biggest and best-advertised craft beer in the country), Sierra Nevada (a best-seller from California) and New England makers like Vermont's Magic Hat and the Tremont Brewery, a tiny Boston producer.
"A lot of it, at this point, is just credibility," said Marc Kadish, the bar's owner. "Breweries change, and the owners change. Or it's simply not fresh. Somebody takes a chance, tries an interesting microbrew and is disappointed. Why do people go to McDonald's? It's consistent, and people know what they're going to get."
Even very good beer makers ran into problems. Some, expecting the euphoria of the beer craze to continue, poured borrowed money into beer-making and were caught with a lot of shiny equipment to make too much beer for too few drinkers. Catamount, Vermont's first microbrewery, completed a $5 million dollar plant just as growth began to top out. It closed last month.
The Frederick Brewing Company of Maryland found itself in a similar predicament in 1997. It built an $8 million beer-making plant with a 100,000-barrel annual capacity, but wound up producing only about 32,000 barrels there. Last year, Frederick was bought by the Snyder International Brewing Group of Ohio.
Irene Firmat, a founder of the Oregon-based Full Sail, has seen several brewers in her region merge or consolidate. Others continue to struggle with whether to go public, stay private or form a partnership with an industry giant. Her own company faced the same question when two of her partners recently wanted out of the business. Full Sail employees bought them out in 1999, and the brewery is now worker-owned.
Ms. Firmat credits Full Sail's survival, in part, to the Pacific Northwest's taste for better beer. "Craft beer is part of the consciousness of the region," she said, pointing out that special brews account for about 10 percent of beer sales in the area, as opposed to about 3 percent nationally. "That helps a lot to buffer the changes in the industry."
One change was increased competition from imported beers. If a customer was willing to spend a little more for a six pack, it turned out he was more likely to buy a brand that had been around for 50 years than 50 days. East Coast brewers in particular felt the competition of brands like Heineken, Corona and Bass, which helped push consumption of imports to 9.2 percent of the American market last year.
The craft beer promoters have themselves to blame.
"In general, tastes have definitely developed," said Mr. Kadish, the bar owner. "People were so scared of the imports and the dark beers, and now I.P.A. is a household word." As with India Pale Ales, customers barely sputter when they order a Bitburger, Warstiener or Hackerphscorr.
To further erode consumer confidence, the megabrewers played an awkward role in the specialty beer field. The large beer makers answered the call for unique beers with their own homespun-sounding labels, including Anheuser-Busch's Red Wolf, Coors's Killian's Red and Miller's Red Dog. As if that scarlet trio were not confusing enough, consumers were unsure whether they were drinking a hometown favorite or a quaintly packaged version of a megabrew.
Meanwhile, some smaller companies, eager for expansion money, became megabrewer protectorates. Miller, the Milwaukee-based giant, bought a 50 percent stake in the fast-growing Shipyard in 1995. In exchange, Shipyard gained access to Miller's laboratories and, probably most important, its distribution system. But Miller apparently lost interest when Shipyard's barrel production dropped from 39,500 in 1996, to 25,300 in 1998. Last month, Shipyard announced it was taking on some debt to buy back those shares.
Despite the recent doldrums, industry analysts are optimistic. Beer sales increased 1.6 percent last year, primarily because the prime beer drinking population, considered to be people (mostly men) in their 20's and early 30's, is also up. Beer prices, which have lagged behind inflation for some 15 years, have climbed.
There are still over 420 small brewers in the United States -- up from about 200 in 1994 -- and their stories are as varied as their labels. Together, sales at four of the largest specialty brewers -- Boston Beer, Pete's Wicked, Redhook and Pyramid -- fell 24 percent between 1996 and 1999. Yet half of the top 50 craft brewers had double digit sales growth last year.
Some have been blissfully unaffected by the turmoil. New Belgium sales were up more than 40 percent last year. Sierra Nevada, the second-largest craft brewer in the United States, has grown right along since its founding in 1981, increasing its sales nearly 15 percent last year and 26 percent the year before.
Mr. Doyle, the beer association chairman, said resisting the temptation to go for maximum growth helped his Harpoon Brewery keep its footing as others around him slipped. "We were not leveraged, we're not highly leveraged now," he said. "Our focus was making sure that we were very profitable at the size we were, to store up resources for the time when the industry thawed again."
So far this year, most of the specialty brands have reported an upturn in sales, said Frank C. Walters, the director of research for the trade newsletter Impact. "A lot of the streamlining, getting rid of the deadwood brands, we think was probably completed in the last half of 1999," he said. "Things are starting to grow again."
Shakeouts have their advantages. At the National Craft Brewers Conference in Milwaukee last month, attendees were mostly experienced brewers interested in seminars like Hopping to Perfection and The Biodiversity of Yeast. There were fewer newcomers looking to hop on a bandwagon. "These events used to be full of tire kickers," said Gary Fish, president of the Deschutes Brewery. "There's not so many of those people any more."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Coffee Group Stumbles In Plan to Raise Prices

BYLINE: By JENNIFER L. RICH 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, May 29

 BODY:
Borrowing a page from OPEC's strategy book, the world's leading coffee producers have agreed to withhold beans from the market to raise the price from seven-year lows.
But since they reached that agreement a little more than a week ago, cracks in the unity of the Association of Coffee Producing Countries and its allies have already appeared. 
 The price of coffee, which rose in the days immediately after the agreement, has since relinquished some of that gain. On the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York, coffee for July delivery reached nearly $1.04 a pound after the agreement, but by last Friday it had retreated to $99.2 cents a pound.
Meeting in London on May 19, the 14-member association, working with five nonmember coffee producers, said they were prepared to withhold 20 percent of coffee crops from the market. The producers, which make up about 85 percent of the world's coffee production, said they would come up with a more detailed plan by June 16 when they return to London for another meeting.
Commodities analysts have grown increasingly skeptical, however. They point to the lack of specifics about how such a plan would work, in the face of an increasing world supply of coffee beans.
"The market is in a vacuum," said Arthur Stevenson, a commodities analyst at Prudential Securities in New York. "Only once we find out how the governments involved intend to effectuate those plans and how they intend to finance them will we know whether this whole thing has any real legitimacy and credibility."
Doubts about the success of such an agreement started appearing even before the meeting began, when some of the major world coffee producers, including the leading robusta bean producer, Indonesia, said that they lacked the resources to pay coffee growers to withhold supply.
"I think that one of the challenges in such a plan is putting in the financial or economic mechanisms to be able to fund those within the coffee sectors that would be receiving money to retain their crop," said Robert Nelson, president and chief executive officer of the National Coffee Association of the United States. "That is going to be of primary concern to the farmers."
Mexico, one of the coffee producing association's nonmember observers, along with Vietnam, Honduras, Guatemala and Nicaragua, has said that it planned to offset the lost exports by stimulating domestic consumption of coffee. But stimulating consumption is a long-term process that is unlikely to absorb the excess supply of coffee. Brazil, which is the world's leading producer and exporter of coffee beans, will be the pivotal player in the success of the plan to withhold coffee beans. At the moment, Brazil seems committed to seeing that the plan is successful.
"The government wouldn't being doing all of this if it didn't want the plan to work," said David Nahum Neto, the general secretary of the Association of the Coffee Industry of Brazil.
Marcus Vinicius Pratini de Moraes, the agriculture minister of Brazil, said after the meeting in London that the country had already allocated $167 million to financing the retention of about 3 million 60-kilogram bags of coffee from Brazil's total crop for 1999-2000 of about 27 million bags.
But Brazil's coffee industry, which is expected to expand sharply in the coming years, is taking an increasingly larger share of the world market. That is something that experts say the country will be unlikely to jeopardize by restricting supply over the long term.
Theoretically, at least, withholding coffee is akin to the strategy of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to curtail the production of oil. OPEC has been successful the last few years in restricting how much each member produces, a strategy that has raised the price of oil.
But that may be where the comparison with coffee ends. Coffee, unlike oil, is not critical to the smooth functioning of the world economy, so producers have less influence over the market. To make matters worse for the coffee exporting countries, history does not provide any examples of successful agreements to keep beans off the market.
"In the past, these types of agreements have proven ineffective and unenforceable," said Mr. Nelson of the National Coffee Association of the United States.
Until the June meeting of the coffee producing nations, analysts say, coffee prices will remain vulnerable to speculation about an eventual agreement. Traders will also be keeping a close eye on Brazil, where the onset of winter in June could affect the coffee crop. A damaging frost in the coffee belt of Brazil could make a price agreement unnecessary.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
U.S.-European Union Tax Dispute Is Growing

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 29

 BODY:
Despite the Clinton administration's hope for a quick resolution to a multibillion-dollar dispute with the European Union over corporate tax policy, the problem appeared to be escalating today on the eve of President Clinton's meeting with European leaders in Lisbon.
In a statement issued here before Mr. Clinton's departure, Stuart E. Eizenstat, the deputy treasury secretary, said he was saddened and disappointed by a rebuff on Friday by Pascal Lamy, the European Union's trade commissioner. 
 Mr. Lamy said the administration's proposed revision in the way some foreign sales by United States-based corporations were taxed would still not bring the United States into compliance with the World Trade Organization's rules against subsidizing exports.
"We firmly believe that our proposal is W.T.O. compliant, in fact and in law," Mr. Eizenstat said in his statement.
He added, "I am saddened that the E.U. has not yet seized this opportunity to negotiate a solution based on our proposal. We are disappointed that a chance may be lost to accomplish this goal."
The dispute is over a tax break, worth billions of dollars, that federal law currently allows exporters through the use of so-called foreign sales corporations, subsidiaries set up in places like the Virgin Islands, Barbados and Guam.
Overseas sales channeled through these subsidiaries escape both sales tax and duties. In 1999, hundreds of United States companies, including Boeing, Microsoft and General Motors, saved about $4 billion by using these legally sanctioned offshore tax havens.
Despite an agreement between the United States and the European Union not to challenge each other's tax policies, the E.U. challenged the policy on the ground that amounted to an illegal effort to subsidize exports by making them more competitive.
An appeals panel of the W.T.O. agreed in a ruling three months ago, setting off the administration's effort to come up with an acceptable alternative.
Mr. Eizenstat said today that even in the absence of a negotiated solution, the administration would work with Congress to enact new tax legislation that in its opinion met the world trade body's objections.
The tax issue is only one of several trade-related disputes, including skirmishes over bananas, genetically modified products and aircraft noise, that have cast a shadow over economic relations between the United States and members of the European Union.
Under Mr. Eizenstat's plan, the United States would repeal the foreign sales corporation plan and replace it with special income tax rates for both export and nonexport foreign sales by eligible manufacturers.
The commission said, however, that the changes meant United States-based companies would still have to export to benefit -- the very aspect of the original plan that was condemned by the W.T.O.
The United States proposal also contained two other elements that the commission considered incompatible with global trade rules -- a 50 percent United States content requirement for products benefiting from tax breaks and a transfer pricing plan that allocates a proportion of profits to the foreign sales corporation.

HEADLINE: Museum Brings Town Back to Life

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER 

DATELINE: NORTH ADAMS, Mass.

 BODY:
Of all the dying mill towns in New England, this was the deadest.
By the mid-1980's, 70 percent of its storefronts were empty. The Sprague Electric Company, the city's largest employer and long its dominant presence, closed in 1985, putting 4,137 people out of work and affecting virtually every family in North Adams, a city of 18,000. 
 The unemployment rate, the highest in Massachusetts, ran from 25 percent to 30 percent. The local newspaper kept a front-page box score on plant closings. A developer suggested that the whole town, at the foot of steep mountains, be flooded to provide lakefront property.
"We had hit rock bottom," recalled John Barrett III, the city's mayor for the last 17 years. "We were the butt of jokes. The Adams Print Works closed, another 2,200 jobs. The hotel went bankrupt; it was the third time. Everything was bankrupt."
But now North Adams is in renaissance, a nascent Soho in the Berkshires.
More than two-thirds of the town's shops are occupied, including a downtown-slick restaurant, 55 Main, with spotlights and arty furnishings. Artists have moved into some of the long brick mills, and one old mill houses a farm that grows shiitake mushrooms.
This month, plans were announced for a $5 million project to turn a deteriorating stretch of Victorian houses into a bed and breakfast to be run by the Red Lion Inn of nearby Stockbridge.
"I think it's wonderful to have an excuse to be doing something in North Adams. I think it's a great place," said Nancy Fitzpatrick, president of the Red Lion, a favorite with the crowd that frequents Tanglewood.
The unlikely catalyst of this change, a gigantic museum in an abandoned factory featuring maple trees growing upside down and sculptures made out of tons of industrial debris, was nearly hooted out of existence as a $35 million boondoggle before it could be born.
"You've got to understand, everybody laughed at this," said Mr. Barrett, who remembers and bristles at every slight North Adams has ever suffered.
In the year since it opened last Memorial Day weekend, the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art, known as Mass MOCA, has been hailed as a wild success, drawing more than 105,000 visitors to its galleries, 25,000 more to performing arts events, garnering architectural and preservation awards, and, in an arrangement that is crucial to its financial security, renting commercial space to eight tenants so far, with 60,000 square feet scheduled to be occupied by October.
It was a hard, 14-year struggle into being, a cliffhanger of state funding cut-offs, small-scale fund-raising, deadlines missed and extended, plans juggled and changed.
Much of the credit goes to Mr. Barrett, the blue-collar mayor, and Joseph C. Thompson, a soft-spoken art historian from Williams College via Oklahoma, who has devoted most of his working life to the project.
Refusing to give up a dream, Mr. Thompson and his development director, Jennifer Trainer, went for months without pay, turned down lucrative job offers and, along the way, fell in love, married and now have an infant son. And an infant museum.
"Without Joe, this wouldn't have happened," said Michael Conforte, director of the Clark Art Institute in neighboring Williamstown.
Mass MOCA also owes much to three post-modern phenomena.
The first is the tendency of artists to create works that, although they are called minimalist, are huge, so huge that art experts say 90 percent of them cannot be exhibited. Some are so big and so minimalist that they do not even exist; they are just instructions as to how to build them in the unlikely event there should be room.
The second phenomenon, as manufacturing is abandoned, is the existence of big empty industrial spaces. New York's Soho neighborhood was a manufacturing center, after all, before artists (and later investment bankers) inhabited its lofts.
The third, is the explosive growth of e-commerce and Internet companies in this region, which is being called the Silicon Village. Web companies are among the museum's main tenants, including eZiba.com, which markets exotic crafts over the Internet.
The museum also owes much to Williams College, five miles to the west. Williams gave crucial initial backing to the museum. Some of the college's wealthy and well-connected alumni, who bear a fond allegiance to the surrounding hills, invested in the project. And since the 1960's, the college's art history department has spawned a network of museum directors and curators, including the current director of the Guggenheim, Thomas Krens.
Mr. Krens conceived of Mass MOCA while running a more traditional expansion of the college's Museum of Art, where he was director.
In 1986, when Mr. Krens came looking for more display place, Mayor Barrett showed him the abandoned Sprague plant. It sprawled over a third of the town, with 27 buildings on 13 acres, and resembled a walled medieval city, though in rough industrial brick, with a clock tower, courtyards and a branch of the Hoosic River flowing through it. The plant was built in 1874 for a thriving textile industry; when that went under in 1942, it was bought by Sprague, which made the trigger for the atomic bomb, components for the Gemini moon mission and electronic capacitors.
Entranced, Mr. Krens spun a vision for a museum, involving a luxury hotel, the architect Frank Gehry and the collection of an Italian industrialist, Count Giuseppe Panza di Biumo, who had more than 200 artworks from the 1960's and 1970's.
Michael S. Dukakis, then the governor, bought into the idea as a development plan for this forlorn corner, which had been bypassed by the state's economic boom in the 1980's. Mr. Krens estimated that the museum could be opened by 1990.
But in 1988, Mr. Krens left for the Guggenheim, Mr. Gehry and the Italian count went with him.
In a sense, the Guggenheim's much-hailed museum in Bilbao, Spain, is a flossier version of Mass MOCA, an effort to revive a faded Basque industrial city with a government-funded museum.
Mr. Thompson, a protege of Mr. Krens, inherited the project, but by the next year the "Massachusetts Miracle" went bust. Mr. Dukakis was out by 1990, and the Republican administration of the new governor, William F. Weld, cut the $688,000 in development money that Mr. Dukakis had slipped in the budget.
The Boston Globe sneered at the plan as "endive economics" and other newspapers were equally dismissive, calling it a pipe dream and a hare-brained scheme.
But the sometimes puckish Mr. Weld visited the old factory in the fall of 1992 and, like others, fell under the spell of its space, saying later that he liked its karma. After contemplating an exhibit displayed at the factory, a work by Mario Merz that resembled a spiral of mismatched tables set up for a hotel buffet, Mr. Weld gave the go-ahead for a gradual release of state funds.
But there were more problems, and at one point even the Mayor Barrett said "I'm all MOCA'd out."
The project was finally saved in 1994 when the Jacob's Pillow dance center became a sponsor, as required by legislation. This also changed the plan significantly, adding dance, movies and concerts by singer Patti Smith and others.
Still, even after the years of struggle, the mayor is unable to stifle a giggle as he walks past the art that is saving his town.
Like Joseph Beuys's "Lightning With a Stag in its Glare" which is owned by the Philadelphia Museum of Art, but is too big, at 3,000 pounds and 22 feet tall, to be shown there. It is a huge bronze triangle suspended from the ceiling with an aluminum sawhorse-looking thing and a bunch of little metal lumps.
There is some difference of opinion about which is the lightning (Mr. Thompson says it is the big triangle), but it seems impossible to construe the lumps as anything but, well, deer droppings.
"I can't keep a straight face," Mr. Barrett said. "Droppings, hee, hee, hee. My citizens say they've got stuff like this in their basements."

The large industrial space has allowed the museum to display minimalist artworks, pieces often too big for regular museums. (Photographs by Keith Meyers/The New York Times)

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1855 words

HEADLINE: Few Blacks Where Tips Are High;
Racial Diversity Is Rare for Waiters in Elite Restaurants

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS with MONTE WILLIAMS 

 BODY:
In New York City's restaurant firmament, where establishments ceaselessly open and close, where fortunes are made and lost overnight, and where chefs can go as hot and as cold as the soup, there are few unchanging truths.
But one reality has dominated the city's enormous inventory of distinguished restaurants: a scarcity of black waiters.
"For anyone who eats in high-end restaurants in Manhattan, it is impossible to ignore the fact that there is very little, if any, diversity in many, many restaurants," said Andrew G. Celli Jr., the bureau chief for civil rights in the New York State attorney general's office. "It's really in your face." 
 While more than 26 percent of New York City's population is black, only 10.5 percent of its 48,176 waiters and waitresses are black, according to 1996 census data. Since many of those are working in low-end neighborhood restaurants, the racial disparity among waiters in mid-to-high-priced places is greater.
For many city restaurantgoers, though, that truth takes awhile to sink in.
"People are so used to the exclusion of African-Americans, you don't even notice," said David A. Paterson, a black state senator whose district includes Harlem and part of Washington Heights.
The reasons for the disparity are as complicated as diners' orders. Interviews with dozens of restaurant owners and waiters, and with state, city and labor leaders reveal an industry that acknowledges a dearth of black waiters, but offers several reasons for their absence.
At many Chinese, Japanese, Italian and other ethnic restaurants, for instance, owners say that they employ no blacks as waiters because they need to hire employees sharing their own backgrounds. They say that customers demand the authenticity implied by the presence of ethnic waiters in ethnic restaurants.
Other restaurateurs say few blacks apply for the jobs even though new restaurants are plentiful and waiters are scarce. And both black waiters and leaders acknowledge that black Americans may be rejecting what they perceive as a servile profession.
But many blacks working in high-end restaurants in New York City say that the real reason their numbers are so small is racism.
Waiting jobs could have considerable economic significance in black neighborhoods where boom times have certainly not brought full employment. Jobs in the city's 20,000 restaurants have increased 24 percent since 1992 in an industry that generated about $7.2 billion in revenues in 1998. Waiters at top city restaurants can earn from $40,000 to $70,000 a year or more.
"Restaurant jobs are steppingstones into careers and opportunities for many," said Lloyd A. Williams, president of the Greater Harlem Chamber of Commerce. "There is absolutely no question that blacks are being discriminated against as waiters and waitresses."
Certainly many black waiters perceive this to be true. Chris Harvey, a waiter at Aquagrill in SoHo, said he had been shut out of previous jobs because of his skin color. "Young whites come and go, but it takes me longer to find a job," Mr. Harvey said. "So when I find a place, I stay."
George Thomas, 35, remembered the days when he was trying to get a toehold in the industry. "I have faxed restaurants with my qualifications," recalled Mr. Thomas, who is black, "and they expressed excitement. Then they saw me in person, and the whole conversation changed."
He kept applying for jobs, refused to take no as an answer, and became a waiter, a maitre d'hotel and sommelier at Gotham Bar and Grill in Greenwich Village. He later became a waiter captain at the three-star restaurant Daniel on East 65th Street, and for the last year, he has been a captain at the four-star Bouley Bakery in TriBeCa.
But his is the exceptional story. "In some respects there is a ceiling for black people," Mr. Thomas said, adding that in regard to managers, maitres d'hotel and captains, "there are not many blacks at fine restaurants."
One of them, Daniel Smalls, 36, a former waiter, is now a manager at Guastavino's at Bridgemarket, where 40 percent of the waitstaff of 120 is black. "A lot of black people began to apply here when they saw me," he said.
White waiters predominate at many of New York's better-known restaurants. For example, of the 10 waiters and 5 captains in the dining room of La Cote Basque, the haute cuisine doyenne at 60 West 55th Street, none are black.
Only one of the eight waiters and three captains at Le Perigord, the 36-year-old French grande dame at 405 East 52nd Street, is dark-skinned -- a server from Bangladesh. Of the 48 waiters in the dining room and banquet operation of the four-star Le Cirque 2000, on Madison Avenue between 50th and 51st Streets, two are black.
But the owners of Le Perigord, La Cote Basque and Le Cirque 2000 say they do not have racist employment policies. "The majority of our people working here are minorities," said Sirio Maccioni, the owner of Le Cirque 2000, "including our chef," who is Cambodian.
Nevertheless, Brooks Bitterman, research director of Local 100 of the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees International Union, which organizes the city's nonhotel waiters, said the whiteness of waiters was striking considering "that 99 percent of low-wage kitchen workers are nonwhite minorities, Hispanics and Asians." Dr. Bitterman added, "That contrasts with white senior cooks in many kitchens, and the primarily white front-of-house staffs."
While women's groups and the state attorney general's office have challenged sex discrimination at some of New York's elite restaurants, racial discrimination has not really registered on the official radar screen. Mr. Celli of the attorney general's office said, "We have several open investigations involving several high-end luxury restaurants," but these cases focus on sex discrimination. Racial discrimination may be involved, he added, because "when you look at one thing, you often find other sorts of things."
Restaurant discrimination cases have traditionally been difficult to prove, but in 1998, the Federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission won a prosecution at the Harley-Davidson Cafe in Midtown: an African-American waitress, Lisa McDonald, won $175,000 after complaining that she had been verbally insulted (she accused the manager of saying "you look like Buckwheat") and ordered to redo her hair at the restaurant.
In February 1999, the Times Square Brewery agreed to pay $450,000 to $650,000 to settle a lawsuit involving accusations of discrimination and racial slurs, filed on behalf of 27 employees, but it admitted no wrongdoing.
Mr. Williams, of the Harlem chamber of commerce, suggested that a more representative labor organization might encourage black waiters to enter the restaurant industry. Yet currently only a little more than 10 percent of the city's waiters are represented by the two principal restaurant unions. Leaders of Local 6 of the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees International Union said the union has little control over whom restaurants hire. The local represents nearly 4,000 New York hotel waiters earning $25,000 to $100,000 a year.
Some unionized restaurants contend that seniority rules make new job openings for blacks very scarce. "Our waiters are here for life, and last September we had our first job opening in three or four years," said Georges Briguet, owner of Le Perigord, explaining how he had hired the restaurant's Bangladeshi server.
Individual restaurateurs have made efforts to hire more blacks. Danny Meyer, co-owner of the Union Square Cafe, Gramercy Tavern, Tabla and 11 Madison Park, said that five years ago, he became concerned about the "sameness" of his front-of-house staff. "I asked managers why the staff wasn't more diverse," Mr. Meyer said. "I wasn't satisfied with their answer that 'no minorities applied.' "
So Mr. Meyer gave blacks visible jobs as hostesses and maitres d'hotel, blacks noticed and began applying, and "things have changed dramatically now that we have people of color right at the front door." He added that now his staff is more diverse and so is his clientele.
Mr. Meyer does not insist that his Indian-themed restaurant, Tabla, employ only Indian waiters. Some restaurateurs, though, maintain that they cannot hire black servers because doing so may make ethnic restaurants seem less authentic to customers. "In the older, high-end French and Italian places -- where the proprietor is of a certain age -- these people want to surround themselves with members of their own culture and their own age," said Eric Weiss, whose company, Service Arts Incorporated, has hired the staffs of many high-end restaurants.
But Peter Ward, president of Local 6 of the hotel and restaurant employees' union, said that "it is ridiculous to suppose that you need to be Italian to serve Italian food."
Some black waiters say they have faced racism from customers, too. Mr. Thomas said he would not soon forget the customer at Gotham Bar and Grill who told him, "For a colored boy, you're not too bad." And Mr. Smalls of Guastavino's, who previously worked his way up to manager at the four-star Jean Georges near Columbus Circle, remembers customers there who kept insisting on speaking to the real boss. "I'd have to say to them, 'No, the manager -- that's me,' " he said.
Some blacks say that another problem is the lack of black chefs in New York City's finest kitchens. Carl Redding Jr., 36, said that he was not able to find a top cooking position in a white-owned restaurant, so he opened his own, Amy Ruth's, which serves up home-style Southern cuisine on West 116th Street in Harlem.
But Mr. Redding said that racism works both ways: "there is racism on the part of blacks against whites," meaning that several Harlem restaurants hire only black waiters.
Bedelia Woods of Sylvia's, the soul-food landmark in Harlem, said this is not the case at her restaurant. "Our doors are open to everybody," said Ms. Woods, a daughter of the owner, Sylvia Woods. She added that when white servers answer the restaurant's job advertisements and ask for directions, "when we say uptown in Harlem, they may not come."
Part of the reason for the scarcity of black waiters, some suggest, may be a self-fulfilling prophecy. "Young African-American women and men don't go out for those jobs," State Senator Paterson said. "They think those jobs are closed off to them."
And it may be that the idea of serving people is the hurdle. Perhaps other blacks "think it's a belittling job," Mr. Smalls suggested.
Can patrons change the status quo? Some black leaders suggest that their buying power can speak volumes. "We should not eat where we can't work," said State Assemblyman Keith L. Wright, who represents Harlem.
Mr. Celli of the attorney general's office agreed that the diners hold the cards. "The restaurant industry is driven by consumer likes and dislikes," he said. "If we change the culture so that, as a society, it is no longer attractive to have an all-white, all-male work force, then the customer will have to be right. And there will be change."

HEADLINE: Contact With a Web of Agencies Failed to Prevent a Disabled Girl's Death

BYLINE: By SOMINI SENGUPTA 

 BODY:
In the nearly two weeks since a 5-year-old girl with cerebral palsy was found dead in her Bronx apartment, her body no more than a 17-pound skeleton pocked with roach bites, investigators have been sifting through the details of her short, ailing life. Did she die of malnutrition, as a preliminary autopsy suggested? Was it her mother's fault? Should anyone have spotted the dangers that awaited the child, or prevented her decline?
The answers to those questions are weeks away, and who, if anyone, is culpable for the death of the child, Ahsianea Carzan, is far from certain. The medical examiner's report will take another week, and the city's Administration for Children's Services is conducting its own internal inquiry. 
But interviews and a review of records suggest that over the last few years, Ahsianea and her family came into frequent contact with a web of private social service agencies and government officials charged with helping families in crisis.
Mired in many difficulties at once -- bouncing from one apartment to another, a bitter custody fight, domestic violence charges against the children's father, Caseim Brown -- the Carzans had paraded through Family Court on several occasions. Child welfare caseworkers visited their home at least twice. A probation officer may have, as well.
They were seen by doctors -- as recently as November -- as well as by school officials, a psychologist and at least two private social service agencies that work with needy children.
At almost each point, the family was referred to a sprinkling of services. Whether they were appropriate and whether the mother, Ebony Carzan, availed herself of those services or found them helpful remain unclear.
She seems to have alternately rejected and sought help, particularly when it came to raising Ahsianea, sometimes following the suggestions of professionals, sometimes missing doctors' appointments. She has refused to speak to a reporter.
In the end, it seems, none of those who came into contact with the family were able to pinpoint the perils that Ahsianea faced. Nor, apparently, were they able to aid her mother, a 24-year-old unemployed woman and former orphan who had fled an allegedly abusive boyfriend and was raising four children alone on welfare and disability benefits for her severely disabled daughter.
As for her other children -- 1, 6 and 7 years old, and now in the city's custody -- the attorney appointed by the court to represent them says they, too, suffered.
"It appears there may have been some form of corporal punishment," the lawyer, Aleza Ross, said. She could not say, however, if and how the child welfare agency failed to protect them.
The Carzans first came to the attention of the city school system in April 1998. A doctor at Elmhurst Hospital Center in Queens, where Ahsianea was seen, recommended that she be evaluated for a preschool special education program, according to a spokeswoman for the Board of Education, Margie Feinberg.
School officials in Staten Island, where the family lived at the time, sought the mother's consent, as required by state law. But consent never came. Ahsianea was never evaluated.
A few months later, in October, during a custody battle in Manhattan Family Court, the children came to the attention of the Administration for Children's Services. Mr. Brown accused Ms. Carzan of neglect. Child welfare caseworkers visited her home, and the court ultimately granted custody to the mother and visitation rights to the father. (For her part, Ms. Carzan had already accused Mr. Brown of a string of domestic abuse incidents. His criminal case is pending.)
They may have been visited by a probation officer, frequently used by the courts to inspect homes in contested custody cases, around that time as well. Probation department officials were unable to confirm whether that happened in this instance.
The child welfare agency's investigation found no evidence of neglect. Still, a portrait of a family in crisis emerged. A spokeswoman for the agency, Jennifer Falk, said they referred Ms. Carzan to a shelter for domestic violence victims and suggested that she seek counseling at the Puerto Rican Association for Community Affairs, a troubled agency shut down a few months later.
Ahsianea was also referred for evaluation to the Lucille Murray Child Development Center, a private group in the Bronx that assesses and provides day care services for developmentally disabled children.
There, on Jan. 13, 1999, Ahsianea was seen by a social worker, an occupational therapist, a psychologist and a speech pathologist. Her needs, recalled the social worker, Yolande Schelling, were plainly daunting. The child could not speak or move her limbs. She was blind. She needed intensive treatment -- the sooner the better, by Ms. Schelling's account.
Ms. Carzan, the social worker noticed, had no help in caring for the child. Indeed, their apartment in the Patterson Houses is not even equipped with a wheelchair ramp.
"When the child came in for evaluation, I saw possible signs of neglect," Ms. Schelling said in an interview last week. "The child was not receiving any services, and the child was a paraplegic."
But to get Ahsianea into a program, her mother needed to submit a doctor's report. Two weeks later, when she failed to do so, officials at Lucille Murray said they became worried. On Feb. 4, they faxed a note to the Administration for Children's Services; officials there responded by saying the family was already known to them.
Over the next two months, the center twice dispatched a social worker to the family's home, each time pressing Ms. Carzan to furnish a medical report for Ahsianea. "I was a bit fearful about this case," Ms. Schelling said. "She seemed so overwhelmed, having to bring all these kids. We went to her."
The home visits did not put Ms. Schelling at ease. Ahsianea was sitting in a stroller. Why had her mother not acquired a chair especially designed for paraplegic children, she wondered. The girl's hands were clenched in a fist -- cerebral palsy can severely restrict motion -- and the inside of her palm was covered with festering wounds.
Ms. Carzan did not seem uncaring, Ms. Schelling recalled, just overwhelmed. "She said, 'I try to do my best,' " Ms. Schelling said. "I thought this was a young parent who needed to get that child to treatment."
Ms. Carzan finally furnished the doctor's report in April. Though it was not as thorough as she would have liked, Ms. Schelling said, it allowed Ahsianea to be enrolled in a special education program.
In the end, Ms. Schelling's efforts bore no fruit. The next month, school officials in the Bronx recommended the Lavelle School for the Blind, a private academy in the Bronx under contract with the state. As a kindergarten student, Ahsianea was to attend classes five hours a day, five days a week, and receive language, occupational and physical therapy.
But according to the spokeswoman for the city schools, Ms. Feinberg, the girl's mother refused. And that was her prerogative: state law does not require a child to be in school until first grade.
So even after the mother refused, the school system had no reason to call the state central register on child abuse and neglect, Ms. Feinberg said. "At no time was there any neglect seen," she said.
Officials at the Lavelle School never saw Ahsianea. The next time they heard of their would-be pupil, she was dead.
For its, part, the Administration for Children's Services closed the Carzans case last August, having found no evidence of neglect.
A few months later, in October, Mr. Brown was back in court, again seeking custody and again charging that the children were neglected.
By then, the children's grandmother, Alberta Hanley, had also complained to the agency about possible neglect and abuse. Another visit by a child welfare investigator followed. The older children were interviewed, the home inspected. It does not appear that the caseworker saw Ahsianea. No evidence of abuse or neglect was turned up.
The next month, a doctor at Lincoln Hospital saw the child. Hospital officials said they could not comment on the doctor's diagnosis, except to say that she had been seen at the hospital twice earlier that year. She had also missed a number of appointments, said a hospital official who spoke only on the condition of anonymity.
The caseworker's report, prepared after the second visit, did not appear to indicate whether the family had received any of the services to which they had been referred the first time around, or whether Ahsianea was receiving treatment.
Should the caseworker have done more?
Agency officials said they would not comment until an internal investigation is completed. "We're looking into whether all proper casework was followed," Ms. Falk said.

HEADLINE: French Officials Warn Further Decline of Euro Could Harm the European Economy

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: PARIS, May 29

 BODY:
France's prime minister, finance minister and central bank governor rallied to the support of the sagging euro today, warning that a further decline could damage the economy of the 11 nations that share the currency and adding that the European central bank might take action to halt the slide.
The euro has shed 8.5 percent of its value against the dollar this year, and more than a fifth since its introduction in January 1999. 
 The fall has fanned inflation by increasing the cost of imported goods and raised concerns among many of the region's 290 million citizens about their savings.
France's top officials chose the occasion of the 200th anniversary of the Bank of France, created by Napoleon with a mandate to protect French citizens from inflation, to voice their concerns about the euro's weakness.
More than 100 central bank officials are in Paris today and Tuesday to attend events linked to the anniversary of the French central bank.
The euro's exchange rate "isn't satisfactory," said Prime Minister Lionel Jospin. Finance ministers from the euro nations would support central bank action that led to a "solid and stable" currency, said Laurent Fabius, the finance minister, echoing Jean-Claude Trichet, the Bank of France governor, who said the European central bank would be vigilant to ensure the euro is a "strong currency."
Mr. Fabius said that the European central bank might raise interest rates to halt the currency's decline and ensure inflation did not accelerate. The region's inflation rate averaged 1.9 percent in April, just below the European central bank's 2 percent limit.
Many investors expect the central bank to raise interest rates for a fifth time since early November at the next meeting of policy makers on June 8.
The 3.75 percent benchmark rate is 2.75 percentage points below the United States Federal Reserve's benchmark, a gap which has helped brighten the allure of the dollar. The euro declined 0.5 percent today, to 92.67 cents.
Mr. Fabius indicated that finance ministers might prefer intervention to support the euro in the form of buying the currency on the open market, rather than raising interest rates. Higher borrowing costs would "harm economic growth," making it harder for governments to achieve "full employment, while lowering budget deficits and taxes," he warned.
While unemployment is falling in France and Germany, the euro region's two biggest economies, a tenth of the work force in both countries is still out of work.

HEADLINE: Despite Defeat On China Bill, Labor Is on Rise

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Despite the American labor movement's loss in the bruising battle over the China trade bill, supporters and opponents of the movement say that after years of decline, labor has once again become a powerful political force.
Unions provided important political muscle that helped Vice President Al Gore locked up the Democratic presidential nomination, and they are certain to be a major force for the Democratic Party in the fall. 
 After many people wrote off labor as an irrelevant, toothless dinosaur, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. has displayed considerable muscle on Capitol Hill. Labor has blocked legislation to grant the president fast-track authority to negotiate trade agreements and has helped push through a higher minimum wage and the Family and Medical Leave Act.
In other signs of labor's strength, white-collar workers, including doctors and psychologists, are flocking into unions as never before, and labor registered its biggest organizing victory in 60 years by unionizing 74,000 Los Angeles home-care workers last year.
Much of this rebound has been engineered by John J. Sweeney, who was elected president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. four and a half years ago on a platform of reviving labor after its membership and influence had slipped steadily for two decades. To rebuild labor, Mr. Sweeney has focused on attracting new members; as the best evidence of a turnaround, he points to last year's 265,000 jump in union membership -- by far the largest rise since the 1970's.
Thomas J. Donohue, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, said it would be foolish for anyone to think that labor was weak because the House of Representatives defied it last week and approved permanent normal trade relations with China.
"Anybody who stands up and says, 'We won this thing by a couple of votes and therefore labor is weak,' they don't know how to count," said Mr. Donohue, who led the corporate fight for the trade bill. "Labor has a lot of money. Labor has a lot of forces on the ground. Anyone who wants to declare them weak, just look out for the next fight."
This year, the 13-million-member A.F.L.-C.I.O. has pledged to assemble its biggest army of campaign volunteers; tens of thousands will distribute literature at workplaces and make millions of get-out-the-vote telephone calls.
The labor federation's endorsement of Vice President Gore gave him much-needed assistance in the Democratic presidential primaries, with union foot soldiers helping him trounce former Senator Bill Bradley in the Iowa caucuses and capture the New Hampshire primary.
Political experts also give labor much of the credit for Democratic victories in 1998, from Gray Davis's election as governor in California, to Charles E. Schumer's triumph over Alfonse M. D'Amato for a New York Senate seat, to the party's surprising success in gaining House seats in the last midterm elections.
"It's like night and day comparing the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s political operations today with those in the 1994 elections," said Charles Cook, who publishes a nonpartisan political report. "It's like comparing a Model T with a Ferrari."
But labor has a long way to go to regain the economic might it had in the 1950's. Back then, 35 percent of the nation's work force belonged to unions compared with 13.9 percent today. The sectors where unions have traditionally been strongest, like steel, automobiles, mining and apparel, have been losing jobs the fastest, while the sectors where unions have the least representation, like technology, finance and fast food, are the fastest-growing fields.
Organized labor is losing about half the elections in which workers vote on whether to unionize largely because many corporations mount aggressive and expensive campaigns that urge workers not to join unions. As a result of such corporate tactics, unions now represent fewer than 1 in 10 private-sector workers.
"The labor movement has done very well in the public sector, organizing government employees, but in the private sector, it is still very difficult," said Richard Hurd, a labor relations professor at Cornell University.
Labor also faces other problems: the occasional embarrassing episodes of union corruption, repeated Republican efforts to weaken unions, and internal feuding among union leaders over political strategy and trade issues.
Businesses contribute 15 times as much in campaign money as unions do, and many Democrats still keep their distance, fearful of accusations that they are in Big Labor's pocket. And for all their efforts, unions lost the fight they cared about most in the last few years, the China trade bill.
To reinvigorate labor, Mr. Sweeney has advocated more militant tactics, like those used by thousands of striking Los Angeles janitors who repeatedly blocked traffic last month to draw attention to their low wages. He has also worked to reduce labor's unwanted reputation as a "special interest" by having it focus more on helping low-wage workers and by forming alliances with religious leaders, environmentalists, immigrant groups and college students protesting overseas sweatshops.
"John Sweeney has a commitment to reach out to those who have been largely bypassed by the labor movement," said the Rev. Howard Hubbard, the Roman Catholic bishop of Albany, who has helped lead efforts to rebuild the clergy's once-strong ties with labor. "He's reached out to the forgotten workers -- child-care workers, nurses' aides, janitors, people at the low end of the scale. He's made a commitment to show solidarity with the poorest workers."
With union membership falling by nearly a fourth from 1979 to 1995, Mr. Sweeney has made attracting more members his No. 1 priority. He often cites studies showing that labor's declining power is a major reason that after-inflation wages have declined for most workers in the last quarter-century.
Mr. Sweeney has used his bully pulpit to urge the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s 68 member unions to hire more organizers and to spend millions of dollars more each year on recruiting. Still, in his first three years at the federation's helm, union membership slid by 150,000 as many unionized workers retired or companies closed unionized factories and moved operations overseas.
But Mr. Sweeney's ambitions seemed to pay off last year when the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced that union membership grew by 265,000.
Union leaders say they hope those gains are not a one-time blip, but the start of a long-term upswing, although many labor experts say the jury is still out.
"I think we're starting to turn the corner," Mr. Sweeney said. "While we've had significant progress in terms of organizing, we still have to do a lot more. We can't rest on modest growth." His ambitious -- some say unrealistic -- goal is for unions to organize one million new members each year, meaning there could be a net gain of 500,000 members after layoffs and retirements.
But there is a huge obstacle to reaching this goal. Only a handful of unions, most notably the Service Employees International Union and the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees Union, are making an all-out effort to attract more workers. Mr. Sweeney said he wished that more unions copied the union he once headed, the Service Employees, which devotes 45 percent of its budget to organizing -- 10 times the percentage of many unions. That union recruited 155,000 workers last year, many of them janitors and hospital employees, the most any union has organized in one year since 1918.
"There is still tremendous inertia among certain unions," said Kent Wong, a labor relations professor at the University of California at Los Angeles. "The level of activism among some unions has changed dramatically, but many unions are having tremendous difficulties changing."
In an effort to expand union membership, Mr. Sweeney has gotten the labor movement to reverse its long-held position and embrace immigrant workers, rather than oppose their taking jobs. In the 1980's unions were convinced that immigrants were driving down wages so labor backed a law that punished employers who hired illegal immigrants.
But this year the A.F.L.-C.I.O. has called for ending such employer sanctions and granting amnesty to millions of illegal immigrants. Labor changed direction because it now views immigrants as a natural audience for its message and because it sees many employers taking advantage of illegal immigrants.
One welcome development for labor is the surge in interest shown by white-collar workers. With managed care squeezing their incomes and professional freedom, thousands of doctors are joining unions, while in New York State, 3,000 psychologists have unionized. Nationwide, 10,000 podiatrists have joined unions and so have more than 20,000 customer service workers at United Airlines and US Airways.
Hundreds of I.B.M. workers showed interest in unionizing last year after their company sought to cut their pensions. And even a few dozen workers at Microsoft called for a union because they were angry about being long-term temporary workers, with few benefits, rather than permanent workers.
"In a lot of industries, because of the way things are changing, people realize they need some form of collective voice," Mr. Sweeney said. "People are seeing the problems they're confronted with are too big to resolve by themselves."
In the wake of the China trade battle, one of Mr. Sweeney's biggest problems is that many political and business leaders have pegged him as protectionist and anti-trade. These critics misunderstand his position, he insists.
Convinced that past trade accords have helped business but not labor, Mr. Sweeney said he told the Clinton administration that the A.F.L.-C.I.O. would oppose any trade agreements that did not protect workers rights. So when he learned that the administration's trade deal with China contained no worker protections, he saw no choice but to oppose it.
"I think trade is good for our country," Mr. Sweeney said. "It's important to our successful economy. We recognize that globalization is here to stay, so the question is how do workers around the world share in the fruits of globalization?"

HEADLINE: Gas May Reach $2.25 a Gallon, Schumer Warns

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
Unless action is taken now, gasoline prices will hit $2.25 a gallon this summer followed by a spike in heating oil costs worse than the one last winter, Senator Charles E. Schumer predicted yesterday. But federal energy officials disputed his figures.
Mr. Schumer, a Democrat from New York, urged the Clinton administration to help drive prices down by releasing federal oil reserves into the market. He made his proposal in a joint letter dated Friday with Senator Susan M. Collins, a Republican from Maine, to the federal energy secretary, Bill Richardson. 
 But Secretary Richardson disagreed with both the premise and the proposal. "These are unnecessarily alarmist views, as they do not reflect current market conditions or projections," he said yesterday. His agency's experts forecast a national average price of $1.40 to $1.45 a gallon by the end of summer.
The average price for regular unleaded gasoline in New York City is $1.64 a gallon, up from $1.27 a year ago, according to a recent survey by the AAA automobile association.
The two senators blamed the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, charging that it had failed to keep its promise to increase production enough to hold crude oil prices to $28 a barrel. Instead, the price has been hovering around $30.
"If OPEC continues to constrict supplies of oil and we fail to release reserves, the price of gasoline will go to $2 this summer and $2.25 by Labor Day, and home heating oil prices will be through the roof," Mr. Schumer said at a news conference in Manhattan.
Such increases would divert money from other needs and could curtail summer vacation plans, he said. Worse, increased fuel charges would raise the price of food and other commodities because of higher trucking costs. Such inflation could lead the Federal Reserve to push interest rates up, which would slow the economy. "It points a dagger at the heart of our economy," Mr. Schumer said. "Gasoline at $2.25 a gallon is not just a nuisance; it's a crisis."
The nation's oil reserve is about 600 million barrels stockpiled in Texas and Louisiana, set aside by law for emergencies.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Phone Upstart In China Plans $5 Billion Stock Offering

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, May 29

 BODY:
Two months after China's largest oil company staggered onto the stock market here, the country's second-largest telecommunications company announced today that it would seek to raise as much as $5.26 billion in an initial public offering in Hong Kong and New York.
The company, China Unicom Ltd., hopes to get a warmer reception than PetroChina, a state-owned oil company that was tarred before its offering by charges of labor and human rights abuses. China Unicom will probably be spared those brickbats, analysts said, because it is an upstart phone company rather than a vast oil giant with operations as far apart as Tibet and the Sudan. 
 "China Unicom is a very different animal than PetroChina," said Andrew Look, an independent fund manager here. "PetroChina is a typical old-economy company. China Unicom doesn't have that baggage. It is a technology play, and a play on China's entry into the World Trade Organization."
But Unicom, which was started by the government six years ago to challenge the state monopoly, China Telecom, has its own problems. It recently shelved plans to upgrade its network with a mobile phone technology licensed from Qualcomm. And it has had to unravel joint ventures with more than 20 foreign partners, whose investments the Beijing authorities declared illegal.
Most troubling, China Unicom has only a 14 percent share of the country's burgeoning cellular phone market. China Telecom, which raised $4.2 billion in a stock offering in 1997, has the bulk of the business -- plus the favor of market analysts, who consistently put its shares at the top of their recommended lists.
"Unicom has yet to prove its mettle in the marketplace," said Rohit Sobti, an Asian telecommunications analyst at Salomon Smith Barney here, in a report published in February. "We believe the company has a long way to go before it can effectively compete" with China Telecom.
China Unicom said in its prospectus that it would issue almost 2.46 billion shares, each at a price between 11.50 Hong Kong dollars, or $1.48, and 14.50 Hong Kong dollars, or $1.87. It will also offer 2.34 billion shares in the form of American depository receipts in a price range of $14.76 to $18.61.
If the offering is fully subscribed at the middle of the price range, the company said, it would raise nearly $4 billion. At the top end of the range, the proceeds would be $5.26 billion -- making Unicom the largest stock offering in Asia outside Japan. The Japanese phone giant N.T.T. spun off its cellular operation, NTT DoCoMo, in an offering that raised $18 billion.
Unicom said it planned to use the cash from the offering to underwrite a $12 billion expansion of its cellular, long-distance and data networks. Although the company is an also-ran in the mobile phone market, it operates the largest paging business in China, with 43.5 million subscribers.
"The Chinese authorities have helped Unicom by giving it licenses and injecting the paging business," Mr. Look said. "This is a very sexy story."
Certainly, China Unicom's story has had corporate soap opera qualities. In its early years, the company's status as an upstart was appealing to foreign investors like Deutsche Telekom and France Telecom. They agreed to put in money, even though it meant setting up awkward joint ventures to circumvent China's restrictions on foreign investment in telecommunications networks.
Then, in 1998, Beijing declared these arm's-length investments illegal, and ordered the company to dissolve them. China Unicom spent many months in often-rancorous negotiations with the partners -- in the process becoming a symbol of the perils of foreign investment in the country.
China Unicom said it would take a one-time charge of about $100 million to buy out the remainder of the joint ventures. As part of the settlement, it will also issue warrants that allow its former partners to buy shares of China Unicom six months after the initial public offering.
The company's technology foray has been similarly ill-starred. In February, it signed an agreement with Qualcomm to upgrade its network with a digital mobile phone technology known as C.D.M.A., or code division multiple access. Today, it told investors in Hong Kong that it would abandon the plan because C.D.M.A. was in danger of being superseded in two years by so-called third-generation cellular technology.
With this record of flip-flops and false starts, some analysts say that China Unicom is destined to be a weak sister to China Telecom. But Unicom can take solace from PetroChina: after being picketed by protesters and initially spurned by investors, it now trades comfortably above its offering price.

HEADLINE: Lazio Falls and Splits His Lip, But Keeps Marching at Parade

BYLINE: By MICHAEL COOPER 

DATELINE: BABYLON, N.Y., May 29

 BODY:
Representative Rick A. Lazio tripped and fell face down onto the pavement today at a Memorial Day parade here, splitting his lip. But he dusted himself off and finished the route before going to the hospital, getting eight stitches and then marching in a second parade in Queens alongside the man he replaced in the race for the Senate, Rudolph W. Giuliani.
The injury means that Mr. Lazio will most likely have a swollen lip on Tuesday afternoon, when he is expected to formally accept the Republican nomination for the Senate at the Republican convention in Buffalo. 
 The candidate and his supporters quickly seized upon the accident and sought to turn it to their advantage, both with humor and by using it to try to illustrate Mr. Lazio's perseverance, before it could become the wrong kind of political metaphor about missteps or stumbling on the campaign trail.
And like Bob Dole, who fell off a stage at a campaign stop in California during the 1996 presidential race, Mr. Lazio quickly poked fun at his mishap. "I was so happy to be home that I had to kiss the ground," Mr. Lazio, who fell in his own district, said after leaving the hospital. "I didn't know that it would kiss back."
It was indeed a hometown parade for Mr. Lazio, one he said he has marched in since childhood. Along the way, he greeted many spectators by name, shook many hands and kissed many babies. Then, his jacket and tie and leather dress shoes notwithstanding, he would sprint back to the head of the parade, literally running for office. It was during one of these sprints that he slipped and fell onto Deer Park Avenue.
Dabbing at his mouth with a bloodied handkerchief and a bag of ice from a nearby deli, Mr. Lazio finished the parade.
Some spectators were confused at the sight of him, as shouts of "Good luck, Rick!" and "Keep her out of New York!" were replaced by cries of "You've got lipstick on you," and, more accurately, "Your lip is bleeding!" When Mr. Lazio finished the route, his aides looked on nervously as he paused to talk to reporters before driving back to his home in nearby Brightwaters for help.
Aides said that once he got home, Mr. Lazio got prompt advice from his wife, Patricia, a nurse, who took one look at his lip and recommended a trip to the hospital.
So he got stitches at the Long Island Jewish Medical Center, changed into a pair of rubber-soled boat shoes for better traction, and went back onto the hustings to campaign with Mr. Giuliani at the Little Neck-Douglaston Memorial Day parade along Northern Boulevard.
It was the first time Mr. Giuliani had campaigned with Mr. Lazio since deciding not to seek the Republican nomination for Senate himself.
This parade was not without chaos either. The mayor and the injured congressman soon found themselves facing a crush of reporters so unruly that police reinforcements were called in to restore order, and trying to talk about campaign issues and economic opportunities over the din of the roaring mufflers of Rolling Thunder, a motorcycle club made up of Vietnam veterans who were riding in the parade.
The mayor seized on all this as evidence of Mr. Lazio's grit. "Look at him, he's a real New Yorker," Mr. Giuliani said. "He's got a fat lip, he can talk over the worst kinds of noises, it doesn't bother him and he's out here answering all your questions."
The mayor's comments were a not-so-veiled allusion to Mr. Lazio's Democratic opponent, Hillary Rodham Clinton, who, as first lady, is often kept from the press by the Secret Service.
But if the morning parade was in the heart of Lazio country, the afternoon parade was clearly in Mr. Giuliani's territory. The mayor got the loudest cheers from the crowd.
And Mr. Lazio, while warmly greeted, was not always recognized. "Who's that with the mayor?' " one spectator asked.
But there were plenty of well-wishers. Joe Martino, 73, who served in the Pacific in World War II, said, "I was sorry to see Rudy Giuliani get out of the race, but we're for Lazio."
And Linda Delligatti, 65, who goes to the parade every year and gets a kiss from the mayor, got a kiss from Mr. Lazio, stitched lip and all, this year. "On the cheek," she said. "The mayor kissed me too. I hope he gets better."
Still, for all the spectacle of Mr. Giuliani's endorsing his onetime rival for the Republican nomination and actively stumping for him, many eyes remained on Mr. Lazio's sutured mouth. As the parade continued along Northern Boulevard toward 251st Street, a member of the mayor's staff might have averted another accident when he noticed that Mr. Lazio's shoelaces were untied. "Sir, your shoes," he cried out.
When Mr. Lazio knelt down to tie them, he was instantly surrounded by photographers seeking to capture the moment.
