HEADLINE: POPULATION SHIFT IN THE WEST RAISES WILDFIRE CONCERNS

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 29

 BODY:
The wildfire that swept through Los Alamos, N.M., this month is setting off alarms across the mountain West, where more and more Americans have chosen to live on the forest's edge.
Experts say that housing shift has multiplied the danger that fires could kindle similar disasters elsewhere. And the shift is behind an urgent new Congressional quest for millions of dollars in emergency money to try to ease the risk. 
 The blaze in Los Alamos, which consumed hundreds of homes, was a pre-emptive fire gone awry. But in communities like Ashland, Ore., and Missoula, Mont., whose populations have swelled with former city dwellers, the fire has served fresh notice that residents sit astride a volatile mix.
"It's not a matter of if the fire occurs, it's a matter of when," said Paul Summerfelt, a top Fire Department official in Flagstaff, Ariz., which is surrounded by the world's largest forest of Ponderosa pines and where half of the 60,000 residents are said to face a severe wildfire risk.
Across the country, the damage caused by wildfire to homes and property increased sixfold from the 1980's to the 1990's, to a total of $3.2 billion over the last 10 years, federal officials say. In an average year over the past decade, 1,200 homes burned, more than double the number over the previous decade.
Already this year, more than 40,000 wildfires have consumed more than a million acres, more than in any similar period since 1996.
With the lesson of Los Alamos in mind, Congress and the Clinton administration are working on a plan that would focus an urgent new round of fire-prevention efforts this summer in the danger zones where populations and wild land meet.
"As people get their homes closer and closer to nature, they become more and more at risk," said Kenneth O. Burris Jr., chief operating officer of the United States Fire Administration, which is based in Emmitsburg, Md.
The emergency measure is being drawn up by Senator Jeff Bingaman, Democrat of New Mexico, and other Western lawmakers with help from the Forest Service and other federal agencies. It would nearly double, to $115 million from $65 million, the amount of money available to the government this year for efforts intended to prevent wildfires.
In part, the plan would pay for more prescribed fires, like the one that ignited the Los Alamos blaze, in a fiasco for which the federal government has accepted responsibility. It would also emphasize safer but more costly efforts, relying in part on manual cutting and thinning of the dense, overgrown forests that surround many Western mountain communities and lie at the heart of the fire risk.
"The events of the past two weeks in New Mexico demonstrate that we cannot simply allow nature to take its course," Senator Bingaman wrote in a May 19 letter to Mike Dombeck, the Forest Service chief.
Fire, of course, is a natural event, but few Western forests remain in their natural state. Experts say the current fire problem is a legacy of the last 100 years, in which most fires have been suppressed and large trees logged, leaving today's forests unnaturally dense, choked with debris and fire-prone.
Those years of fuel accumulation have made it more likely that even a small fire caused by lightning will spread. That danger is reflected in statistics showing that the number of wildfires that destroy 1,000 acres or more in the United States has increased to a recent average of about 80 a year from 25 a year in 1984.
But there is no doubt, the experts say, that the wildfire problem has been compounded by rapid population growth in the nation's most forested states, particularly by the building of legions of ranchettes, vacation homes and developments near forest boundaries. That trend has added new fronts to the kind of threat that has long plagued places like Southern California, where population growth into remote canyons and hillsides began several decades ago.
For one thing, the proximity of people to forests makes it more likely that a cigarette or a lawn mower spark, for example, might ignite a blaze; an estimated 90 percent of wildfires are caused by humans. Of even more concern, the experts say, is the fact that the presence of houses makes forest fires more difficult to control, because priority is given to protecting property, and more difficult to prevent, because traditional fire-prevention methods like controlled burns are often unpopular with residents.
"We've created a situation in which the forest is like a wood stove," said Andy Stahl, executive director of the Association of Forest Service Employees for Environmental Ethics, a group of 13,000 current and former employees that is based in Eugene, Ore. "We've loaded that stove with paper and shavings and sticks and the like, but now it's sitting in the middle of a living room, and we're telling the forest managers, O.K., take care of this stuff, but don't burn the house down."
The Forest Service estimates that some 40 million Americans live in what it calls the "urban/wildland interface," directly adjacent to or scattered within unpopulated areas with wild land vegetation. The agency's estimate does not say how many of those people face a wildfire risk, but separate findings by some fire-prone states leave little doubt that the number is high.
In California and Colorado alone, officials there say, about three million people face at least a moderate wildfire risk, including the many who have built new homes in recent years in areas like the Sierra Nevada foothills in California and Jefferson County, west of Denver.
A study by Dave Theobold, a researcher at Colorado State University, focusing on areas within two miles of forest boundaries found that population densities in those once remote parts of the state had quadrupled from 1960 to 1990, even before the last decade's building boom.
"Clearly, the states with a lot of forests have through most of the last decade shown disproportionate growth and disproportionate home building, and that implies that we're going to have more people living close to the forest than in the past," said Michael Carliner, an economist with the National Association of Homebuilders.
What happened in Los Alamos has dealt a major setback, at least for now, to prescribed fire, the method most commonly used by federal officials to reduce fire risks on Forest Service and National Park Service lands. In that case, what was to have been a controlled blaze in the Bandelier National Monument quickly spread out of control, ultimately burning more than 46,000 acres.
The 30-day moratorium on such burning imposed by the federal government remains in effect, and last week Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt extended the ban indefinitely on park service land. Across the West, the example is bound to harden local resistance to the setting of blazes like the one in Los Alamos.
The main alternative, the manual trimming of countless commercially worthless small-diameter trees, faces problems of its own. It is so costly that the Forest Service has typically enlisted timber companies to do the work as part of contracts that also allow traditional logging activity. But such arrangements have also tended to stir strong opposition from environmental groups.
For example, in Ashland, Ore., a community popular among wealthy former city dwellers, a Forest Service plan to reduce the risk of a fire that could cut off the city's water supply has been blocked for the last four years by critics opposed to the fact that it would allow timber companies to carry out new logging.
Frank Carroll, a spokesman for the Potlatch Corporation, a timber company based in Spokane, Wash., criticized such opposition as shortsighted. "We have got to face reality," Mr. Carroll said, "and what's happening now is that various groups are absolutely bent on a course of catastrophe for communities in the West."
As one potential model, some Congressional and administration officials have been looking to a project under way in Flagstaff, where a coalition of government, industry and environmental groups has begun to make a dent in trimming the dense Ponderosa forest that extends even within the city limits.
Even there, however, opposition from groups like the Forest Guardians, an organization based in Santa Fe, N.M., has acted as a brake. The group opposes what it calls the commercialization of the national forests, and its executive director, Rex Wahl, suggested that residents worried about fire danger should not expect someone else to solve the problem for them.
"They move to the forest and then they want to get rid of the forest, because it's being touted as a threat to their property," Mr. Wahl said. "They need to take some responsibility for the danger themselves."

HEADLINE: Franks Uses His Insider Status As a Selling Point in Senate Race

SERIES: IN THE RUNNING -- Second of four profiles of the Republican candidates for the Senate in New Jersey.

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: NEWARK, May 29

 BODY:
Representative Robert D. Franks, just in from Washington and a vote on the House floor, breezed into a candidates' night not long ago at the Days Inn in Roxbury, N.J., wearing his political experience as comfortably as his unwrinkled dark suit.
After some small talk about the cloud formations he had seen as his plane landed, Mr. Franks ticked off a series of accomplishments of the Republican majority in Congress, and argued that his party deserved more credit than President Clinton did for the declining budget deficits and the roaring economy. Then he moved on to his role on the Transportation Committee and the specifics of legislation to ease congestion on state roads. 
 "I'm the one candidate in this race who has served in federal office," said Mr. Franks, a four-term member of Congress who is among the four Republicans seeking the party's Senate nomination in the June 6 primary. "And I believe I have accumulated the experience to weigh in on your behalf."
Such declarations of Beltway familiarity sometimes breed contempt -- or paeans to term limits -- but Bob Franks projects his Washington experience as a plus.
He has spent a lifetime steeped in politics and government. It started at age 15, when he worked as a youth coordinator in an early State Assembly campaign of Thomas H. Kean, who would later become governor. Mr. Franks himself was elected to the Assembly at 28, and later served as the state Republican chairman from 1989 to 1992, the year he won his seat in Congress.
During that rise he forged relationships with county leaders, healed divisions in the state party and exuded an earnestness and ambition that Mr. Kean said came across to most as "a love and enthusiasm for government that is very rare."
"But he's different from a career politician, because he takes courageous stands," said Mr. Kean, a reference to their shared views in favor of abortion rights and on other social issues. "He is one of those people who can bring people together in the center, because he is not off to the right or the left."
Despite these encouraging words, the former governor has not endorsed anyone in the primary race, which also includes State Senator William L. Gormley, another of his longtime political allies. The other candidates are James W. Treffinger, the Essex County executive, and Murray Sabrin, a former Libertarian.
Still, in a state where Republicans seeking to advance to higher office are stacked up like jets waiting to land in fog at Newark International Airport, Mr. Franks has had his share of problems lately in promoting amity and bringing people together. His "career track," according to one prominent Republican, had always pointed toward running for governor in 2001.
But that goal put him on a collision course with his fellow Union County Republican, Donald T. DiFrancesco, the State Senate president. That played out in a battle for control of the Union County Republican Party chairmanship in 1998, a fight Mr. DiFrancesco's side won.
When Gov. Christine Todd Whitman decided last fall not to run for the Senate seat being vacated by Frank R. Lautenberg, Mr. Franks averted any further confrontation by shifting to the Senate race. But it may be a temporary cease-fire. "Bob's modus operandi is collaboration," one Republican leader said, "but all bets may be off if he doesn't win the Senate nomination and decides to return to a run for governor."
In an interview, Mr. Franks, 48, admitted that as a career politician, he could face hostility from time to time. But he has tried to blunt the label by voluntarily returning 5 percent of his annual Congressional salary of $141,300, adopting a gift ban in his Congressional office and donating his frequent flier miles to the Make-a-Wish Foundation, which grants wishes to children with life-threatening illnesses.
"I'm not your father's politician," he said, "and that's why I have won consistently in a district that has 22,000 more Democrats than Republicans." He was born in Hackensack but spent part of his childhood in the Chicago suburb of Glen Ellyn.
It was there that his passion for politics seems to have surfaced. At 13, he found himself drawn to a storefront plastered with campaign posters for Charles Percy, a Republican candidate for governor of Illinois. Mr. Franks said he walked in and emerged with the job of handing out campaign literature, "a fun thing to do." Mr. Percy lost, but two years later Mr. Franks worked on his successful Senate campaign.
Soon after, the Franks family returned to New Jersey. Mr. Franks recalled his father, a pharmaceuticals salesman, softening the blow of the relocation by telling him that their new community of Summit was staunchly Republican. The teenager quickly became active in the party, helping to resuscitate the local Young Republicans and recruiting volunteers in local campaigns.
He attended college at DePauw University in Greencastle, Ind., and later earned a law degree from Southern Methodist University in Dallas.
After returning to New Jersey, he began his political career in earnest, with a plan to run for the Board of Freeholders in Union County in 1979. But then a veteran state senator decided to step down, allowing the area's Republican assemblyman to move up. Mr. Franks set his sights on Trenton. He won, and served 13 years in the Assembly.
By 1989, the Republicans were in disarray, unable to hold the governor's mansion against the onslaught of Jim Florio. The party chairman resigned, and Mr. Franks, who had developed a reputation as a diligent lawmaker who could bring factions together, was tapped to be leader of the state party.
Three years later, Representative Matthew Rinaldi, a veteran Republican, left the party in the lurch when he resigned and ended his re-election bid just three months short of the general election. The well-liked Mr. Franks was a shoo-in as a last-minute replacement.
In the race for the Senate nomination, Mr. Gormley has raised the most money, but Mr. Franks is not far behind with his goal of raising $2.5 million for the primary. And he has something that Mr. Gormley does not, Sheriff Edward Rochford of Morris County said: a grass-roots network around the state made up of people whom Mr. Franks helped as a state legislator, party chairman and congressman.
"I met him when he was my instructor in Republican 'candidates school' when I first ran in 1992," Sheriff Rochford said. "He taught me what he does, and that is to try to make most of the people accept you by sitting down and explaining your positions to them and by embracing your opponents and not going negative."
That has changed some in the thick of the battle with Mr. Gormley, as Mr. Franks has been aggressive in recent debates.
Glenn Paulsen, the Republican chairman in Burlington County and a Franks supporter, recalled how 11 years ago when Mr. Paulsen sought to oust a longtime Republican officeholder who had made a racial slur, Mr. Franks, then party chairman, stood with him "without flinching and on principle." Mr. Franks used to show up unannounced at the campaign headquarters to help out.
"He seemed young but tremendously energetic, and you knew this wasn't just another politician, but a real guy," Mr. Paulsen said. "So when he announced that he was running for the Senate nomination, I didn't hesitate and was on the phone to him asking what he needed me to do."
One of the keys to Mr. Franks's seeming broad appeal is his moderate record. While he voted with the Republican majority to impeach President Clinton and joined with Newt Gingrich, the former House speaker, in pushing the Republican Contract With America in 1994, he continued to be moderate on domestic economic issues as well as on foreign policy, while liberal on many of the social and cultural issues dear to conservative Republicans.
"On the core values of the Republican Party, which are freedom, economic opportunity, personal responsibility, I'm a bedrock Republican," Mr. Franks said. "While in Washington I have concentrated on sending the power and the authority back to the states."

HEADLINE: Summer Residents Want Year-Round Voice

BYLINE: By BLAINE HARDEN 

DATELINE: SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y., May 26

 BODY:
Behind the privet hedges that shield the many monstrous mansions in this village by the sea, something semi-revolutionary is brewing.
The rich people who summer in the Village of Southampton are up in arms, in an understated, law-abiding kind of way, about an American principle for which Colonial patriots tossed tea into Boston Harbor: taxation without representation. 
 "We don't say we cannot afford to pay the taxes -- we never admit to that -- but we don't like to pay taxes that are onerous and we don't like to be ripped off," said Lowell Harwood, a seasonal resident. Though he owns a beach house here that he estimates is worth $6 million, Mr. Harwood, like others with a permanent residence elsewhere, cannot vote in village elections.
The seasonal residents of Southampton are hardly alone in their hunger for a vote away from home. From Cape Cod to Colorado, second-home owners are clamoring -- usually with the help of their lawyers -- for a limited franchise. They want a voice in how their tax dollars are spent and in how much year-rounders may charge them for services they seldom use.
Mr. Harwood, 70, who made his fortune in parking and property development in Manhattan and whose glass-and-wood home in the dunes has a swimming pool, tennis court and putting green, doesn't expect sympathy.
"Nobody is going to feel sorry for us," he said, referring to himself and his wealthy neighbors on Southampton's Meadow Lane. "That is not what we are looking for. We just want justice."
This village, which predates the Boston Tea Party by 133 years, has been floating in a deep green sea of property tax money since the 1890's. That's when plutocrats like W. K. Vanderbilt began to erect gargantuan houses that they insisted on calling cottages. Since then, in an inexorable march of the moneyed to the sea, more and more summer people have bought their way into Southampton, as more and more year-round village residents have been bought out.
Village officials say that about three-quarters of the village's property taxes are paid by summer people, who have no vote in local elections unless they choose to make Southampton their permanent residence. The justice that summer people seek is the right to vote on village matters, like who will be mayor and the setting of special tax assessments for roads and water service, while keeping their permanent residence back home, which usually means Manhattan or the suburbs of New York.
Like most states, New York allows residents to claim only one legal residence for voting purposes. "You can't have two addresses for voting," said Lee Daghlian, a spokesman for the State Board of Elections. "That is the election law."
Yet even some year-round residents of resort communities are beginning to agree with summer people that the law should bend to the reality of an increasingly affluent nation where sales of vacation homes continue to soar. According to a survey this month by the National Association of Realtors, 377,000 vacation homes were sold in 1999, an increase of 9.3 percent from the last survey in 1997.
"It really is a taxation-without-representation thing up here," said John Quenell, a year-round resident of Lower St. Regis Lake in the Adirondacks and a councilman in the Town of Brighton, N.Y. "The way things work out in the eastern end of Long Island or up here, it is the people who don't live year-round and don't use the services who end up footing most of the bills. It is not fair."
In the Adirondack village of Speculator, year-round residents approved spending $5.3 million last year to build a school for 103 students. In response, part-time residents, who account for about 40 percent of the school district's tax base and could not vote on the proposal, filed a federal lawsuit, which is pending.
There are about a dozen states, including Connecticut, Colorado, North Dakota and Indiana, that grant nonresidents a vote on some local issues. The right was endorsed three years ago by a federal appeals court in Denver, which ruled that seasonal residents who owned property in the tiny resort of Mountain View could vote on all local matters, in a town where they pay eight times more property taxes than year-round residents.
"It is clear that the nonresident property owners have a sufficient interest in town affairs to make it rational for the town to include them in the political process," the Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit ruled.
That is exactly what Bill Hattrick, a former mayor of Southampton, believes is both fair and inevitable for summer communities on the South Fork of Long Island.
"It is a grave injustice in this country to take the money of the summer residents and not give them full membership in the club," said Mr. Hattrick, a year-round village resident who is president of the Southampton Association, a group of about 700 mostly part-time residents who own large estates.
Scholars who study tax policy in the United States dispute just how grave that injustice may be.
"I have never been too concerned that the very wealthy are underrepresented by our political system," said James Hines, a professor of business economics at the University of Michigan Business School and director of the school's Office of Tax Policy Research. "Even if they have one vote, or in this case, no votes, their interests are still represented by their economic power."
There is a limit to how much the locals can charge the rich, Professor Hines said, because the rich can simply move away. But he added that in the Hamptons, where competition is keen among the rich and celebrated to flaunt their money and celebrity, the soak-the-rich limit might well be incalculable.
"On one hand, it is unfair," said Professor Hines, referring to what he said is a well-established pattern of year-round residents' extracting high taxes from seasonal property owners. "On the other hand, it is hard to cry your eyes out about it, given all the other tragedies in the world."
Year-round residents of the Hamptons, who spend their summers stuck in traffic and who have seen countless potato farms gobbled up by supersized mansions, certainly are not shedding tears for the disfranchised pain of summer people.
"You can't really make an intelligent decision as a voter if you are only out here three months a year," said Francesca Haley, a waitress at Silver's Restaurant on Main Street in Southampton, who lives in nearby Bridgehampton. "I don't feel they have a right to dictate how my life is going to be when they are not here."
Mr. Harwood, the wealthy developer who lives on Meadow Lane in Southampton, says he does not want to dictate anything to the year-round residents. He merely wants to fix a costly problem with his water bill, which he says is a monument to "taxation without representation and taxation without service."
Mr. Harwood and about 100 other similarly rich property owners on Meadow Lane pay hefty water taxes to the nearby Hampton Bays Water District, although they do not receive a drop of water from the district.
Mr. Harwood pays $1,800 a year for this nondelivery of water. He also pays about $700 a year for water that he does receive from the Town of Southampton Water Authority.
Since a hurricane severed a water line in 1938, no one in Southampton Village has been able to take water from the Hampton Bays Water District. But this has not stopped the annual billing. The 5,900 or so people who do receive water (and who live next door in Hampton Bays, a moderate-income community) like having their water taxes subsidized by rich Southampton people who cannot use what they must pay for.
"If I can afford a house like mine, these people feel that I can afford to pay their water bill," Mr. Harwood said. "I don't mind giving money away to charity, but I don't like it taken away."
A referendum has been proposed that would allow voters in the water district to decide if the 100 Southampton property owners in the district who get no water can stop paying bills, which average $1,500 a year. The rub in any such referendum is that property owners like Mr. Harwood, whose permanent residence is in Short Hills, N.J., would not be eligible to vote.
"We are going to see if we can get the vote," Mr. Harwood said. "Then we are probably going to have to sue."
Politicians in the Hamptons say they are sympathetic to both the frustrations of summer residents and resentments of year-rounders.
"Permanent residents feel they can't drive around any more because of traffic, and sometimes they can't even walk around because of the crowds of summer people," said Joseph Romanosky Jr., the mayor of Southampton Village, which has a year-round population of 3,900 and a summer population of 25,000.
"And now you are telling them that the summer people should have the right to vote?" asked the mayor. "They don't know these people and they don't trust them."
Fred Thiele, the assemblyman whose district includes Southampton, said the Legislature in Albany would sooner or later be forced to address the voting matter seriously. In his district on the South Fork, nonresidents own more than half the residential property.
"This issue is not going to go away," he said.

HEADLINE: News Analysis;
Peru Election Turmoil: Stability vs. Democracy

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, May 29

 BODY:
The students have been back in the streets, throwing Molotov cocktails at the presidential palace, and the police have been firing back, with tear gas and water cannon. A journalist was tortured last week after he said he had evidence that the intelligence chief was conspiring with election officials. The army called for order. 
 On the surface it appeared so familiar, as President Alberto K. Fujimori rode to a third term on Sunday in an election so full of dirty tricks that Alejandro Toledo, the opposition candidate, withdrew from the race, and all the international election monitors backed off, too, before a single vote was cast.
But this battle has a different script. Issues that were important before the end of Communism are not the issues any longer, and the same is true around the region.
Old issues of land, class conflict and resistance to imperialism that were foremost during the waves of guerrilla insurrections, university revolts and military coups in Peru from the 1960's into the early 1990's are no longer setting the sparks.
The new dominant issue facing Peruvians is whether the nation is best served by politicians who put democracy first, or those who put stability first. It is a question that was not resolved Sunday, because the election was effectively not contested.
"Before, the issue was survival," said Francisco Diez Canseco, a former congressman and human rights activist. "Now it's about whether the virtues of authoritarianism are to be replaced by the growing desire of people for broader political participation."
The question crosses class and ideological boundaries. It raises uncomfortable choices for a nation whose few experiments in democracy brought corruption, inefficiency, instability and economic chaos.
And United States policy makers also find themselves in a quandary, wanting to encourage free elections but also to support a government that has been a strong ally against terrorism and drug trafficking.
The cast of characters and alliances would have seemed impossible before Communism's collapse, when the political currents flowing across Latin America originated in Washington, Moscow and Havana.
Take Mr. Toledo, whose resume and platform would have been unthinkable just a few years ago for someone proposing to annul an election and overthrow a government.
Though he comes from a poor family, Mr. Toledo is a former World Bank employee and business school professor, and has a doctorate from Stanford. He says his first project, if he ever makes it to the presidential palace, would be to create an independent uncorrupt judiciary. His core constituency is the urban middle class.
For Mr. Toledo, the choice for Peru now is between "democracy and dictatorship."
In the past, moderates like him usually found themselves facing a choice between the right and the left, and they usually lost out in coalitions with Marxist guerrillas or right wing generals. Today in Peru, the moderates are leading the revolution and the leftists are following.
Standing between this rather unrevolutionary lot and power is President Fujimori. The son of Japanese immigrants, Mr. Fujimori remains in many ways the ultimate outsider even after 10 years in power. He is still the target of nasty racial jokes by the Lima elites, and he is proud that his core constituency entails the urban shantytown dwellers and Indian villagers in regions most severely attacked by Maoist terrorists in the 1980's and early 1990's.
Mr. Fujimori has a long list of accomplishments, ranging from the defeat of two terrorist groups and hyperinflation to making peace with Ecuador after more than a century of border strife. He has probably built more schools, roads and health clinics to serve the poor than every other Peruvian president combined.
The problem with Mr. Fujimori, according to his critics, is that he fires judges when they disagree with him, he uses his intelligence agency to harass his opponents, he finds ways to put cronies in charge of television stations, and is willing to convict suspected terrorists without giving their lawyers the benefit of cross-examination. In short, he does not give democratic rules a very high priority.
In an interview last week, Mr. Fujimori said his muscular tactics may not be pretty but they are necessary. "In emergency situations," he said, "I had to take emergency measures that may have appeared anti-democratic." He promised that once he is inaugurated on July 28, "there will be certain corrections."
In 1992, Mr. Fujimori temporarily disbanded the Congress and Supreme Court, saying he needed more powers to defeat the terrorists and narcotics traffickers. The traditional political parties that controlled those institutions, he argued, only stood in the way. Washington and Latin democracies were highly critical, but the Peruvian people went along enthusiastically, and Mr. Fujimori won a re-election landslide in 1995.
Opinion polls suggest that the Peruvian president might well have won a clean, uncontested election this year again, although by a much narrower margin. With Peru no longer in crisis, a growing number of voters appeared ready to give democracy a chance again.
In the end, historians will probably judge Mr. Fujimori on the basis of how he puts Peru in shape for an eventual change to democratic rule.
What Mr. Toledo and Mr. Fujimori have in common is their blurring of ideological distinctions. What does it mean to be conservative or progressive -- when the two candidates, who otherwise seem to be at war with each other, essentially share economic and social goals?
It is much the same in Mexico, where some left-leaning activists are backing the conservative presidential candidate as the best way to crack the dominance of a ruling party that has been in power for seven decades. Or in Chile, where the first Socialist president in a generation has embraced the heart of the free market economic policies first put in place by the Pinochet dictatorship.
Or in Bolivia, where a former military dictator now rules as a democratically elected president in alliance with former guerrillas. Or even in Colombia, where guerrillas with Marxist origins recently took to exchanging views with visiting investors from Wall Street.
Political turbulence continues to roil much of the region. Only the whiff of tear gas remains the same.

HEADLINE: A Holiday Weekend Turns Manhattan Into an Isle of Calm

BYLINE: By SHAILA K. DEWAN 

 BODY:
The sun sidled up over Manhattan ever so quietly yesterday, indifferent to the chill of the air. It matched the mood of the city: introverted, solitary, almost secretive.
Deserters who thought that they were leaving the city to be overrun by holiday tourists could think again. What they left behind was a muted New York, with sparse streets and unhurried pedestrians. 
 With summer, like a watched pot, refusing to boil, everything seemed subdued and, after a frenzied weekend, eerily serene. Taxis scudded through Times Square with nary a honk. A movie director could not have arranged for sidewalks so modestly populated. At a Starbucks, the young baristas who usually juggle orders from a crowd four deep took it easy while a man in a black velvet coat and black shades napped in an overstuffed armchair.
Even the shoppers on 34th Street moved more as if nursing hangovers than hunting down Memorial Day bargains. Those who normally considered themselves lucky to get a seat in the small sliver in the center of Herald Square presided over entire tables. Enisa Terzic, a Macy's clerk with cropped dark hair and lips lined in black, read her copy of Cosmopolitan with as much composure as if she were sitting in the window of Dean & DeLuca's.
But for Rene Ramirez, a Barnes & Noble deliveryman, and many others who tried to conduct business yesterday, the ease of getting around, and in Mr. Ramirez's case, the promise of $3 instead of $2 for every book that safely reached its purchaser, did not make up for the absence of people. "Today, maybe a lot of people go upstate or to other places, and it's not easy to find them," he said.
At a street fair on Madison Avenue below 53rd Street, business was hardly any better for Paul's Concessions, a sausage stand. "I got a break all day long," carped Paul's son, Eric Behling, 31, giving away two corn dogs.
At the Empire State Building, the yards of velvet rope used to control traffic hung undisturbed and unemployed. What was usually a three- to four-hour wait had dropped to 30 minutes.
"This is the deadest I've ever seen it for Memorial Day," said Joey Lopez, an observatory guard, shaking his head as though in sorrow for all those who would miss the sight of four states from one spot. "It's unlimited today. The view is impeccable."
Theories. There were theories. "I think a lot of people come to New York for the shows, and there are no shows today," said Marie Burke, up from Boston for the shows and a little shopping.
Behind her, a Japanese woman had pulled a chair up to Bryant Park's grassy lawn as if it were a breakfast table, and sat down to peruse her newspaper. She did not have much to say, not even her name. "I'm just enjoying this solitariness," was all she would venture.
Resting together on the largely vacant steps of the main branch of the New York Public Library, two retired women from Flatbush, Brooklyn, who had walked uptown after shopping, made their guesses.
"Everyone's going to the parade, and I think it's not high summer yet," Elsie Fabio said. Then, she conjectured that it was simply a matter of locale. "While we were walking up, everyone seemed to be going down," she said.
But even the usually clogged sidewalks of SoHo were free-flowing enough to attract even those accustomed to avoiding that part of town. Susan and Jason Salgado, TriBeCa residents who identified themselves as "members of the financial community," had come home early from a weekend in Syracuse just for the pleasure of having the city (almost) to themselves. "That's what we love about New York, finding times when the city is less crowded," Mrs. Salgado said.
The afternoon shadows were lengthening, people were returning from their long weekends, and the air was beginning once more to strum and vibrate. A not-so-distant car honked. But the Salgados grinned at each other, the errands they had saved up for weeks completed, and a few shopping bags over Mr. Salgado's arm. "It just has a very kind of European feel to it, just walking out on the streets," he said. "Nothing to do, nowhere to go. We don't have to be any place."

HEADLINE: The Fear of Taking Paternity Leave

BYLINE: By MELINDA LIGOS 

 BODY:
James M. Strauss does not consider himself a wimp. But Mr. Strauss, a Manhattan lawyer, was not going to take an extended leave of absence when his son Evan was born last June. One of the reasons: He feared that his co-workers would question his machismo.
"If I had said that I was planning to take more than two weeks off, people would have looked at me askance," said Mr. Strauss, an associate at Putney, Twombly, Hall & Hirson. Instead, he took just three days of vacation to help his wife with their newborn. "There's definitely a perception out there that child care is a burden that's still expected to fall on women," Mr. Strauss said. 
 Though it has been seven years since Congress signed the Family and Medical Leave Act, which requires companies with more than 50 employees to provide up to 12 weeks of unpaid leave for new parents, most men do not take advantage of this legal right. Some decline for economic reasons, but for others, it is fear that keeps them in the workplace -- fear of being ridiculed, fear of being discriminated against, even fear of losing their jobs -- some specialists say.
"Men are terrified to take parental leave," said Suzanne Braun Levine, a former editor of Ms. Magazine and author of "Father Courage: What Happens When Men Put Family First" (Harcourt, 2000). "While their organizations may profess to be family friendly, their bosses are giving them the message that men who take leave are not very manly, or are somehow letting down the team."
That's the message that a former South Carolina state trooper, David Roberts, says he got when he asked for six weeks off to care for his newborn daughter Cindy in 1996. Mr. Roberts, who had been with the state police nine years at the time, says he made the request because his wife was still in nursing school. He says his superiors responded by telling him that "a man's job was to work, not stay home with the kids."
"One of my bosses told me this long story about how he had never let his wife work -- even though they had so little money that they had to eat beanie weenies to make ends meet," Mr. Roberts said. "Basically, he said I was less of a man for wanting to care for my child." Mr. Roberts said he was intimidated into withdrawing his request and was later dismissed in retaliation for making it in the first place.
Last June, the American Civil Liberties Union filed a lawsuit against the South Carolina Department of Public Safety on his behalf. The department's lawyer, Vance J. Bettis, has filed a motion to dismiss the lawsuit, and said that Mr. Roberts's accusations "just aren't true."
The former trooper, Mr. Bettis said, "was terminated for reasons unrelated to his requesting leave."
In a strikingly similar case, also brought by the A.C.L.U., a jury awarded a former Maryland state trooper, Kevin Knussman, $375,000 in February 1999 for the first-ever sex-discrimination verdict in conjunction with the 1993 federal family leave law. Mr. Knussman contends that his supervisors told him that "God made women to breast-feed babies, and men can't fulfill that role." That case is being appealed, and Betty Stemley Sconion, principal counsel for the Maryland State Police, says that Mr. Knussman was not discriminated against. "He made a mountain out of a molehill," Ms. Stemley Sconion said. "His superiors made an attempt to accommodate his request for leave."
Sara Mandelbaum, a Manhattan lawyer who represents both Mr. Roberts and Mr. Knussman for the A.C.L.U., says accusations of bias against family-oriented fathers is not confined to blue-collar male bastions like law enforcement. "We hear about situations like this all the time in the white-collar world, although sometimes the message is more subtle," Ms. Mandelbaum said. 'I often hear from men on Wall Street, or from lawyers, who say their bosses have hinted that they wouldn't get promoted if they took an extended leave for nurturing purposes.'
Paula Rayman, director of the Radcliffe Public Policy Center, which studies workplace issues, says a Harvard professor recently confided that his boss told him he would never get tenure if he took time out from work to care for a new baby.
"Companies like to put on a family-friendly front," Ms. Rayman said, "but behind the scenes, managers are sending out a totally different message."
In researching her book, Ms. Braun Levine says she interviewed a human resources manager for a major company who said he advised male colleagues to take a combination of sick leave and vacation time to avoid having the words "parental leave" emblazoned in their employee records. "He seemed to feel that taking paternity leave would be a strike against you," she said.
Even at some companies where parental leave is encouraged, human resources managers say they see few male takers. "Very few men here take more than a week off for the birth of a baby, and usually, they just use vacation time," said Donna Klein, a vice president at Marriott International in Bethesda, Md. "If you're a man, there's still somewhat of a stigma attached to taking paternity leave per se."
The only companies that see larger numbers of men taking parental leave are the ones that offer paid leave -- and even there, senior executives have to set an example first, according to workplace experts.
"It makes a big difference if you've got a manager to lead the way," said Marcia Brumit Kropf, vice president for research and information services for Catalyst, a New York-based research group that studies women's issues.
Such a manager may have made the difference for Joseph J. Kelleher, an associate at Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy, a Manhattan law firm that offers both male and female employees a full month of paid leave after the birth of a child. Mr. Kelleher took advantage of the firm's policy after both of his daughters, now 3 and 5, were born. "I didn't feel funny about it, mainly because there are several folks here who have children and have done the same thing," Mr. Kelleher said.
According to Christine Wagner, director of legal personnel for the firm, more than 80 percent of eligible men have taken advantage of the policy since its inception in 1993, including several partners. But Ms. Wagner knows her firm is in the minority.
"A lot of firms offer some kind of leave policy, but their managers don't walk the talk," she said. "Here, our male partners did -- and it's really opened the floodgates."

HEADLINE: Gambling On a Hip-Hop Musical;
Drawing on Roots and Legends in a Show at the Apollo

BYLINE: By NINA SIEGAL 

 BODY:
When a group of rap legends and Harlem-based artists announced last month that they would be mounting a Broadway-style musical in the landmark Apollo Theater, the show was presented not only as an indicator of Harlem's economic and cultural renewal, but as the birth of a virtually new theatrical genre as well: the hip-hop musical.
But nothing is ever simple when it comes to exploring an embryonic artistic form, or, for that matter, stretching the borders of artistic expression in Harlem. The Apollo has never been known as a venue for plays. And while hip-hop may have invaded every other aspect of culture, it has not yet established a place for itself on the American stage. 
 The play, "Echo Park," opens tomorrow. It has drawn on rap legends and community resources like the National Black Theater and the Julia de Burgos Cultural Center, and it looks to set down a version of hip-hop history at a time when the genre, now more than 20 years old, is given more and more to reflection and historiography. As with almost any theatrical production, this one has had its share of artistic struggles, sleepless nights and financial headaches, but "Echo Park" also comes to the stage bearing the burden of trying something that has not been done before.
A week before the curtain was to rise, the big dance numbers were almost seamless, with break dancers leaping effortlessly into back flips and diving across the stage into head spins, and the rappers hitting their marks dead on. But the director was lamenting that the dramatic scenes verged on lethargy, and the producers were still worrying about the financial troubles of a venture that must turn a profit.
The first installment of a trilogy that traces the genre's history since 1978, "Echo Park" is a would-be "Hair" for the hip-hop generation, chronicling the rise of a rough-hewn cultural form from the neglected parks and train yards of Harlem and the Bronx to a multibillion-dollar industry. The cast includes the rap luminaries Kurtis Blow, Grandmaster Caz and D.J. Hollywood, but the producers, Lifted Productions, also took a grass-roots approach, enlisting graffiti writers to design the set, city B-boys for break-dancing parts and untested neighborhood actors for other roles.
The producers, who regard this presentation of Echo Park as a work in progress, have held ticket prices to $20 to $35 and have not invited critics to the one-month run at the Apollo.
"We want to get input from the community and improve it so it's ready for a tour, or going overseas, or maybe going to Broadway," said Eric H. Vinson, the executive producer. "The idea is to get an affirmation from the Harlem community, because, if you've ever watched 'Amateur Night at the Apollo,' you know how hard the audiences there can be. That's the real test for us."
The project was born two and a half years ago, when Kelly D. Scott, a former model and actor who has appeared in small parts in television sitcoms like "Martin" and "Living Single," teamed up with Sean Couch, a former N.B.A. basketball player and, later, a financial analyst for such Wall Street firms as PaineWebber and Shearson Lehman.
At the time, Mr. Couch and Ms. Scott were both working on an all-black production of the Maxwell Anderson play "The Bad Seed" at the Victoria Five Theater in Harlem. Neither is an accomplished playwright, though each has done some theatrical writing -- in 1996, after Mr. Couch left Wall Street, he wrote "The History of the Blues," for the National Black Theater; Ms. Scott, a published poet, has written two unproduced scripts. They wrote the script and produced "Echo Park" together, with Ms. Scott, a neophyte, directing.
The two had grown up just blocks apart in Inwood Heights but had never met, and they shared many of the same childhood experiences. Both spent time in the late 1970's in Echo Park, off Tremont Avenue in the west Bronx, where disc jockeys would rig their sound systems to lampposts and mix funk and R & B sounds r to create a danceable beat. They witnessed the emergence of break dancing at such "park jams," where teenagers from opposing gangs faced off and "battled" each other to flaunt head spins, back flips, robotic maneuvers and other novel moves.
"We now have a whole generation of kids who grew up in hip-hop culture but don't understand its origins," Mr. Couch said. "They don't know that it's a lot more than them getting on the mike and rapping. Hip-hop was an explosion of suppression. The thread that runs through it all was the desire to be seen and heard, the ability to shine. I wanted to tell that history through the people who lived it."
The writers looked to their own experiences for inspiration.
"I wrote the park scenes because I was in the park a lot playing ball, and the club scenes were Kelly, because her aunt was a big promoter and she was in the modeling scene," Mr. Couch said.
But they were also influenced by the stories of those around them. As Ms. Scott put it, "D.J. Hollywood, Grandmaster Flash and all those guys were my heroes."
Most notably, they lifted moments from the life of Grandmaster Caz, born in the Bronx as Curtis Brown, and reborn in the 70's as M.C. and D.J. Casanova Fly. When he was 19 and a member of the Cold Crush Four, Mr. Brown offered a book of his rhymes to his group's manager, Henry (Big Bank Hank) Jackson, who went on to record the seminal "Rapper's Delight" ("I said, hip hop, the hippie, the hippie, to the hip hip hop") as part of the Sugarhill Gang in 1979.
The song is widely regarded as the hit that began rap's invasion of the mainstream, and Casanova Fly, supported by a number of hip-hop historians, claims authorship, although he says he has never seen a dollar for his work. In the play, a character named Doc achieves fame after stealing the main character's signature raps.
Mr. Brown's is a quintessential music business story, and because he is also performing in the show, it hovers in the rehearsal hall like a kind of medieval morality play. As a generic D.J. narrator in "Echo Park," Mr. Brown is boyishly gleeful in his role, especially when he's spinning mixes at the turntables. "I think this story is based on everyone's story," he said. "Everyone coming up in the pioneer days of hip-hop can relate to it."
The authors also borrowed loosely from Kurtis Blow's early life. Born Kurt Walker, he was a precocious young man who grew up in Harlem in the 70's and much to his mother's consternation spent a lot of his time scratching up her records. "At 13, I knew I wanted to be a D.J.," he said. "I knew this was going to be big, huge. I had no doubt."
The main character, Scott Jenkins, routinely clashes with his mother, secretly a rhythm and blues singer, who calls his form of expression "loud, stupid music."
Mr. Walker, as he prefers to be called, now 40, was living in Woodland Hills, Calif., enjoying life as a family man with his three young sons, writing theme songs for the NBA teams, and working as a disc jockey on the Los Angeles radio station KPWR, "Power 106," when Ms. Scott, an old friend, asked him to return to New York City for the production last year.
Back in the city for the first time in 15 years, Mr. Blow, who is on a leave of absence from his radio job, appreciates the admirers who stop him as he walks from the East Harlem rehearsal studio to a pizza place nearby. "I go home feeling life has revisited these old bones," he said.
Although he wonders privately if the M.C. character, Doc, may be portrayed as a bit too much of "a snake," (arguing that M.C.'s were often the ones who got lost in the fame game) he says he wanted to participate in the musical because it helps set the record straight.
"There's so many different versions of the history," he said. "Now, everyone is fighting for their own part of the history when in actuality, we're all part of the fabric."
Because the writers were on a mission to create a comprehensive picture of hip-hop's early years, 1978 to 1981, they brought a variety of elements together on the stage: break dancing, graffiti art, D.J.'s and rappers.
"This show is the first of its kind to incorporate all the elements of hip-hop culture, the music, dance, art and spoken word," said the show's choreographer, Adesola A. Osakalumi. "You're not just seeing the parts, but the integration of the parts."
Mr. Osakalumi, who has been break dancing since the 70's, is a member of GhettOriginal Productions, the dance company behind "Jam on the Groove," which ran at the Minetta Lane Theater in 1995. Jon Pareles, the chief pop critic of The New York Times, called the show "jubilantly hyperactive" in a review.
But Mr. Osakalumi said that keeping the dances period-specific was a challenge. "There were dance moves that were done then that are now lost," he said. "Then there are others that have evolved, like the elbow spin -- they used to do a half-spin and now they do four or five spins -- so the dancers have to resist the temptation to push it forward."
Similar difficulties were faced by the Big Time Crew, a graffiti art group from the Tremont section of the Bronx, which spraypainted the boldly colorful wild-style graffiti set. "It's much more elemental than the work today," said Joe Rodriguez, a member of the Crew. "Now, we're more into background and sceneries. Before, it was just your name, or wild-style train art."
The producers spent two years looking for the right mix of artists, and, about a year ago, held auditions that attracted actors and dancers from as far away as Germany and Japan. But they decided to cast closer to home.
One dancer, Josh Ortiz, 18, is a nephew of the Bronx dancers the Incredible Breakers and learned many of his moves from his uncles. Alien Ness, 32, born Luis Martinez in the Bronx, was an original member of Zulu Nation, a group that assembled around the rap figure Afrika Bambaataa, and often frequented Echo Park as a teenager. "I'm practically playing myself," said Mr. Martinez, whose character in the show is called Kid Ness. "That's what they called me when I was 12."
Because many in the cast had no professional acting experience, the group spent six weeks training at the National Black Theater in Harlem. And they spent five weeks in rehearsal at the Burgos center in East Harlem.
Writing the script and assembling the cast, the producers said, was easier than securing financial support. Mr. Couch and Ms. Kelly enlisted Mr. Vinson to do the heavy hitting. Until 1993 Mr. Vinson headed a sports and entertainment management and marketing company whose clients included Savion Glover and Ossie Davis; he is now a managing partner in Interactive Sports Signals, which he said enhances the sound systems in sports arenas. As executive producer, he had enough pull to convince executives at Colgate-Palmolive and Pepsi to support the production through joint marketing efforts. But Ms. Scott, Mr. Couch and Mr. Vinson also invested some of their own money in the production, which has a $250,000 budget.
There were also nonbudgetary hurdles.
The Apollo, acclaimed for starting the careers of musical giants like Ella Fitzgerald and James Brown and producing the television show "It's Showtime at the Apollo," has never been known as a theatrical venue, although it regularly presents shows touring on the "chitlin circuit" of black-oriented theater pieces. By opening up the theater's doors to productions like this, said Grace Blake, executive director of the Apollo Theater Foundation, the theater's governing board, the theater hopes to attract a new crowd.
Those involved hope it will also serve another purpose.
"A person like me who has been in hip-hop for 25 years wants to see the same things stay alive -- the routines and the mannerisms -- passed down through the generations," said Mr. Blow. "Because as much as we need to change the bad things, the good things need to be passed along too."

HEADLINE: Consumer Confidence Resurfaced Last Month

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Consumer confidence surged in May and came close to the record it reached in January, despite the roller coaster stock market and six increases in interest rates in the last year.
The results of the monthly survey released yesterday represented a sharp turnaround from April and confounded expectations that consumer spending, the main driver of the longest economic expansion in United States history, was headed for a downturn. 
 The Conference Board, a New York-based research group, said its consumer confidence index rose to 144.4 in May, approaching its high of 144.7 reached in January.
The closely watched indicator had declined in the previous three months, in which wild swings occurred in the stock market. Economists had expected another decline in the index in May, to 136, from a revised 137.7 in April.
"Stock prices have been going down, but people have been getting used to it and realizing that the market is not collapsing," said David Wyss, chief economist of Standard & Poor's DRI. "Everybody's got a job; incomes are going up; inflation is still low -- all's right with the world."
The consumer confidence report is closely watched by economists and financial markets because consumer spending makes up about two-thirds of America's economy.
The turnaround in consumer confidence came despite an aggressive campaign by the Fed to slow the economy. The Fed has raised short-term rates six times over the last year, including a half-point on May 16, the biggest increase in five years.
Signs are beginning to emerge that the higher borrowing costs are slowing down purchases of major items like homes. Nonetheless, the Conference Board's survey showed that consumers' appetite for big-ticket purchases remained strong. The May results found that 3.6 percent of respondents intended to buy a home in the next six months; only 3.2 percent said so in April. Also, 32 percent said they planned to buy a major appliance, up from 29.7 percent.
Lynn Franco, director of the Conference Board's research center, said consumers were focused on favorable conditions in the labor market, including a 30-year low in unemployment. She predicted that consumer confidence would remain strong through the summer.
Analysts said the report did not clear up questions about whether the Fed would continue to tighten credit at its next regular meeting, June 27 and 28.
"We'll be watching things like car sales to see if consumers actually do spend more," said Gary Thayer, chief economist for the brokerage firm of A. G. Edwards & Sons.

HEADLINE: Indulging Russia Is Risky Business

BYLINE: By Zbigniew Brzezinski; Zbigniew Brzezinski was national security adviser in the Carter administration.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
With Air Force One scheduled to land in Moscow later this week, President Clinton still has not faced the fact that his policy of "engagement" with Russia has become a colossal disappointment. But in his visit to Moscow, he will encounter that reality face to face, when he is greeted by President Vladimir Putin, a former colonel in the K.G.B., the son of a party apparatchik as well of the grandson of a trusted member of Lenin's and then Stalin's personal detail.
Let it be said that in the area of relations with Russia, Mr. Clinton deserves some credit. The denuclearization of Ukraine and Belarus and the reductions of strategic forces by both the United States and Russia were negotiated with persistence and success. Ukraine's independence has been strongly supported. The United States expanded its relations with independent states in the southern Caucasus and Central Asia. Most important, under Mr. Clinton's leadership, NATO was enlarged eastward, and the administration has pledged to continue that expansion, including the Baltic states. 
 Unfortunately, however, the policy of "engagement" with Russia has deteriorated into a one-sided courtship. No longer is the Clinton administration striking a balance between positive inducements and negative pressures. The administration not only endorsed Boris Yeltsin's bombardment of the Russian parliament in 1993, but persisted in hailing Mr. Yeltsin as a tested democrat, even though his erratic presidency was a mixture of anarchy and authoritarianism. Sadly, doing so discredited the very meaning of the word democracy in the eyes of many Russians.
The policy of engagement hit a low with Mr. Putin. Though his election in March was precipitated by an arrangement whereby Mr. Yeltsin resigned the presidency and Mr. Putin became acting president, and no real alternative candidate was available to the Russian people, the White House praised the election, hailing it as the country's first democratic transfer of power in Russia's nearly 1,000-year existence. It even hailed Mr. Putin himself as a "reformer," despite some justifiable concern about his background. Mr. Putin's prompt appointment of five secret police and military officials -- one is widely known as a specialist in suppressing dissent -- as supergovernors was quietly ignored.
In the years leading up to this "election," the Clinton administration financially supported and promoted economic reforms in Russia that enriched only a few, including some top Russian leaders. The resulting pervasive corruption was simply ignored until Western and Russian news media exposed it -- and even then, the administration did not alter its policy.
The Clinton administration excused and even justified two Russian wars against the Chechen people. President Clinton compared the Russian campaign to Lincoln's efforts to preserve American unity and proclaimed, to widespread criticism, that the war's objective was "to liberate Grozny."
The summit this weekend, if not handled properly, poses new risks. First, President Clinton, in his eagerness to embrace a "democratic" Russia, could reach a hastily contrived agreement regarding missile defense that may undermine stable strategic deterrence while prompting allied disunity. Such a quick deal -- designed as a defense against North Korea -- could precipitate China's efforts to upgrade its nuclear forces and ignite allied fears that the United States is seeking security for itself alone.
Second, Mr. Putin could seek to enlist the United States in his effort to assume the role of protector of the Central Asian regimes against fundamentalist pressures emanating from Afghanistan. He would like support for a Russian-sponsored anti-Islamic coalition that would regain a dominant role for Russia in that region.
Mr. Clinton must not once again be so hasty in extolling the new Russian president as a democratic reformer. A dose of dignified restraint, based on a realistic assessment of where Russia is headed, could help redeem a policy of "engagement" that has gradually lost its way. It is not too late. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: With Trade Links Stronger, U.S. Insurers Scout for Business in China

BYLINE: By CRAIG S. SMITH 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, May 30

 BODY:
Sy Sternberg, the chairman of New York Life Insurance, is in China this week trying to figure out whom to meet so as to ensure that his company is next among the dozens of insurers who have applied for a license to do business in China.
"We don't know what the process is in awarding licenses," said Mr. Sternberg, though New York Life has devoted more resources than almost any other American insurer to securing the right to operate here. He has tried to touch all the bases -- from officials of the China Insurance Regulatory Commission to Prime Minister Zhu Rongji. Still, he cannot be sure that he has met the person who makes the final decision. 
 So it goes in China's murky business world, where market access depends on whom you know and how happy you have made them -- though no one will tell you who those people are. Instead, chief executives like Mr. Sternberg operate on supposition and hearsay to identify the hidden decision makers and cultivate "top of mind," which means making their company the first that Chinese leaders think of when considering foreign supplicants from their industry.
China's entry into the World Trade Organization is supposed to change all that, and with the House willing to grant China permanent normal trade relations, American companies are expected to share in any W.T.O. bounty. The Senate is also considered likely to approve normal trading status for China. Were Congress not to grant Beijing such status, it could enter the W.T.O. anyway and exclude the United States from many trade benefits that W.T.O. membership conveys.
As part of China's W.T.O. membership, the country has promised to publish all rules and regulations governing trade and to create clear procedures for acquiring licenses to do things like sell insurance in the country. If Beijing holds to its promise, China will undergo a sea change in how business is conducted and take a step toward government by rule of law instead of administrative fiat.
"It's not going to happen overnight, but 10 years from now we'll look back and say it was a turning point," said Patrick Cranley, the head of the Cigna Corporation's efforts to win a license in China and chairman of the American Chamber of Commerce here in Shanghai.
In fact, China's transition to Western-style transparency is likely to be piecemeal and slow. But the insurance industry is one of the areas that promises a reasonable pace of change, for one thing because there is little concern that foreign companies can dominate a market in which comfort and familiarity play such a key role. The state-owned People's Insurance Company of China currently has 70 percent of the market.
Domestic companies stand to benefit almost as much as foreign concerns from the promised candor. Already, Western insurers have helped crack open markets that orthodox state-owned companies never considered or dared not try to enter for fear of angering officials in Beijing.
For example, no Chinese insurer sold life insurance to individuals before the American International Group won a license to do so in Shanghai seven years ago. The slim commissions paid to Chinese insurance agents did not warrant the effort. Then A.I.G. began paying its agents as much as 40 percent of the first year's premium and the individual life insurance business took off.
"No one imagined that Beijing would allow that, so no one ever tried," said Albert Lu, a former agent for the China Pacific Insurance Company and now ING Insurance's chief representative in China. All major Chinese life insurers offer individual policies today.
China needs a developed insurance industry now more than ever as the country tries to shift the burden of cradle-to-grave benefits away from its over-encumbered state enterprises, half of them only breaking even or losing money. Instead of providing free medical care, many state-owned companies are buying health insurance for their employees. A move from state-subsidized housing in favor of individually owned homes has increased the need for property and casualty insurance. And many people now buy life insurance with an annuity attached that serves as a pension.
Growth in the market has slowed from what it was a few years ago, but remains higher than in Western economies. Life insurance premiums, which grew 40 percent annually early in the 1990's, are still growing at more than 10 percent a year. And life insurance premiums account for only about 1 percent of China's total economic output -- one of the lowest rates in the world, and behind nations like Bulgaria and Zimbabwe.
Once China enters the W.T.O., it has promised to lift restrictions on the number of foreign companies it will allow to operate. Foreigners are to be allowed to sell insurance in at least three cities immediately upon China's joining the global trade group. After three years, all national restrictions are to disappear and foreign insurers allowed to sell group insurance, the market's largest segment, from which foreign companies are still barred.
For now, though, no one knows what the licensing process will be and so companies like New York Life and Cigna are continuing their relationship-building strategy. New York Life, for example, has established a $250 million infrastructure investment fund that it will use to support Beijing's current drive to build up the country's long-neglected Western regions. To help invest the money, the insurance company has hired the China Development Bank, run by Chen Yuan, former deputy governor of the Chinese central bank, which was the country's insurance regulator until late 1998.
Mr. Sternberg of New York Life has spent much of his own time lobbying for the license or otherwise trying to demonstrate his support for China, meeting for example with more than 100 members of Congress to push for normal trading relations.
"Our growth strategy is to expand into high-growth emerging markets," Mr. Sternberg said, "and China is an important part of that strategy, so it's important that I dedicate my time."

LENGTH: 909 words

HEADLINE: Premier, It Seems, Isn't Alone in Seeing Japan as Divine

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 30

 BODY:
With a furor over his characterization of Japan threatening his party's hold on power, Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori stood before journalists for 40 minutes on Friday denying that he had blurred the boundary between church and state.
Mr. Mori's strenuous self-defense rested on his contention that in calling Japan "a divine country with an emperor at its center," he had intended to say nothing more than that the emperor is a popular and cherished national symbol. 
 But whatever the prime minister's intentions, by touching on a taboo subject with such little caution he has shown the jagged edge of a nostalgic form of nationalism that is enjoying a powerful resurgence among conservative politicians.
His statement continues to embroil his office, giving his cabinet a 19 percent approval rating in a poll after he had made the remarks, the lowest ratings of any prime minister on the eve of national elections.
The problem with the denials is that the pronouncement was a perfect summation of State Shinto, the racist official religion that that drove Japan's expansionism in Asia and its war with the United States.
Mr. Mori may have denied that he was advocating a state religion or deification of the emperor, as existed in the past, saying, "That is utterly contrary to my personal belief."
But critics said it strained credulity for him to argue that his phrase, uttered before a Shinto political group, was unrelated to militarist Japan's wartime creed.
"Of course he recognized the nuance of what he said, and tried to show his sympathy for the people he was addressing," Takeshi Sasaki, a professor of politics at Tokyo University, said. "He tries to do this at whatever gathering. It may not have seemed like a very serious statement, but it has become a very serious matter."
To be properly understood, critics and historians say, the "divine nation" remarks must be seen in the light of recent right-wing statements and initiatives that call for, among other goals, moral indoctrination for youth, a clampdown on foreigners and a national holiday to honor the wartime emperor, Hirohito.
Late last summer, conservatives in the legislature won passage of a law to legalize the flag and a national anthem that is a paean to the emperor. Others have begun agitating for rearming the country, potentially even with nuclear weapons. A deputy defense minister, Shingo Nishimura, had to resign in the fall in a storm of criticism after he made such a proposal.
At the heart of the conservatives' project is the revision of a constitution written under American occupation and a dream of reversion to a mythical state that is strong and unsullied by undue foreign influences.
That members of the Liberal Democratic Party, which has governed since 1955, except for a period of less than two years, openly contemplate such ideas is at once an expression of the party's strength and its weakness.
The party remains powerful because more than ever it lacks an effective opposition. Even the diplomatic constraints of the cold war, when Japan was locked in an anticommunist alliance with the United States and several Asian countries, have faded.
"Although many L.D.P. members have a reactionary view of history, they were not able to express themselves, because of the overwhelming influence of the United States on the one hand and because of the restraint required by the international situation in East Asia on the other," said Yasuaki Onuma, a professor international law at Tokyo University. "However, with the sharp decline of the Socialist Party and the end of the cold war, the feeling of the majority is that we have gone too far in keeping silent on the issues of our relationships with others and national identity."
Although the constraints have loosened, the Liberal Democratic Party has been weakened by a decade of economic decline as severe as any advanced nation has experienced since the Great Depression.
Even though there is no strong opposition, the party owes its governing majority to an unusual and unpopular alliance with a pacifist Buddhist-affiliated party. And nowadays, most voters are skeptical independents.
Seen in this light, the appeals to the values and methods of the past may simply reflect a party desperately reaching to the past for answers to Japan's problems -- and to appeal to voters.
Mr. Mori's plummeting poll numbers since the "divine country" remarks, however, strongly suggest that such a clumsy approach is doomed to backfire.
And the ruling class's nostalgia may cost it more than votes. When a legislator states, as one did in Parliament this week, that Hirohito "built today's peaceful and prosperous Japan," the first casualty is the truth.
But beyond the historical record, as long as the leaders remain prisoners of an unexamined past, other countries will continue to look on Japan as an insincere, untrustworthy and potentially threatening nation.
"The Mori refusal to retract his statement harms Japan, and understandably so, because for Westerners in particular, Pearl Harbor caused Japan to be labeled as treacherous," said Herbert P. Bix, an American historian at Hitsosubashi University in Tokyo, and author of a coming biography of Hirohito. "His explanation borders on deceitfulness of the worst sort. Over and over again in Japanese politics, you can see leaders speaking out of both sides of the mouth, and the result is that Japan just isn't trusted."
